webTitle: It all goes wrong for Ferguson

fields.headline: It all goes wrong for Ferguson
fields.standfirst:
Vasco de Gama punish Neville errors as Manchester United crash out
Butt 81 | Romario 24, 26; Edmundo 43
fields.trailText: All those months of vilification and all those recent days of embarrassment counted for nothing as Vasco Da Gama bundled Manchester United out of the Fifa Club World championship last night.
fields.body:
All those months of vilification and all those recent days of embarrassment counted for nothing as Vasco Da Gama bundled Manchester United out of the Fifa Club World championship last night.

Wounded by their decision to forsake the FA Cup in favour of ambassadorial duties with Fifa, the damage-limitation job against Necaxa in midweek was undone by Rio's wily old birds Romario and Edmundo who punished United - and Gary Neville in particular - for woeful first half defending.

A late consolation - when Nicky Butt prodded in a late Roy Keane lay-back - was not enough as Vasco marched on to dispute the group with Necaxa.

Phil Neville stepped in for the suspended David Beckham while Ferguson, watching from deep in the stands after being sent off on Thursday, opted to replace Andy Cole with Ole Gunnar Solksjaer. United, having lost the toss, had to play - as against Necaxa - into the setting sun in the first half. This was something Ferguson had partly blamed for their poor first half display against the Mexicans.

The game kicked off in stifling 95 degrees heat and high humidity and with the European champions obviously intent on getting through the first half hour, when the sun set behind the stadium roof

Their plan initially worked, as they repeatedly caught Vasco with an offside trap that placed a dangerous emphasis on the flag of the nervous referee's assistant.

Just as United appeared to be getting through the 25-minute mark, which Ferguson described as crucial, Gary Neville made the first of his blunders.

Attempting a pass back to Mark Bosnich, Neville played the ball straight into Edmundo's path. The player, forgetting his toilet door dispute and other personal difference with veteran Romario, passed the ball to the right for the 33-year-old striker to tap the ball into the empty net.

This time, the official's hesitant flag, which waved up and down throughout the first half without ever seeming to know what it wanted to do, stayed down despite United protests.

Three minutes later, in a near replay, Juninho floated a long ball forward, Gary Neville attempted to chest the ball back to Mark Bosnich only to see the diminutive, balding forward nip in, round Bosnich to score a replica goal. Again, Mohammed appeared to first raise his flag before keeping it down.

United, helped by Vasco's habit of dropping back after scoring, threatened a brief revival until the 'Animal' produced the type of skill which would have made him one of the world's great players, were it not for his troubles with referees, the law and just about anyone he has ever played with or against.

Receiving a pass from Juninho with his back to goal, Edmundo shimmied past Mikael Silvestre and placed his shot beyond Bosnich, who had just made a brilliant save to push away a low shot by Felipe but was left powerless this time.

United may have expected further punishment after the break, but Vasco did what they always do in such situations_dropping back, en masse, into their own half to defend.

Encouraged by this and thriving in the cooler conditions, United began to look threatening.

Teddy Sheringham, a halftime substitute for Ole Solskjaer, had the ball in the net in the 50th minute but it was disallowed because he kicked it out of the hands of goalkeeper Helton.

Sheringham was also booked for his pains, the first time the clearly nervous Kuwaiti referee Saad Mane had produced a card.

Helton, thrown in because first choice Carlos Germano is in a pay dispute with the club, turned away a Roy Keane drive, shortly after Dwight York had wasted a good chance by firing wide when he had the time and space to do better.

In the 64th minute, Giggs missed United's best chance in front of an almost open goal.

Manchester Utd : Bosnich, G. Neville, Irwin, Silvestre, Stam, Butt, Giggs, P. Neville, Keane, Yorke, Solskjaer (Sheringham 46). Subs not used : Rachubka, Van Der Gouw, Higginbottom, Cole, Cruyff, Greening, Wilson, Berg, Wallwork, Fortune.

Vasco de Gama : Helton, Jorginho, Galvao, Amaral, Felipe, Juninho, Ramon, Edmundo, Romario, Gilberto, Junior Baiano. Subs not used: Germano, Marcio, Odvan, Donizete, Torres, Miranda, Pedrinho, Valber, Viola, Oliveira, Nasa, Alex.

Referee : Saad Kameel Mane (Kuwait)

fields.headline: Fash fixes it for Kanu
fields.trailText: Nwankwo Kanu and the Nigerian FA made unexpected U-turns last night, and the Arsenal striker will play in today's FA Cup Fourth Round tie against Leicester City.
fields.body:
Nwankwo Kanu and the Nigerian FA made unexpected U-turns last night, and the Arsenal striker will play in today's FA Cup Fourth Round tie against Leicester City.

Kanu was recalled after he had already left home to catch a late flight to Nigeria's Malaga training camp for the African Nations Cup. Arsenal had initially released a lunchtime statement accepting Nigeria's right to take him.

Fifa rules entitled Nigeria to call on Kanu yesterday, the statutory two weeks before a tournament starts, and originally threatened to invoke Arsenal's expulsion from the FA Cup if they played him today. Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger's response had been vitriolic in his opposition to the Nigerians' demands.

But further talks throughout the afternoon and early evening - requested by Prince Bola Ajibola, the London-based Excellency High Commissioner of Nigeria, and set up by Nigerian Sports Ambassador John Fashanu, the former Wimbledon and Aston Villa striker - created a diplomatic breakthrough.

Fashanu arrived in London yesterday morning, having been recalled from Nigeria by High Commissioner Ajibola, who, along with his head of information Mr Zahradeen, saw a need for diplomacy amid a potentially damaging international incident.

The trio of officials contacted Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein and by 7pm, a fax appeared from Nigeria clearing Kanu to play and complete a remarkable turnaround which Kanu himself had failed to achieve in a personal call to his FA on Friday night.

Fashanu said: 'The High Commissioner and Mr Zahradeen pulled this one off after asking me to make contact between themselves and Arsenal. What appeared a lost cause suddenly became a possibility again. All the parties involved are delighted with the outcome. Mr Dein is thrilled.' So thrilled that they have been invited to attend today's Cup tie as Arsenal's guests.

Ajibola said: 'I had to intervene. Sport has moved into an area of diplomacy and Nigeria want to do their very best to have and maintain friendly relations with every club in England. If the situation does not have a detrimental effect on our national team, as in this case, we feel we should bend over backwards to assist our players' clubs. Nigeria does not want to be seen as lacking in co-operation or being difficult.'

So, another FA Cup fairytale seems set to end happily, after all. Ajibola added: 'The happy ending to this tale would be to see Kanu help Arsenal progress in the FA Cup.'.

fields.headline: There's no time to waste
fields.standfirst: Can trendy 'natural capitalism' really save the planet?
fields.trailText: Can trendy 'natural capitalism' really save the planet?
fields.body:
Over the past few months, President Clinton has lost few opportunities to sing the praises of his favourite book. In November, he told a conference attended by Tony Blair that it was no longer necessary to choose between growth and environment. He took as evidence Natural Capitalism, The Next Industrial Revolution (Paul Hawken and Amory and Hunter Lovins, Earthscan, pounds 18.99), which 'proves beyond argument that there are presently available technologies, and those just on the horizon, which will permit us to get richer by cleaning, not by spoiling, the environment. This is a huge deal,' Clinton said.

It's a suitably millennial claim. The authors argue that 'capitalism, as practised, is a financially profitable, nonsustainable aberration in human development... [which] does not fully conform to its own accounting principles. It liquidates its capital and calls it income. It neglects to assign any value to the largest stocks of capital it employs, the natural resources and living systems, as well as the social and cultural systems that are the basis of human capital.'

Companies, as has been well said, are brilliant externalising machines, pocketing the profits and shunting the costs of their enterprise on to the collectivity. Thus, the NHS pays for the profits of big tobacco, and the Government subsidises cars by building roads. Put it another way, business is a free rider on the environment and the services it provides, services which have been tentatively valued by Nature magazine at $36 trillion annually, roughly the same as world GDP.

The reason business is so profligate with the the environment (the 'natural capital' of the book) is that its goods are assumed by economists to be free and infinitely substitutable. So they are uncosted. But in reality they are not free. They are produced by the earth's 3.8-billion-year store of natural capital which, as the authors rehearse with hair-raising thoroughness, is being eroded so fast that by the end of this century there will be little left. And there is no conceivable substitute, for example, for the biosphere's ability to produce oxygen.

The authors manage to recast this rush to disaster as a story with a (potentially) happier ending. Their grounds for optimism are partly familiar American technological optimism, if natural resources were treated as scarce and expensive, then nanotechnology and biotechnology could multiply four or even tenfold the outputs from today's inputs. Hence Clinton's enthusiasm.

But more crucial to the project is a complete mental flip of what an 'output' consists of (as Edwin Land once said, a great idea is often 'not having a new thought but stopping having an old one').

At present, it is entirely conceivable that one-quarter or even half of the GDP of advanced countries makes not value but waste. Most industrial processes, and the economy as a whole, are inefficient , at best achieving 10 per cent of their potential likewise their products. A car uses just 1 per cent of the energy it burns to propel the driver, the rest to warm the atmosphere, deafen pedestrians and shift ponderous steel boxes between traffic jams.

Moreover, waste is cumulative, so an increasing income has to be spent on alleviating growth's byproducts, pollution, traffic accidents and congestion, crime. Hence the phenomenon of uneconomic growth, where increases in nominal wealth produce no net gain in quality of life or standard of living: in real terms 80 per cent of Americans are no better off than they were in 1979.

However, the grossness of the waste is, say the authors, also a measure of the huge potential for improvement if the spiral changed to virtuous. The secret is taking a systems view in which it is always more expensive to get rid of waste than to design it out in the first place. Given the wastefulness of most current systems, improvements of 10 to 100 times in overall efficiency are possible even with existing technology.

Much of what the Lovins and Hawken propose is not new. Frances Cairncross wrote about costing the earth 10 years ago, and Richard Schonberger coined the term 'frugal manufacturing' in the 1980s. What is new is the way these ideas are brought together in a systems approach to business and the environment, and the coopting of markets as the mechanism which can be used to turn things around.

There is some irony here, of course. The greatest obstacle to 'natural capitalism' in practice will be the vested interests and special pleading of those most vociferous champions of capitalist orthodoxy, US companies, which emerge from this book the masters of the perverse, not to mention grotesque, hidden subsidy, whether of agriculture, cars, or their wealthy executives.

Persuading them to confront their own bad faith will be no easy matter. But, as someone once said, the economy is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the environment, and time is running out for the parent to bring it to heel.

· simon.caulkin@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Players' huge salaries are hardly wages of sin

fields.headline: Players' huge salaries are hardly wages of sin
fields.trailText: A man who knows both Diego Maradona and Romario thinks that their weird behaviour is largely due to that sense of unease. They love luxury but feel guilty about it. The combination prompts self-destruction.
fields.body:
Two years ago I spoke to a footballer who grew up poor in southern Europe and now plays for one of the biggest Italian clubs. He said that when he drove his sports car through the neighbourhood of his birth he felt guilty.

Something was wrong.

Many other players seem to feel the same. A man who knows both Diego Maradona and Romario thinks that their weird behaviour is largely due to that sense of unease. Both players grew up in slums, still claim to be political radicals (Maradona hangs out with Fidel Castro, Romario campaigns for left-wing politicians), but are always splashing out, partying and fighting. They love luxury but feel guilty about it. The combination prompts self-destruction.

All this is worth saying because the debate about footballers' pay is raging again. Roy Keane has negotiated a salary of £50,000 a week, Darren Anderton is demanding more than half that to stay at Spurs, and Sam Hammam, Wimbledon owner, predicts that soon some players will be earning £20 million a year.

The usual line is that footballers now earn unparalleled amounts, particularly in England, and cannot see the problem with it even though they themselves grew up poor; in short, that they are on 'ridiculous wages'. (It is odd that when it comes to footballers, people still talk about 'wages', the working-class word for salaries.)

Whether their salaries are ridiculous or not is a moral judgment, and therefore impossible to resolve. What can be said for certain is that many of the arguments currently being made are ridiculous.

Firstly, some footballers do see a problem with their salaries. Even in the 1980s there was a QPR forward, Ian Stewart, who turned down a pay rise. Admittedly there have been no recent reports of footballers doing the same, but many do give away lots of money. George Weah subsidises much of the Liberian population, Lucas Radebe demanded a salary from Leeds that would set up his dozen or so siblings for life, and Mauro Milanese, an Italian defender with Perugia, has just given Ronaldo a sponsored Brazilian child as a wedding present. It must be said that at Manchester United players continue to spend their money on worthwhile things, like trousers or Ferraris.

Secondly, it is nonsense to say that footballers grew up poorer than most people. Yes, Maradona and Romario grew up in slums, but so did many Latin Americans. Countless footballers were raised wealthy: Marcel Desailly, son of an African diplomat, Gianluca Vialli, son of an Italian industrialist, the chic Brazilian brothers Socrates and Rai, the chic Danish Laudrups, and Paolo Maldini, son of a football manager.

The slums do not produce a disproportionate number of footballers.

Rather, the best indicator of whether or not you will become a good player is whether your father was one. Pele, Michael Owen, Maldini and the Laudrups are all children of ex-pros. Football is a family trade, like being a doctor or a hangman.

It is also ridiculous to argue that footballers' pay is unique, existing in a biosphere of its own. The most generous employers in Britain are not Manchester United or even Newcastle United but large merchant banks, law firms and high-tech companies. The National Lottery has probably produced more millionaires than all of British football. Microsoft alone has created about 10,000, most of them in the Seattle area. Even the company's head lawyer, William Neukom, is worth $625 million. That too may be a 'ridiculous' amount of money, but it certainly implies that football is not uniquely ridiculous.

And it is also false to say that within football the most 'ridiculous wages' are paid in England. In a recent survey of footballers' salaries by World Soccer, Alessandro del Piero of Juventus topped the global list with a monthly salary of about £275,000. In second place was an Englishman, but an Englishman who plays abroad: Steve McManaman of Real Madrid on £260,000 a month. Christian Vieri was estimated to earn £220,000 a month and his Inter team-mate Ronaldo £200,000, about the same as Keane's new salary. The second-best paid player in England was Alan Shearer, with just £112,000 a month.

The survey did prove conclusively that there is no link between playing well and earning lots. Zinedine Zidane earns a little over a third as much as his Juventus teammate Del Piero, while Holland's best paid player is Irishman David Connolly, who after failing at Feyenoord was sent on loan to a small first-division club, Excelsior, where he pockets £77,000 monthly.

Admittedly these figures ignore signing-on fees, bonuses and boot contracts. But some bankers or company executives receive options and Christmas bonuses worth several times their salaries. In the law, a transfer market has developed for the best barristers. Football is not alone.

Arguing that footballers earn ridiculous wages remains a reasonable position. Most people in Britain argue exactly that. Yet they refuse to vote for any party that pledges to raise the top rate of income tax above 40 per cent. Even tax raises for the super-rich go down very badly. The current talk about ridiculous wages will surely remain just talk.

fields.headline: A journey back from hell
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's image-maker and a former Labour leader write - without spin - about their clubs
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's image-maker and a former Labour leader write - without spin - about their clubs.
fields.body:
Alistair Campbell on Burnley

Coventry versus Burnley, and unpleasant childhood memories come flooding back.

I was nearing my twelfth birthday in 1969 and my present was to take to the game friends I'd been trying to convert to the Burnley cause since moving to Leicester from Keighley a few months earlier. As Burnley had already done the double over City (2-0 away, 2-1 at home) and already beaten Manchester United, Newcastle and Chelsea, and positively marmalised Leeds 5-1 (not to mention getting to the League Cup semi-final), these Leicester fans were ripe for recruitment . Like so many of my Burnley experiences, it ended in massive disappointment. A 4-1 thrashing and brutal mickey-taking all the way home.

We suffered the same scoreline, and I the same humiliation, on the sole occasion I persuaded Tony Blair to watch Burnley, away at Hartlepool, the humiliation deepened by the sight of Peter Mandelson, 'well-known Hartlepool fan', boasting afterwards that 'we' beat 'you'.

Yesterday's 3-0 defeat was by no means a humiliation. Indeed for 20 minutes in the second half I thought we might equalise, but then a second defensive error led to the second goal, the third came not long after and that was that.

Looking back, there's no point denying the disappointments outweigh the moments of magic. When I was three, Burnley were League champions. The year I first saw them, aged five, we were two games away from winning the Double. I followed them from the very top to the very bottom. By the time I was 29, in 1987, we had to win 'The Orient Game' to stay in the League; a spectacular fall. Victory that day was as momentous in its way as those that had given us our two League championships and our 1914 FA Cup triumph. Having survived, every Burnley fan is convinced that though it's now a quarter of a century since we left the top flight, one day we'll be back.

Go to Burnley on match days, and you know there's a game on. We get bigger crowds per head of local population than any club in the country, possibly the world (Manchester United would need about 300,000 a game to get near us, or so we tell each other). And go to parks and playgrounds in the town_if kids are wearing strips, they're Burnley strips, not Man U. There is a passion for the club that few can match. Ask all the former players who've settled there and go back every week. And I believe it's a passion reborn by the 'The Orient Game', when a whole community woke up to the significance of what it was they almost lost.

Visitors to my office sometimes seem perplexed to see prominent on the wall a picture of David Eyres and Gary Parkinson, not exactly Burnley's most famous names, but our scorers when we beat nine-man Stockport at Wembley in 1994 to win promotion to Division One (from which, incidentally, we dropped a year later). It was magical purely by comparison with the ghastliness of years spent traipsing around uncovered away ends being patronised in programme notes. 'Great tradition but you're crap' was the general message.

Or I think back to 1983, another relegation year (to Division Three) when we none the less got to the sixth round of the FA Cup and in the League Cup beat Bury, Middlesbrough, First Division Coventry and Birmingham before, on the day manager Brian Miller was sacked, thumping Spurs 4-1 at White Hart Lane. That feels a whole lot better when you've recently lost five on the trot, including a home defeat to loathed, despised, reviled Blackburn Rovers. And though we lost 3-0 in the semi-final first leg at Liverpool, we beat them 1-0 in the second leg, so that was magical too, even if we missed the last train home.

It's been such a topsy-turvy time that there is a select band of people who are not only members of the 92 Club (93 including Wycombe) but who have seen Burnley play at all 93 and who long for a Cup tie with Cheltenham to make in 94. It's why we are able to boast, along with Wolves, of being one of just two clubs who have won all four divisional titles. Which reminds me of another magical moment, when second-time-around manager Brian Miller led out Burnley against Wolves in the 1988 Sherpa Van Trophy final. Laugh you might, but here's one for your quiz nights - when was the last time the Wembley crowd topped 80,000? Answer, the '88 Sherpa Van final... and, yes, we lost, which is why the magical moment came when the team emerged from the tunnel, hotly followed by disappointment.

So when The Observer asks for my all-time 11, I'm afraid none of our recent players make it. The only two who come close are goalkeeper Marlon Beresford, now not playing for Middlesbrough, but who helped us from fourth to first in two years; and Steve Davis, part of the same side, who left for Luton and is now back for another spell.

Nor is the team I've chosen an all-time 11 of the best players I saw, but those I remember. I was apparently at the final games of Jimmy McIl roy, reckoned to be the greatest player who ever wore claret-and-blue and who recently opened the fantastic new stand named in his honour, and Jimmy Adamson, still one of just two uncapped footballers of the year (the other is Tony Book).

Older fans say that hearing McIlroy was going to Stoke was one of those 'where were you when...' moments, on a par with moon landings and presidential assassinations, so it is a cause of shame as well as regret that I have no recollection of him playing. Likewise with Adamson, on sleepless nights I urge my memory to throw up just a flash of him running with the ball at his feet, but to no avail.

So it's Alan Stevenson in goal (what a pleasant surprise to see him at Coventry yesterday), Peter Noble, Colin Waldron, Brian Miller and Keith Newton in defence; a midfield trio of Trevor Steven, Martin Dobson and Ralph Coates and, up front, Andy Lochhead flanked by wingers Willie Morgan and Leighton James. If we were talking squads I could throw in Ray Pointer, Willie Irvine, John Connelly, Alex Elder, Frank Casper, Steve Kindon, Dave Thomas, Billy Hamilton, Brian Flynn, Adrian Heath and for sentiment's sake Neil Grewcock and Ian Britton who, as scorers of the goals that won 'The Orient Game' are photographically prominent in my home rather than merely my office.

Given our history , on train journeys back it's fair to say we spend as much time on all-time worst teams as all-time best. Mine tend to come from the 'era' I stopped going, after John Bond became manager from 1983-84. He was a disaster, bringing his ways and his players from Manchester City, getting rid of Trevor Steven, Brian Laws and Lee Dixon and stripping Martin Dobson of the captaincy.

Bond is as reviled in Burnley as Dobson was loved, so much so that when he went on to become Shrewsbury manager, and they played Burnley in the Cup, he didn't turn up, claiming his life was threatened. We drew 1-1. Bond reportedly went to the replay disguised as a steward and we won in the last minute. Another of those magical moments.

Leighton James was - is - my favourite player of all time. A couple of years back I ran into him, and was reduced to groupie meeting pop star babble before telling my sons they'd just met the greatest footballer of all time, to which one of them said George Best looked a lot different on the telly.

But I look at today's kids, millions of them who 'support' Man United, and pity them. The vast majority never get to see them play. And as their team has just won everything, including the Champions League, in the most breathtaking manner imaginable, all they've got ahead is disappointment. Those of us reared on disappointment will have far more truly magical moments in sport than those raised to expect that every game, and every trophy, is a piece of cake. For young United fans, the only way is down and, believe me, it's a hellish journey to make.

Michael Foot on Plymouth Argyle

Yesterday was Cup day and I had my seat for the game - just as I saw Argyle beat Reading in the third round. I reckoned, before kick-off, they were sure to beat Preston too. I started going when I was six or seven just after the First World War. I'd go every Saturday; to watch the first team one week, the reserves the next. The whole family were Argyle supporters but I was always keener than the others.

We've always had a reputation for playing good football - keeping the ball on the ground and never losing our nerve - and the present manager Kevin Hodges has maintained that. We probably play better football than anyone else in the division, with the possible exception of Swansea. We have a tradition of trying, and often succeeding, in playing good football and I'm glad to see the crowds are getting larger. There were 13,000 for the game at Torquay and there were surely as many as the ground can hold for the game against Preston. We used to get 25,000 at Home Park but our stand was bombed during the war. There was quite a problem getting everything going again afterwards but the local spirit was very strong. I've always thought it was better than everyone else's but, of course, that's not true.

The present team is on the way to the Premiership which is where they should be. We nearly made it before the Second World War. I can remember watching them beat Spurs 2-1 at White Hart Lane. Sammy Black was on the left wing, the greatest winger of his age, he could score equally well with his right or left foot. Then there was Jack Leslie, who was one of the first black players to play in the English league, at inside-left. He came from Africa and played about 20 years for Argyle. He was wonderfully skilled, more noted for his skill than his brawn, although his brawn was very considerable. He could have scored more goals but he was always keen to see his friend Sammy Black score. The captain was was Moses Russell, a Welsh international and was absolutely bald - before Yul Brynner made it famous - and by the end of the game his white pate would be black from heading the ball.

We would have made it to the First Division, it was only the Second World War which stopped us. I always promised that I wouldn't conk out myself until we were there... I may be cutting it a bit fine.

The game has changed. I'm absolutely opposed to the richer clubs buying up the whole game - that would be terrible. There should be more support for the smaller clubs otherwise there is a danger they will be driven out of existence, which would do an injury not just to football but to the social welfare of the country. The attachment of fans to their home team is one of the game's greatest attractions.

Alastair Campbell and I agree on this. There are some people who support their local team for show, but not Alastair. He has real enthusiasm for Burnley and is a genuine football enthusiast. So are many of the others, they have backed their local team through thick and thin. Poor old Roy Hattersley is stuck with Sheffield Wednesday.

Before the War, I used to watch that wonderful Arsenal team because of the Plymouth connection. David Jack, the other inside-forward alongside Alex James, was the son of Robert Jack who managed Argyle for 20 years. They were an extraordinary combination: Jack was six feet tall and James was two feet tall!

At that time I can remember being down in Fleet Street and bumping into Alex James. That was real fame.

fields.headline: Fox leaves Exeter
fields.trailText: The Exeter City manager Peter Fox has left the Third Division club.
fields.body:
The Exeter City manager Peter Fox has left the Third Division club.

The 42-year-old ended his five-season reign at St James' Park after a meeting with the chairman Ivor Doble.

The club said: "With great regret Exeter have agreed to release Peter Fox from his contract with the club with immediate effect."

The club said: "With great regret Exeter have agreed to release Peter Fox from his contract with the club with immediate effect."

webTitle: Reds feel heat of own making

fields.headline: Reds feel heat of own making
fields.trailText: Thirty years on from the 1970 World Cup, it seems that English football has still not learned from its painful experience in Mexico.
fields.body:
Thirty years on from the 1970 World Cup, it seems that English football has still not learned from its painful experience in Mexico.

That was the cup when the locals fervently supported England's opponents in every match after Sir Alf Ramsey's men implied, through bringing their own food and bus driver, that the Mexicans could not cook, drive or perform any other every day task.

Manchester United have not achieved quite the same level of unpopularity in Rio de Janeiro, but they have certainly done nothing to dispel the popular image in Brazil that they English are a snotty race with their heads buried in the last century.

The adjectives 'arrogant', 'cold', 'uppity' and 'opulent' have been used in almost every Brazilian newspaper story about United. Their opening game with Necaxa was billed by one paper as 'The Kings of Opulence against Friendliness Football Club'.

Since arriving in Brazil last Sunday, United have behaved as if on enemy territory, closing off their training sessions to the public - a cardinal sin in Brazil - and refusing any contact with the local media, apart from a couple of grudging media conferences. They have brought their own cook and most of their own food.

Brazilian newspapers have been full of reports about the team's lavish habits, pointing out that of the eight teams in the competition, United's players are the only ones who do not have to share rooms.

The contrast with Necaxa, the Mexican team who they played last Thursday, could not be greater.

The Mexicans arrived 10 days before their first match, opened all but one training session to the public and admitted they were charmed by the city's delights, including the local women. They scored a huge public relations hit by going on walkabout in a shanty-town handing out shirts to the locals. 'It's the reality of Brazil and the reality of our country as well,' said player Israel Vasquez.

Manager Raul Arias explained: 'We have very good memories of Brazilian football in Mexico, ever since the 1970 World Cup. It's a way of thanking everyone for the legacy that Brazilian football has left in our country. We want to do something to make sure we keep up the exchange and a good relationship.'

When they finally decided to talk to the locals, Sir Alex Ferguson and his captain, Roy Keane, were unable to display any interest in or knowledge of the host nation and their football, apart from the fact that it is hot and humid and that Romario is a difficult player to mark.

The consequences were predictable. United's players were greeted by a chorus of resounding jeers as they took the field to face Necaxa, and the Mexicans were supported as if they were the home team.

David Beckham was booed every time he touched the ball, the public perhaps influenced by reports that he had pushed away a Mexican woman who had asked for his autograph as the team went for a brief stroll near their hotel, and the British national anthem got the same treatment.

If in part the reason for United's visit was to promote England's bid to host the 2006 World Cup, then they might have done better defending the FA Cup. The impression given to Mexicans, Brazilians and everyone else was that the British remain as insular as ever.

Ferguson's gripes about the weather, however, are legitimate. It is so hot in Rio at this time of year that not even the locals play. The Brazilian season normally runs from early February to the end of December. Playing in January is unheard of and regarded as silly.

The Brazilian Football Confederation (CBF) wanted to hold the event all along to boost their bid for the 2006 World Cup. They have gone out of their way to impress visiting teams and dignitaries, upgrading the previously shoddy Maracana and Morumbi stadiums and generally trying to be nice to everyone. In typical style, they left everything to the last minute - two days before Manchester United played Necaxa, piles of rubble and loose wires were strewn around the Maracana - but so far it has gone well for them.

Sadly, their treatment of the Brazilian public, who have no votes when it comes to deciding where the 2006 Cup will take place, has been shoddy.

Ticket sales have been a hopeless shambles with fans turning up at advertised selling points to find only cheaper tickets for the next day on sale or, in some cases, none at all. Anyone venturing to buy over the Internet is greeted with the 'Server not replying' message.

The organisers happily admitted it was a deliberate policy to withhold tickets for later matches. 'We didn't want everyone just buying tickets for the game between Vasco de Gama and Manchester United,' said an official. 'We wanted to force them to see Vasco play South Melbourne first.'

On leaving sales points empty-handed, supporters have then run the gauntlet of touts selling any variety of ticket that exists. On Friday, before the Real Madrid-Corinthians game, touts were happily doing business in front of the Morumbi stadium in Sao Paulo, long after official sales points had sold out.

'Business is too good to be true,' said tout Paulo Joaquim da Silva.

The result of the confusion was that only 16,000 saw the opening games in Sao Paulo, and most of them turned up merely for the second match between Corinthians and Raja Casablanca. Real Madrid and Al Nassr, who opened a double bill of matches at the Morumbi, kicked off in front of an estimated crowd of 1,000. This was despite modest prices of Real 10 (around £3.30 ) for the cheapest seats to Real 50 (£16.60) for the most expensive.

South Melbourne's players spent most of their official practice at the Maracana taking photographs of each other on the famous turf rather than actually training, clearly unable to believe the change in their fortunes.

The team's previous international outing, at the Oceania club championship, had been played in Fiji's national stadium against teams from such footballing powers as the Soloman Islands, Vanuatu and Tonga.

Manager Ange Postecoglou said of the Oceania tournament: 'Some football was played, but most of it was just a fight.'

The Australians' shirts were banned at the last minute by Fifa because of excess advertising. They had to have replacements made locally 24 hours before the match.

Raja Casablanca were equally wide-eyed after playing Vasco da Gama in a warm-up friendly before the tournament. As soon as the final whistle went, they surrounded Romario for his autograph and persuaded him to pose for photos with them. They did not get his shirt, however. That was given, on request, to the match referee.

Both the Maracana and Morumbi stadiums have shrunk. The Maracana once accommodated over 200,000 for a match but its capacity, with new plastic seats on the upper tier and the standing-only area shut, has been reduced to 70,000 for the championship. The Morumbi's capacity is down from 120,000 to 59,000.

The unhappiest man was 67-year-old Victoria Guttemberg, official stadium announcer since 1961 at the Maracana, who was ejected in favour of a bilingual double-act provided by Fifa. 'I turned up for work and there were already two people sitting in my place,' he said. 'They didn't tell me anything.'

Former Arsenal striker Nicolas Anelka's quest to become the first player to score a hat-trick in the competition may have cost Real Madrid a place in the final.

With the score in Friday's match against Corinthians level at 2-2, Madrid were awarded a penalty in the 71st minute after Fabio Luciano fouled Savio inside the area.

Anelka, who had scored twice but had also squandered a couple of relatively easy chances with scuffed shots, decided he and not Savio, Madrid's recently appointed penalty-taker, would take the kick.

As Arsenal's least popular old boy was placing the ball, defender Christian Karembeu sprinted the length of the pitch screaming at the top of his voice for professionalism to rule and his team-mates to stop Anelka from seeking glory.

Sadly for Madrid, however, Karembeu's appeals fell on deaf ears and Anelka went ahead, only for his feeble effort to be parried away by Brazilian national team keeper Dida - his eighth penalty save this season. The match ended 2-2 and to qualify for the final Madrid now need a better result against Raja Casablanca than Corinthians achieve against Al Nassr.

It's a way of thanking everyone for the legacy that Brazilian football has left in our country. We want to do something to make sure we keep up the exchange and a good relationship.' When they finally decided to talk to the locals, Sir Alex Ferguson and his captain, Roy Keane, were unable to display any interest in or knowledge of the host nation and their football, apart from the fact that it is hot and humid and that Romario is a difficult player to mark. The consequences were predictable. United's players were greeted by a chorus of resounding jeers as they took the field to face Necaxa, and the Mexicans were supported as if they were the home team. David Beckham was booed every time he touched the ball, the public perhaps influenced by reports that he had pushed away a Mexican woman who had asked for his autograph as the team went for a brief stroll near their hotel, and the British national anthem got the same treatment. If in part the reason for United's visit was to promote England's bid to host the 2006 World Cup, then they might have done better defending the FA Cup. The impression given to Mexicans, Brazilians and everyone else was that the British remain as insular as ever. Ferguson's gripes about the weather, however, are legitimate. It is so hot in Rio at this time of year that not even the locals play. The Brazilian season normally runs from early February to the end of December. Playing in January is unheard of and regarded as silly. The Brazilian Football Confederation (CBF) wanted to hold the event all along to boost their bid for the 2006 World Cup. They have gone out of their way to impress visiting teams and dignitaries, upgrading the previously shoddy Maracana and Morumbi stadiums and generally trying to be nice to everyone. In typical style, they left everything to the last minute - two days before Manchester United played Necaxa, piles of rubble and loose wires were strewn around the Maracana - but so far it has gone well for them. Sadly, their treatment of the Brazilian public, who have no votes when it comes to deciding where the 2006 Cup will take place, has been shoddy. Ticket sales have been a hopeless shambles with fans turning up at advertised selling points to find only cheaper tickets for the next day on sale or, in some cases, none at all. Anyone venturing to buy over the Internet is greeted with the 'Server not replying' message. The organisers happily admitted it was a deliberate policy to withhold tickets for later matches. 'We didn't want everyone just buying tickets for the game between Vasco de Gama and Manchester United,' said an official. 'We wanted to force them to see Vasco play South Melbourne first.' On leaving sales points empty-handed, supporters have then run the gauntlet of touts selling any variety of ticket that exists. On Friday, before the Real Madrid-Corinthians game, touts were happily doing business in front of the Morumbi stadium in Sao Paulo, long after official sales points had sold out. 'Business is too good to be true,' said tout Paulo Joaquim da Silva. The result of the confusion was that only 16,000 saw the opening games in Sao Paulo, and most of them turned up merely for the second match between Corinthians and Raja Casablanca. Real Madrid and Al Nassr, who opened a double bill of matches at the Morumbi, kicked off in front of an estimated crowd of 1,000. This was despite modest prices of Real 10 (around £3.30 ) for the cheapest seats to Real 50 (£16.60) for the most expensive. South Melbourne's players spent most of their official practice at the Maracana taking photographs of each other on the famous turf rather than actually training, clearly unable to believe the change in their fortunes. The team's previous international outing, at the Oceania club championship, had been played in Fiji's national stadium against teams from such footballing powers as the Soloman Islands, Vanuatu and Tonga. Manager Ange Postecoglou said of the Oceania tournament: 'Some football was played, but most of it was just a fight.' The Australians' shirts were banned at the last minute by Fifa because of excess advertising. They had to have replacements made locally 24 hours before the match. Raja Casablanca were equally wide-eyed after playing Vasco da Gama in a warm-up friendly before the tournament. As soon as the final whistle went, they surrounded Romario for his autograph and persuaded him to pose for photos with them. They did not get his shirt, however. That was given, on request, to the match referee. Both the Maracana and Morumbi stadiums have shrunk. The Maracana once accommodated over 200,000 for a match but its capacity, with new plastic seats on the upper tier and the standing-only area shut, has been reduced to 70,000 for the championship. The Morumbi's capacity is down from 120,000 to 59,000. The unhappiest man was 67-year-old Victoria Guttemberg, official stadium announcer since 1961 at the Maracana, who was ejected in favour of a bilingual double-act provided by Fifa. 'I turned up for work and there were already two people sitting in my place,' he said. 'They didn't tell me anything.' Former Arsenal striker Nicolas Anelka's quest to become the first player to score a hat-trick in the competition may have cost Real Madrid a place in the final. With the score in Friday's match against Corinthians level at 2-2, Madrid were awarded a penalty in the 71st minute after Fabio Luciano fouled Savio inside the area. Anelka, who had scored twice but had also squandered a couple of relatively easy chances with scuffed shots, decided he and not Savio, Madrid's recently appointed penalty-taker, would take the kick. As Arsenal's least popular old boy was placing the ball, defender Christian Karembeu sprinted the length of the pitch screaming at the top of his voice for professionalism to rule and his team-mates to stop Anelka from seeking glory. Sadly for Madrid, however, Karembeu's appeals fell on deaf ears and Anelka went ahead, only for his feeble effort to be parried away by Brazilian national team keeper Dida - his eighth penalty save this season. The match ended 2-2 and to qualify for the final Madrid now need a better result against Raja Casablanca than Corinthians achieve against Al Nassr.

webTitle: United face more failure as Necaxa march on

fields.headline: United face more failure as Necaxa march on
fields.trailText: Manchester United's interest in the World Club Championship is almost over after Mexican outfit Necaxa beat South Melbourne of Australia 3-1 at the Maracana stadium in Rio last night. Necaxa have four points - three more than Sir Alec Ferguson's men - and could still reach the final if they pull off a surprise and upset United's conquerors Vasca da Gama in their last Group B match.
fields.body:
Manchester United's interest in the World Club Championship is almost over after Mexican outfit Necaxa beat South Melbourne of Australia 3-1 at the Maracana stadium in Rio last night. Necaxa have four points - three more than Sir Alec Ferguson's men - and could still reach the final if they pull off a surprise and upset United's conquerors Vasca da Gama in their last Group B match.

But failing that, a draw would be enough to secure a third-place play-off and relegate United, who also have an inferior goal difference, to also-rans even if the European champions were to see off the Australians in their final group game.

The Mexicans, the reigning CONCACAF championship title-holders, ousted the best that Oceania can provide in a near-deserted Maracana with the help of two penalties. Cristian Montecinos, who netted against United, put Necaxa ahead from the spot after 19 minutes and Agustin Delgado made it 2-0 on the half-hour to put the Central Americans firmly in the driving seat.

But John Anastasiadis pulled one back for Melbourne on the stroke of half-time with their first goal of the tournament and it needed another penalty, this time converted by Salvador Cabrera, 11 minutes from time to make the game safe for Necaxa.

Melbourne have the consolation of a final flourish against United in what for them will have been a useful learning process.

fields.headline: Di Matteo supplies finish
fields.standfirst: Italian duo prove there's no substitute for class as City show their survival tactics
fields.trailText: Bradford 1 - 1 Chelsea
fields.body:
A Chelsea bench boasting the mercurial talents of Roberto Di Matteo and Gianfranco Zola finally ended the visitors' frustration in front of goal as the former, with his first touch, set up Dan Petrescu for a thoroughly merited equaliser.

Until that point, Chelsea appeared to be heading for an extraordinary loss as they failed to convert any of the seemingly endless reserve of chances they created in the Premiership's only match of the day.

In an extraordinary start to the contest it took Bradford just 59 seconds to find the net and provide real hope that they could climb out of the bottom three.

Unbeaten at Valley Parade since Sunderland sauntered to a 4-0 victory on the opening weekend in October, Bradford have recently shown genuine signs of a recovery that could yet see them kick off next season in the Premiership.

Their major failing has been a lack of goals - 15 in 20 games before yesterday representing the Premiership's worst return - so such a start against a resurgent Chelsea was, to say the least, unexpected.

A short pass from Robbie Blake found Dean Saunders on the right and the Welsh veteran's precise cross bisected Chelsea's central defensive pair and found the head of Lee Mills. It was a particularly sweet moment for Saunders, subjected to merciless verbal abuse by visiting fans who have still not forgotten his part in the collision that ended Paul Elliott's career.

Still, personal retribution aside, it was a vitally important goal for the home team, not least because Chelsea's response was committed and instantaneous. The ensuing eight minutes might have brought five Chelsea goals as the blue shirts flowed forward; pace, passing and excellent movement seeing the ball worked to the front two of Chris Sutton and Tore Andre Flo with ease.

The best opportunity for an early equaliser came after just three minutes as home keeper Matt Clarke misjudged a Den nis Wise corner and presented defender John Terry with an unopposed shot on an open goal. The young Chelsea man must have been as surprised as anyone to find himself in such a position and his unconvincing shot was cleared off the line by Gunnar Halle.

Within a minute Wise found Sutton for an off-target shot from distance, 60 seconds on and Albert Ferrer set up Wise for a strike that was parried by Clarke, then Flo missed the first two of a host of chances, shooting off target and then watching Clarke block a chance with his feet.

Bradford were living dangerously and had to be thankful for Flo's profligacy as, twice more, the Norwegian striker wasted opportunities. But as the first half wore on, chances began to materialise in front of the Chelsea goal.

Mills missed two good openings then Halle careered down the right and sent a fabulous left-foot strike curling towards goal where De Goey produced a smart, one-handed reflex save.

After the interval, it was the turn of Gustavo Poyet to continue the trend of missed opportunities, shooting over an open goal from eight yards and heading over from a promising position.

Mercifully Di Matteo's first touch, as a 57th minute substitute for Wise, saw him release Petrescu just inside the Brad ford half and the Romanian possessed the necessary pace and poise to carry the ball half the length of the field and slip it past Clarke.

fields.headline: Villa's revival rolls on
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 1 - 0 Southampton
fields.body:
Given a helpful draw, Aston Villa look the sort of side who could go all the way to Wembley now that they appear to have arrested their alarming autumn slide. They will need to improve on the wasteful finishing of yesterday, however, when their victory over a woeful Southampton was, in terms of goals, about one sixth as convincing as it should have been.

Fortunately for Villa, their captain Gareth Southgate, the defensive rock on whom so much of their game relies, showed his forwards how to do it and grabbed his third goal in a week after the brace in the win at Leeds, to take them through with considerably more ease than the scoreline suggests.

The omens were not good for Southampton, even if they did win here in the third round on their way to winning the Cup in 1977. Saints also managed a 1-0 win over Villa in the League in November in the middle of the home side's bad patch when John Gregory's job as manager was called into question, but more recently were beaten 4-0 in the Worthington Cup, a result that helped Villa regain some of their confidence.

To Southampton went the game's first half-chance, Kevin Davies crossing low from the right and Marian Pahars just failing to reach it at the far post, but it served only to sting Villa into action. Soon, with Ian Taylor and George Boateng establishing a grip over the Norwegian Jo Tessem and Chris Marsden in midfield, they were pouring through a porous Saints defence.

Julian Joachim got between the unsteady pairing of Claus Lundekvam and Francis Benali and headed Steve Watson's cross just wide, and Joachim then should have opened the scoring, clipping Taylor's knock-down from Paul Merson's ball forward over the bar. Alan Wright was then similarly culpable, sidefooting wide from eight yards after Taylor had put him in the clear.

A goal surely had to come and duly it did. After Lundekvam had held back Joachim, the eager, inventive Merson delivered a clever, accurate free kick to the far post where Taylor headed down for Southgate to stoop and head home from a few yards out.

More should have followed before half-time. Lundekvam slid in to block Joachim's shot when it seemed certain that he would turn home Boateng's cut back from the byline and Paul Jones flew across his goal to turn aside Carbone's curling 20-yard free kick.

The interval only interrupted, rather than stemmed, the tide. Wright saw his low shot saved by Jones after Benito Carbone had missed an overhead kick from an astute cross by Joachim, who also forced the goalkeeper into a save after nipping behind a dreaming Southampton defence to reach Southgate's clearance.

Taylor, his industry and energy making him the game's outstanding player, then came close to sealing the match for Villa, rising to meet Merson's chip only to see his header thump against the bar and away to safety.

Villa could have done with the second so that they could have confidently rested players before Tuesday's Worthington Cup replay at West Ham. Instead, they did so with reservations, the more so because Southampton introduced Mark Hughes for a final attempt to secure a replay, although to create a chance would have been a start.

The fear for Villa was that self-doubt might creep in after their dominance had failed to yield more than one goal. In the end, though, Southampton were simply too inadequate to fight their way back into the tie.

fields.headline: Sedgley not so simply
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 1 - 1 Wolves
fields.body:
Bottom of the Premiership, attendances plummeting, millions in debt. You can hardly blame Sheffield Wednesday for clinging on to any hope they can in this most miserable of seasons, even if it was from two centuries ago.

In the build-up to this match it was pointed out that Wednesday had beaten Wolves on the way to winning the FA Cup back in 1896. Sadly for them, on this occasion even the omens were against them.

In the end, they were grateful for a replay after being almost totally outplayed for most of this match. They will hardly travel to Molineux with confidence against a side they have now not beaten in their last five meetings.

Row after row of empty blue seats showed what the Sheffield public think of this season's lopsided FA Cup. In contrast, the away end was a scene of swaying gold and black, a testament to the enduring hold of this competition for Wolves.

Jack Hayward, the Wolves owner, still values the cup above promotion to the Premiership, and his ambition remains to lift the trophy 'while I'm still strong enough'.

But it was Wednesday's fans who were able to strike up the first tune of glory. Fewer than 10 minutes had been played when Wim Jonk hit a free-kick towards the Wolves back post for Peter Atherton to pick out the unmarked Niclas Alexandersson. The Swede's scuffed volley bounced apologetically over the line via the post.

For the next 15 minutes Wednesday left Wolves in no doubt as to who were the Premiership outfit as they swarmed forward in num bers, threatening to overwhelm the First Division side.

Atherton again spread panic in the Wolves defence in the 20th minute when he got on the end of an Andy Hinchcliffe corner to put in a header which Lee Naylor cleared off the line. Wolves were still reeling from this let-off when Gerald Sibon fired in a low shot which Michael Oakes did well to push around the post.

Seconds later the visitors had another escape when Sibon's shot was deflected into the path of Danny Sonner, but his effort was placed well wide when he should have done better.

Perhaps it was their inability to capitalise on these chances which sapped Werdnesday's confidence, because suddenly they found them selves on the back foot as Wolves won a series of corners. From one of these, taken by Darren Bazeley in the 24th minute, the on-loan striker Michael Branch wrapped his boot round a shot which flew narrowly wide. Yet for all their possession it took Wolves until the 69th minute before they equalised. And what a confusing and controversial goal it was.

Bazeley put in a corner which amid the melee was headed against the post. Pavel Srnicek palmed the ball away only for the assistant referee - who was perfectly placed - to signal that the ball had crossed the line.

Branch reeled away as if he had scored. It was only after the final whistle on video evidence that Steve Sedgley was credited with the goal. It was the one memorable moment of a second half, which until that point had lapsed into a lull from which it seemed it would never stir.

At the final whistle, Srnicek remonstrated angrily for several moments with Graham Barber, the referee, but was waved away.

Defeat would have been cruel on a Wolves side who enjoyed more of the ball and played the better football, even if they did create few clear-cut opportunities.

History will now be on their side in the replay a week on Tuesday. Five years ago they came out on top in similar circumstances after a penalty shoot-out. That night, Wednesday's Chris Waddle took his first spot-kick since his miss in the 1990 World Cup semi-final, and failed again.

fields.headline: Unsworth's double
fields.trailText: Everton 2 - 0 Birmingham
fields.body:
It may be a new millennium but some things never change and, as Birmingham found to their cost, football is still a game of two halves. After dominating the first half, the First Division side paid a heavy price for their profligacy as Everton exposed the gulf in status by turning the game on its head during the second period to secure a place in the fifth round courtesy of two late penalties from David Unsworth.

Having been the victims of giant-killing acts on more occasions than they would care to remember, it was understandable for Everton to view the arrival of one of the First Division's most viable promotion prospects with a certain degree of trepidation. No fewer than eight lower-division clubs have profited from Everton's fragility in cup competitions over the past six years, and Exeter City had taken them to within six minutes of extra time in the previous round.

For the opening 20 minutes, Everton were unrecognisable from the side who had gone unbeaten at home in the Premiership since April. Wave after wave of attacks lapped up on the hosts' penalty area as Birmingham, ravaged by injuries and blighted by poor form, took the initiative.

Bryan Hughes, a boyhood Evertonian, was culpable of a horrible miss during a one-sided opening, while Gary Rowett and Martin O'Connor also had clear sights at goal before the home side finally awoke.

It took a spectacular effort from Francis Jeffers to ignite Walter Smith's men, striking the base of Ian Bennett's left post with a venomous left-foot drive from 30 yards. But there was no mistaking the lack of belief running through his colleagues. Was this really the same side who had beaten Sunderland 5-0 only a fortnight earlier?

After ushering in the new century in a police cell, Jeffers had an extra incentive to impress on his return to the side. Smith also restored Richard Dunne into the line-up and Michael Ball on to the bench after disciplining them both for taking the festive celebrations too far. Presumably, the manager felt compelled to have more strong words during the interval here. Everton were like a side transformed in the remaining 45 minutes, only to find Bennett in inspired form.

Kevin Campbell alone had half a dozen opportunities to put the home side ahead before Nicky Barmby scampered into the penalty area and was tripped by the substitute Eddie Newton.

Unsworth's left-foot finish was low and precise, and the defender picked out exactly the same spot in injury time after Campbell had been impeded by Graham Hyde.

'We were not working well in the first half, but it was completely different after the interval and it was much more positive from us,' said the Everton manager. 'Unsworth took his penalties well and I think it was a fair reflection given our second-half performance.'

But there was no mistaking the lack of belief running through his colleagues. Was this really the same side who had beaten Sunderland 5-0 only a fortnight earlier? After ushering in the new century in a police cell, Jeffers had an extra incentive to impress on his return to the side. Smith also restored Richard Dunne into the line-up and Michael Ball on to the bench after disciplining them both for taking the festive celebrations too far. Presumably, the manager felt compelled to have more strong words during the interval here. Everton were like a side transformed in the remaining 45 minutes, only to find Bennett in inspired form. Kevin Campbell alone had half a dozen opportunities to put the home side ahead before Nicky Barmby scampered into the penalty area and was tripped by the substitute Eddie Newton. Unsworth's left-foot finish was low and precise, and the defender picked out exactly the same spot in injury time after Campbell had been impeded by Graham Hyde. 'We were not working well in the first half, but it was completely different after the interval and it was much more positive from us,' said the Everton manager. 'Unsworth took his penalties well and I think it was a fair reflection given our second-half performance.'

fields.headline: Preston enjoy the gifts
fields.trailText: Plymouth 0 - 3 Preston
fields.body:
Preston North End experienced West Country hospitality at its most generous yesterday. Two own goals and a gifted penalty gave them a trouble-free passage into the fifth round. Something had to give at Home Park - either Plymouth's unbeaten home record or the visitors' handsome away form. In the end Preston prevailed easily and the FA Cup bade farewell to its last Third Division side. Plymouth were brave but ultimately outplayed, though it took Preston a while to show their superior pedigree.

Until the first goal in the 39th minute, the first half was full of endeavour but not much else. There were some sterling exhibitions of head tennis between the two sides, 10 consecutive headers setting the record. And it was intriguing to see how Steve McCall, the 39-year-old Plymouth assistant manager, fared in the hustle and bustle of a crowded midfield. For 65 minutes - until he was substituted - he coped rather well, distinguishable by the fact that he passed the ball along the ground to one of his own side.

For half an hour the gap between the teams was not discernible, but gradually Preston's extra polish and speed began to tell. In the 30th minute David Eyres, sprinting in from the left, provoked the first save of the match. Then a neat move down the right, a chipped cross from Jonathan Macken and the ball was headed past the helpless Argyle keeper, John Sheffield. Preston striker Kurt Nogan claimed the goal. Wayne O'Sullivan, Plymouth's right-back didn't but he looked suitably guilty and downcast. The cameras soon confirmed an own goal.

If the first half was low key, the second began at a rare pace. For five minutes Plymouth pitched camp in the Preston penalty area and threatened, usually through Chris Leadbitter. But Preston rallied and their second goal finished the game as a contest. Eyres, with just the keeper to beat, was brought down and Graham Alexander emphatically converted his seventh penalty of the season.

Soon after, the Plymouth left-back Jon Beswetherick confounded his own keeper with a fierce back header from a corner. Thereafter Preston were struggling, grateful for their free gift. Presumably they were given complementary scones and cream to accompany their post-match cup of tea.

fields.headline: Videos
fields.standfirst: Ten Things I Hate About You | Basket Case | Rogue Trader | Titanic Town
fields.trailText: Ten Things I Hate About You (1999, 15, Buena Vista, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)
fields.body:
Ten Things I Hate About You (1999, 15, Buena Vista, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)

From Ford's The Quiet Man to Kiss Me Kate there have been many screen variations on The Taming of the Shrew , as well as several straight versions. None has been cleverer or funnier than Gil Junger's transposition of Shakespeare's sex-war comedy to Padua High School in Seattle, where the Stratford sisters, Bianca and Katarina, are respectively a beautiful conformist sophomore and an aggressive feminist senior who reads Plath and the Brontës, plays a mean game of soccer and despises boys. This clever movie sends up the high school genre and respects its source. As the school's black Eng Lit teacher says: 'Shakespeare was a dead white guy but he knows his shit.'

Basket Case (1981, Tartan, VHS,Rental/Retail)

Frank Henenlotter's low-budget schlock-horror flick got caught up in the 'video nasties' scandal of the early Eighties and now appears on the Tartan Terror cult label. After a mysterious upstate New York killing, an innocent country boy moves into a sleazy hotel near Times Square clutching a wicker basket that contains Belial, the lad's homicidal Siamese twin. The pair are seeking bloody revenge on the trio of doctors who separated them. The movie strives for a kind of comic badness that Ed Wood achieved effortlessly.

Rogue Trader (1999, 15, Fox Pathé, VHS/Rental)

Writer-director James Dearden (working with co-producer Sir David Frost, the first film-maker since Sir C. Aubrey Smith to use his knighthood in the credits) adds little to what we already know about Nick Leeson. The ubiquitous Ewan McGregor impersonates the over-reaching son of a Watford plasterer whose inept dealings in the Far East destroyed Barings Bank, one of the City's most patrician institutions.

Always watchable, never revealing, the film desperately needed a Bertolt Brecht, a Francesco Rosi or a David Hare to explore its implications. Anna Friel is given nothing to bite on as Lisa Leeson.

Titanic Town (1998, 15, Alliance Atlantis, VHS, Retail)

Roger Michell's spirited tragi-comedy (adapted by playwright Anne Devlin from a novel by Mary Costello, the daughter of an early Ulster peace campaigner) gives Julie Walters one of her best screen roles. Walters plays a tough-minded Belfast housewife in Catholic Andersonstown in 1972 attempting with little success to introduce common sense into the conflict between bigots, bureaucrats and paramilitaries. She's neither idealised nor patronised, and of course she fails, but the film is packed with incident, dark humour, humanity and flickering hope.

fields.headline: In Hell's Kitchen, everybody's toast...
fields.standfirst: Scorsese returns to  Taxi Driver territory in this blood-spattered fable of New York paramedics - but this time he's really got his foot on the gas
fields.trailText: Philip French: Our attention is constantly gripped and the movie is kept on the rails by the intensity of the performances, the attention to detail, the black humour, the unerring precision of each cut and camera movement and the director's sheer conviction in what he is doing
fields.body:
In Louis Malle's Atlantic City, an ageing hoodlum, played by Burt Lancaster, rhapsodises on the town's lost splendours: 'Yes, it used to be beautiful, what with the rackets, whoring, guns. Sometimes things would happen and I'd have to kill a few people. The Atlantic Ocean was something then. Yes, you should have seen the Atlantic Ocean in those days.'

Martin Scorsese would agree with the sentiment. Although in Kundun he looked back in wonder to the idyllic Tibet before the Chinese invasion, he usually likes to celebrate the bad old days when hell was all around us - the mob-run Las Vegas of Casino, for instance, before the big corporations turned it into a destination for family fun, and now in Bringing Out the Dead, New York City before Mayor Giuliani cleaned up the streets and made it a safe place to live in.

The new movie, scripted by Scorsese's longtime collaborator Paul Schrader, is set in the early Nineties in that infernal area of the West Side between 35th Street and 57th Street and Eighth Avenue and the Hudson River, known since the nineteenth century as Hell's Kitchen.

Bringing Out the Dead is, in effect, Taxi Driver transferred to the Emergency Medical Services, the chief difference being that the ambulances driven by the EMS paramedics never pick up any ordinary fares. Their passengers are murder victims, junkies, whores, winos, cardiac arrests, poor, desperate people who leave blood, not tips, behind them.

Another difference is that whereas Travis Bickle's taxi often cruises in slow motion, the ambulances in Bringing Out the Dead accelerate out of control in a flashing blur.

De Niro's Travis was a psychopath with a tight grip on his mad life. Nicolas Cage's Frank Pierce is a sane man at the end of his tether, a divorcé from a respectable, blue-collar Catholic family with a copy of Céline's Journey to the End of the Night on his bedside table, a whisky bottle in his glove compartment and a mission to serve mankind.

'My mother once said you look like a priest,' he recalls, and over three nights we see him tested physically and spiritually to near destruction. His contrasted fellow paramedics are a fat, food-guzzling cynic (John Goodman), a womanising, Bible-thumping black man (Ving Rhames), a psychopathic racist who beats up patients and smashes his own ambulance (Tom Sizemore), and a twitching boss right out of Catch 22 who refuses to fire Frank because he's still capable of reporting for duty.

There's not much help there, and their thoughts and doubts are of a different order. Every act, every failure tortures Frank and he's especially haunted by the ghost of Rose, a Hispanic teenage prostitute, who died in his arms one winter night after the paramedics mistook an asthma attack for an overdose. He comes to suspect that his role 'is less about saving lives than bearing witness'.

The movie verges on self-parody. The run-down hospital Frank works for makes ER look like Dr Cameron's surgery in Tannochbrae and is called Our Lady of Perpetual Mercy. The ex-junkie daughter of an elderly heart patient he cares for is called Mary (Patricia Arquette) and predictably in the fade-out scene she clutches him in a pietà.

But our attention is constantly gripped and the movie is kept on the rails by the intensity of the performances, the attention to detail, the black humour, the unerring precision of each cut and camera movement and the director's sheer conviction in what he is doing.

Making movies is to Scorsese what being a paramedic is to Frank - a matter of total commitment, a religious vocation, a life-and-death affair.

webTitle: The role of a lifetime: John Malkovich has found his ideal part

fields.headline: The role of a lifetime: John Malkovich has found his ideal part
fields.trailText: It's no secret that most of Hollywood's best paid actors make their living playing subtle variations of themselves. So when the world's highest paid actress Julia Roberts played exactly that in Notting Hill, no one blinked.
fields.body:
It's no secret that most of Hollywood's best paid actors make their living playing subtle variations of themselves. So when the world's highest paid actress Julia Roberts played exactly that in Notting Hill, no one blinked.

That's why American critics have fallen over themselves to praise John Malkovich's performance in Being John Malkovich, a surrealist comedy.

Malkovich plays himself very well: researching the part must have been straightforward, a long look in a mirror followed by a glance at his CV. The film was one of last year's critical hits in America, impressing reviewers with its wit and imagination.

Last December the New York Film Critics awarded Malkovich the Best Supporting Actor award. Presumably they thought it was a part no one else could have played better. An Oscar nomination is a real possibility too.

Malkovich's case raises an interesting question about the nature of acting: Hollywood stars have long played variations of themselves on screen, which is not as easy as it sounds. John Wayne never changed but audiences didn't feel short-changed, rather the opposite. Being natural on camera is a priceless skill after all. Movies are littered with embarrassing cameos from celebrities and thespians 'playing themselves', but looking like they've been miscast.

The bizarre plot Of Being John Malkovich revolves around a lowly office worker (John Cusack) who finds a portal into Malkovich's brain and discovers he can control the actor for 15-minute spells. Naturally he invites family and friends along to enjoy the experience. Well you would, wouldn't you?

Malkovich's appearance is certainly not a case of cinema realism running riot. Cusack and pals control Malkovich's personality for much of his time on screen, literally manipulating him like a puppet. The 'Malkovich' character is to some extent a generic journeyman actor, no one can actually remember a film he's appeared in, 'wasn't he in that one about the jewel thief,' everyone asks erroneously.

So let's give him his due, Being John Malkovich is comedic tour-de-force for Malkovich, his best roles in ages. Best of all he didn't have to look far to find the character.

webTitle: Erykah Badu's move from music to movies

fields.headline: Erykah Badu's move from music to movies
fields.trailText: If you want to get ahead, get a headwrap. The advice has served singer-turned-actress Erykah Badu well. As a diva she's been part of the Lauryn Hill-Macy Gray generation, busy reshaping American soul music over the past few years.
fields.body:
If you want to get ahead, get a headwrap. The advice has served singer-turned-actress Erykah Badu well. As a diva she's been part of the Lauryn Hill-Macy Gray generation, busy reshaping American soul music over the past few years.

Intensely spiritual, she cites The Creator as her muse, lighting incense and candles before every performance. Proudly Afrocentric, she is hardly ever seen without an African headdress, colourful traditional dress and ornate jewellery. She's hardly a rival to midriff-bearing Britney Spears - Erykah would be more likely to advise the teen sensation to wear a cardigan before she catches a chill.

Therefore she's barely recognisable in her second film The Cider House Rules . There's no headdress or solo number for Badu in this quietly moving adaptation of John Irving's sprawling 600-page novel.

Instead the 29-year-old gives a convincing performance as an orchard worker who befriends idealistic protagonist Tobey Maguire while carrying a terrible secret. It's a tribute to her MTV image that, while one expects a statuesque figure, she looks suitably waifish as Rose Rose.

On screen she is a natural performer, at ease sagely reprimanding Maguire, yet elsewhere playfully naive. In truth, her role as an itinerant worker in a period drama doesn't represent a great leap forward, but she acquits herself well. As Hollywood emerges from the gangsta-flick of the Nineties, producing more aspirational films about black middle-class life, Badu is a likely star in the making. Irving, who adapted his own novel, edited many of his trademark picaresque moments, although its strong pro-choice abortion stance remains, much to the consternation of US prolifers.

Despite the resultant controversy, Badu is better off in the hot water caused by this film than in the cool reception accorded to her first screen outing: Blues Brothers 2000 . While shielding their eyes in dismay, most moviegoers probably missed her brief appearance as a voodoo queen in the ill-advised sequel to the cult favourite.

Judging by her predecessors, future crossover success is uncertain. After Diana Ross's searing portrait of Billie Holliday in Lady Sings the Blues , poor roles followed culminating in the ill-advised Wizard of Oz remake, The Wiz . Nineties rock icon Courtney Love has fared well in film ( The People vs Larry Flynt ), although her music career has subsequently suffered.

Badu, a strikingly attractive former drama student, seemed destined for the movies. The 1997 video to 'On & On' was inspired by The Color Purple 's plot. That track came from her acclaimed Grammy award-winning 1997 album Baduizm, a languid hybrid of hip hop and soul.

Born Erica Wright, she changed her 'slave name' as a teenager to Badu. It came from a phrase she perfected in scat singing, although she later made the fortunate discovery that the newly acquired surname actually means 'to manifest truth and light' in Arabic.

Raised in Dallas, Badu remains proud of her Southern roots, which inspired her music. In 'Southern Gul', her recent single, she sang: 'I'm countrified/Everything I eat is fried.' Ever aware of her roots, it will be interesting to see if Badu can ever 'go Hollywood' and still keep her head up high.

Five things you should know about Erykah Badu

1. She worked at Grinder's, a Dallas coffee house, between 1993 and 1995.

2. She collaborated with the late Curtis Mayfield for a track on the Eve's Bayou soundtrack.

3. She named her two-year-old son Seven because it is a 'divine name which cannot be divided'.

4. She gave her first live performance at the age of four with her mum at the Dallas Theatre Centre.

5. She successfully auditioned for a performing arts college, impressing the judges as one half of a rap duo, calling herself MC Apples.

fields.headline: Fulham's class sinks Dons
fields.trailText: Fulham 3 - 0 Wimbledon
fields.body:
It took the might of Manchester United to end Fulham's run to the fifth round of the FA Cup last season, so they believe their name may be on the trophy this year as they have made it to the last 32 again while the holders are going nuts in Brazil.

With promotion to the Premiership also in their sights and a League Cup quarter-final at Leicester to follow on Wednesday, Fulham's title could end up on sorts of silverware come the end of the season. This was certainly another day of hampers and champers for Fulham owner Mohamed Al Fayed.

Wimbledon became their latest Premiership scalp, joining the fallen of Southampton (twice), Aston Villa and Tottenham as recent cup victims. Two goals from Wayne Collins and a Steve Finnan strike secured this victory, and they were joined by a scarf-waving Fayed on their lap of honour.Both teams, but Wimbledon in particular, did their best to kill off a cracking Craven Cottage Cup atmosphere with some mind numbing football early on.

At least Fulham had an attacking edge to them while the visitors just whacked the ball long and high to deep cries of 'hoof' from the Fulham fans desperate to keep themselves amused.

Then, on 20 minutes, Fulham's Barry Hayles turned on the ball like Johan Cruyff on a good day and set up an attack that brought the game to life.

A similar piece of Hayles trickery enabled him to create Fulham's opening goal two minutes later. Hayles' chipped cross was met by Collins, who squeezed his header inside a post.

Hayles laid on a second goal in the 25th minute. Lee Clark's pass carved through the Wimbledon back line and Hayles ran on to pull the ball back from the byline for Steve Finnan to bundle over the line from three yards.

Aside from an own goal from Tranmere last Monday, Fulham had not scored in the First Division for almost nine hours before this game. The thrill of sudden death obviously stirs them, though, because they had scored eight in their last three League and FA Cup ties.
