He brought Carl Cort and Marcus Gayle in from the flanks to form a central strike partnership and replaced Carl Leaburn with the width of Neal Ardley to supply the ammunition.

And it worked in that Wimbledon, after a shotless first half, won a few corners and managed two attempts on goal within five minutes of the restart. Defender Damien Francis then lifted a gilt-edged chance over the bar and the Dons started to flag again.

Hayles, simultaneously, shifted back into top gear and produced three excellent saves from Neil Sullivan around the hour mark.

Fulham's third goal duly came with 12 minutes to go. A neat build-up ended with Horsfield supplying a low cross, which Collins finished from close range.

fields.headline: Late threat to Allison'sgoal joy
fields.trailText: Tranmere 1 - 0 Sunderland
fields.body:
This might not have been the Maracana or the Club World Championship, but fans of traditional January pastimes will be happy to know the FA Cup tie is alive and well, complete with farcical controversy.

Tranmere Rovers disposing of Premiership opponents hardly counts as a shock any more, with West Ham having been humbled in the last round and Coventry and Middlesbrough knocked out of this season's Worthington Cup, but the passion and commitment both sides brought to a classic cup encounter was warmer than anything so far seen from South America.

Tranmere reached the fifth round for only the second time by merit, and on this form will not be a pushover for anyone, but their victory was soured by a mix-up between officials in the final minute when the home side were effectively allowed to send on substitute Stephen Frail for Clint Hill, who had just received the red card for a second booking. The error was soon spotted and Andy Parkinson sheepishly made his way to the bench, but for around 30 seconds after Hill's dismissal, during which time they defended the free-kick he had conceded, Tranmere had 11 men on the field. Sunderland are bound to appeal.

The first half, which only came to life in the 25th minute when Tranmere unexpectedly took the lead. That is not to suggest the goal came against the run of play, at that stage there had hardly been any play to speak of, but Sunderland had been doing marginally more of the attacking. Nicky Summerbee had the beating of Gareth Roberts on the right, but the Sunderland winger is wasteful with his final ball at the best of times and in the absence of his usual target, Niall Quinn, could not always pick out lone striker Kevin Phillips.Suddenly a goal appeared out of nothing. Steve Bould was penalised for climbing all over his man for what appeared to be the umpteenth time, and though Parkinson's free-kick into the box was flighted towards David Kelly, the headed knock down fell perfectly for Wayne Allison at the far post for the Tranmere captain to show a cool finish from a narrow angle.

Suddenly everyone stopped wondering what the temperature might be in Brazil and remembered what they were doing in Birkenhead.

Sunderland came straight back down the field and almost grabbed an immediate equaliser, but though Phillips appeared certain to score from Summerbee's accurate cross, Clint Hill came to his goalkeeper's rescue by somehow deflecting a header from five yards out on to his crossbar and away.

John Achterberg came into his own as Sunderland continued to press before half time, making comfortable saves from Phillips and Alex Rae and an inspired one from Summerbee.

Summerbee is not a finisher anyway and any doubt on this matter was removed when he wasted Sunderland's last chance of the half, cutting purposefully into the penalty area past Roberts but selfishly blazing into the crowd.

Jody Craddock appeared instead of Bould for the second half, not a critical switch since it was the Tranmere defence having to soak up all the pressure. Had Sunderland been able to field Quinn, or even his deputy Danny Dichio, they would surely have profited from Summerbee's regular supply of crosses, but Achterberg, Hill and Dave Challinor were just about equal to everything their visitors were able to throw at them. The nearest Sunderland came to scoring was a long shot from Chris Makin which Achterberg acrobatically tipped over the bar.

Tranmere were never reduced to defending with 11 men behind the ball, however, and their clear ability to strike on the break prevented Sunderland sending everyone into attack.

Gary Jones curled a shot just a foot too high from the edge of the area, and when Allison flicked on one of Challinor's long throws, Kelly's goalbound effort was blocked on the line by Gavin McCann. Tramere held out comfortably in the end, they did not need or benefit by their involuntary infringement of the rules, but with just one point from their last nine in the Premiership and now an FA Cup exit, Sunderland will be exploring every possibility.

webTitle: Forest leave it late, Bart-Williams to the rescue

fields.headline: Forest leave it late, Bart-Williams to the rescue
fields.standfirst: Cup round-up
fields.trailText: Nottingham Forest yesterday set themselves up for a lucrative fourth-round tie at Chelsea with the most dramatic of victories.
fields.body:
Nottingham Forest yesterday set themselves up for a lucrative fourth-round tie at Chelsea with the most dramatic of victories.

A goal down in the third-round replay at Oxford, they hit three in eight minutes to leave onlookers with the feeling that their player-manager, David Platt, must have been born under a lucky star.

Although Oxford played the better football in the first half, it was Forest who cre ated the better chances. They were punished for not taking any of them when Paul Power gave Oxford a 1-0 lead in the second half.

However, Forest got back on level terms nine minutes from the end through Chris Bart-Williams, and were given a further boost the next minute when Oxford's Paul Lundin was sent off. Bart-Williams made it 2-1 from a penalty and Alan Rogers scored their other goal.

Wrexham, having produced one of the best performances of the third round with their win over Middlesbrough, found it a rather different story against their fellow Second Division strugglers Cambridge.

The latter might have a dodgy defence - they have achieved only one clean sheet in the league this season - but they also have two of the most respected strikers outside the top flight in Trevor Benjamin and Martin Butler. Both men have attracted transfer speculation in recent weeks, and they again emphasised the reasons when Benjamin gave Cambridge a 15th-minute lead from Butler's cross.

Wrexham had dominated up to then, and continued to do so. The pressure finally told deep into injury time as Karl Connelly sent a perfect looping header into the net from substitute Paul Barrett's cross.

However, Cambridge's threat up front was seen again in the 52nd minute, when Butler making it 2-1

Another team who failed to make the most of their home advantage were Grimsby. They fell 2-0 to Bolton,.

Bolton's Icelandic international, Eidur Gudjohnsen. has a reputation for scoring difficult goals, and thanks to a static Grimsby defence, he he lived up to it on this occa sion with a fine right-foot shot into the net from the edge of the box. Bo Hansen scored Bolton's second.

There were not many chances to be seen in Charlton's 1-0 win over QPR, especially from the visitors. They failed to register a single shot of target in the whole of the first half.

Charlton, who had not exactly caused the opposing goalkeeper to work overtime themselves, broke the deadlock in the 68th minute through Charlie MacDonald.

Blackburn, who will need all the defensive expertise they can get in tomorrow's fourth-round tie at Liverpool, have received an unexpected bonus - the likely return of their Irish Republic international goalkeeper, Alan Kelly.

Kelly has made remarkable progress since being carried off with ankle ligament damage at Portsmouth on 28 December, an injury that was expected to put him out of action for between four and six weeks.

Blackburn's manager, Tony Parkes, said: 'Alan told us that he is a quick healer, but for me, this is a miracle. Our physios are fairly confident he will be fit for Monday.'

fields.headline: Dynamic duo strike
fields.trailText: Newcastle 4 - 1 Sheff Wed
fields.byline: Ed Jones at St James's Park
fields.body:
After an early scare Newcastle convincingly stayed on course for a third consecutive FA Cup Final with an emphatic victory over the form team of the First Division - featuring another brace of goals for the Alan Shearer-Duncan Ferguson partnership.

Sheffield United held their own in the first half, but Newcastle found an extra gear after the break. With nine goals in the last five matches, Newcastle's £23 million strikeforce are finally appearing to look capable of making it third time lucky at Wembley for the double-losing finalists.

Kieron Dyer was back in place of Robert Lee for Newcastle after recovering from a groin strain, and he almost fashioned an incredible opener after just 20 seconds.

He surged clear down the right directly from the kick-off and crossed deep for Duncan Ferguson, who headed the ball back across goal - Alan Shearer's header flew narrowly over.

However, Shearer got it right three minutes later. Nolberto Solano's corner whistled through a statuesque defence and Shearer found space to prod it home unmarked at the far post for his 19th goal for the season.

Shearer could have doubled his tally from Dyer's pull-back shortly afterwards but the ball sailed high over the bar.

Roared on by 4,000 supporters, the visitors, boasting a seven-match unbeaten record since the arrival of talismanic manager Neil Warnock, recovered well from the early set-back.

Despite missing four regulars, Warnock's men had already threatened to level the scores through Shaun Derry before they fashioned a brilliant equaliser.

Jonathan Hunt's cross was met impeccably in his stride by former Sunderland striker Martin Smith, who curled the ball past Steve Harper for his fifteenth goal of the season.

The goal knocked Newcastle completely out of their stride, and apart from a Fer guson header which flew narrowly wide from another Solano corner, they hardly threatened again before the break.

But Newcastle started the second half as they did the first, with a goal, and once again it came from a Solano corner.

Gary Speed was the first to the ball, which looped in the air before Nikos Dabizas bundled it over the line from close range.

This time, they did not lose the initiative and took complete control. Alessandro Pistone, recalled to the first team since the arrival of manager Bobby Robson, broke clear on the left and pulled the ball back to Ferguson just inside the area.

His precise side-footed shot into the bottom right corner gave Simon Tracey in the Sheffield United goal no chance. It was the Scot's sixth goal of the season.

The biggest celebration of the day, however, came when Shearer flicked a long ball on for Kevin Gallacher who, from ten yards, smashed in his first goal since arriving from Blackburn, a powerful drive to Tracey's left.

fields.headline: Coventry's class decisive
fields.standfirst: Burnley battle but the Sky Blues' stylish Moroccans prove too much for them
fields.trailText: Coventry 3 - 0 Burnley
fields.body:
Coventry negotiated the potentially hazardous challenge of Burnley with commendable thoroughness and rarely a hint of a slip-up.

Under Gordon Strachan's management they have not failed to reach the fifth round of the FA Cup and this time he possesses a team with an extra dimension who are good enough to go a good deal further.

The problem is that Coven try are almost certain to be without the influential Moustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo for the next round in three weeks' time.

The Moroccan pair are committed to the African Nations Cup and only an early exit from that competition will bring them back in time. 'That looks pretty unlikely,' admitted Strachan.

Chippo's two goals deflated Burnley's chances of matching their victory at Derby in the previous round, although the Second Division side, roared on by 5,000 fans, did not stop working and ensured it was never easy.

'We lost our shape after the first 25 minutes and until the second went in I was worried it might be their day,' said Strachan. 'We indulged in too many passes, too many flicks, and too many missed chances.'

He may have been somewhat over-critical of a team who quickly took control of the game - from the moment that Chippo fired a splendid effort into the top corner from the edge of the penalty box after linking up with Gary McAllister, Coventry looked a sound bet to win with something to spare.

Had Cedric Roussel and Robbie Keane accepted easier chances they would have done. Instead, Burnley came forward with plenty of adventure in the second half, with leading scorer Andy Payton turning sweetly to hit a shot just over the crossbar.

Twenty minutes from the end Coventry gave themselves breathing space, with Chippo hitting a precise low angled drive into the far corner beyond Paul Crichton, who was beaten by an awkward bobble of the ball.

That was an end to Burnley's hopes and substitute Noel Whelan rubbed it in with his first touch - a neat turn and emphatic finish.

'We gave a good account and certainly did not embarrass ourselves,' said the Burnley manager Stan Ternent. 'The second goal was the killer. Going two down to a Premiership side is always going to be hard.'

webTitle: 'Public relations' - those are dirty words for United

fields.headline: 'Public relations' - those are dirty words for United
fields.trailText: I nearly choked on my stale mince pie as I listened to a suntanned Martin Edwards in Brazil. He announced to the world on television that 'We're certainly not here for the money.' The arrogance of the club is breathtaking.
fields.body:
I nearly choked on my stale mince pie as I listened to a suntanned Martin Edwards in Brazil. He announced to the world on television that 'We're certainly not here for the money.' From that moment it was obvious that this ill-conceived jaunt by Manchester United would become a PR disaster. The Rio tournament has made the Dome look like a roaring success.

Manchester United are supposed to be the biggest and richest football club in the world and as such you would expect them to have a large communications department with a high-powered boss. The fact that they do not displays not only a complete lack of professionalism, it displays arrogance too. Alex Ferguson is a friend of Tony Blair's football-mad press secretary Alastair Campbell. He would be the first to tell him that you can't expect the press to be nice to you if you if you don't work at it.

It's fine for a spin doctor to be abusive to the media - I should know - but just as Blair would never harangue a journalist in public, neither should a football manager. Unless he doesn't care what the media say. Ferguson clearly does.

Manchester United initially got a very enthusiastic welcome when they arrived in Brazil. This turned sour very quickly as the club revealed their notoriously awful PR skills to the astonished Brazilians. We are, of course, used to them. Who will ever forget the American businessman from Sky who wanted to buy the club but couldn't name the Manchester United full-back?

In Rio someone with as much media savvy as Glenn Hoddle decided to hold a closed training session, thus alienating the world's media in one go. Someone obviously forgot that in accepting the invitation to play in Brazil, United were supposed to be helping to win friends at Fifa and votes for England's 2006 World Cup bid.

The arrogance of the club is breathtaking. Not content with annoying football fans in England by refusing to play in the FA Cup, they now seem intent on doing the same in Brazil. There is little more one can say about David Beckham that has not already been said. You would expect his manager to support him but any sympathy for him evaporated immediately when Ferguson - who looked like he was suffering from extreme sunburn - blamed his sending-off on the Mexican players for overreacting. A certain incident at Derby this season immediately came to mind.

The tiny band of loyal, and rich Manchester United fans who have travelled to South America will be laughing all along Copacabana as their close rivals in the race for the Championship drop vital points while they frolic in the sun.

And it's not just the fans who are frolicking in the sun. The pictures of Beckham, Teddy Sheringham and Dwight Yorke playing volleyball on the beach and splashing about in the swimming-pool was the most wasted and inappropriate photo opportunity since William Hague posed in a baseball cap at the Notting Hill Carnival. How much better would have been a photo of the players giving away footballs to Brazilian kids in the Rio slums. If ever a picture told a story this was it.

For Manchester United the trip to Brazil is in reality just a winter break, giving them the chance to recharge their batteries and return to England fighting fit. It's no wonder that all the other teams in the league are totally fed up with the preferential treatment Manchester United get. One manager, who understandably won't want to be named,' told me that there was one rule for them and another for everyone else.

Incidentally, my criticisms of Manchester United have nothing to do with the fact that when I returned from my own winter break some moron had painted MU on my garden wall.

The week's public relations problems have not been confined to Old Trafford. Arsène Wenger seems to have joined the Manchester United school of PR skills, judging by his comments this week about Nwankwo Kanu's call-up by Nigeria. Had Wenger stuck by his guns and played Kanu in today's FA Cup tie against Leicester without permission from the Nigerian FA, it would have led to Arsenal being expelled from the competition by Fifa.

Wenger is miffed that Nigeria want Kanu at their training camp ahead of the African Nations Cup. Under Fifa rules, which state that players report 14 days before the tournament starts, Nigeria are within their rights to insist on his release. It's not their fault that, because of TV, the tie has been moved to today. Had it been yesterday Kanu could have played.

Wenger should blame TV, not Nigeria. One might ask why it is that only Arsenal are facing this problem. Coventry have negotiated the release of their two Moroccans to play for them next weekend and Cameroon are allowing West Ham's Marc Vivien Foe to stay for Tuesday's game against Villa. It may be because Wenger has made it clear he does not give a stuff about international call-ups. He knew the rules when he signed Kanu - and he shouldn't have said anything in public to rile the Nigerians.

Unless he doesn't care what the media say. Ferguson clearly does. Manchester United initially got a very enthusiastic welcome when they arrived in Brazil. This turned sour very quickly as the club revealed their notoriously awful PR skills to the astonished Brazilians. We are, of course, used to them. Who will ever forget the American businessman from Sky who wanted to buy the club but couldn't name the Manchester United full-back? In Rio someone with as much media savvy as Glenn Hoddle decided to hold a closed training session, thus alienating the world's media in one go. Someone obviously forgot that in accepting the invitation to play in Brazil, United were supposed to be helping to win friends at Fifa and votes for England's 2006 World Cup bid. The arrogance of the club is breathtaking. Not content with annoying football fans in England by refusing to play in the FA Cup, they now seem intent on doing the same in Brazil. There is little more one can say about David Beckham that has not already been said. You would expect his manager to support him but any sympathy for him evaporated immediately when Ferguson - who looked like he was suffering from extreme sunburn - blamed his sending-off on the Mexican players for overreacting. A certain incident at Derby this season immediately came to mind. The tiny band of loyal, and rich Manchester United fans who have travelled to South America will be laughing all along Copacabana as their close rivals in the race for the Championship drop vital points while they frolic in the sun. And it's not just the fans who are frolicking in the sun. The pictures of Beckham, Teddy Sheringham and Dwight Yorke playing volleyball on the beach and splashing about in the swimming-pool was the most wasted and inappropriate photo opportunity since William Hague posed in a baseball cap at the Notting Hill Carnival. How much better would have been a photo of the players giving away footballs to Brazilian kids in the Rio slums. If ever a picture told a story this was it. For Manchester United the trip to Brazil is in reality just a winter break, giving them the chance to recharge their batteries and return to England fighting fit. It's no wonder that all the other teams in the league are totally fed up with the preferential treatment Manchester United get. One manager, who understandably won't want to be named,' told me that there was one rule for them and another for everyone else. Incidentally, my criticisms of Manchester United have nothing to do with the fact that when I returned from my own winter break some moron had painted MU on my garden wall. The week's public relations problems have not been confined to Old Trafford. Arsène Wenger seems to have joined the Manchester United school of PR skills, judging by his comments this week about Nwankwo Kanu's call-up by Nigeria. Had Wenger stuck by his guns and played Kanu in today's FA Cup tie against Leicester without permission from the Nigerian FA, it would have led to Arsenal being expelled from the competition by Fifa. Wenger is miffed that Nigeria want Kanu at their training camp ahead of the African Nations Cup. Under Fifa rules, which state that players report 14 days before the tournament starts, Nigeria are within their rights to insist on his release. It's not their fault that, because of TV, the tie has been moved to today. Had it been yesterday Kanu could have played. Wenger should blame TV, not Nigeria. One might ask why it is that only Arsenal are facing this problem. Coventry have negotiated the release of their two Moroccans to play for them next weekend and Cameroon are allowing West Ham's Marc Vivien Foe to stay for Tuesday's game against Villa. It may be because Wenger has made it clear he does not give a stuff about international call-ups. He knew the rules when he signed Kanu - and he shouldn't have said anything in public to rile the Nigerians.

webTitle: Stopper on the road to the top

fields.headline: Stopper on the road to the top
fields.trailText: Amy Lawrence meets Nicky Weaver, a coltish goalkeeper brimming with boldness and burning with quality, who steps out for Manchester City in the clubs fourth round tie against Leeds United this afternoon.
fields.body:
If the thirtysomething Nigel Martyn doesn't feel relatively geriatric when he glances round the Leeds United dressing-room from time to time, he might sprout a grey hair or two when he looks at his opposite number this afternoon at Maine Road. There he will see a coltish goalkeeper brimming with boldness and burning with quality. He's a young man hurtling up a learning curve with such staggering accomplishment the old adage about keepers maturing late must be brought into question.

Nicky Weaver contemplates the notion he is expected to peak in around a decade's time. 'That means I've got another 10 years of improvement,' he concludes. In an era when the delicate business of nurturing sporting prospects is threatened by salivating hype merchants, Manchester City's huge starlet possesses an easy nonchalance that may just see him through. He's serious about that improvement. At the moment he is working on his concentration to stop his mind from wandering during games.

Weaver's life has changed radically since his sudden elevation to the City first team during last season's promotion campaign. Having been stuck in the reserves after a £200,000 move from Mansfield, he emerged as an overnight sensation, eventually notching up a club record 22 clean sheets and inspiring worship from the fans. At the season's climax, that dramatic play-off final against Gillingham, he etched his name into City folklore as penalty shoot-out hero. He seemed to symbolise a bright future running like an unchained maniac away from years of sorry depression.

'Over the summer after that I used to watch it every morning when I got up; it took a month or six weeks for what I'd actually done to sink in,' he recalls. Was public perception altered with that moment? The reply only emphasises Weaver's level-headedness. 'Just saving two penalties doesn't make you a great goalkeeper. Obviously they were important saves but I think performances this year have been more pleasing for me.

'Before the season started I was a bit nervous about stepping up into the First Division because I'd never played at that level before. I thought it would be a lot harder than it is. I soon realised it was just like last year, carried on as normal, and things have been going really well.'

He has faith that the Division One leaders can sustain their run through to a successive promotion. Playing in the Premiership this time next year would be, he says airily, the realisation of his wildest dream.

This afternoon he samples a taste of it against Leeds, currently the brightest exponents of the joys of youthful football in England. 'It's encouraging,' says the affable Weaver. 'Someone said a few years ago that you never win anything with kids. Man United proved them wrong and Leeds can do the same this year. They are not in a bad position, are they? I know a few of their players from under-21s and they are cracking players. Michael Bridges, Lee Bowyer, Harry Kewell, they are all matchwinners in their own right. I can't wait to face them. If we beat them it will send out a statement to everyone in the country that we do mean business.' He will also be measuring himself against the keeper he rates as the best on current form.

Kevin Keegan has taken the hint and is a watchful admirer. Weaver brushes off the hype. 'I get nervous about games but not about what people expect. I expect certain levels from myself and try to meet them every time I play. It would be nice to have a good game, on the television, and be compared favourably with Nigel Martyn but everyone knows one game doesn't make you into a good keeper.'

fields.headline: Tales from the tabs
fields.trailText: Liverpool deny Sergi, Thatch swoop
fields.body:
Liverpool deny Sergi, Thatch swoop

Gerard Houllier has denied offering £6.5m for Barcelona left-back Sergi. A summer deal for Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher, though, is still on the cards.

Gunners make most of Alex

Arsenal and Chelsea are locked in a desperate race to land Russian midfielder Aleksandr Mostovoi. Mostovoi, 31, is available on a Bosman this summer.

And the rest...

David O'Leary's search for a senior striker could end with a loan move for Milan reserve George Weah - Weah's representatives have offered him to Leeds , Arsenal and Monaco ; Arsenal have been linked again with a move for Wimbledon's out-of-contract keeper Neil Sullivan; Aston Villa are looking again at Celta Vigo midfielder Haim Revivo; Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond has dismissed reports of a move for Sheffield Wednesday's Andy Booth: 'At this moment it is simply speculation'; Chelsea have had a work permit application for £4m-rated Georgian star Rati Aleksidse of Dinamo Tblisi rejected; Sheffield Wednesday's Danny Sonner is a target for Derby and Manchester City; Ipswich have rejected a £4m move from Middlesbrough for striker David Johnson, but Viv Anderson remains confident of a deal; Newcastle's Nolberto Solano is being tracked by Real Madrid - but Bobby Robson wants to link him with £4m Argentinian ace Christian Bassedas; Danny Wilson has denied offering Sheffield Wednesday's Pavel Srnicek in exchange for Forest's Mark Crossley; Preston's Colin Murdock could be set for a Premiership move; Everton's Michael Ball wants to follow Terry Phelan by leaving Goodison on loan; Argentinian striker Emanuel Ruiz has joined Sunderland on trial; Watford are close to signing Dean Holdsworth from Bolton ; Barnsley defender David Tuttle wants a move back to London; Birmingham are chasing Newcastle youngster Paul Robinson; and Charlton want to take Roberto Baggio on loan.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: David Hills with more of the bits that you won't read anywhere else.
fields.body:
China in quick hands

Wanda Group, the owner of China's top club Dalian Wanda, has announced it is pulling out of the game because of 'endemic corruption'. Chinese paper Youth Daily reported last week how the real estate company had decided that gambling-related corruption has destroyed the sport in China, and that Dalian, from whom Terry Venables signed one of the first two Chinese players to come to England, would now be 'dispensed with'. 'These teams are not playing football, they are putting on an act,' Wanda chairman Wang Jianlin told the paper. 'If such trends continue, there is no potential for Chinese football, and it's not worth expending effort on something that has no future.'

Wanda - league champions four times in the last six years - made headlines here last year when they re-signed Sun Jihai from Crystal Palace, and then failed to pay Palace the £700,000 fee until Fifa forced their hand. No sooner had the money been handed over than Fifa banned Jihai for a year for headbutting a linesman. With Wanda losing their grip on the championship, the football association offering rewards in return for proof of match fixing, the national team still without a manager, and its captain Fan Zihyi, hero to a billion obsessive fans, still preferring life at troubled Selhurst Park to a return to China - Wang believes the game is in terminal decline. 'China will again miss out on World Cup qualification, while it's management is eating up the game, not managing it. I despair.'

Aussies give XXXX for Matildas

South Melbourne's appearance in the Club World Championship may not be causing much of a stir - one defeat played out in borrowed shirts - but the concurrent women's Australia Cup has managed to catch the public mood. The tournament, which opened last Friday, has drawn unprecedented media interest following the home nation squad's controversial topless calendar stunt - which, says Soccer Association chief exec Warren Fisher, has made up for the absence of America's World Cup winning stars ( Said& Done , 2 Jan). 'Sure, the Australian public wants to see the best of the best,' says Fisher, 'and the withdrawal of all the American stars has caused some promotional difficulties, but the Matildas have attracted plenty of interest for themselves.' The nude calendars - which provoked furious protests despite full frontal striker Amy Taylor (above) claiming 'I did it to promote soccer and the women's side of things', certainly paid off. The first two print runs sold out quickly and demand is now expected to exceed 90,000 copies. Interest in the tournament - which the Matildas won last year with wins over Italy and Canada - has soared accordingly. 'We don't need to be obsessed about the U.S. stars not being here,' said Fisher. 'The public is inquisitive as to whether our calendar girls can actually play.' And can they? A 2-0 defeat to Sweden on Friday focused minds. 'Now they're really under pressure to perform,' says Fisher.

Desailly - Headhunters are so charming

Marcel Desailly may feel the Premiership is over-stocked with rough, uncultured cloggers, but he does have a soft spot for English fans.

Referring to his time in Italy with AC Milan, Desailly explained last week that life on the Kings Road, Chelsea is an altogether more civilised experience. 'The Italian fan,' says Marcel, 'upon recognising you in a bar, places your coffee to one side to put his notebook there, pushes your little cake to make room for his pen and asks you for an autograph while calling his pals over for a chat. When he leaves without saying thank you, you find that your cappuccino has gone cold'.

Desailly is happy that life in England with Chelsea's supporters means his drinks are taken at just the right temperature. '(English fans) applaud and sing for you on the pitch, but leave you in peace in the streets. There is a greater respect for the human being in England'.

I think it's a penalty, Barry

A bad day for Becks should have meant a great one for the Beeb - but somehow, say Said & Done correspondents - Thursday's Necaxa coverage just didn't quite work. 'It's all very well being able to pronounce Solskjaer as well as Ole's teacher at morning assembly', says one, 'but if you can't spot a penalty without the help of Trevor Brooking, you shouldn't be commentating on matches for 10 million viewers'. So while Barry Davies was giving his views on Mrs Becks and Sir Alec (with a c) while the action passed him by, where was BBC number one John Motson? Taking, it seems, the FA Cup moral line. 'They couldn't leave Match of the Day unprotected,' Motty tells us, 'especially with the FA Cup cover. It was a mutual agreement - Barry quite fancied it and I didn't mind staying behind.' So that leaves Barry and Trev to take us through the final on Friday. 'It was a very amicable decision', says Motty. Tell that to the viewers.

Said & Done: david.hills@observer.co.uk

webTitle: I just felt numb andsuicide beckoned...

fields.headline: I just felt numb andsuicide beckoned...
fields.standfirst: English football's greatest enigma opens up on Ulrika, John Gregory, his illness and the long road back
fields.trailText: English football's greatest enigma opens up to Ian Ridley on Ulrika, John Gregory, his illness and the long road back
fields.body:
Painful, poignant memories Stan Collymore admits, are coming back and FA Cup weekend will not have helped. All around him are the echoes of this time 12 months ago when he sank into a clinical depression that caused him - and he drops it into the conversation with no change of matter-of-fact tone, so logical did it seem at the time - to contemplate suicide.

Once you know that, it seems less significant that this has been a lost year in the footballing career of one of the country's most naturally talented players, a year that has turned the English game's greatest enigma into an isolated, vilified £7 million outcast. And once you know that, the tendency to point a judgmental finger at this wounded but, gradually, now healing human being bravely opening up opposite you, there is a guilt at having bought into all the scornful, sensational stories ridiculing his plight.

The one story that sticks brings remorse. Yes, he assaulted his then girlfriend Ulrika Jonsson in Paris on a visit to the 1998 World Cup finals and he is ashamed and sorry. The one-off moment of madness was, he says, 'a turning point' in his life, probably hurrying him to the depressive basement he reached and which led him to the Priory treatment centre in London to seek rehabilitation.

Otherwise, he vehemently denies, and is taking legal action over, the suggestion that he showed pictures of Ulrika naked to team-mates while on loan at Fulham and that he flew into a violent rage when he found another female friend, Estelle Williams, with a man. He denies, too, a recent tale that he is about to quit and go and live in the United States.

Collymore also resents the picture painted of him at Aston Villa, the club he has loved since boyhood, as a surly, uncooperative figure who has refused all loan moves and transfers, as well as efforts to motivate him; a mercenary content simply to pick up £20,000 a week for the rest of the 18 months on his contract.

He insists he is desperate for another chance to play after an illness from which he is recovering thanks to ongoing therapy and anti-depressants but has not been given a reason by the manager John Gregory why he is not considered for selection. 'How come,' he wonders, 'when I was at the Priory three days a week and at Villa for two last season, I was seen as an active member of the first-team squad but then, when I'm fit at the start of this season I was frozen out from day one?'

The pleading in his question is a good sign; he cares again. A year ago he had no energy to.

'It was the day of my birthday, 22 Jan uary, the day before we played Fulham in the FA Cup,' he recalls. 'I was sat on the settee at home and I was empty. I rang the Villa physio Jim Walker and said, "Jim I need to see somebody." I had nothing left, physically or emotionally. If I'd had something physically, I would have gone out there. The emotional I could have overcome. As a footballer you can.

'It had been coming on for more than two years, going back to my time at Liverpool. For two years at Nottingham Forest then 18 months at Liverpool I felt fit, on top of things, but then I saw a gradual decline in terms of performance and consistency, not just as a footballer but as a person.

'I was tired all the time, sleeping a lot. I would get back from training at 1pm and sleep right through until the next morning. That wasn't unusual. Then I would have stages of being an insomniac where I couldn't sleep at all. Even going up the stairs was a chore. I had all sorts of physical tests and they came back A1.' Nor did a visit to a Birmingham psychiatrist help.

'Then my agent showed me an article about the Priory and I thought "I have got to do this". I think I was probably open to it because my sister has been a psychiatric nurse for more than 20 years. I told the doctor there about the sleep and general lethargy. He showed me a book which told me that I had the classic symptoms of clinical depression.'

When it emerged publicly that Collymore had been to the centre, the reaction of many - including the manager at Villa, he says - of 'how can you be depressed on X-amount per week,' cut deep into him. He wished indeed he could have bought himself out of it.

There was plenty of advice. The Villa chairman Doug Ellis reckoned that hard work would see him through. Others told him to cheer up and enjoy his wealth and way of life, to pull himself together. It just made things worse. As if he didn't want to do all those things. Because he was ill, he simply could not.

Was this the suicidal time? 'Yes. I was reading a really good piece about depression by Derek Draper, who used to be a spin doctor for the Labour Party, and he said that suicide for him was a practical solution, not a cry for help. I could understand that. He became so detached, he couldn't feel anything. Neither could I.

'It's really hard to describe to somebody who is functioning normally and going through ups and downs what it is to be in an emotional void. Some people in the Priory would talk about self-harming and for a long time being an outsider, I would wonder why people cut themselves. Then I spoke to a girl in there and she said, "it's because I can actually feel something then".

'When I was at Liverpool, I had my hair blond. My dad had left when I was five years old and now he did a piece in the papers saying black people shouldn't have blond hair. I remember feeling absolutely nothing. Looking back, I knew something was wrong with me.

'A few days after the Fulham game, I sat at home and I considered suicide because I thought, "Well, what's the alternative?" It's like being in a bubble of nothing. It's as if somebody takes your brain out, takes your physical capabilities away. I would pinch myself but I just felt numb. You think back to days when you wake up as a kid and think, "Great. New day, sun shining, go and play football with my mates, go and swim", and I could remember what that felt like. Not having it, I felt I was being teased.'

At the Priory, Collymore began Cognitive Behavioural Therapy, an examination of behaviour patterns that triggered his depressions, learning to recognise them and avoiding repeating them. It involved one-on-one and group therapy for relationship issues and naturally the Ulrika episode figured large. 'It was a chance to get to the bottom of it,' he says. 'It must have been part and parcel of the whole process, though at the time it just seemed a unique set of circumstances.

'It was probably a defining moment in my life and hers. We still talk now and again. We get on well, we really do. I think we both learned a lot from that and other things that have happened subsequently. We are very alike in a lot of ways but I think as a couple we are better as friends than in a relationship.

'If you take Paris out of the equation and we had met now, I wouldn't have gone into a relationship. It would have been more of a friendship because it was obvious from the outset that we had great likenesses but also rubbed each other up the wrong way. Because of our insecurities when they come together, they come together in a big way. To me she will always be very special and I know for a fact that I will be for her.'

The lesson has been for him how to be assertive without being aggressive but the worry, he says, is that everything he does now is judged by the incident. 'It's what people still label you by. In a lot of situations subsequently, a justifiable argument I have with someone goes by the board because of that.'

As at Villa. His routine of Monday and Friday at the club, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at the Priory frustrated John Gregory and his team-mates. Collymore felt helpless. 'All the vibes were that it was a weakness but if people only knew how many times I would come and do a session even though I was on empty, maybe people would have a bit of respect rather than being condescending.' Indeed, the cheap chants of 'You're mad and you know you are,' at games now seem even more distasteful.

'When I came back, one or two of the players said, "What the fuck's going on? You just turn up on a Saturday." I said, "Hold on a sec, I've had an illness, I've been in a clinic." The medical staff should have let everybody know. Dion Dublin has recently done his neck badly and they had a meeting in the dressing room the next day to let people know that he was in hospital. I bet that didn't happen with me.' It is why Collymore finds Doug Ellis's suggestion of an apology for his absence last season hard to take; why should he apologise for illness?

'To his credit, Mark Bosnich said, "Hold on the lad's been ill",' Collymore continues, 'and once I explained what the illness was, from then I think the players have been fine.' Does not the whole episode confirm, though, a reputation as being an uncommunicative loner in a dressing room, intense and not a team player?

'I guess I am intense and that was one of the things that got me into a depression for so long,' he concedes. 'I think about things a lot. Can he see a reconciliation with John Gregory? He blows out his cheeks. 'Reconciliation means two sides coming together. Villa is my club and I wanted to be fit to play my best for them.'

'I just want somebody to say, "I want you to do well for me as a footballer. You have had your stuff but forget it. Let's start from today. Let's incorporate you in the team, get the best out of you." I don't want punishment or special treatment but to be equal and for people to take on board that I am me.

'I've no doubt with the frame I was blessed with, having had no major injuries except a hamstring tear, with a fair wind I can play top-class football for years. Once you know that, it seems less significant that this has been a lost year in the footballing career of one of the country's most naturally talented players, a year that has turned the English game's greatest enigma into an isolated, vilified £7 million outcast. My dad had left when I was five years old and now he did a piece in the papers saying black people shouldn't have blond hair. I remember feeling absolutely nothing. Looking back, I knew something was wrong with me. 'A few days after the Fulham game, I sat at home and I considered suicide because I thought, "Well, what's the alternative?" It's like being in a bubble of nothing. It's as if somebody takes your brain out, takes your physical capabilities away. I would pinch myself but I just felt numb. You think back to days when you wake up as a kid and think, "Great. New day, sun shining, go and play football with my mates, go and swim", and I could remember what that felt like. 'It must have been part and parcel of the whole process, though at the time it just seemed a unique set of circumstances. 'It was probably a defining moment in my life and hers. We still talk now and again. We get on well, we really do. I think we both learned a lot from that and other things that have happened subsequently. fields.headline: Explain... heat exhaustion
fields.trailText: Manchester United will have been disappointed by their team's performance in their first game of the Club World Championship in Rio on Thursday. But, given that they had arrived in the country just a few days earlier, it should have come as no surprise.
fields.body:
Manchester United will have been disappointed by their team's performance in their first game of the Club World Championship in Rio on Thursday. But, given that they had arrived in the country just a few days earlier, it should have come as no surprise.

Received wisdom has it that acclimatisation to such temperatures (it was 93°F on Thursday) takes some three weeks of training, although the process is 95 per cent complete after 14 days and 75 per cent complete after five. Heat, of course, is the enemy of many an athlete, and for many reasons.

Firstly, an athlete has to practically re-educate his muscles before he is ready to perform at high temperatures. During exercise in Rio-esque heat, the level of cutaneous blood flow increases. This improves heat loss, but reduces the blood supply that provides oxygen to work the muscles. So the cardiovascular system must work much harder to meet the competing demands of thermoregulation (stopping yourself from overheating) and muscle metabolism (stopping yourself from stopping). This takes some getting used to.

Then there's the problem of getting rid of the body's heat. About 80 per cent of all the energy an athlete produces ends up as heat, a comparatively tiny proportion is converted to muscle use. Most heat is traditionally lost through sweat evaporation, but in a humid environment (like Brazil's) where the air is already moist, much less sweat evaporates. The athlete must also consume much more liquid to compensate for the increased amount of sweat that is produced. This should involve sensible drinking during exercise - but not of water, which decreases plasma osmolality. A high sodium intake is recommended after exercise, via a dedicated sports drink, or better still, a bowl of ultra-high sodium chicken soup and noodles.

Good training can all but eliminate the risk to the athlete. The only question is whether, after four days, United's players will be ready. Thursday's performance - and Beckham's dizzy challenge - suggests that they weren't.

fields.headline: Cottee's Highbury burden
fields.trailText: Some famous football names are forever intertwined with FA Cup glory, and Tony Cottee has long suspected his might not be one of them. Paul Wilson talks to the journeyman who does not have time on his side.
fields.body:
Some famous football names are forever intertwined with FA Cup glory, and Tony Cottee has long suspected his might not be one of them.

'I wouldn't say I was jinxed, I don't believe in fate to that extent, but I got the message loud and clear when I was at Everton,' he explained. 'When I went in 1988 they had won the league and the FA Cup within the previous three seasons. While I was there they won nothing, then when I left in 1994 they won the FA Cup the following season.'

To make matters even worse Arsenal, the team Cottee turned down in favour of a move to Merseyside, managed the not inconsiderable haul of two titles, an FA Cup and a European Cup Winners' Cup during the same six-year period.

Time is running out for the well-travelled Cottee, 34, who has yet to win a medal of any description in English football, and though he could have been forgiven for dreaming of a romantic run to Wembley in what may prove to be his last season in the top flight, the gods presiding over the fourth round draw clearly had other plans.

'You can't get tougher than Arsenal away,' Cottee said resignedly. 'Even in a normal year that's a tall order, but with Manchester United out of the competition we've defi nitely drawn the shortest straw. It doesn't do to give up hope in this game, you won't get anywhere without confidence and self-belief, but let's just say if this is to be the season I finally get to play in an FA Cup final we will certainly have done it the hard way.'

Cottee doesn't mind admitting he fancied Leicester's chances with the FA Cup holders out of the picture, only for the pairing with Arsenal to hit him like a personal slap in the face. 'I just love going to Highbury,' he joked. 'Lovely ground, great atmosphere, and best of all, the supporters have such long memories. They all know that I went to Everton for more money than Arsenal were offering, they know I ended up with nothing while they were enjoying one of their greatest eras, and they never get tired of reminding me.

'I don't mind that, it's part of the fun, but it does get a bit boring. The only way I can shut them up is to remind them that had George Graham got me he might never have been in the market for Ian Wright.'

The question hanging in the air is whether Cottee has ever regretted the choice of club he made as a 23-year-old, and the answer he is sticking with is no.

'Obviously with hindsight I can see things might have worked out very different for me had I gone to Arsenal from West Ham, but there's nothing to say I would have been a success at Highbury, and I might even have broken a leg or something and had no career at all,' he said.

'You can never see into the future, all you can do is try to make sure you are making the right decision for the right reasons and then stick with it. Arsenal could have made it a lot easier for me by offering terms comparable to Everton's, but there was a world between the two offers. I met George Graham twice but he couldn't up the money, so believing I was taking the most important financial decision of my career I decided to accept the highest offer.

'The daft thing is that players these days would laugh if they knew the sums we were talking about. Half of them wouldn't get out of bed for that sort of money any more, let alone go to the other end of the country, but at the time I was more than happy with the Everton deal.'

It was Cottee's misfortune to arrive in time to discover that Colin Harvey's talent was for coaching and not management, and though Howard Kendall made a more favourable impression on his first return, the Everton that lurched unsteadily into the Nineties was already just a shadow of the moneybags outfit that had so confidently outbid Arsenal for his services. Cottee eventually decamped back to West Ham, where he averaged a goal every three games for a couple of seasons before surprisingly - in view of what has happened since - quitting English football for Malaysia.

It is surprising because although he managed a cup-winner's medal in his one season with Selangor, 31 seemed a young age for a still-functioning striker to consider retiring. And although Cottee now insists he never intended to turn his back on the English game, Malaysia is not the sort of place you go to put yourself in the shop window.

'I had very few other options,' he explained. 'Harry Redknapp had just bought in a load of foreigners and dropped me down the pecking order, so I could see I had no future at West Ham. I told Harry I'd take a move and waited for the offers to come in, but none did. It was a bit embarrassing after a while, all I had was this one offer from Malaysia, so in the end I decided to take it.'

Cottee imagined he would return down the divisions but the last three years have worked out so well for him and Leicester that it will be astonishing if he is again bereft of offers when his present contract expires at the end of this season.

Finishing top scorer and being voted player of the year last season was beyond his wildest dreams, as was getting an unexpected chance to rake in some of the modern footballer's dizzying wages. Well, perhaps not his wildest dreams. Those would involve dismantling Arsenal today, or at the very least going all the way to Wembley in the Worthington Cup.

'I'm running out of years, and at my age you are more appreciative of what might be your last chance in this competition, or your last game at this venue,' he said. 'I've never made any secret of wanting to give management a try, but since I've proved I can still score goals, I'm now thinking in terms of combining the two and finding a player-manager's job somewhere. They say that's the hardest job of all, so it sounds about right for me.'

I met George Graham twice but he couldn't up the money, so believing I was taking the most important financial decision of my career I decided to accept the highest offer. 'The daft thing is that players these days would laugh if they knew the sums we were talking about. Half of them wouldn't get out of bed for that sort of money any more, let alone go to the other end of the country, but at the time I was more than happy with the Everton deal.' It was Cottee's misfortune to arrive in time to discover that Colin Harvey's talent was for coaching and not management, and though Howard Kendall made a more favourable impression on his first return, the Everton that lurched unsteadily into the Nineties was already just a shadow of the moneybags outfit that had so confidently outbid Arsenal for his services. Cottee eventually decamped back to West Ham, where he averaged a goal every three games for a couple of seasons before surprisingly - in view of what has happened since - quitting English football for Malaysia. It is surprising because although he managed a cup-winner's medal in his one season with Selangor, 31 seemed a young age for a still-functioning striker to consider retiring. And although Cottee now insists he never intended to turn his back on the English game, Malaysia is not the sort of place you go to put yourself in the shop window. 'I had very few other options,' he explained. 'Harry Redknapp had just bought in a load of foreigners and dropped me down the pecking order, so I could see I had no future at West Ham. I told Harry I'd take a move and waited for the offers to come in, but none did. It was a bit embarrassing after a while, all I had was this one offer from Malaysia, so in the end I decided to take it.' Cottee imagined he would return down the divisions but the last three years have worked out so well for him and Leicester that it will be astonishing if he is again bereft of offers when his present contract expires at the end of this season. Finishing top scorer and being voted player of the year last season was beyond his wildest dreams, as was getting an unexpected chance to rake in some of the modern footballer's dizzying wages. Well, perhaps not his wildest dreams. Those would involve dismantling Arsenal today, or at the very least going all the way to Wembley in the Worthington Cup. 'I'm running out of years, and at my age you are more appreciative of what might be your last chance in this competition, or your last game at this venue,' he said. 'I've never made any secret of wanting to give management a try, but since I've proved I can still score goals, I'm now thinking in terms of combining the two and finding a player-manager's job somewhere. They say that's the hardest job of all, so it sounds about right for me.'

webTitle: Arsenal lose their fight over Kanu

fields.headline: Arsenal lose their fight over Kanu
fields.trailText: Nwankwo Kanu's final plea for Nigeria to let him play for Arsenal against Leicester today has been rejected and the club have reluctantly released him for African Cup of Nations duty.
fields.body:
Nwankwo Kanu's final plea for Nigeria to let him play for Arsenal against Leicester today has been rejected and the club have reluctantly released him for African Cup of Nations duty.

Arsène Wenger, the Arsenal manager, had hoped the Nigerians would relent on their insistence to have Kanu, their captain and African Footballer of the Year, join a training camp in Spain 14 days ahead of the tournament, which they are co-hosting with Ghana from 22 January to 13 February.

But after a week-long club versus country row, Arsenal announced yesterday: 'Sadly the Nigerian Football Association have refused to reconsider and, consequently, Kanu will not feature in the Leicester cup tie.'

The decision left Wenger seething over the Nigerians' intransigence and claiming all parties would be better off if Kanu played a competitive match at Highbury instead of merely joining his international team-mates for an extra night at their hotel in Marbella. The deadline for naming squads for the Cup of Nations is not until next Thursday, but Nigeria are within their rights to call Kanu two weeks before the opening game.

Kanu will miss up to six club matches if Nigeria reach the final.

Chelsea will also have to do without midfielder Celestine Babayaro, who left after yesterday's game at Brad ford. Their request to keep him for Wednesday's match against Tottenham has also been rejected.

Arsenal and Chelsea are upset that while Nigeria are insisting on the presence of their full squad by this morning, South Africa and Cameroon, who also contest the Cup of Nations, are allowing Lucas Radebe of Leeds and West Ham's Marc-Vivien Foe to delay their arrival for international duty until after club cup ties.

fields.headline: WorthyCup is losing its shine
fields.trailText: Ian Whittell on why the Worthington Cup is falling out of favour and beginning to resemble the Auto-Windscreens Shield.
fields.body:
When West Ham United and Bolton Wanderers met in the first ever Wembley Cup Final, a crowd of more than 200,000 was kept in line by a policeman on a white horse. It is quite feasible that those two clubs will meet again in this year's League Cup final, the penultimate major final at the old stadium, and that only 60,000 will turn up.

The League Cup's obituaries have been written before but, set in the historical context of the White Horse FA Cup Final of 1923, this year's final might well provide the most conclusive evidence yet that the competition is dying on its feet.

Bolton meet Tranmere Rovers in the first leg of their semi-final at the Reebok Stadium on Wednesday, which means a Nationwide League team will definitely be at Wembley on February 27. Nothing wrong with that, of course, but their presence will test the theory that at least the competition comes alive on final day.

When these two North West clubs enjoyed successful runs in the competition in 1994 and 1995 respectively they were attracting crowds approaching 20,000 before the semi-final stage, yet in this year's quarter-final the attendances for home games against Premiership opposition barely crept into five figures.

Bolton officials estimate that their 26,000-seat ground will be half-full - or half-empty - on Wednesday night. Still more alarmingly, Bolton believe they would sell fewer than 25,000 tickets for the final. And this at a club which averaged home crowds of that size in the Premiership two seasons ago.

Bolton manager Sam Allardyce admits that the competition has lost much of its lustre, but believes the enthusiasm it engenders at the later stages makes it worthwhile. 'When you get towards the quarter-final, the commitment shown and publicity generated tells you it's still worthwhile,' he said.

Wednesday's semi-final first leg at the Reebok Stadium was viewed as such a turn-off that ITV opted not to televise it live, a decision since reversed. The U-turn was applauded by both clubs, who will each take an additional £200,000 revenue as a consequence of the local coverage, but they are perhaps mindful that television has also been a major contributor in the competition's downfall.

The vexed question of European qualification casts the greatest doubt over the future of the competition, which was almost a non-event when it was first contested in 1960-61 but gained kudos upon the introduction of a Uefa Cup place for the winners in 1971.

Yet, increasingly, the barometer of a Premiership club's ambition is not how much they spend on players but with how much disdain they treat the Worthington Cup. While fielding reserve teams is the prerogative of teams such as Manchester United, it has also diminished the competition's value in the eyes of supporters.

John Nagle, the Football League's media relations executive, this week put a brave face on the League Cup's dwindling appeal: 'This year's winners are definitely guaranteed a place in Europe. As I understand, the situation will be reviewed annually in negotiations with the FA. There is no pressure from the Premier League for the situation to change. The vast majority of clubs are in favour of the cup retaining its European place.'

Interestingly, Aston Villa's John Gregory - as of yesterday morning still involved in both domestic cups - fears the devaluation process could be transmitted to the FA Cup and not just because of Manchester United's self-imposed exile.

'It used to be every boy's dream to play at Wembley in the FA Cup Final,' says Gregory. 'As a kid, me and my mates would act out finals in the backyard.

'Now, it hasn't got the same appeal. It's rather like the Auto-Windscreens Shield in that nobody pays any attention to it until the final.'

webTitle: Kohl crony set to launch party coup

fields.headline: Kohl crony set to launch party coup
fields.trailText: Germany's opposition Christian Democrats struggled to maintain a show of unity yesterday - but there was no disguising the poisonous atmosphere engulfing the party as renewed bitterness followed reports that former Chancellor Helmut Kohl is backing a challenge to the leadership of his successor, Wolfgang Schäuble.
fields.body:
Germany's opposition Christian Democrats struggled to maintain a show of unity yesterday - but there was no disguising the poisonous atmosphere engulfing the party as renewed bitterness followed reports that former Chancellor Helmut Kohl is backing a challenge to the leadership of his successor, Wolfgang Schäuble.

The liberal Süddeutsche Zeitung newspaper claims that Kohl, angered by Schäuble's efforts to distance himself from the scandal surrounding secret payments to the party, is encouraging a former Cabinet Minister, Jürgen Rüttgers, to make a bid for the leadership at the CDU's annual conference in April.

Rüttgers - the party's candidate in a crucial state election in North Rhine-Wesphalia in May - is one of the few leading figures who has remained loyal to the former Chancellor since prosecutors began a criminal investigation into Kohl's financial dealings last week. Kohl has admitted accepting up to DM2 million in anonymous cash donations and channelling the money through secret accounts to local party organisations. The former Chancellor's supporters are outraged at Schäuble's increasingly strident demands that Kohl should identify the donors to dispel suspicion that donations influenced government policy during his 16 years in power.

Kohl is understood to have told friends he believes Rüttgers would be a better party leader than Schäuble. The Süddeutsche Zeitung quotes him saying: 'My troops are ready.'

A leadership challenge could be backed by party organisations in four states where local leadership has criticised Schäuble's handling of the crisis. With one third of the delegates at the party conference coming from Rüttgers' home state of North-Rhine Westphalia, the challenger would have a good chance of winning a majority.

Kohl and Rüttgers yesterday dismissed talk of a challenge as 'a pure invention', but as the CDU leadership ended a two-day strategy meeting near Hamburg the mood within the party was grim.

Before the meeting began, Schäuble delivered his sharpest criticism of the former Chancellor to date: 'The Kohl era ended when he lost the election in 1998 and quit as party chairman. Obviously we cannot take responsibility for things that happened before that we did not know about. There is no alternative to explaining as fully as possible breaches of the party funding law that Helmut Kohl has himself admitted and taking the appropriate consequences. No matter how bitter that path is, it is and remains the only option,' Schäuble said.

In a humiliating snub to Kohl, CDU activists in the northern state of Schleswig-Holstein have told him to stay away during the campaign leading up to next month's state election. The party's chances of defeating the governing coalition of Social Democrats (SPD) and Greens in the state have diminished as the scandal over party funding has damaged the standing of the CDU. 'Kohl's presence would not be helpful,' said Johann Wadephul, the CDU's campaign manager.

Rüttgers, on the other hand, made an elaborate display of loyalty to his old boss last week when he rounded angrily on party colleagues who called on Kohl to give up his parliamentary seat while the investigation continues. Many CDU activists, regardless of their feelings towards Kohl, regard Rüttgers as having a better chance than Schäuble of defeating Chancellor Gerhard Schröder at the next federal election in 2002.

Opinion polls show Schröder's popularity has soared since the scandal broke and his Social Democrats are now 3 per cent ahead of the Christian Democrats. And as speculation rages about a possible leadership contest, new allegations emerged about the source of Kohl's secret donations. The weekly magazine Focus claimed a Munich construction magnate gave the former Chancellor 'a six-figure sum' in cash during the early 1990s. The magazine quoted a friend as saying that the businessman, who died in 1995, was 'quite astonished' when he discovered Kohl did not lodge the money in the CDU's official accounts.

'I have no intention of making any comment on that,' Kohl said through a spokesman.

Denis Staunton writes for The Irish Times

webTitle: You've got the brains but have you got the touch?

fields.headline: You've got the brains but have you got the touch?
fields.standfirst: Forget IQ. If you want to be a success, it's EQ that counts now.
fields.trailText: Forget IQ. If you want to be a success, it's EQ that counts now.
fields.body:
Do your resolutions for the new millennium include progressing your career, improving your relationships, or being a better parent? If so, the first step is checking your EQ. While IQ has traditionally been the means by which we judge someone's abilities and potential, EQ - the E stands for Emotional - is the new benchmark for a new world. If you've got it, you're more likely to be powerful, successful and have fulfilling relationships than if you haven't. Emotional intelligence - the ability to understand and control your emotions, and recognise and respond to those of others - is emerging as the single most important and effective business and personal skill of the new century.

At American Express, financial advisers who'd been through emotional intelligence training improved sales by up to 20 per cent, significantly more than the company average. A 10-year study by Sheffield University of over 100 small- and medium-sized UK businesses found that people management was three times as important as research and development in improving productivity and profitability and six times as important as business strategy.

Daniel Goleman, a US science journalist-turned-consultant with a background in psychology, first popularised the notion of emotional intelligence in the mid-Nineties. He claims it is twice as important as cognitive (intellectual) or technical skills for high job performance and, at top level, virtually all-important. Analysing the profiles of top executives in 15 global companies, including IBM, PepsiCo and Volvo, he found what distinguished the 'star' performers was not superior technical or intellectual ability but emotional competence: political awareness, self-confidence, drive, influence.

Using IQ as a measure of ability, Goleman believes, is outdated. Correlating IQ test scores with people's later success, he found IQ contributes, at best, 25 per cent and, at worst, 4 per cent. Suddenly you understand why all so many brilliantly successful people were academic no-hopers at school: they have exemplary EQ skills. Richard Branson, Mo Mowlam and Sir Brian Pitman (the guiding vision behind the Lloyds/TSB merger) are good examples.

Goleman defines five elements of emotional intelligence: self-awareness, self-control, motivation, empathy and social skills. Sceptics argue this sounds suspiciously like the old 'soft' skills, in management-course speak, dressed up in new clothing. But Tim Sparrow, of human performance consultants Buckholdt Associates, points out there are two crucial differences. 'Soft skills training was only about interpersonal intelligence - relating to others. Emotional intelligence involves intrapersonal - knowing yourself - as well. You can't be interpersonally intelligent if you don't recognise feelings in yourself. Secondly, soft skills are considered a "bolt-on". That doesn't work for emotional intelligence, which is about cultural change, and needs to be knitted in to the whole business strategy.'

But is it just another management fad? Not to mention a new money-spinner for the overcrowded consultancy industry? Malcolm Higgs and Vic Dulewicz, of the organisational behaviour faculty at Henley Management College, admit they were sceptical on first reading Goleman's work. They felt it was too anecdotally based and lacked rigorous testing. They subjected personal and competency data they had collected on 100 management and business leaders to more objective modelling. Crucially, the data tracked their advancement over a seven-year period.

The results, they admit, staggered them. 'We were amazed at how consistent they were,' says Higgs. 'It was the same message: emotional intelligence was more highly related to success than IQ alone.'

The rise of emotional intelligence is directly linked to the new world of work. Increased globalisation, competitiveness, speed and quality of information exchange means people have to cope with unprecedented levels of change. We've got to be more flexible, more creative, more adept and more responsive if we want to survive.

Competitive advantage today comes from attracting and retaining top talent. 'It's a scarce resource,' says Higgs. 'You have to think differently about how to lead these people. The non-analytic side becomes important.' They aren't going to hang around if they don't feel comfortable.

The costs of neglecting emotional intelligence can thus be high: increased staff turnover, low creativity, poached talent. On a personal level it can be costly, too. Goleman cites the example of a chief operating officer: powerful mind, excellent technical skills, at 45 years old perfect CEO material. On paper. He was fired by the incumbent CEO because he was 'not particularly likeable', 'brutally acerbic' and 'socially awkward'.

But it is not simply a case of being nice. The misconception, says Sparrow, is that people confuse taking account of feelings with being soft. 'With emotional intelligence you have to know when to stand firm. It's how you do it that counts.' Imagine, he says, you've got an urgent deadline and need staff to stay behind. But one is complaining. 'If you say, "I see you're very upset but I need you to stay and work," you're more likely to get them to do so because you've shown you recognise they're upset. Far less likely if you say, "Tough shit, sit down and work."'

Emotional intelligence is not restricted to work. It is applicable to relationships, parenting, marriage, education. Antidote is the campaign for emotional literacy with a particular focus on introducing emotional and skills training in schools. 'Emotional intelligence is a life skill. Developing it from childhood could transform the society we live in,' says Antidote director, James Park.

Interest in emotional intelligence in the UK lags three to four years behind the States and is only just taking off - it was one of the keynote addresses at last year's Institute of Personnel and Development conference in Harrogate. Businesses can use it both in recruitment - drawing up EI profiles of applicants to compare with known 'star' performers - and personal and team development. So hot an issue has emotional intelligence become, that corporations - as well as individuals - are now queuing up for the plethora of new courses promising to provide participants with a high EQ.

But Higgs warns to be suspicious of anything that offers a quick-fix solution. It is not something you can learn in a two-day seminar. There are no short cuts. It needs self-assessment, a conscious behavioural change, determination,practice and feedback. 'It's about changing culture,' says Isles. 'The test is whether your behaviour has changed. And that takes a lot longer.' It won't turn you into a touchy-feely, tree-hugger. It's far more difficult. 'It's the ability to balance hard elements with emotions,' says Higgs. 'High drive, clear focus balanced with empathy and sensitivity to the needs of others. And that's tough. To be emotionally intelligent doesn't mean you're a cuddly person.' The good news is that you're never too old to start learning.

Further help/information
'Emotional Intelligence' and 'Working with Emotional Intelligence', Daniel Goleman, Bloomsbury, £7.99 each. 'Emotionally Intelligent Parenting', by Maurice Elias, Steven Tobias & Brian Friedlander, Hodder & Stoughton, £9.99. 'Making Sense of Emotional Intelligence', by Malcolm Higgs and Vic Dulewicz, NFER-Nelson, £14.99. Buckholdt Associates, 01452 741106. Antidote , 5th Floor, 45 Beech Street, London, EC2Y 8AD, 020-7588 5151.

Emotionally intelligent parenting
 Make clear the values and rules you consider important, eg 'we share', 'we listen'. Be consistent.
 Help children solve problems rather than provide answers. Use open-ended questions. Ask them: What would you like to happen?
 Only children can calm themselves, but you can help them, eg, count to 10 together and then suggest talking about it.
 If children are squabbling, don't get hung up on who did what to whom. Ask what each wanted and how they hoped to achieve it.
 Getting children to admit guilt shouldn't be the goal. Get them to see they have a problem that needs solving.
 See their point of view. Listen to their arguments, encourage them to think of solutions. You don't have to agree, just acknowledge.
 Keep your sense of humour. Laugh at yourself: children will see you're a friend not an enemy.
 Be aware you can irritate or appear rude to them, eg by forgetting their friends' names. If you don't give respect, you can't expect to receive it.

How to be emotionally intelligent
 Be aware of your body. Posture and gesture reflect your feelings, eg if your hands are clenched what are you angry about? Practise reading body signals.
 Turn down the sound on the television. Notice which situations or people make you feel uncomfortable. Work out why.
 Anticipate situations you don't like. Think what you want to achieve and keep focused on it.
 If you feel you're going to loose it, count to 10. Then ask: do i want to shout or do I have an alternative?
 Ask for feedback. Knowing how you come across identifies strengths and weaknesses.
 Set achievable targets, such as: I'm going to talk to two new people at the party; I'm going to phone that new company and request a meeting to discuss opportunities.
 Twice a day listen to someone without interrupting. Then repeat what they say: 'So you think...' It helps you understand others' feelings.

Emotional intelligence at work
 Give feedback, not criticism.
 If criticised, acknowledge responsibility, then see it as an opportunity to solve a problem.
 Identify and cultivate key people who would be useful when difficulties occur. They will respond more willingly.
 Be available; this is more important the higher up you go.
 Set achievable targets, eg I'll make two points at the meeting.
 If someone is shouting, don't shout back. Keep eye contact and say what you want to say calmly.
 Acknowledge new ideas even if they're hopeless. Instant dismissal crushes creativity.
 Take the role of the other person - colleague, boss, employee, customer. What do they want to achieve?
 In times of uncertainty keep everyone informed. Lack of knowledge creates distrust and low morale.
