But Tim Sparrow, of human performance consultants Buckholdt Associates, points out there are two crucial differences. 'Soft skills training was only about interpersonal intelligence - relating to others. Emotional intelligence involves intrapersonal - knowing yourself - as well. You can't be interpersonally intelligent if you don't recognise feelings in yourself. Secondly, soft skills are considered a "bolt-on". That doesn't work for emotional intelligence, which is about cultural change, and needs to be knitted in to the whole business strategy.' But is it just another management fad? Not to mention a new money-spinner for the overcrowded consultancy industry? Malcolm Higgs and Vic Dulewicz, of the organisational behaviour faculty at Henley Management College, admit they were sceptical on first reading Goleman's work. They felt it was too anecdotally based and lacked rigorous testing. They subjected personal and competency data they had collected on 100 management and business leaders to more objective modelling. Crucially, the data tracked their advancement over a seven-year period. The results, they admit, staggered them. 'We were amazed at how consistent they were,' says Higgs. 'It was the same message: emotional intelligence was more highly related to success than IQ alone.' The rise of emotional intelligence is directly linked to the new world of work. Increased globalisation, competitiveness, speed and quality of information exchange means people have to cope with unprecedented levels of change. We've got to be more flexible, more creative, more adept and more responsive if we want to survive. Competitive advantage today comes from attracting and retaining top talent. 'It's a scarce resource,' says Higgs. 'You have to think differently about how to lead these people. The non-analytic side becomes important.' They aren't going to hang around if they don't feel comfortable. The costs of neglecting emotional intelligence can thus be high: increased staff turnover, low creativity, poached talent. On a personal level it can be costly, too. Goleman cites the example of a chief operating officer: powerful mind, excellent technical skills, at 45 years old perfect CEO material. On paper. He was fired by the incumbent CEO because he was 'not particularly likeable', 'brutally acerbic' and 'socially awkward'. But it is not simply a case of being nice. The misconception, says Sparrow, is that people confuse taking account of feelings with being soft. 'With emotional intelligence you have to know when to stand firm. It's how you do it that counts.' Imagine, he says, you've got an urgent deadline and need staff to stay behind. But one is complaining. 'If you say, "I see you're very upset but I need you to stay and work," you're more likely to get them to do so because you've shown you recognise they're upset. Far less likely if you say, "Tough shit, sit down and work."' Emotional intelligence is not restricted to work. It is applicable to relationships, parenting, marriage, education. Antidote is the campaign for emotional literacy with a particular focus on introducing emotional and skills training in schools. 'Emotional intelligence is a life skill. Developing it from childhood could transform the society we live in,' says Antidote director, James Park. Interest in emotional intelligence in the UK lags three to four years behind the States and is only just taking off - it was one of the keynote addresses at last year's Institute of Personnel and Development conference in Harrogate. Businesses can use it both in recruitment - drawing up EI profiles of applicants to compare with known 'star' performers - and personal and team development. So hot an issue has emotional intelligence become, that corporations - as well as individuals - are now queuing up for the plethora of new courses promising to provide participants with a high EQ. But Higgs warns to be suspicious of anything that offers a quick-fix solution. It is not something you can learn in a two-day seminar. There are no short cuts. It needs self-assessment, a conscious behavioural change, determination,practice and feedback. 'It's about changing culture,' says Isles. 'The test is whether your behaviour has changed. And that takes a lot longer.' It won't turn you into a touchy-feely, tree-hugger. It's far more difficult. 'It's the ability to balance hard elements with emotions,' says Higgs. 'High drive, clear focus balanced with empathy and sensitivity to the needs of others. And that's tough. To be emotionally intelligent doesn't mean you're a cuddly person.' The good news is that you're never too old to start learning. Further help/information 'Emotional Intelligence' and 'Working with Emotional Intelligence', Daniel Goleman, Bloomsbury, £7.99 each. 'Emotionally Intelligent Parenting', by Maurice Elias, Steven Tobias & Brian Friedlander, Hodder & Stoughton, £9.99. 'Making Sense of Emotional Intelligence', by Malcolm Higgs and Vic Dulewicz, NFER-Nelson, £14.99. Buckholdt Associates, 01452 741106. Antidote , 5th Floor, 45 Beech Street, London, EC2Y 8AD, 020-7588 5151. Emotionally intelligent parenting  Make clear the values and rules you consider important, eg 'we share', 'we listen'. Be consistent.  Help children solve problems rather than provide answers. Use open-ended questions. Ask them: What would you like to happen?  Only children can calm themselves, but you can help them, eg, count to 10 together and then suggest talking about it.  If children are squabbling, don't get hung up on who did what to whom. Ask what each wanted and how they hoped to achieve it.  Getting children to admit guilt shouldn't be the goal. Get them to see they have a problem that needs solving.  See their point of view. Listen to their arguments, encourage them to think of solutions. You don't have to agree, just acknowledge.  Keep your sense of humour. Laugh at yourself: children will see you're a friend not an enemy.  Be aware you can irritate or appear rude to them, eg by forgetting their friends' names. If you don't give respect, you can't expect to receive it. How to be emotionally intelligent  Be aware of your body. Posture and gesture reflect your feelings, eg if your hands are clenched what are you angry about? Practise reading body signals.  Turn down the sound on the television. Notice which situations or people make you feel uncomfortable. Work out why.  Anticipate situations you don't like. Think what you want to achieve and keep focused on it.  If you feel you're going to loose it, count to 10. Then ask: do i want to shout or do I have an alternative?  Ask for feedback. Knowing how you come across identifies strengths and weaknesses.  Set achievable targets, such as: I'm going to talk to two new people at the party; I'm going to phone that new company and request a meeting to discuss opportunities.  Twice a day listen to someone without interrupting. Then repeat what they say: 'So you think...' It helps you understand others' feelings. Emotional intelligence at work  Give feedback, not criticism.  If criticised, acknowledge responsibility, then see it as an opportunity to solve a problem.  Identify and cultivate key people who would be useful when difficulties occur. They will respond more willingly.  Be available; this is more important the higher up you go.  Set achievable targets, eg I'll make two points at the meeting.  If someone is shouting, don't shout back. Keep eye contact and say what you want to say calmly.  Acknowledge new ideas even if they're hopeless. Instant dismissal crushes creativity.  Take the role of the other person - colleague, boss, employee, customer. What do they want to achieve?  In times of uncertainty keep everyone informed. Lack of knowledge creates distrust and low morale.

fields.headline: Eat well, live well
fields.standfirst: Eating well is the foundation of health and wellbeing, but most of us are still confused about what that means. Jane Clarke sorts out the mixed messages to deliver the real principles of a good diet
fields.trailText: Eating well is the foundation of health and wellbeing, but most of us are still confused about what that means. Jane Clarke sorts out the mixed messages to deliver the real principles of a good diet
fields.body:
This last millennium brought about dramatic changes in the way we perceive the importance of food. Not so long ago, to be worried about diet would have been a luxury only afforded by the rich; nowadays thousands of nutrition books and articles appear on the internet and in bookstores - our appetite for information appears insatiable. Yet despite having the information at our fingertips, our diets are far less balanced and the prevalence of diet-related illness is rocketing. We've the highest rate of obesity in Europe, an appalling record of diet-related cancers and too much heart disease, even in youngsters.

Why people seem unable or unwilling to eat healthily is, in part, down to confusion and some degree of apathy. We've been faced with so many 'thou shalt not' messages that the majority of us have long since switched off. However, now is a perfect time to work out how you can enjoyably eat foods that are good for you. Prioritise now and you're far more likely to feel well in the short term (spend less time fighting colds, existing rather than living) and less likely to enter old age with problems that could have been prevented or made less serious. Simple rules like eating five portions of fruit and vegetables a day can make all the difference.

Five ways to eat five portions
Roast pumpkin to make soup  Juice tangerines and grapefruit in the morning  Roast some vegetables to serve with cold meat l Have a spicy tomato juice, with or without the vodka  Eat a handful of dried dates and a few fresh walnuts as a snack

Water Works
Water is the first thing we don't get enough of. Without sufficient water, our bodies are unable to glean the health-giving nutrients from the foods, to excrete the unwanted waste products and to hydrate the skin and other essential organs. Aim for two-and-a-half litres (roughly five pints) every day, sparkling or still, cold or hot. This does not include tea or coffee (or chocolate and cola) as they contain caffeine. Excess caffeine (over two to three cups a day) inhibits the absorption of essential minerals such as calcium, and increases the pancreas's capacity to secrete insulin (the hormone which breaks down sugar in the blood) making sugar and energy levels much more volatile. It can also exacerbate blood pressure and other heart conditions. Decaff can be fine, as long as you choose blends which have been treated with water and not chemicals - solvent residues are a concern. Herbal teas are best kept simple (see the box on herbal teas). Watch the fruity concoctions - they can be nothing more than an additive-enriched powder. Stagger fluid intake: aim for a glass or mug an hour; kidneys and bladder will soon adapt.

Five herbal teas to try
Camomile, mint, ginger, verveine, tilleul

Go with the grain
The wholegrain/wholemeal family (cereals, breads etc) contain other crucial nutrients (zinc and B vitamins etc). This doesn't mean that white bread, pasta and rice are bad - they can provide a good source of slow-release fuel (watch their tendency to induce a short-term dose of soporific hormones, while they're being digested), calcium, as is the case with some types of white bread, and contain relatively few calories per portion.

Choose fruit as your main sweet food: too many quickly absorbed sugars - chocolates, sweet biscuits etc - can cause tooth decay, obesity, and energy and mood fluctuations. These foods can be part of a healthy diet as long as you eat them after you have some fibre in your stomach - eat your custard tart after a meal rather than in between.

Protein power
Our gut bacteria and every other cell in our body depends on receiving a good supply of protein, fibres, vitamins and minerals, a small amount of fat and slow-release sugars. Protein wise, this involves eating 1gm per kilo of our body weight, every day - this dose equips our body with the amino-acids - the building blocks of proteins. Protein taken in excess of the target is either broken down into glucose to produce energy or stored in the body as fat. For the average adult this equates to eating a piece of lean protein about the size of a chicken breast for your main meal, plus an additional portion, half this size, in a smaller meal or snack. For a number of health reasons it's best to choose a lean source (one without noticeable fat) rather than fatty meats or products such as pies or sausages. If you don't like red meat, your diet can be balanced, but you need to take care that you include a good source of iron. If you have a tendency towards iron-deficiency anaemia (one of the most common causes of hair loss and fatigue in women) look at the box on iron-rich foods and try to include a valuable source at least three times a week. Vegetarians should have one portion of protein-rich food as a main meal and half this portion as a second meal - a portion could be two eggs, about 150g (5oz) cooked weight of pulses, 90g (3oz) nuts (be careful with children) or 225g (8oz) tofu. Since non-animal proteins don't contain the full spectrum of essential amino-acids, strict vegetarians should accompany each of their protein foods (pulses, nuts, lentils, tofu etc) with a cereal food (such as pasta, bread or rice) in both meals. This ensures the body receives the right protein balance.

Five reasons to eat protein
To build strong muscles, repair tissues, maintain an effective immune and hormonal system and help the brain receive a steady supply of serotonin and noradrenaline - aka happy hormones.

Eat fish
Oily fish stand out on their own - besides being an excellent source of protein, salmon, sardines, mullet and herrings etc, contain beneficial fish oils called omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, which help prevent certain types of cancer and heart disease, reduce inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, even period pain and psoriasis. Despite some fears over the dioxin levels in some oily fish, the balance of benefits verses potential risks still favours that you eat them twice a week.

Five iron-rich foods
Eggs, green leafy vegetables, lentils, beans, oily fish

The fat debate still continues to confuse people. If you're trying to keep your calorie intake in check, keeping your fat consumption down is one of the most effective measures. Fat of whatever sort - animal or vegetable - is rich in calories (with twice the calories per gram as proteins or carbohydrates). Saturated fats - butter, cream, cheese etc - can, in excess, produce unwanted LDL, aka bad cholesterol. Olive oil and other vegetable fats, however, increase HDL - the good cholesterol. If you have a high bad cholesterol level you should lean towards the vegetable fats, but if LDL is not an issue choose the fat you like and just eat a small amount of it.

I don't recommend you eat low-fat foods, such as low-fat cheese (cut rind off soft cheese and you can decrease its fat content by up to two-thirds) or margarine - they not only taste inferior but are frequently over-processed and contain unhealthy additives and preservatives. Have full-fat food, but keep the quantity down - after all, our bodies need a small amount of proper fat to metabolise essential fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E and K. The most efficient way to enable your body to cope with fat is to match fat with fibre.

Feed your bones
Since calcium is one of the most crucial bone-building and maintaining minerals, include some dairy produce or other calcium-rich food in your daily diet. Cheese, milk and yoghurt (cow, goat or sheep) are the easiest absorbed and healthiest sources. The daily requirement is around 800mg per day for adults. To put this in perspective, 250ml (1/2 pint) cow's milk or 150g (5oz) yoghurt contains 300mg calcium.

Non-dairy calcium foods
Dark green leafy vegetables, tofu, pulses, figs and apricots, canned fish such as sardines, tahini and some nuts

The F-word
Fibre swells in the presence of water and acts as a buffer to the absorption of fat. Serve cheese with oat cakes, fruits, vegetables such as celery or a slice of wholegrain bread rather than eating it on its own. Fibre is one of the most beneficial nutrients we can derive from our diets - it stimulates the gut to digest food efficiently, excrete unwanted waste products and ensure the absorption of nutrients (such as sugar) from food occurs in a gradual and sustainable fashion.

Roughage stimulates the body (by being rich in antioxidants) to produce substances that limit free-radical damage. Free radicals are highly reactive compounds produced in our body, which are inoffensive in small amounts, but in excess (which frequently occurs when we live in a polluted, stressful, smoky, too-much-sun environment) they can lead to disease and ageing. Eat at least five portions of fruits and vegetables every day.

With fruits and vegetables, the fresher the better, so include local, fresh, organic produce as much as possible. Even though I say organic, the organic debate is far from conclusive. Locally grown organic produce is ideal, but if this is impossible (as is likely for the majority), you're much better not to stress yourself out about organic or non-organic - just buy fresh. Shop as frequently as you can, so that your routine uses supermarket produce as soon after purchase as possible. Keep cooking times down to a minimum. Don't rule out soups and casseroles, but 'balance' with a good dose of rawness - fresh fruit or salads and freshly squeezed juices. Frozen vegetables can contain more nutrients than some fresh produce, so they're a useful stand-by.

Foods high in fibre
Fruits (fresh and dried - choose dried fruits which haven't been exposed to sulphur dioxide), vegetables, whole grains, pulses, lentils, oats

Gut Reactions
Another simple and, to many, surprising target, is keeping your gut bacteria healthy. Flora (the bacteria not the margarine) in your intestine, produce essential nutrients such as vitamin K and several energy substrates. Recently it has been suggested that they're also involved in the production of butyrates and other by-products known to reduce the incidence of certain cancers, digestive problems such as ulcerative colitis and heart disease. Many people are walking around with more bad than good bacteria in their gut (tell-tale signs include wind, bloating, bad breath and stomach aches). Antibiotics strip the gut of its good bacteria and so does a generally unhealthy diet.

The good bacteria
Either take a small pot of live yoghurt every day containing either lactobacillus, acidophilus and bifidus or take an acidophilus pill daily (available from health food stores). There is still some scepticism over the amount of these probiotic bacteria (when taken as a pill or within yoghurt) which manage to survive the stomach acids and make it down into the bowel where it's needed. Even so, much scientific and anecdotal evidence leads me to believe it's well worth including probiotic bacteria in your millennium diet. People with irritable bowel syndrome, Crohn's disease or rheumatoid arthritis may react adversely to these bacteria, so check with your doctor before you take the acidophilus pills.

fields.headline: Change your mind change your life
fields.standfirst: What is Life Coaching? What a personal trainer does for your body,   a life coach does for the rest of your life. A life coach will meet you, get   to know you, discover what areas of your life you feel dissatisfied or   confused about, then help you develop a strategy for improving them. After the initial meeting, which may take several hours, most coaching can be done by telephone - you'll have follow-up meetings only if you want them. Coaches then do what personal trainers do - they push you, encourage you, watch over you, and don't let you get away with not turning your new plans and strategies into action. What coaching is not is therapy.
fields.trailText:
Whatever your problem, the techniques of life coaching can help you. Over the 
next four weeks we'll be showing you how to be your own life coach. 
Part 1. Relationships
fields.body:
'Therapy focuses on the roots of your problems and deals, to a large extent, with your emotions,' says top British coach Eileen Mulligan. 'Coaching is far more pragmatic and goal-orientated. We don't focus on the roots of problems, but on their solutions.'
1. Relationships

Where are you now?
'Before I begin a one-to-one session, I ask people to do something very simple,' says Eileen. 'Write down the numbers 1-10 in a straight line. One is very unhappy, 10 is very happy. Circle the number that describes how you currently feel about your relationship.' You shouldn't think too long before you circle your number - it gives a statement of where you are to start working from.

The List
Make a list. On a piece of paper, write down these headings: goals, personal strengths, immediate challenges/blocks/problems, development skills, achievements. Now start to fill them in, using these guidelines:

Goals: Goals are the foundation stones of life coaching. Make these something you want to gain, not something you want to get rid of. So, as we're looking at relationships, you might write something like 'to spend more time with my partner' or 'to meet a new partner'. If you write something like 'to stop getting so angry with my partner' you're describing a problem, not a goal. Resist the temptation to make goals for others, for example, 'to get my partner to pay me more attention'. Your relationship goals may well involve your partner, but you cannot think or make goals for them, only for yourself.
Personal strengths: For the moment, concentrate on your strengths, not your weaknesses. Don't downgrade your strengths. If you want a good relationship, you have to believe you are worthy of one. Listing your strengths is a good way to focus on what you have to offer. You could write something like 'I always make an effort to be there for my partner' or 'people are attracted to my warm and optimistic personality'. Other strengths might include honesty, loyalty or the ability to be faithful, supportive, loving. List as many as you can think of, and prepare a list of the qualities you'd most like your partner to have.
Immediate challenges/blocks/problems: This is where we get to the negative things. It's important to focus on problems that directly affect you - don't list problems that blame or involve other people. So you might write something like 'my relationships never last longer than six months' or 'I find it hard to tell my partner what my needs are'. Although you may feel that your problems are to do with another person - 'my partner works such long hours, he doesn't give me any attention' or 'my last two relationships were with people who were unfaithful to me' - it's important to focus on the problem in a way that allows you to see the part you can play in the solution. And don't forget that you can't 'make' somebody do something, so don't write 'make my partner work fewer hours'. Instead, consider the problem from another angle. Is there a way you can accommodate those long hours? Fill them with something absorbing and stimulating, so your partner's absence bothers you less. Or see the problem not as your partners always being unfaithful, but as yourself being attracted to people who treat you badly. This way, you aren't blaming somebody else, which puts the feeling outside your control. You're seeing the problem in a way that gives you control over solving it.
Development skills: This is an area you can develop and improve. Listing these is a great way to focus on ways you can move forward, even in a good relationship. You are recognising that it takes two to make a partnership, and that you will take responsibility for the part you play. You might write 'learn to listen more', 'improve communication skills' or 'learn to be more independent'.
Achievements: List achievements you are proud of. Even if you feel that your personal life is a disaster, there will be aspects of it, past or present, that you can feel good about. And if your relationship is basically good, having a list of achievements to fall back on really helps in the tougher times. One of my clients in an unsatisfactory relationship said, 'Well, at least I stuck it out for two years.' I persuaded her to change that to 'I've shown that I can commit to a relationship'. Other things you might write are 'I have been happily married for 10 years', 'I am not afraid to admit that I really want to be in a loving, committed relationship', 'I found the strength to leave a bad relationship and look for a good one', 'I am willing to tackle problems in my relationship' or 'I don't quit when the going gets tough'. How have I progressed? What have I gained from the relationship? How would I do things differently next time?

Know your own values
Now that you have come this far, you need to list your personal core values. We all have these, whether we're aware of them or not. When we live in conflict with our own inner values, it can lead to unhappiness, frustration and blocks. Becoming aware of your values, and prioritising them, helps you to discover what you really want. Clare's values' list, for example (see above), helped her see her relationship problems very differently, and made her reassess her goals. Start by making a list of 10 values that you feel are important to you. Some common examples include: love, security, respect, money, achievement, health, success, ambition, freedom, integrity, compassion, independence, family, children, travel, trust. Next, try to put your own values in order, from 1-10. This can be difficult, and you may need to rework your list a few times before you feel it really reflects how you think and feel. Once you've done that, look at what the list is telling you. For example, if security, family and love are high on your list, and you're having an affair, you are behaving in opposition to your values, and it will never make you happy. At the beginning of this lesson, you listed your goals, with the immediate problems or challenges that prevent you from achieving it. Remember to keep the focus on your own place in the problem. So, if the problem is that you feel that your partner doesn't listen to you, express it as 'I need to find better ways to communicate with my partner'. If you keep asking yourself positive, self-focused and solution-focused questions - 'How can I ask questions in a way that my partner doesn't find threatening?', 'Where can I meet different people' - you may find a way through your problem quite quickly. But relationships often present complicated problems. If you find it difficult to see a way past the problem, try the following method.

The doorway technique
Think of every possible solution there could be to this goal, whether you like the sound of it or not - putting up with the problem, finding a way not to be upset by it, leaving your partner, etc. Now close your eyes and imagine each solution written on a doorway. Then stand in front of one of the doors and walk through it. What's on the other side? If you don't like it, you can walk back through the door and try another one. Visualisation can be an unnerving but very powerful tool, which helps you to see just what you most fear from making a particular decision. Using visualisation lets you walk through the doors again and again, until it looks less threatening. Keep asking yourself the right questions. How can I make this work for me? How can I turn this situation around?

 Acknowledge your own goals before working on joint goals.
 To find a solution to a problem, you have to be clear about how it affects you - the effect is something you can control.
 You are not trying to solve other people's problems. To achieve your goals you have to focus on the relevance a problem has to you.
 It's usually easier to find a problem than a goal, so work on discovering your true goals.
 If you feel weighed down by a problem, work on your personal strengths, development skills and achievements. This will prepare you to make the right decision.
 Use the 'doorway' technique when you feel really stuck.

Relationship Problems

Eileen (the coach):
Clare is a 39-year-old lawyer, with two young children. She came to see me because she was having problems in her marriage. She and her husband had been arguing a lot, often about money and work, and had reached a point where he was considering leaving. Clare was upset and angry, but clear that she did not want to separate.

I began by asking her to fill in her 'personal values' sheet. She found this very hard to do, but when she completed the form, she listed 'learning and personal development' as her number-one value. This helped us to see her relationship problems in a new light. Clare had given up a good job to be at home with her children. While she felt it was a good decision, she was becoming increasingly frustrated that her husband wasn't progressing in his work as Clare thought he should be, and that their income was reduced.

In fact, frustration at lack of progress and having less money is a problem for Clare, not her husband. She is projecting her own frustrations about her current lack of progress on to him, which makes him angry and resentful. Clare could acknowledge this, and set herself short, medium and long-term goals which would improve her sense of learning and development, and which would also enable her to earn more money and therefore feel valued. Very often, clients see me because of issues with one area of their lives, but the real issue turns out to be somewhere else. That's why identifying values and completing the list is so helpful.

Clare (the client):
I felt very emotional at my first meeting with Eileen. But coaching isn't therapy. It doesn't allow you to examine your feelings in detail, it just sets out to understand how you got to this point and how you can move past it, in a very pragmatic way. I found filling in the values sheet hard work. My first list was all about achievement and progress, with love and security fairly low down - numbers six and seven. I didn't like that list. It wasn't the list I wanted to live my life by. I reworked it to reflect the way I think I really feel and want to be - learning and development came first, with love and family second and third. Making that list is more useful than you think - it gives you a map to guide yourself by. And realising that I was projecting my own frustrations and insecurities on to my husband was quite revelatory. I think it's true, but I hadn't connected that to us being so miserable. Most of my goals are to work on myself, and building a sense of achievement and progress into my life. I can see how life coaching can be very effective. My husband and I are getting on much better, and I feel calmer and more in control of my circumstances. I've spoken to Eileen by phone since, to evolve goals, check progress, and discuss other blocks as they come up. But, like working with a personal trainer, I worry that all the good work and resolution will go out of the window once the phone calls stop...

fields.headline: 110 ways to live to 110
fields.standfirst: The good news is that we can all expect to live longer and better   than any generation in history. And the even better news?    How well we age is largely up to us
fields.trailText: The good news is that we can all expect to live longer and better   than any generation in history. And the even better news?    How well we age is largely up to us
fields.body:
Mid-century, three score and 10 used to seem a 'a good innings': now five score and 10 seems more like it. What's happened? In addition to its other marvels (splitting the atom, transplanting a beating human heart, and cracking our genetic code), the 20th century is likely to be remembered for having the biggest hike in life expectancy in recorded history, rising from 52 to 79 for women and from 49 to 74 for men - a leap of nearly 50 per cent. What's more, in every decade of the last century, the average life span rose by about two years - a trend that shows no signs of abating.

What are we doing with all these extra years? All the indications are that we are living not just longer but better. With unprecedented numbers of fit, healthy people now hitting 70, 80, and even 90, it's becoming clear that gloomy predictions of a greying population, beset by ever increasing and expensive degenerative diseases, have been overdone.

In fact, over the last 10 years surveys from the US have repeatedly shown that the period of illness and infirmity we call 'old age' is actually shortening: in the short space of just seven years (1982 to 1989), for example, the probability of an 85-year-old remaining free from disabilities rose by nearly 30 per cent.

Already, there is an ever-growing expansion of what we think of as 'youth' and a postponement of 'old age', with the middle years appearing to expand indefinitely. Many of today's octogenarians are enjoying a quality of life that used to be the prerogative of the newly retired - travelling to new destinations, acquiring new skills, taking up new sports, interests and studies, starting or continuing to run businesses and actively looking forward to each new day. If our own definition of old age is a constantly moving target, it's not just because it always jumps on 10 years as we ourselves get older. It's also because what it means to reach 60, 70, 80 or even 90 is itself undergoing a dramatic attitude shift.

The challenge in front of all of us now is to age as successfully as we can. It's becoming clear that there are two sorts of ageing - chronological and biological, and while we can't change our chronological age, we can do a lot to slow down biological ageing by adopting the 110 lifestyle and attitude changes listed here.

Heredity/Luck
Have one, or preferably two, long-lived parents (85+).
Be a well-educated, well-off westerner. Undemocratic but true: wealth buys health.
Have access to the best health care and make use of it.
Get to grips with your family history. Find out what your close relations died of: cancer, heart disease, stroke, and ask your doctor about screening tests for these conditions.

Lifestyle
Never take up smoking, or give it up now, using medical aids, such as nicotine gum, to help you.
Wear sunscreen - SPF of 15 or more - every day in the summer.
Use condoms or barrier method contraception if not in a monogamous relationship to reduce susceptibility to STDs.
Walk tall. Good posture is a common Super-young characteristic: unlearn slouching tendencies via yoga, Pilates or the Alexander Technique.
Keep an eye on your weight - know your Body Mass Index and keep it in the low 20s.
Once weight has stabilised, keep it steady - no fluctuations of more than seven pounds either way.
Watch your waist-to-hip ratio - apple-type fat that barrels around the middle is a big risk factor for several serious diseases, while pear-type fat is not: your waist should be 0.7 or less of your hip measurement for women, 0.85 for men.
Sleep needs reduce with age, and may be as little as three or four hours after age 65; don't let bouts of insomnia worry you and certainly don't take sleeping pills other than for short-term help at crisis points.
Try not to have a caffeine-containing drink less than four hours before bedtime.
Floss teeth daily and keep regular dental hygiene appointments: tooth/gum bacteria have been linked to heart disease and serious digestive disorders.
Keep your anxiety level down - it interferes with memory, mental functioning and disables the immune system.

Nutrition
Train yourself to eat fewer calories - cut out snacks, eat smaller quantities, chew slowly, stop when full and have a modest meal at the end of the day.
Move towards a more plant-based diet - non meat-eaters really do live longer.
Have at least five helpings of fruit/ vegetables daily, varying the colours as much as possible to get the full spectrum of health-giving antioxidants.
Eat vegetables raw or very lightly cooked to conserve valuable vitamins and include a salad with your meal at least once a day.
Eat three to four helpings of wholegrains a day for B-complex vitamins - important to heart health.
Buy a juicer and have an 240ml (8floz) glass of both fruit and vegetable juice every day.
Rebalance your system with fortnightly one- or two-day vegetable juice fasts.
Eat organic produce and free-range meat/ fish where possible.
Cut down on foods that are high in saturated fat.
Keep added sugar to a minimum.
Choose foods as close as possible to their natural state.
Eat oily fish three times a week for health-giving omega-3 fatty acids that will especially benefit the heart and circulation - salmon, tuna, mackerel, halibut, herring.
Limit red meat to once or twice a week.
Cook with monounsaturated rather than polyunsaturated fat (ie, olive oil rather than safflower and sunflower) and use hazelnut and walnut oils in dressings.
Vary your diet: explore different ethnic cuisines and continually introduce novelty.
Train yourself to look on food as a source of pleasure rather than guilt or anxiety.
Don't rely on pills to make good any deficiencies in your diet but bolster your defences with a daily multivitamin supplement - that includes the antioxidant vitamins C (up to 500mg) and E (400-800 ius) and the B-complex vitamins, including folic acid (400 ug), B6 (up to 100mg) and B12 (up to 100mcg).

Habits
Cut back on alcohol if you drink every day or exceed 27 units a week (21 for women).
Avoid binge drinking (5 units or more).
Have at least one alcohol-free day a week.
Enjoy a guilt-free glass or two of wine in the evening - red wine is especially good.
Keep spirits and beers as occasional treats.
Limit caffeine to two cups of coffee/tea a day.
Explore non-caffeine alternatives: chicory, herb and (especially) antioxidant-rich green teas and tinctures.
Drink 2 1/2 litres of water a day.
Avoid regular laxative use; increase the amount of fibre you eat and activity you take until your system regularises itself.
Learn the art of relaxation, via meditation mantra, taught techniques, breathing methods or autogenic training, and put it to good use every day.

Activity
Get moving immediately: if not taking any other form of exercise, just getting out for a brisk walk for at least 30 minutes a day could cut your risk of a heart attack by a third.
Make it easier by implementing a policy of walking distances of less than a mile and leaving the car behind, while moving at a brisker pace than you're accustomed to.
Get a dog (or find a neighbour's one) who needs walking to accompany you
Consider investing in a heart monitor to learn how your heart responds to, and recovers from, exertion.
Try to have aerobic sessions to condition heart and lungs three times a week for 20-40 minutes and keep it up for the rest of your healthy life.
If turned off by vigorous exercise such as running, jogging or biking, substitute a mixture of brisk walking and swimming.
For choice, select a weight-bearing exercise that will stimulate bone turnover and keep the skeleton strong: walking, jogging, skipping, rebounding, cycling, low-impact aerobics and ski-machines and Stairmaster-type climbers all qualify.
Use stairs rather than lifts to give an additionally beneficial jolt to the bones.
Try to include some strength work to maintain muscle mass - especially important for women, who are more likely to become prematurely enfeebled, with dire consequences for both balance and mobility.
Embark on a specific strength-training programme - studies at Tufts University in Boston show that year-long participation reverses the course of ageing by 15 to 20 years in elderly women.
Include a yoga-type stretching component to keep joints supple through the full range of movement.

Screening
Be vigilant: report any untoward change in health and body function to your doctor.
Regularly examine your body for new or changed moles and ask a relative, friend or practice nurse to check you over too.
Have blood pressure checks at least once every two years.
Have cholesterol/homocysteine checks for arterial and heart health from time to time and adjust diet if indicated.
lPay for one-off sigmoidoscopy at 50 to 55 to check for pre-malignant growths, known as polyps, on the colon, and be advised about further screens if/as necessary.
Ask your doctor about supplementing this with regular foecal occult blood tests to detect hidden blood in bowel movements - a possible sign of pre-malignant activity.
Report persisting changes in bowel habit.
Have flu vaccinations over age 65.
Have regular glaucoma eye checks every two years from age 40 (35 if you've a family history of the condition).

Women's health
Examine your breasts at least once a month - ask your doctor/ nurse to show you how.
Take up invitations for mammography - issued three-yearly between ages 50 and 65.
Ask for screening to be continued after age 65. Although the invitations will cease, there is provision.
Have regular smears and, if your health authority only offers them five-yearly, consider paying for interim smear tests privately to keep screening intervals optimal.
Keep up to speed on contraception: the Pill offers valuable protection against ovarian cancer.
Never diet to a point where menstruation stops. It could have serious consequences for bone and heart health.
See your doctor if you've pain or bloating in the abdomen, pain or bleeding during sex or post-menopausal bleeding.
Consider hormone replacement at menopause - now shown to benefit brain as well as bones and, probably, heart - though these pluses must be balanced against extra risk of breast cancer.
Consider having a bone scan (either state-of-the-art DEXA or cheaper heel ultrasound) to get indication of bone density at menopause.
Consider taking extra calcium, best combined with magnesium for optimum absorption at a ratio of 2:1 calcium to magnesium.
If deciding against HRT, consider taking phyto-oestrogens and get into the habit of adding tofu, soya and wheatgerm to your diet. It could afford a natural protection against breast cancer and, possibly, thinning bones.
Exercise your pelvic floor whenever you pass water; if muscles are weak, try toning them with cones.

Men's health
Men see their doctor much less often than women: arrange to have a regular health check at least every two years.
Examine your testicles regularly for lumps.
Be aware of signs and symptoms of prostate cancer, the commonest and most treatable cancer in men provided it is caught early.
Ask your doctor about having a PSA test to help flag a possible early-stage tumour.
Drink a daily glass of tomato juice: men who have more than 10 servings of tomato a week, whether raw and fresh or even on pizza, have significantly lower rates of prostate cancer, possibly due to the antioxidant lycopene which gives the tomato its red colour.

Medical
Wise up. Information is power, especially as we age.
Be aware of symptoms of high blood pressure and late-life diabetes - both conditions need active management if not to lead on to more serious problems.
Avoid illicit drugs - even a benign weed like marijuana wrecks the memory.
Check all prescription drugs are really necessary (especially repeats). Iatrogenic (medicine-induced) illness is a big cause of ill health in later life.
For any long-term chronic problems explore alternatives, such as homeopathy, acupuncture and dietary manipulation, that could enable you to cut out or cut down on medication.

Safety
Always wear a seat belt.
Never drive with any amount of alcohol in your blood, or get into a car where you know the driver has been drinking.
Use a hands-free phone system to make calls when driving, or pull over before telephoning.

Social
Never stop networking: renew old contacts and forge new ones.
Mix with a broad spectrum of people of all ages, especially younger ones.
Be open to new romantic and sexual opportunities.

Attitudes
Foster optimism, a common Super-young characteristic, by refusing to tolerate prolonged boredom or unhappiness.
Challenge other people's assumptions that you can't do something 'at your age' - especially if it's sex - lively libidos are a common characteristic of the Super-young.
Remain alert to your own false assumptions, too, or you may to readily impose unnecessary limitations on yourself.
Plan for your retirement - so you don't get ambushed by those empty hours opening up in front of you.
Don't let anyone persuade you that any aspect of ill health, from chronic pain to depression, is 'to be expected' in later life. It's not. Get it checked out and/or ask for a second opinion.
Indulge your sense of humour whenever and wherever you can.

Intellect
Junk junk TV - only watch programmes that stimulate and enrich you.
Keep up to speed with advances in technology.
Stretch your mind - learning offsets decreases in brain capacity with age, so take up a musical instrument, learn a language, subscribe to a specialist journal, or embark on an adult education course.
Don't get mentally lazy: take regular exercise by working out sums in your head, memorising phone numbers and poems, doing crosswords, playing chess or bridge.
Find a hobby or interest that really absorbs you and get immersed.

Spirit
Find a constructive way of helping others.
Maintain interest in spirituality and a belief, however free-floating, of a force outside yourself while remaining sceptical of eternal life on earth.

Hope or hype? The new elixirs of youth

The latest 'miracle treatments' in the battle against ageing are focusing on genes, enzymes and hormones - particularly those that peak in early adulthood and then slowly decline. Whether these are a cause of the ageing process or merely an effect is too soon to say, but these are the 'wonder drugs' currently causing the most excitement - and controversy:

Melatonin - the world's only effective answer to jet lag, melatonin works by resetting the body's diurnal clock. But whether it can rewind time itself is much less certain. Melatonin is released by the pineal gland in response to the external cues of darkness and daylight. It is a weak antioxidant but not sufficiently strong to produce the miraculous effects ascribed to it. Because it is a brain hormone with very general effects on the body, physicians recommend caution.
Status: unproven.

fields.bodyText: Mid-century, three score and 10 used to seem a 'a good innings': now five score and 10 seems more like it. What's happened? In addition to its other marvels (splitting the atom, transplanting a beating human heart, and cracking our genetic code), the 20th century is likely to be remembered for having the biggest hike in life expectancy in recorded history, rising from 52 to 79 for women and from 49 to 74 for men - a leap of nearly 50 per cent. What's more, in every decade of the last century, the average life span rose by about two years - a trend that shows no signs of abating. What are we doing with all these extra years? All the indications are that we are living not just longer but better. With unprecedented numbers of fit, healthy people now hitting 70, 80, and even 90, it's becoming clear that gloomy predictions of a greying population, beset by ever increasing and expensive degenerative diseases, have been overdone. In fact, over the last 10 years surveys from the US have repeatedly shown that the period of illness and infirmity we call 'old age' is actually shortening: in the short space of just seven years (1982 to 1989), for example, the probability of an 85-year-old remaining free from disabilities rose by nearly 30 per cent. Already, there is an ever-growing expansion of what we think of as 'youth' and a postponement of 'old age', with the middle years appearing to expand indefinitely. Many of today's octogenarians are enjoying a quality of life that used to be the prerogative of the newly retired - travelling to new destinations, acquiring new skills, taking up new sports, interests and studies, starting or continuing to run businesses and actively looking forward to each new day. If our own definition of old age is a constantly moving target, it's not just because it always jumps on 10 years as we ourselves get older. It's also because what it means to reach 60, 70, 80 or even 90 is itself undergoing a dramatic attitude shift. The challenge in front of all of us now is to age as successfully as we can. It's becoming clear that there are two sorts of ageing - chronological and biological, and while we can't change our chronological age, we can do a lot to slow down biological ageing by adopting the 110 lifestyle and attitude changes listed here. Heredity/Luck Have one, or preferably two, long-lived parents (85+). Be a well-educated, well-off westerner. Undemocratic but true: wealth buys health. Have access to the best health care and make use of it. Get to grips with your family history. Find out what your close relations died of: cancer, heart disease, stroke, and ask your doctor about screening tests for these conditions. Lifestyle Never take up smoking, or give it up now, using medical aids, such as nicotine gum, to help you. Wear sunscreen - SPF of 15 or more - every day in the summer. Use condoms or barrier method contraception if not in a monogamous relationship to reduce susceptibility to STDs. Walk tall. Good posture is a common Super-young characteristic: unlearn slouching tendencies via yoga, Pilates or the Alexander Technique. Keep an eye on your weight - know your Body Mass Index and keep it in the low 20s. Once weight has stabilised, keep it steady - no fluctuations of more than seven pounds either way. Watch your waist-to-hip ratio - apple-type fat that barrels around the middle is a big risk factor for several serious diseases, while pear-type fat is not: your waist should be 0.7 or less of your hip measurement for women, 0.85 for men. Sleep needs reduce with age, and may be as little as three or four hours after age 65; don't let bouts of insomnia worry you and certainly don't take sleeping pills other than for short-term help at crisis points. Try not to have a caffeine-containing drink less than four hours before bedtime. Floss teeth daily and keep regular dental hygiene appointments: tooth/gum bacteria have been linked to heart disease and serious digestive disorders. Keep your anxiety level down - it interferes with memory, mental functioning and disables the immune system. Nutrition Train yourself to eat fewer calories - cut out snacks, eat smaller quantities, chew slowly, stop when full and have a modest meal at the end of the day. Move towards a more plant-based diet - non meat-eaters really do live longer. Have at least five helpings of fruit/ vegetables daily, varying the colours as much as possible to get the full spectrum of health-giving antioxidants. Eat vegetables raw or very lightly cooked to conserve valuable vitamins and include a salad with your meal at least once a day. Eat three to four helpings of wholegrains a day for B-complex vitamins - important to heart health. Buy a juicer and have an 240ml (8floz) glass of both fruit and vegetable juice every day. Rebalance your system with fortnightly one- or two-day vegetable juice fasts. Eat organic produce and free-range meat/ fish where possible. Cut down on foods that are high in saturated fat. Keep added sugar to a minimum. Choose foods as close as possible to their natural state. Eat oily fish three times a week for health-giving omega-3 fatty acids that will especially benefit the heart and circulation - salmon, tuna, mackerel, halibut, herring. Limit red meat to once or twice a week. Cook with monounsaturated rather than polyunsaturated fat (ie, olive oil rather than safflower and sunflower) and use hazelnut and walnut oils in dressings. Vary your diet: explore different ethnic cuisines and continually introduce novelty. Train yourself to look on food as a source of pleasure rather than guilt or anxiety. Don't rely on pills to make good any deficiencies in your diet but bolster your defences with a daily multivitamin supplement - that includes the antioxidant vitamins C (up to 500mg) and E (400-800 ius) and the B-complex vitamins, including folic acid (400 ug), B6 (up to 100mg) and B12 (up to 100mcg). Habits Cut back on alcohol if you drink every day or exceed 27 units a week (21 for women). Avoid binge drinking (5 units or more). Have at least one alcohol-free day a week. For choice, select a weight-bearing exercise that will stimulate bone turnover and keep the skeleton strong: walking, jogging, skipping, rebounding, cycling, low-impact aerobics and ski-machines and Stairmaster-type climbers all qualify. Try to include some strength work to maintain muscle mass - especially important for women, who are more likely to become prematurely enfeebled, with dire consequences for both balance and mobility. Embark on a specific strength-training programme - studies at Tufts University in Boston show that year-long participation reverses the course of ageing by 15 to 20 years in elderly women. Include a yoga-type stretching component to keep joints supple through the full range of movement. Screening Be vigilant: report any untoward change in health and body function to your doctor. Regularly examine your body for new or changed moles and ask a relative, friend or practice nurse to check you over too. Have blood pressure checks at least once every two years. It could have serious consequences for bone and heart health. See your doctor if you've pain or bloating in the abdomen, pain or bleeding during sex or post-menopausal bleeding. If deciding against HRT, consider taking phyto-oestrogens and get into the habit of adding tofu, soya and wheatgerm to your diet. It could afford a natural protection against breast cancer and, possibly, thinning bones. Exercise your pelvic floor whenever you pass water; if muscles are weak, try toning them with cones. Be aware of signs and symptoms of prostate cancer, the commonest and most treatable cancer in men provided it is caught early. Ask your doctor about having a PSA test to help flag a possible early-stage tumour. Drink a daily glass of tomato juice: men who have more than 10 servings of tomato a week, whether raw and fresh or even on pizza, have significantly lower rates of prostate cancer, possibly due to the antioxidant lycopene which gives the tomato its red colour. Be aware of symptoms of high blood pressure and late-life diabetes - both conditions need active management if not to lead on to more serious problems. Avoid illicit drugs - even a benign weed like marijuana wrecks the memory. Check all prescription drugs are really necessary (especially repeats). Iatrogenic (medicine-induced) illness is a big cause of ill health in later life. For any long-term chronic problems explore alternatives, such as homeopathy, acupuncture and dietary manipulation, that could enable you to cut out or cut down on medication. Safety Always wear a seat belt. Never drive with any amount of alcohol in your blood, or get into a car where you know the driver has been drinking. Use a hands-free phone system to make calls when driving, or pull over before telephoning. Social Never stop networking: renew old contacts and forge new ones. Mix with a broad spectrum of people of all ages, especially younger ones. Be open to new romantic and sexual opportunities. Attitudes Foster optimism, a common Super-young characteristic, by refusing to tolerate prolonged boredom or unhappiness. Challenge other people's assumptions that you can't do something 'at your age' - especially if it's sex - lively libidos are a common characteristic of the Super-young. Remain alert to your own false assumptions, too, or you may to readily impose unnecessary limitations on yourself. Plan for your retirement - so you don't get ambushed by those empty hours opening up in front of you. Don't let anyone persuade you that any aspect of ill health, from chronic pain to depression, is 'to be expected' in later life. It's not. Get it checked out and/or ask for a second opinion. Indulge your sense of humour whenever and wherever you can. Intellect Junk junk TV - only watch programmes that stimulate and enrich you. Keep up to speed with advances in technology. Stretch your mind - learning offsets decreases in brain capacity with age, so take up a musical instrument, learn a language, subscribe to a specialist journal, or embark on an adult education course. Don't get mentally lazy: take regular exercise by working out sums in your head, memorising phone numbers and poems, doing crosswords, playing chess or bridge. Find a hobby or interest that really absorbs you and get immersed. Spirit Find a constructive way of helping others. fields.headline: Mixed and matched
fields.standfirst: First out of the stalls in 2000's debut novel stakes is Zadie Smith's heavily hyped tale of three families in multicultural modern England, White Teeth. Is it all it's cracked up to be?
fields.trailText: First out of the stalls in 2000's debut novel stakes is Zadie Smith's heavily hyped tale of three families in multicultural modern England. Is it all it's cracked up to be?
fields.body:
White Teeth
Zadie Smith
Hamish Hamilton, £12.99, pp462

It is more than 300 years since Daniel Defoe, in his poem 'The True-born Englishman' first recognised the essentially heterogeneous condition of the nation. He described the English as a people composed of mongrelised 'mixtures', identifying the Scot, Pict and Dane among many other constituent elements. Should Defoe have been able to glance at modern, postcolonial Britain, he would have to add the West Indian, the Indian and the African. It is precisely this helpless heterogeneity that Zadie Smith recognises and celebrates in this restless and wonderfully poised first novel, White Teeth.

The novel follows the fortunes of the families of two best friends: Archie Jones, a white, working-class man who works in a mail-order delivery firm, and who is married for a second time to a Jamaican woman, Clara, and Samad Iqbal, a Bangladeshi who is married to Alansa, and who works in a restaurant. As the hinge of generation turns, their children begin to complicate the lives of these two men. Samad has twin boys, Magid and Millat, and Archie has a daughter, Irie. Naturally enough, the children become friends and they create a dazzlingly complex world of cross-cultural fusion in modern-day London.

Samad is concerned at the way in which his sons are growing up in Britain (Magid has taken to being addressed as 'Mark Smith'), so he dispatches Magid back 'home' to be brought up by relatives. After Magid's departure, Millat Iqbal and Irie Jones befriend a boy called Joshua and a third family, the Chalfens, take centre stage. Marcus Chalfen, an eccentric scientist and university lecturer, and his wife Joyce, a mother and author of The Inner Life of Houseplants, have four children, including their eldest, Joshua.

The Chalfens are a liberal, pseudo-Marxist, white middle-class family who, as one might expect, welcome this 'exciting' rush of hybridity into their lives. Eventually, Marcus becomes penpals with the orientally exiled Magid, and on Magid's return to Britain it is Marcus who meets him at Heathrow and begins to make plans for this now level-headed, polite young man to study law. Meanwhile, Millat has renounced 'white birds' and joined 'the Cricklewood branch of the Keepers of the Eternal and Victorious Islamic Nation', which Irie points out have an 'acronym problem' - Kevin.

Samad and Archie 'observe' events from the vantage point of their retreat, O'Connell's Café on the Finchley Road, a place run by Abdul-Mickey, the son of an immigrant named Ali. All five sons were named Abdul, but Ali took the precaution of attaching an English name as a gesture to the clarity demanded by the new country. O'Connell's offers Samad and Archie a place from which they can view the interaction between the various families as the novel ranges back and forth in both contemporary and historical time. This multi-layered, deeply-plotted novel resists easy categorisation, which is precisely the author's point.

Britain has perennially sought to define herself and her character by defining others. Naturally enough, the country finds herself in great difficulty when presented with those who seem keen to resist definition. These 'in-betweens', these Abdul-Mickeys (or his brother Abdul-Colin), these working-class white men, like Archie, who marry Jamaican women 20 years their junior, these non-believing 'Muslims' such as Millat, these 'white birds' who go weak at the knees for people such as Magid - such people present Britain with a problem of categorisation.

For those of a colonial mindset, this swirling postcolonial world is blurring distinctions and challenging received wisdoms at an alarming rate. It is uncomfortably clear to those of the 'old school' that the hitherto familiar cultural signifiers of belonging are no longer the preserve of one group to the exclusion of another. One only needs to overhear a conversation on practically any London street corner:

'For your information,' snapped Irie, moving the nut out of Millat's reach, 'old people like coconuts. They can use the milk for their tea.'

Irie pressed on in the face of Millat's retching. 'And I got some crusty French bread and some cheese-singlets and some apples - '

'We got apples, you chief,' cut in Millat, 'chief', for some inexplicable reason hidden in the etymology of north London slang, meaning fool, arse, wanker, a loser of the most colossal proportions.

'Well, I got some more and better apples, akchully, and some Kendal mint cake and some ackee and saltfish.'

'I hate ackee and saltfish.'

However, it is not only those of a colonial mindset who must open themselves to change. When 'nature' visits Britain in October 1987, in the form of a hurricane, the Iqbals' world is shaken up. While Samad and Millat hurry to flee the house, Alansa sits stubbornly on the sofa confident that nothing will happen because 'Mr Fish', the BBC weatherman, has assured 'her' that all will be fine. When she relents, and gets in the car and drives from the house with 110mph winds howling, she confesses that her world has changed.

She is of an immigrant generation that expected to encounter a benign Britain; a 'civilised' Britain, as characterised by BBC announcers in dinner-jackets, crumpets for tea and the comforting thwack of leather on willow. Quite probably a Britain that never existed, but nonetheless - in her mind - a more reliable Britain than that to which she is currently being exposed:

'England, this is meant to be! I moved to England so I wouldn't have to do this. Never again will I trust that Mr Crab.'

'Amma, it's Mr Fish.'

'From now on, he's Mr Crab to me,' snapped Alansa with a dark look. 'BBC or no BBC.'

The depiction of the dysfunctional Chalfen family, while often funny, finally seems too cartoon-like. Marcus and Joyce Chalfen tolerate the foul-mouthed Millat, who rolls joints at their table, drinks their alcohol and generally calls the shots around their house.

'Oh, Millat, don't smoke that stuff. Every time we see you these days you're smoking. It upsets Oscar so much. He's not that young and he understands more than you think. He understands about marijuana.'

'What's mary wana?' asked Oscar.

'You know what it is, Oscar. It's what makes Millat all horrible, like we were talking about today, and it's what kills the little brain cells he has.'

'Get off my fucking back, Joyce.'

It is frustrating not to have a more 'substantial' white family at the heart of the novel, for Irie, Millat and Magid are treated by the Chalfens with a degree of patronage that is unsurprising. Their son, Joshua, has a more complicated response to the situation, for Irie is the object of his desire. However, his two-dimensional parents do little more than enliven the more farcical elements of the narrative.

There is nothing farcical about the pain of wanting to belong. In this respect, White Teeth is full of false smiles and contrived faces, masks that are repeatedly donned in order to better hide the pain. The 'mongrel' nation that is Britain is still struggling to find a way to stare into the mirror and accept the ebb and flow of history that has produced this fortuitously diverse condition and its concomitant pain.

Zadie Smith's first novel is an audaciously assured contribution to this process of staring into the mirror. Her narrator is deeply self-conscious, so much so that one can almost hear the crisp echo of Salman Rushdie's footsteps. However, her wit, her breadth of vision and her ambition are of her own making. The plot is rich, at times dizzyingly so, but White Teeth squares up to the two questions which gnaw at the very roots of our modern condition: Who are we? Why are we here?

While Samad and Millat hurry to flee the house, Alansa sits stubbornly on the sofa confident that nothing will happen because 'Mr Fish', the BBC weatherman, has assured 'her' that all will be fine. When she relents, and gets in the car and drives from the house with 110mph winds howling, she confesses that her world has changed. She is of an immigrant generation that expected to encounter a benign Britain; a 'civilised' Britain, as characterised by BBC announcers in dinner-jackets, crumpets for tea and the comforting thwack of leather on willow. Quite probably a Britain that never existed, but nonetheless - in her mind - a more reliable Britain than that to which she is currently being exposed: 'England, this is meant to be! I moved to England so I wouldn't have to do this. Never again will I trust that Mr Crab.' 'Amma, it's Mr Fish.' 'From now on, he's Mr Crab to me,' snapped Alansa with a dark look. 'BBC or no BBC.' The depiction of the dysfunctional Chalfen family, while often funny, finally seems too cartoon-like. Marcus and Joyce Chalfen tolerate the foul-mouthed Millat, who rolls joints at their table, drinks their alcohol and generally calls the shots around their house. 'Oh, Millat, don't smoke that stuff. Every time we see you these days you're smoking. It upsets Oscar so much. He's not that young and he understands more than you think. He understands about marijuana.' 'What's mary wana?' asked Oscar. 'You know what it is, Oscar. It's what makes Millat all horrible, like we were talking about today, and it's what kills the little brain cells he has.' 'Get off my fucking back, Joyce.' It is frustrating not to have a more 'substantial' white family at the heart of the novel, for Irie, Millat and Magid are treated by the Chalfens with a degree of patronage that is unsurprising. Their son, Joshua, has a more complicated response to the situation, for Irie is the object of his desire. However, his two-dimensional parents do little more than enliven the more farcical elements of the narrative. There is nothing farcical about the pain of wanting to belong. In this respect, White Teeth is full of false smiles and contrived faces, masks that are repeatedly donned in order to better hide the pain. The 'mongrel' nation that is Britain is still struggling to find a way to stare into the mirror and accept the ebb and flow of history that has produced this fortuitously diverse condition and its concomitant pain. Zadie Smith's first novel is an audaciously assured contribution to this process of staring into the mirror. Her narrator is deeply self-conscious, so much so that one can almost hear the crisp echo of Salman Rushdie's footsteps. However, her wit, her breadth of vision and her ambition are of her own making. The plot is rich, at times dizzyingly so, but White Teeth squares up to the two questions which gnaw at the very roots of our modern condition: Who are we? Why are we here?

webTitle: Journey to the heart of Darcus

fields.headline: Journey to the heart of Darcus
fields.standfirst:
The former Black Panther Darcus Howe has grown to love England since he came here in 1961. But he finds he has more in common with Bernard Manning than with Tony Blair

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: So Bernard Manning asked me, straight up - I was the only black man in the place - where I was from, and I told him, Brixton. He smiled, and said he'd been there once, so he could be my daddy.
fields.body:
So Bernard Manning asked me, straight up - I was the only black man in the place - where I was from, and I told him, Brixton. He smiled, and said he'd been there once, so he could be my daddy.

'And I kind of liked that. It's the same joke black people crack to each other round here. Me and Bernard, we sat and talked afterwards. Warmly. You see, it's dying out, that stuff, it's on its last legs, and I suddenly realised he had just been, all along, a working-class Mancunian telling the jokes they told. And it's over now, all over. We parted friends. I felt a little sorry for him.'

Darcus Howe, one-time Black Panther, has finally made his peace with Bernard Manning, one-time racist git. He has also made his peace with England, the land he has grown to love since coming here from Trinidad in 1961. He hasn't made his peace with authority, and I suspect he never will. One of the fine ironies about the fast-changing nature of England and the English is that this passionate black activist, this stern, sharp, fearless and unforgiving Devil's Advocate, has more time now for Bernard Manning than he does for Tony Blair.

England and the English are what fascinate him these days, and he's been spending the past months travelling round the country trying to find what and who they are, as the tattered flag of 'Britain' drops ever-further. Channel 4's White Tribes series, which opens on Thursday, is an honourable attempt to define the 'ordinary' English person at the turn of the century, and find out what Englishness means to them.

So he travelled. Not to Henley, or Lords, or any of the totemic parts of the mythical green and pleasant land he spent his childhood in Trinidad wondering about, but to a host of ordinary, working-class places, caught in a huge upheaval of transition. 'They are all at an interregnum,' he says. 'The old Britain is dead but nothing is yet taking its place.'

He found, he believes, traces, but sad traces, of a faint rearguard action. 'The older generation are still keeping hold of an idea of England, they still believe. They tell me England is still the greatest country in the world. They say it spitefully, with slightly racist overtones. But that's dying. They're dying. That's not really the spirit of most of England.'

What confuses me, I explain, as we sit, smoking, in the comfy hot shambles of his Brixton front room, is whether he felt they were hanging on to a myth or a reality. 'Oh, definitely a reality. There was a pride in the old England, their England, and some very good bits to it. Apart from the racism, of course. But there was some order, some working-class organisation, some compromise from the bourgeoisie, a belief in the welfare state. All gave Britain a post-war prosperity, and the schooling, too, seemed to make for receptive minds. But that's over. Economics, and politics, have changed it forever.'

He seems saddened, truly saddened, by some of his experiences, particularly the remnants of racism, tied implicitly to economics. 'Racism was much, much worse back then, when I first came across. You couldn't walk the street at night if you were black. We have come a very long way. You should understand that when something is coming to an end, such as racism, it can be much more violent than it was in the beginning - thus Stephen Lawrence.

'I only really saw it badly in two places. I saw it in Oldham, which is now really, really poor. The white people are what they'd call in America "white trash". There are also lots of young Pakistanis, and most of them are making money, wheeling and dealing, wearing the suits - and the hatred from the whites, the real, bitter, twisted hatred. I'd never come across that before. It was a violent hatred. They wanted the Pakistanis physically eliminated.

'And I saw it in Dover, where the refugee row was going on. People told me there were Albanians, Kosovars, wandering the streets smothered in gold, and stocking up at the butcher's every day with their tax money. Ha. I could hardly find any. I found three Kosovar kids, on a bench. They'd lost their father, lost everything, didn't have a hope. And the locals were throw ing stones at them. I cried. I thought "This place has the mark of the Beast."

'So racism still exists in places where the world of work has disappeared, and where there are foreigners somewhere near. In places, this is still a dangerous England. That's partly why this all fascinates me, the way it could go. I'm terrified of a racial backlash in this country. It has always been at the back of my head. And Europe can be a very murderous place.

'But I found so many good things. This is a nice country. There are negatives about the English - the xenophobia, not racism but xenophobia; and that danger of inertia, a lack of sense of adventure, a fear of breaking barriers, being safe; and a certain anti-intellectualism. But there are so many positives. A tremendous literary tradition. Craftsmanship. The notion of work as a dignified activity. Tolerance. Eloquence. Humour. And a great ability to enjoy themselves - if only they were allowed to.

'And it could turn out well, very well, in the future. With the best bits of Englishness, I can see the country as some kind of huge Greek city-state - without the slavery, but with all we can do so well. Leisure, music, art, wit, creativity, dance, writing - all the things that commerce has appropriated and vulgarised. That could be the future. This is what the English people could do.

'But those in power, just now, will never trust them. Look at the Dome stuff last week! There was some stuff in the Mail congratulating the police on keeping the crowds quiet. It's a problem with modern governments. When I first came here the country was being run by landed gentry, Macmillan and the High Tories, who had virtually reached a consensus with Labour. Then there rose a whole new caste; the office-class. Blair, Brown, Thatcher; I don't really separate them. And this new breed, as whenever you're seeking to replace a governmental caste, are not really at ease with the idea of government. And that's why we've had so much either authoritarianism or control-freakery; none of them actually trust the people they're meant to represent.'

His distrust of authority will, it seems, never die; never has done since he fled Trinidad, where his father was a vicar, to escape 'constant constraints' and find an England that gave him freedom.

'The England that is going to come is going to give ordinary people, once more, a sense of their own power. The new England should be completely free of the old constraints. But if Blair thinks he can mould it with words - well, the new doesn't come by declaration, never has done.'

He pauses, and laughs. 'You know, it's just struck me. I'm 56. I'm older than them. You knowI think I know this country more than they do.'

fields.headline: Ford staff threaten strike
fields.trailText: Leaders of salaried staff at Ford are threatening strikes because the carmaker has agreed to give production line workers effective pay rises of 15 per cent over three years - 4 per cent more than the white-collar employees will get.
fields.body:
Leaders of salaried staff at Ford are threatening strikes because the carmaker has agreed to give production line workers effective pay rises of 15 per cent over three years - 4 per cent more than the white-collar employees will get.

Unions claim strike action by up to 7,000 staff could halt Ford production in Britain within days of it starting.

The threat comes on top of a spate of industrial relations problems for Ford, including walk-outs over racism at its Dagenham plant, and industrial action by toolmakers during negotiations over last year's deal.

The Manufacturing Science and Finance Union and the Transport and General Workers Union's salaried section, ACTS, will ballot their members on 19 January. The result will be announced on 3 February.

The manual workers' deal was made up of an 11 per cent pay rise plus a reduction in working week from 39 to 37.5 hours. This effectively works out at a 15 per cent rise. The salaried workers got the 11 per cent, but no reduction in working hours. Although many of the white-collar workers have been on 37.5 hour contracts, they believe their responsibilities and workloads have increased. They are demanding either an extra increase in salary or a reduction in hours to make their offer comparable with the manual deal.

The MSF and ACTS staff manage production, run Ford's internal logistics and financial services and develop new models. They are based in all UK Ford plants as well as at the firm's design centre at Dunton, Essex.

An MSF source said: 'Our members feel that they have been unfairly dealt with, and that the differential between them and the manual workers has narrowed. They want the differential back.'

A Ford spokesman said: 'We made the final offer last year. Given the business climate that faces Ford, we believe it is a fair offer.'
