fields.headline: Painful memories of the Troubles
fields.trailText: I have spent the long millennial wake immersed in a quite extraordinary book.
fields.body:
I have spent the long millennial wake immersed in a quite extraordinary book. It is not fiction, though it is full of heartrending stories, any one of which might provide a gifted writer with the bare bones of a shattering novel. It is not biography, though it is full of ordinary people's lives. It is not really journalism, though it has been compiled by four journalists who may, collectively, have just written the book of their career.

It is, in fact, that most disparaged genre, contemporary history, the essential first draft of some terrible events to which, in years to come, professional historians, poets, novelists and biographers will surely turn for the unvarnished truth.

Lost Lives (Mainstream £25, pp 1,630) is also a book that has had scant review attention, apart from in The Observer, which wrote about it in November last year. Perhaps its stark subtitle and colossal length were too off-putting: 'The stories of the men, women and children who died as a result of the Northern Ireland Troubles'.

Between 1966 and 1999, 3,636 lives were lost in the Troubles and Lost Lives contains a brief record of every one: name, date of death, location, profession, religion, age and marital status, together with a brief summary of the circumstances of the particular death.

The authors of this massive memorial are David McKittrick of the Independent, Seamus Kelters of the BBC, and two respected Belfast journalists, Brian Feeney and Chris Thornton. They write that they 'shed tears while researching and writing' this work. You would have to have a heart of stone to be unmoved by some of the stories uncovered here.

Consider the case of 11-year-old Alan McCrum (no relation) who was killed on 15 March 1982 by a no-warning car-bomb left by the IRA in the centre of Banbridge, one of a total of 34 people injured in the explosion. The Protestant schoolboy had been waiting for a friend to give him a lift home. His grieving father was reported as saying: 'It's terrible that a wee lad coming home from school should be mowed down in such a horrible way. What purpose is there in this? It's senseless. This will not be the last though, I'm sure. It will go on and on.'

And go on and on it did, piling senseless killing on pointless slaughter, in a danse macabre that should, perhaps, have found some memorial amid the festivities of the past weekend. The senselessness of the killing in Ulster, in fact, is one great theme that the four authors identify in their introduction.

There were, too, terrible moments of fateful farce in which the 'wrong' people died. A nine-year-old Derry boy, playing cowboys with his brother in the garden, stumbled over a tripwire and set off a bomb which killed him. A man burst into a house in Belfast, shot dead the occupant and then exclaimed: 'Christ, I'm in the wrong house.' Elsewhere, a dying man says to his wife: 'The bastards; why did they shoot me? I'm not in anything.'

Lost Lives shows that while the great majority of the killing was done by republican groups and loyalist paramilitary organisations, the deepest source of resentment and sense of injustice is to be found among the several hundred families which lost members at the hands of the security forces.

There is not space to do justice to the scholarly comprehensiveness, the magisterial evenhandedness or the moral integrity of this astonishing book. Now that the Troubles seem to be over, the publication of Lost Lives is perhaps the great monument for which the bloody history of Northern Ireland has been waiting.

robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk
Buy it at BOL

fields.headline: There's no time to waste
fields.standfirst: Management:  Can trendy 'natural capitalism' really save the planet?
fields.trailText: Natural Capitalism - The Next Industrial Revolution 'proves beyond argument that there are presently available technologies, and those just on the horizon, which will permit us to get richer by cleaning, not by spoiling, the environment'.
fields.body:
Over the past few months, President Clinton has lost few opportunities to sing the praises of his favourite book. In November, he told a conference attended by Tony Blair that it was no longer necessary to choose between growth and environment. He took as evidence Natural Capitalism - The Next Industrial Revolution (Paul Hawken and Amory and Hunter Lovins, Earthscan, £18.99), which 'proves beyond argument that there are presently available technologies, and those just on the horizon, which will permit us to get richer by cleaning, not by spoiling, the environment. This is a huge deal,' Clinton said.

It's a suitably millennial claim. The authors argue that 'capitalism, as practised, is a financially profitable, nonsustainable aberration in human development ... [which] does not fully conform to its own accounting principles. It liquidates its capital and calls it income. It neglects to assign any value to the largest stocks of capital it employs - the natural resources and living systems, as well as the social and cultural systems that are the basis of human capital.'

Companies, as has been well said, are brilliant externalising machines - pocketing the profits and shunting the costs of their enterprise on to the collectivity. Thus, the NHS pays for the profits of big tobacco, and the Government subsidises cars by building roads. Put it another way, business is a free rider on the environment and the services it provides, services which have been tentatively valued by Nature magazine at $36 trillion annually, roughly the same as world GDP.

The reason business is so profligate with the the environment (the 'natural capital' of the book) is that its goods are assumed by economists to be free and infinitely substitutable. So they are uncosted. But in reality they are not free. They are produced by the earth's 3.8-billion-year store of natural capital which, as the authors rehearse with hair-raising thoroughness, is being eroded so fast that by the end of this century there will be little left. And there is no conceivable substitute, for example, for the biosphere's ability to produce oxygen.

The authors manage to recast this rush to disaster as a story with a (potentially) happier ending. Their grounds for optimism are partly familiar American technological optimism - if natural resources were treated as scarce and expensive, then nanotechnology and biotechnology could multiply four or even tenfold the outputs from today's inputs. Hence Clinton's enthusiasm.

But more crucial to the project is a complete mental flip of what an 'output' consists of (as Edwin Land once said, a great idea is often 'not having a new thought but stopping having an old one').

At present, it is entirely conceivable that one-quarter or even half of the GDP of advanced countries makes not value but waste. Most industrial processes, and the economy as a whole, are inefficient - at best achieving 10 per cent of their potential; likewise their products. A car uses just 1 per cent of the energy it burns to propel the driver, the rest to warm the atmosphere, deafen pedestrians and shift ponderous steel boxes between traffic jams.

Moreover, waste is cumulative, so an increasing income has to be spent on alleviating growth's byproducts - pollution, traffic accidents and congestion, crime. Hence the phenomenon of uneconomic growth, where increases in nominal wealth produce no net gain in quality of life or standard of living: in real terms 80 per cent of Americans are no better off than they were in 1979.

However, the grossness of the waste is, say the authors, also a measure of the huge potential for improvement if the spiral changed to virtuous. The secret is taking a systems view in which it is always more expensive to get rid of waste than to design it out in the first place. Given the wastefulness of most current systems, improvements of 10 to 100 times in overall efficiency are possible even with existing technology.

Much of what the Lovins and Hawken propose is not new. Frances Cairncross wrote about costing the earth 10 years ago, and Richard Schonberger coined the term 'frugal manufacturing' in the 1980s. What is new is the way these ideas are brought together in a systems approach to business and the environment, and the coopting of markets as the mechanism which can be used to turn things around.

There is some irony here, of course. The greatest obstacle to 'natural capitalism' in practice will be the vested interests and special pleading of those most vociferous champions of capitalist orthodoxy, US com panies, which emerge from this book the masters of the perverse, not to mention grotesque, hidden subsidy - whether of agriculture, cars, or their wealthy executives.

Persuading them to confront their own bad faith will be no easy matter. But, as someone once said, the economy is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the environment, and time is running out for the parent to bring it to heel.

Tomes of influence

The Wealth of Nations, Adam Smith (1776). Smith's sprawling masterpiece is the most quoted, though least often read, book of economics.

Das Kapital, Karl Marx (1867). Also largely unread, even when fashionable, Marx's critique of capitalism lost its talismanic power with the fall of the Soviet Union.

The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money, J.M. Keynes (1936. The best-written and most brilliantly expounded economics treatise.

The Road to Serfdom, Friedrich von Hayek (1944). Hayek argued that the smallest step away from classical economic orthodoxy led to socialism. Hayek ended up in Chicago, where he was succeeded in influence by ...

Freedom to Choose, Milton and Rose Friedman (1980). High priest of monetarism, Chicago's Friedman was the guru of Reaganomics and Thatcherism.
fields.bodyText: Over the past few months, President Clinton has lost few opportunities to sing the praises of his favourite book. In November, he told a conference attended by Tony Blair that it was no longer necessary to choose between growth and environment. He took as evidence Natural Capitalism - The Next Industrial Revolution (Paul Hawken and Amory and Hunter Lovins, Earthscan, £18.99), which 'proves beyond argument that there are presently available technologies, and those just on the horizon, which will permit us to get richer by cleaning, not by spoiling, the environment. This is a huge deal,' Clinton said. It's a suitably millennial claim. The authors argue that 'capitalism, as practised, is a financially profitable, nonsustainable aberration in human development ... [which] does not fully conform to its own accounting principles. It liquidates its capital and calls it income. It neglects to assign any value to the largest stocks of capital it employs - the natural resources and living systems, as well as the social and cultural systems that are the basis of human capital.' Companies, as has been well said, are brilliant externalising machines - pocketing the profits and shunting the costs of their enterprise on to the collectivity. Thus, the NHS pays for the profits of big tobacco, and the Government subsidises cars by building roads. Put it another way, business is a free rider on the environment and the services it provides, services which have been tentatively valued by Nature magazine at $36 trillion annually, roughly the same as world GDP. The reason business is so profligate with the the environment (the 'natural capital' of the book) is that its goods are assumed by economists to be free and infinitely substitutable. So they are uncosted. But in reality they are not free. They are produced by the earth's 3.8-billion-year store of natural capital which, as the authors rehearse with hair-raising thoroughness, is being eroded so fast that by the end of this century there will be little left. And there is no conceivable substitute, for example, for the biosphere's ability to produce oxygen. The authors manage to recast this rush to disaster as a story with a (potentially) happier ending. Their grounds for optimism are partly familiar American technological optimism - if natural resources were treated as scarce and expensive, then nanotechnology and biotechnology could multiply four or even tenfold the outputs from today's inputs. Hence Clinton's enthusiasm. But more crucial to the project is a complete mental flip of what an 'output' consists of (as Edwin Land once said, a great idea is often 'not having a new thought but stopping having an old one'). At present, it is entirely conceivable that one-quarter or even half of the GDP of advanced countries makes not value but waste. Most industrial processes, and the economy as a whole, are inefficient - at best achieving 10 per cent of their potential; likewise their products. A car uses just 1 per cent of the energy it burns to propel the driver, the rest to warm the atmosphere, deafen pedestrians and shift ponderous steel boxes between traffic jams. Moreover, waste is cumulative, so an increasing income has to be spent on alleviating growth's byproducts - pollution, traffic accidents and congestion, crime. Hence the phenomenon of uneconomic growth, where increases in nominal wealth produce no net gain in quality of life or standard of living: in real terms 80 per cent of Americans are no better off than they were in 1979. However, the grossness of the waste is, say the authors, also a measure of the huge potential for improvement if the spiral changed to virtuous. The secret is taking a systems view in which it is always more expensive to get rid of waste than to design it out in the first place. Given the wastefulness of most current systems, improvements of 10 to 100 times in overall efficiency are possible even with existing technology. Much of what the Lovins and Hawken propose is not new. Frances Cairncross wrote about costing the earth 10 years ago, and Richard Schonberger coined the term 'frugal manufacturing' in the 1980s. What is new is the way these ideas are brought together in a systems approach to business and the environment, and the coopting of markets as the mechanism which can be used to turn things around. There is some irony here, of course. The greatest obstacle to 'natural capitalism' in practice will be the vested interests and special pleading of those most vociferous champions of capitalist orthodoxy, US com panies, which emerge from this book the masters of the perverse, not to mention grotesque, hidden subsidy - whether of agriculture, cars, or their wealthy executives. Persuading them to confront their own bad faith will be no easy matter. But, as someone once said, the economy is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the environment, and time is running out for the parent to bring it to heel. webTitle: Robinson book set to be shelved

fields.headline: Robinson book set to be shelved
fields.standfirst: Geoffrey Robinson's plans to publish a revealing account of his life as a Minister, including details of his controversial house loan to Peter Mandelson, now look set to be shelved
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Robinson's plans to publish a revealing account of his life as a Minister, including details of his controversial house loan to Peter Mandelson, now look set to be shelved
fields.body:
Geoffrey Robinson's plans to publish a revealing account of his life as a Minister, including details of his controversial house loan to Peter Mandelson, now look set to be shelved.

The change of heart follows discussions with his publishers, who appear to be disappointed that the book is not going to be as full of damaging disclosures as first imagined.

Robinson, the former Treasury Paymaster General, has been under discreet private pressure from Downing Street, especially from Tony Blair's personal assistant, to dilute the contents of what had been billed as potentially one of the most explosive political memoirs of recent times. Downing Street is desperate not to reopen old wounds surrounding the loan that led to the resignation of Mandelson and Robinson nearly a year ago.

Robinson has insisted that the book was intended to be a relatively dry account of his role as a Treasury Minister, including his part in launching the Private Finance Initiative or salvaging parts of the coal industry. The publishers had been hoping for an account of Cabinet battles and the rivalries between the Chancellor Gordon Brown and Peter Mandelson.

Briefings, either from the publishers or the Robinson circle, suggested the book would be a lurid look at Cabinet struggles, personal betrayal and high finance.

Robinson's reluctance to mount a frontal disclosure may have been affected by the collapse of TransTec, the engineering firm which he chaired until the 1997 General Election. Although any legal action against Robinson would not be initiated by Ministers, it would hardly be politically astute for Robinson to be lambasting the Government when his financial affairs were under scrutiny.

Arthur Andersen, the accounting firm, was appointed TransTec's receivers on 30 December by a group of lenders believed to be owed about £70m.

Subsequently, it emerged that Ford Motors submitted a claim for more than £10.9m when the group was still chaired by Robinson.

No mention of the claim was made when in the summer of 1996 Transtec launched a £57.6m rights issue to buy BSK, a Midlands-based engineering firm.

webTitle: Fund the NHS to the full

fields.headline: Fund the NHS to the full
fields.trailText: Labour was elected to make a difference, but so far the differences are slight. After 30 months of New Labour, most public services are creaking at the seams, just as they did under the Tories. Even right-wing, monetarist City economists shake their heads at the ultra-Gladstonian principals of finance upon which New Labour is founded, and worry that the extraordinary scale of the budget surpluses the Government is now creating are becoming a major economic distortion in themselves. The economy needs a steady supply of government bonds so that savers can have a balanced portfolio of investment options; the supply has dried up and the national debt is set to dwindle alarmingly quickly.
fields.body:
Labour was elected to make a difference, but so far the differences are slight. After 30 months of New Labour, most public services are creaking at the seams, just as they did under the Tories. Even right-wing, monetarist City economists shake their heads at the ultra-Gladstonian principals of finance upon which New Labour is founded, and worry that the extraordinary scale of the budget surpluses the Government is now creating are becoming a major economic distortion in themselves. The economy needs a steady supply of government bonds so that savers can have a balanced portfolio of investment options; the supply has dried up and the national debt is set to dwindle alarmingly quickly.

The other side of this coin is a cash-starved public sector, notably the National Health Service, now uppermost in voter concerns. On top of the seasonal demonstration of lack of beds in the middle of a flu epidemic, there is growing concern that the NHS lacks the capacity to screen and prevent the mounting incidence of cancer, as revealed in statistics released last week. And an internal report by the Public Health Genetics Unit circulating in Whitehall warns that the revolution in gene science and the accompanying medical remedies will be so costly that they will 'impinge with devastating significance on clinical practice'. It says all options for the future funding of the NHS must be considered.

But the NHS has never been properly backed. There are more than 30,000 avoidable deaths annually, a figure that receives too little publicity. This slaughter, with which the Government connives, is a disgrace. It is the direct result of spending 1 per cent of GDP less on health than the international average - equivalent to some £9 billion a year - and of the NHS having negligible accountability, so that the results of its rationing are disguised from the public. Both must change.

This does not mean that the NHS has to introduce private insurance, the stock response from private-sector lobbyists and their allies in the right-wing press. The advances of gene technology, so that every individual's predisposition to certain illnesses will be predictable from their gene structure, means that private insurance will be prohibitively expensive for those individuals who most need financial support. What insurance company will offer insurance to individuals whose gene make-up guarantees that they will make expensive medical claims? The only viable form of future finance for the NHS is general taxation and social insurance.

The Treasury is in a financial position to raise spending on the NHS while retaining its ultra-Gladstonian financial position. New Labour has the chance to put the NHS on a firm financial footing for the first time in its history. It must seize the moment.

fields.headline: Flu epidemic exposes NHS crisis
fields.standfirst: Painful consequences of past cuts push beleaguered hospitals to breaking point
fields.trailText: The handset is barely replaced on the phone when the ringing starts up again. Staff at NHS Direct call centres across the country are at the sharp end of the flu crisis that has been engulfing the country. In a normal month they take around 100,000 calls; in the past two weeks alone they have taken 209,000.
fields.byline: by Tracy McVeigh and Anthony Browne
fields.body:
The handset is barely replaced on the phone when the ringing starts up again. Staff at NHS Direct call centres across the country are at the sharp end of the flu crisis that has been engulfing the country. In a normal month they take around 100,000 calls; in the past two weeks alone they have taken 209,000.

'It's been incredibly busy,' said a spokeswoman. 'A lot of it's about flu. Many people have been phoning NHS Direct rather than go to their GPs, and then they've been treating themselves if necessary. But if it's serious they may need an ambulance.'

NHS Direct is not the only place where the phones have not stopped. The ambulance service has seen a 25 per cent increase on calls compared to the same period last year.

The crisis - which the Government has warned is set to turn into the first full-blown flu epidemic since 1989 - has stretched the NHS almost to breaking point and sometimes beyond. The flu has been particularly bad in Wales, the north of England, and Scotland.

Many of those getting the flu have been elderly, for whom it is a serious and often life-threatening disease. Most hospitals in the country have quite simply run out of intensive-care beds in which to put them - or patients with other conditions.

A pensioner died last week after he was ferried between three hospitals following major heart surgery when no bed could be found for him. Harold Smith, 74, died 200 miles from his home in Ross-on-Wye near Hereford after a desperate five-hour search for an intensive-care bed. The Government now insists his death was due to human error rather than a shortage of beds.

Last week at Bromley Hospital in Kent, 30 patients waited overnight in the hospital for beds. One member of staff described the scene as chaotic: 'Some were in cubicles, some were in side rooms and some were in operating theatres which were not being used.'

In East Sussex, a refrigerated lorry is being used as a makeshift morgue after a hospital's mortuary filled up with patients. Eastbourne Hospital had to place 60 bodies in the lorry after the number of deaths over Christmas and New Year was triple that of the same period last year.

At Winchester's Royal County Hospital, Hampshire, the lack of nurses was so severe that medical chiefs ordered ex-employees to be contacted and asked to come back in. Admissions doubled, and the hospital asked all staff to cancel their leave. Many other hospitals are coping by cancelling all but the most urgent of operations.

The severity of the flu outbreak has meant that the NHS winter crisis - a depressingly regular annual event - is much worse that normal. Hospitals do all they can to plan for it, but there is little doubt among most medical professionals that health policy is making it worse each year.

Much of it is due to so-called 'efficiency-savings'. London alone has lost 40 per cent of its acute beds since 1982, a figure that is reflected nationally. The number of hospitals with accident and emergency departments in London has also fallen from 47 in 1981 to 31 now.

Elizabeth Manero, chair of community health watchdog London Health Link, said: 'The NHS appears quite simply to have shrunk - shrunk too far to be able to cope with the predictable periods when more people are likely to need its services.'

Hospitals are now running almost permanently at close to full capacity. A decade ago, occupancy rates for beds were around 75 per cent, whereas now they are running at more than 95 per cent. It is also increasingly difficult for hospitals to discharge elderly patients because of a shortage of nursing homes for them to go to.

Stephen Thornton, the chief executive of the NHS Confederation - which represents hospital trusts - said: 'It all adds up to the inevitability of a January crisis. Occupancy rates are so high, that when hospitals do get a burst of activity they can't cope. The Government is doing nothing to prevent it happening next year.'

Hospitals are doing the best they can, insisted Thornton, but they just can't cope. 'It's an embarrassment to the people I represent,' he said. 'It is just not an acceptable level of modern healthcare.'

The crisis has also been made worse because high-risk groups, including the elderly, have not been going to their GP for the flu vaccine which is available.The Public Health Laboratory Service has identified a 'clear need to increase uptake of influenza vaccine in high-risk patients, particularly those aged less than 65 years.'

A few hospitals have been-successful in pre-empting the crisis. Northwick Hospital in Middlesex arranged a house-to-house leaflet campaign to warn everyone of the dangers of flu and what measures to take. It has paid off with the hospital being one of the few to cope well with flu cases.

But it is not up to hospitals alone, and many doctors blame the Government for inaction. The British Medical Association in Scotland has slammed the Scottish Executive for ignoring their warnings months ago about the need for preventative vaccination for at-risk groups.

Dr John Garner, the chairman of the BMA's Scottish Council, blamed the crisis on the Scottish Executive. He said the BMA had urged the executive to vaccinate over-75s and other groups months ago, but this had been ignored.

'Government short-sightedness has meant people who should be at home are instead lying in hospital, while patients who should be in hospital are instead forced to wait and worry at home.'

webTitle: NHS crisis as flu grips Britain

fields.headline: NHS crisis as flu grips Britain
fields.trailText: Britain is in the grip of a serious flu epidemic, the Government has declared. The outbreak is forcing hospitals to cancel thousands of urgent operations and is leading to an overcrowding crisis amid scenes of chaos in wards.
fields.byline: by Patrick Wintour, Tracy McVeigh and Anthony Browne
fields.body:
Britain is in the grip of a serious flu epidemic, the Government has declared. The outbreak is forcing hospitals to cancel thousands of urgent operations and is leading to an overcrowding crisis amid scenes of chaos in wards.

The last epidemic 10 years ago claimed 26,000 lives. The current outbreak has already stretched many hospitals to breaking point and led to an acute shortage of intensive-care beds as elderly patients become critically ill and medical staff fall sick. There are even plans for some patients to be sent to France for treatment.

Liam Donaldson, Chief Medical Officer, last night revealed there were probably twice as many people suffering from flu as official figures suggest, and declared: 'It is a serious flu epidemic.' Government figures out tomorrow will show that the official number of cases rose last week by more than 50 per cent to 200 per 100,000.

But Donaldson believes changes in the health service mean the official figures significantly under-report the real scale of the flu, and that the true figure is likely to be 300 per 100,000 - meaning, by one definition, that it is classed as an epidemic.

The Public Health Laboratory Service, the government body that monitors the spread of influenza, has warned hospitals that this week is likely to be worse than last. A PHLS spokesman said: 'We're coming towards the peak, and this week may well be higher than last, but we don't know what level it's going to reach.'

St Thomas' Hospital in London will tomorrow start cancelling non-urgent operations. Ruth Russell, the duty manager, said: 'Our concern is not for today because we can just about cope with emergency admissions but for the urgent operations scheduled for the next few weeks. Our first task is to look at admissions for operations and see which must be cancelled. We won't actually know until then if we can get any in.'

St Thomas' has had to refuse to take patients from other hospitals across London, and as far afield as Swindon and Oxford, which are trying to cope with shortages. Sickness among patients at St Thomas' has exacerbated staff shortages. More than 30 per cent of its intensive care nursing posts are unfilled.

The Royal Infirmary in Edinburgh this weekend cancelled all non-urgent operations, putting itself on red alert after receiving more than 1,000 admissions in one week - 300 more than its previous record high. All its intensive care beds are full, and it has had to transfer intensive care patients to other units in the hospital.

'It's almost all due to flu and respiratory illness,' said Charles Swainson, the medical director. 'This year the scale of the problem has been worse than anticipated. We're cancelling major operations and minor ones. We're only taking urgent and emergency operations such as heart disease and cancer.'

Addenbrookes Hospital in Cambridge has also run out of intensive care beds, and has had to transfer patients to hospitals elsewhere in East Anglia. A spokeswoman for Royal Hallamshire Hospital in Sheffield said: 'We're absolutely full - we don't have a single spare bed in intensive care.'

Usually intensive care beds are split 50-50 between surgical cases and emergencies, but Glasgow Royal Infirmary says virtually all its beds are now for respiratory illnesses.

Private hospitals have offered to help ease the intensive care crisis by leasing beds to the NHS, an idea backed by Tory health spokesman Dr Liam Fox. But Health Secretary Alan Milburn insisted the NHS was coping: 'Any patient who needs intensive care will get it.'

Seven black citizens have died in police custody in the past two years after being 'restrained'. Their families are asking why - but still await answers

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Next Tuesday the family of Roger Sylvester will gather outside Tottenham Police Station for a vigil in his memory. As they light candles and say prayers, they could be forgiven for wondering when their struggle will end. fields.body:
Next Tuesday the family of Roger Sylvester will gather outside Tottenham Police Station for a vigil in his memory. As they light candles and say prayers, they could be forgiven for wondering when their struggle will end. It is a year since the violent arrest that led, eight days later, to the 30-year-old administrative worker's death in hospital. They still do not know what happened that cold January night. 'We're a big family so we can give each other support,' says his brother Bernard. 'I don't know how we'd have got through the ordeal otherwise.'

The Sylvesters are unlikely to take comfort from the fact they are just one of a number of black families fighting for the truth. An Observer investigation has found that black detainees are five times more likely than whites to die in police custody, if subjected to the sort of action experienced by Roger Sylvester during their arrest .

The majority of deaths in police custody are due to suicide or drunkenness. Overall, black deaths represent 9 per cent of the whole, greatly out of proportion considering they make up 1.8 per cent of the population. Police sources have long argued that this is because a disproportionate number of black people pass through police custody.

In a significant number of cases the death is unconnected with suicide or drunkenness, but instead follows arrest procedures by the officers involved, such as physical restraint or the use of CS spray. The Observer's study, which looked at cases covering the years 1997 to 1999, has found that more than 43 per cent of black deaths in custody are in this category. Only 8 per cent of white people die in such circumstances.

The findings will make dismal reading for police forces across Britain which, in the age of the Stephen Lawrence Inquiry and the Macpherson Report, are meant to be racially aware. They show no improvement from the dark days of the early and mid-Nineties when the deaths in police custody of Joy Gardner, Wayne Douglas, Brian Douglas (no relation) and Shiji Lapite as a result of suffocation under police restraint drew sharp criticism of police relations with the black community. Britain's ethnic minorities have the right to expect better.

Our study has identified seven black deaths out of 17 between 1997 and 1999 which followed police action. The figures are completely consistent with a Home Office report covering the years 1990 to 1996 which associated nine out of 19 black deaths in police custody with behaviour by the officers involved. In the Home Office report no attempt was made to apportion blame, only to identify cases where actions of police officers appeared to be relevant in the death of a victim. We used the same criteria.

Criminal charges against police officers are pending in one of the cases from our study. The Police Complaints Authority are investigating a further two. In the remaining four, no further investigations are being conducted and no charges have been brought against any officers. That does not mean the families have had all their questions answered, however. All of them want to know what happened. All of them want to know if the deaths could have been avoided.

The most high profile case is Roger Sylvester's. He was arrested outside his home in North London by eight police officers after reports that a naked man had been seen in the dead of night, banging on doors and rolling on the ground. According to one account, he was bundled into a police van and taken to St. Ann's Hospital, a nearby psychiatric unit, where he was placed, still naked, in the custody of five police officers. A doctor came to assess his condition, then left the room to get a sedative. When she returned Roger had gone limp. Attempts were made to revive him but he never regained consciousness. He was eventually transferred to the Whittington Hospital where, on 18 January 1999, his life support machine was turned off and he was pronounced dead.

At one point police sources told journalists that callers to the police that night had described him as 'aggressive'. The police later withdrew the allegation, saying Roger had committed no criminal offence that night, and an apology to the family was issued. Today the case is still the subject of an investigation by the Essex Constabulary on behalf of the Police Complaints Authority and a file has been sent to the Crown Prosecution Service for review.

'It seems to me that there is a pattern to these things,' his brother Bernard now says. 'A person dies during arrest and the police then use the media to blame the victim. Everything goes to an inquest, no prosecution takes place and that's just about it. The process is very time consum ing and we've come to the conclusion that it's designed to wear us down.'

Part of their problem has been gaining access to information and reports held by the investigating officers, despite the issuing of guidelines by the Home Office earlier last year instructing them to co-operate more readily with families of victims.

The Sylvester's pathologist has now been allowed access to the report prepared by the pathologist for Essex Police, but they are determined not to reduce the pressure they are placing on the authorities, hence next week's vigil. 'We want people to know that we're still here,' says Bernard. 'We want people to know that we haven't gone away.'

Part of the problem in establishing exactly what happened to Roger is the medical arguments surrounding the use of restraint by law enforcement officers and whether it can be solely responsible for a death.

Professor Bernard Knight, 68, is a former Professor of Forensic Pathology at the University of Cardiff. Widely regarded as an expert in pathological signs of restraint, Knight says doctors and coroners find indicators of restraint hard to determine.

'You can't say someone died from excessive restraint when there are no witnesses. There have been cases were people were hog-tied and forced face-down onto the ground. That has meant that some people couldn't breathe. In other cases, alcohol is a contributing factor that further obstructs the assessment of doctors examining the victims.

'Most of these cases are hard to pinpoint simply because of the delays in coroner's reports,' he says.

'It's a very slow moving process that understandably aggravates the families of the victims. Yes there are guidelines with restraint: people are not supposed to be held on the ground face-down for any longer than five minutes. But in the heat of the moment, how can that be regulated? And how does a coroner pick up the signs?'

The Sylvester family have some idea of what happened to Roger. The family of Sarah Thomas, a 35-year-old architectural design student at North London University, have almost none. She was arrested using restraint last August in North London for what has been described as a minor public order offence. By the time she reached hospital she was in a coma. She later died there. 'We are still waiting to ascertain exactly what occurred on that night,' says Fiona Murphy, solicitor for Ms Thomas' family, who has wide experience of death in custody cases. 'It's clear to us that the authorities are still failing to grasp the nettle of accountability and transparency in the investigation process.'

Little can be said about the exact details of Christopher Alder's death, as it is the subject of a forthcoming criminal case. He died in Hull police station on 1 April, 1998, where he was taken after being arrested for breach of the peace. On arrival he was found to be unconscious. Nearly two years after his death, he has yet to be buried: a preliminary inquest is set for later this summer.

'I find the attitude of the police incredible,' says his sister, Janet. 'After his death, I spoke to the police who acted like they didn't care. We live in a predominantly white area around here, yet as an act of sympathy they sent out a black liaison officer to speak to us: something I found deeply patronising. And you begin to wonder just how long it will take to get any justice: coming on to two years from his death, his body is being kept in storage.'

Peter San Pedro, 25, of Wood Green in North London, was taken to Kent and Canterbury Hospital in April 1997. He died of injuries sustained when he ran in front of traffic on the A2 motorway in Kent. In his final hours, he was subjected to CS spray by police officers during an arrest though he was later released. His family claim he was disorientated when he crossed the road: at an inquest in December 1997, a police-appointed doctor said he had given San Pedro a visual check-up and pronounced him fit for release.

'CS gas, like the use of restraint, is another factor that needs to be examined,' says Judy Kennish, the San Pedro family's solicitor. 'There hasn't been enough research done into the way it is used, and how victims cope with the effects afterwards.'

Hoosen Aubeeluck, of Mauritian descent, died at Wexham Park Hospital in Slough in September 1998. He had gone to the hospital for an appointment with a consultant who told him he had cancer. He became agitated on learning his diagnosis and began damaging hospital equipment. Police were called and they restrained him during which time he collapsed, and later died. His death was attributed to natural causes.

In April 1997 police officers in Redruth, Cornwall went to interview an unnamed man of Australian Aboriginal descent in connection with theft. The man threatened the officer with a knife. When colleagues arrived to provide support the officers restrained the man, who was later found to have a stab wound to his leg. He died at the scene.

Finally in May 1997 police in Berkshire assisted the medical services in restraining Darren Baverstock, who had taken an overdose of amphetamines. He later collapsed and died. An inquest ruled his death accidental and attrib uted it to amphetamine poisoning.

Acccording to campaigners the real problem for families of victims is that they have little or no access to resources to help them find out exactly what happened. The Macpherson Report following the Lawrence Inquiry recommended that families be granted legal aid to enable them to be represented at coroner's inquests, possibly the only tribunal at which the exact circumstances of a death in custody will ever be established. Shortly after publication of the report the Home Secretary announced that legal aid would be granted to families for such inquests in 'exceptional circumstances' but this, in fact, was no change; the granting of public funds had always been in the gift of the Lord Chancellor.

'In a lot of cases where we don't know what happened we may only find out more if families are allowed legal aid,' says Helen Shaw of Inquest, the organisation which campaigns for the families of people who have died in the custody of the state. 'What we really want is a review of all the procedures surrounding the investigation of deaths in custody. The relationship between the Police Complaints Authority, the Crown Prosecution Service and the Coroner's Court is very unclear.' She also criticises the continuing lack of disclosure of documents to families by police officers investigating suspicious deaths.

There is no central database bringing together the figures for deaths in police custody alongside those in prisons and care units. Establishing the cause of a death inside mental institutions, for example, is particularly hard. The Mental Health Act Commission (MHAC), set up by the Department of Health in 1983, has no figures for deaths by restraint in psychiatric care around the UK. A report covering 1997-98 highlighted 374 deaths, 81 of them attributed to unnatural causes.

A new report is being compiled for May, says MGHAC chief executive William Bingley. 'It's hard to draw conclusions from general numbers. We can pin these down to hanging, patients jumping off buildings or being run over by cars. But the backgrounds to the deaths cannot be conclusive. Anything drawn from the numbers will always be speculative.'

The death of David 'Rocky' Bennett, who was black, is a case in point. He was certified dead in the early hours of Saturday, 31 October 1998. He spent the majority of his adult life in psychiatric care; he was a patient at the Norvic medium secure unit in Norwich at the time of his death. That night he was involved in a violent incident with another patient. His family was told that Bennett had been restrained by a group of nurses. Over a year later, an inquest is still awaiting a police investigation.

His sister, Dr Joanna Bennett, 43, is a clinical psychologist. She blames inadequate nursing for his death; the guidelines that regulate restraint in prisons and police cells aren't as yet applied to institutional care. 'David became very disillusioned because he felt he was being slowly institutionalised, despite all his protests. We watched him turn from someone who was very intelligent and enthusiastic, to someone incredibly frustrated by his treatment. He would only ever be discharged once marked symptom-free - but those symptoms were never diagnosed. All he felt - and we saw - was the prescription of more drugs for his responses.'

She voices a complaint common to those involved with deaths in custody: frustration with waiting for the system to provide answers. 'We're still no clearer on what exactly happened with Rocky,' she says. 'Sometimes it feels as if only the family are interested in finding out the facts. You find yourself having to go around knocking on walls to get the answers yourself. If I left it to the authorities, I'd never get to the bottom of it.'

Families of the victims of deaths in police custody wonder if they will ever succeed in their quest. A spokesman for the Home Office said the Government was committed to dealing with the problem. 'Deaths in custody and any racial imbalance involved is something we take very seriously. It's absolutely crucial that the right kind of restraint techniques are used and to that end training of police officers has been stepped up. There are also checks and balances in place to make sure proper investigations are carried out.'

These are good words. But they do not help the bereft families. They are left with three questions: How did their loved one die? Why did they die? And did the colour of their skin have anything to do with it? They look so simple written down like that, so straightforward. But where deaths in police custody are concerned, nothing ever is.

fields.headline: Smile - you're on candid camera
fields.standfirst: Wonderland, Michael Winterbottom's latest movie, pushes realism to new extremes, involving 'ordinary' Londoners in the shoot - without their knowledge.  Damon Wise asks if that's a clever move or plain intrusive
fields.trailText: Wonderland , Michael Winterbottom's latest movie, pushes realism to new extremes, involving 'ordinary' Londoners in the shoot - without their knowledge. Damon Wise asks if that's a clever move or plain intrusive
fields.body:
Some years ago, Canadian actress Molly Parker was playing a prostitute in a TV show. As she recalls, she looked the part - 'halter top, miniskirt, knee-length boots' - as she lounged on a street corner, chewing gum and looking out into the middle distance with dead-eyed boredom. Suddenly a car pulled to a halt and the driver beckoned her over. She does not remember much about him except that he was deeply average, just an ordinary, middle-class, middle-aged man, but she does remember the two empty child safety seats in the back.

Walking cautiously over to him, Parker leaned over and whispered something that made his blood run cold: 'I'd get out of here, if I were you. You're being filmed.' And with that, she motioned to a camera crew sta tioned across the road, close enough to get the naturalistic shot they wanted and far enough to be unobtrusive to the careless kerb crawler. The driver panicked and hit the accelerator, making a dramatic U-turn. Parker does not know exactly what he said to the crew but she found out later that he was almost in tears of desperation, begging for the film, offering money if they promised to destroy it. 'I almost felt sorry for him,' she says with a wry smile.

The scene, of course, was never used, but it is tempting to wonder what the director of Parker's latest film, Wonderland , might have done with such material. For in Wonderland Michael Winterbottom goes further than anything we have seen since the heyday of Italian neo-realism, making unwitting stars of the people of London as a backdrop to a complex and moving family drama.

Written by Laurence Coriat, Wonderland centres on three working-class sisters - Nadia (Gina McKee), Debbie (Shirley Henderson) and Molly (Molly Parker) - who are trying to keep on top of life in the fast-moving capital. Sandwich bar assistant Nadia is single and looking for love in the lonely hearts column; hairdresser Debbie is a reluctant single mother, while Molly is coping with heavy pregnancy and a commitment-phobic boyfriend.

These stories may be ordinary, but Wonderland is definitely not. 'What appealed to me about the screenplay was that it created a picture of London which I recognised but hadn't seen on film before,' said Winterbottom. 'That sense of restlessness, of that constant battle [people have] to keep their heads above water and, more importantly, find some space and time in which to try and enjoy life.' To convey that, Winterbottom and co-producer Andrew Eaton decided to abandon the rulebook and go into London with a hit-and-run crew of just three or four, shooting almost unobtrusively with a 16mm camera and next to no lighting. Eaton said: 'We wanted to go into real places, use real people and tell the story in what was almost a documentary style.'

The result is possibly one of the most authentic depictions of London ever filmed, balancing the shimmering glare of the capital's nightlife with the mundaneness of day-to-day life. But some might question the ethics of filming 'ordinary' people without their knowledge. 'Michael had this very clear idea of how he wanted us to rehearse,' said Parker, 'and that wasn't in the traditional sense of sitting down with the text and going through it together. He really wanted us to actively go out and try to participate in these characters' lives.'

Which meant that Winterbottom had some very unusual requests for his cast. Kika Markham, who plays Eileen, the girls' mother, was sent out Christmas shopping in character to buy presents for her entire screen 'family'. The three sisters, plus the actor who plays their estranged brother Darren, all had to spend a couple of days in the house that served as the location for their parents' house - even though some of them did not even have any scenes there. Parker, after deciding that her character was a primary school teacher, was promptly dispatched to a local school, where she spent a day helping out with a class of four- and five-year-olds.

Curiously, her character's occupation is never shown or mentioned. And although Parker was fitted with a bulky padded dress that gave some sense of how it would physically feel to be pregnant, that still was not quite enough. 'Michael had me get on a bus,' she says, 'and go to all these hospitals to find out what it's actually like to be that pregnant. I talked to all these fantastic women who were just really frank with me about the gory details.'

Just in case that was not enough realism, Molly has her child - on location, in Lewisham Hospital, south London. 'There were two babies that we used; two babies that were born that morning. Truly newborns - their bottoms and their heads fit into one hand - and their mothers were right there. It was an extraordinary experience, but what was so neat about the way Michael made this film was that we didn't have to go into some studio, we actually got to do it in a maternity ward, where women were giving birth almost literally in the next room. And the midwife in the film is the midwife in the hospital. She's amazing - I want her to be my midwife if I ever have children.'

But although these flourishes seem, at worst, a little eccentric, what responsibility do the filmmakers have to the real people being used? Parker stresses that there was a script - a written, well-crafted script, with characters and scenarios - but concedes that the dialogue frequently had to be abandoned if real life came too close. 'And because we were so often outside, we were just like regular people walking around, so we had to be open to anything that would happen. We couldn't possibly be in a situation where we could be exact, stick to the script, and do it over and over again, because within seconds we'd have 20 people standing and watching. We had to be much more incognito than that.'

'There's this amazing bit of footage of Gina McKee taking the Tube, and they just followed her, through the station, on the train. It was about 45 minutes of footage and it was during rush hour. But nobody even looked at the camera. All these people! Once in a while someone would, but I'm sure they thought it was just a newsreel.'

In some ways, Wonderland is perhaps just a sad indictment of the indifference of Londoners. An example of this is the scene in which Parker's character is about to give birth. She's standing on the corner of Shaftesbury Avenue and Dean Street, clutching her stomach and screaming, while 'Debbie' tries to hail a cab. A man walks up to see if she's all right; Molly all but ignores him and the camera tracks back into the distance. So, once the scene was over, did she explain to him that she was an actress? No. The man took off and they simply kept filming. 'All these people were coming up to me,' says Parker, 'and Shirley - she cracks me up - was going, "Dahn't warry, she's 'avin' a bay-bee." With a cigarette hanging out of her mouth! And immediately all the men turned and walked away, but the women stayed. But because it's London, it took Shirley 15 minutes to get a cab. fields.bodyText: Some years ago, Canadian actress Molly Parker was playing a prostitute in a TV show. As she recalls, she looked the part - 'halter top, miniskirt, knee-length boots' - as she lounged on a street corner, chewing gum and looking out into the middle distance with dead-eyed boredom. Suddenly a car pulled to a halt and the driver beckoned her over. She does not remember much about him except that he was deeply average, just an ordinary, middle-class, middle-aged man, but she does remember the two empty child safety seats in the back. Walking cautiously over to him, Parker leaned over and whispered something that made his blood run cold: 'I'd get out of here, if I were you. You're being filmed.' And with that, she motioned to a camera crew sta tioned across the road, close enough to get the naturalistic shot they wanted and far enough to be unobtrusive to the careless kerb crawler. The driver panicked and hit the accelerator, making a dramatic U-turn. Parker does not know exactly what he said to the crew but she found out later that he was almost in tears of desperation, begging for the film, offering money if they promised to destroy it. 'I almost felt sorry for him,' she says with a wry smile. The scene, of course, was never used, but it is tempting to wonder what the director of Parker's latest film, Wonderland , might have done with such material. For in Wonderland Michael Winterbottom goes further than anything we have seen since the heyday of Italian neo-realism, making unwitting stars of the people of London as a backdrop to a complex and moving family drama. Written by Laurence Coriat, Wonderland centres on three working-class sisters - Nadia (Gina McKee), Debbie (Shirley Henderson) and Molly (Molly Parker) - who are trying to keep on top of life in the fast-moving capital. Sandwich bar assistant Nadia is single and looking for love in the lonely hearts column; hairdresser Debbie is a reluctant single mother, while Molly is coping with heavy pregnancy and a commitment-phobic boyfriend. These stories may be ordinary, but Wonderland is definitely not. 'What appealed to me about the screenplay was that it created a picture of London which I recognised but hadn't seen on film before,' said Winterbottom. 'That sense of restlessness, of that constant battle [people have] to keep their heads above water and, more importantly, find some space and time in which to try and enjoy life.' To convey that, Winterbottom and co-producer Andrew Eaton decided to abandon the rulebook and go into London with a hit-and-run crew of just three or four, shooting almost unobtrusively with a 16mm camera and next to no lighting. Eaton said: 'We wanted to go into real places, use real people and tell the story in what was almost a documentary style.' The result is possibly one of the most authentic depictions of London ever filmed, balancing the shimmering glare of the capital's nightlife with the mundaneness of day-to-day life. But some might question the ethics of filming 'ordinary' people without their knowledge. 'Michael had this very clear idea of how he wanted us to rehearse,' said Parker, 'and that wasn't in the traditional sense of sitting down with the text and going through it together. He really wanted us to actively go out and try to participate in these characters' lives.' Which meant that Winterbottom had some very unusual requests for his cast. Kika Markham, who plays Eileen, the girls' mother, was sent out Christmas shopping in character to buy presents for her entire screen 'family'. The three sisters, plus the actor who plays their estranged brother Darren, all had to spend a couple of days in the house that served as the location for their parents' house - even though some of them did not even have any scenes there. Parker, after deciding that her character was a primary school teacher, was promptly dispatched to a local school, where she spent a day helping out with a class of four- and five-year-olds. Curiously, her character's occupation is never shown or mentioned. And although Parker was fitted with a bulky padded dress that gave some sense of how it would physically feel to be pregnant, that still was not quite enough. 'Michael had me get on a bus,' she says, 'and go to all these hospitals to find out what it's actually like to be that pregnant. I talked to all these fantastic women who were just really frank with me about the gory details.' Just in case that was not enough realism, Molly has her child - on location, in Lewisham Hospital, south London. 'There were two babies that we used; two babies that were born that morning. Truly newborns - their bottoms and their heads fit into one hand - and their mothers were right there. It was an extraordinary experience, but what was so neat about the way Michael made this film was that we didn't have to go into some studio, we actually got to do it in a maternity ward, where women were giving birth almost literally in the next room. And the midwife in the film is the midwife in the hospital. She's amazing - I want her to be my midwife if I ever have children.' But although these flourishes seem, at worst, a little eccentric, what responsibility do the filmmakers have to the real people being used? Parker stresses that there was a script - a written, well-crafted script, with characters and scenarios - but concedes that the dialogue frequently had to be abandoned if real life came too close. 'And because we were so often outside, we were just like regular people walking around, so we had to be open to anything that would happen. We couldn't possibly be in a situation where we could be exact, stick to the script, and do it over and over again, because within seconds we'd have 20 people standing and watching. We had to be much more incognito than that.' 'There's this amazing bit of footage of Gina McKee taking the Tube, and they just followed her, through the station, on the train. It was about 45 minutes of footage and it was during rush hour. But nobody even looked at the camera. All these people! Once in a while someone would, but I'm sure they thought it was just a newsreel.' In some ways, Wonderland is perhaps just a sad indictment of the indifference of Londoners. An example of this is the scene in which Parker's character is about to give birth. She's standing on the corner of Shaftesbury Avenue and Dean Street, clutching her stomach and screaming, while 'Debbie' tries to hail a cab. A man walks up to see if she's all right; Molly all but ignores him and the camera tracks back into the distance. So, once the scene was over, did she explain to him that she was an actress? webTitle: Brit pack in Tinseltown gold rush

fields.headline: Brit pack in Tinseltown gold rush
fields.standfirst: Imported talent is set to show its dominance in the Golden Globe awards
fields.trailText: As Hollywood gears up for the Golden Globe Awards in a fortnight (23 January), it does so against the backdrop of British talent's new domination in the world's largest film-making community.
fields.body:
As Hollywood gears up for the Golden Globe Awards in a fortnight (23 January), it does so against the backdrop of British talent's new domination in the world's largest film-making community.

The British are evident all over the American industry, winning plaudits for screenplays, direction, scores and acting skills. Names such as Mike Leigh, Anthony Minghella, Sam Mendes, Hugh Grant, Ralph Fiennes and Rupert Everett suddenly have just as much financial clout as their homegrown Hollywood contemporaries.

Young British actresses are also causing excitement among US critics. Samantha Morton, star of Woody Allen's new film Sweet and Lowdown, and Janet McTeer, star of Tumbleweeds, have both been nominated for prestigious Golden Globes and could win Academy Awards in March.

Emily Watson and Kate Winslet are also thought to be Oscar contenders following acclaimed performances in the Alan Parker film version of Frank McCourt's Angela's Ashes and in Holy Smoke, a film in which Winslet plays opposite Harvey Keitel.

Every winter the Golden Globes, together with the New York Critics' Circle Awards, are seen as strong indicators of how the Oscars will be spread later in the spring. 'The big crop of British names in the nominations this year reflects the fact that Hollywood money is able to spot and back our talent,' said Stephen Garrett, British Producer of Among Giants. The British industry has matured over the past few years but it still acts as something of a nursery ground for Hollywood.'

His own current project, The Man Standing on Platform Five, started as an adaptation of a very British story by Robert Llewellyn.

'It was impossible for the industry in Britain to compete with the offer made to me by NewLine, so it will now be an American story.'

During 1999 the Hollywood film industry has turned sharply away from big budget action films and moved towards drama, comedy and period costume pieces. This change in tone has opened the door to a British invasion.

The young English theatre director, Sam Mendes, is in the vanguard, threatening to sweep the board with a clutch of nominations for his first film, American Beauty, starring Kevin Spacey and Annette Bening.

Twentieth Century Fox Los Angeles executive Lynsey Law sees Mendes's success as part of a continuing trend.

'Distinctive quality films win nominations for awards and those are often films made with lower budgets, that don't then have to please such a wide audience in order to meet the bottom line,' he said.

'These films with lower budgets still tend to have British stars or screenwriters because they are cheaper.' Mike Leigh, one such low budget director, has already won the New York Critics' Circle award and the New York Times award for his portrayal of the lives of the creators of the Savoy operas, Gilbert and Sullivan. Called Topsy-Turvy, the film stars British actors Jim Broadbent and Timothy Spall and is tipped for Oscar success.

Anthony Minghella, director of The English Patient, has scored again with his new film, The Talented Mr Ripley. Jane Austen is still providing the right sort of plot too, it seems. Mansfield Park, a BBC film, has created a stir, in particular the supporting performance given by British playwright and actor Harold Pinter.

Among the senior rank of stars, Michael Caine has a Globe nomination in the bag for his role in The Cider House Rules and Nigel Hawthorne has been applauded for his tour de force in David Mamet's The Winslow Boy.

Other British stars, so far unrecognised by awards, are also being touted for Academy nominations. Jeremy Northam, for example has become a sought-after leading man following performances in An Ideal Husband and The Winslow Boy .

The transatlantic invasion

British names in the 2000 Golden Globe awards in bold type:

Best drama
American Beauty, directed by Sam Mendes (DreamWorks)

The End of the Affair, starring Ralph Fiennes (Columbia)

The Talented Mr Ripley, directed and written by Anthony Minghella starring Jude Law (Paramount Pictures/Miramax)

Best performance by an actress - drama
Annette Bening in Sam Mendes's American Beauty

Best performance by an actor - drama
Kevin Spacey in Mendes's American Beauty

Best musical or comedy
Notting Hill directed by Roger Michell and screenplay by Richard Curtis (A Working Title Film/Duncan Kenworthy Prods)

Best performance by an actress - musical or comedy
Janet McTeer in Tumbleweeds Julia Roberts in Roger Michell's Notting Hill

Best performance by an actor - musical or comedy
Rupert Everett in An Ideal Husband Hugh Grant in Notting Hill

Best performance by an actress in supporting role
Samantha Morton in Sweet and Lowdown

Best performance by an actor in supporting role
Michael Caine in The Cider House Rules Jude Law in Anthony Minghella's The Talented Mr Ripley

Best director
Sam Mendes for American Beauty

Anthony Minghella for The Talented Mr Ripley

Best original score

George Fenton for Anna and the King Michael Nyman for The End of the Affair Jocelyn Pook for Eyes Wide Shut

fields.headline: New you: an introduction
fields.trailText: It's your life, the only one you'll get. Do you want to spend it feeling less than yourself? Or do you want to go into a new era stronger, happier, and more successful? In spite of the hype and hysteria, this is no ordinary new year. If you know deep down that you want to make changes in your life, there's never been a better time to do it. But what changes? And how will you make them?
fields.body:
It's your life, the only one you'll get. Do you want to spend it feeling less than yourself? Or do you want to go into a new era stronger, happier, and more successful? In spite of the hype and hysteria, this is no ordinary new year. If you know deep down that you want to make changes in your life, there's never been a better time to do it. But what changes? And how will you make them?

The first step towards a new you - or the old you, before the bad habits and wrong turns - is looking at the big picture. body, mind, relationships, behaviour, belief: they're you, inseparable, and inter-related. Most 'change your life' plans fail because they concentrate on just one area and ignore the rest. Losing two inches off your waist might be a bonus, but if your relationship is miserable and you hate your job, it's not going to make you happier or give you back a sense of purpose. Sometimes, our plans don't work out because we're looking at our lives the wrong way. You can do more than you realise to change your life. But you can't do much to change anybody else's. Your problem may be a moody partner or a sadistic boss, but the one that needs to change is you. In the course of the next month, you'll be making that mind shift and looking at your life in a new and powerful way.

What New You isn't about is an impossible ideal of physical perfection or outrageous ambitions. It's about leading a bigger, better and more authentic life. And that means top to bottom, inside and out.

We'll begin with your body. In recent years, we've become far more aware of how our physical selves affect the way we think and relate to the world. Feeling depressed about sagging muscles or spreading flesh isn't just narcissism. It's an awareness that our body doesn't reflect the way we feel or want to feel inside. Energy, good health, sensuality... they should be an everyday reality, not an occasional gift.

Nutritionist Jane Clarke will take you through a four-week programme based on the latest, proven nutritional research, designed to make food and eating a simple pleasure, and your body feel great again. From eating for weight loss, to foods to combat ageing and disease, she unravels the myths and misinformation we're all fed about food to reveal the facts about what 'healthy eating' really means - and what it can do for you.

No programme can promise you energy, health and vitality and not include exercise. If you've tried and failed with exercise plans before, it's probably because you've been doing the wrong kind of exercise. What's the right kind? The kind that matches your body type, lifestyle, personality and schedule. We've got a quiz, compiled by our panel of body experts, to help you find the individually tailored programme that's right for you. After that, we'll go through the programme, and show you how never to give up on exercise again. And if you still can't make it to the gym, we've designed a perfect home exercise programme you can do anywhere, anytime.

Once you've rethought your diet and reclaimed your body, it's time to look inwards. Over the next four weeks we're focusing on the stuff that overwhelms us: the stresses that leave us exhausted, anxious, and feeling out of control. We've found the best and most practical strategies for overcoming stress, managing your time and getting your life back. When you're calmer, you'll have time to consider the really big questions: what do I really want? Can I do this job for another 20 years? Is my relationship in good shape? Leading Life Coach Eileen Mulligan is expert in helping her clients find the answer to questions just like these. Using simple but powerful techniques and exercises every week, she'll show you how to discover your real needs and desires, and then help you to make them a reality.

The experts

Matt Roberts A successful international sprinter, Matt now owns his own personal training business in central London. He's known as personal trainer to the stars, working with many celebrity clients, but Matt believes passionately in fitness for everyone. 'Most of us can remember a time when we were happier with our physical condition. Through a series of goals, regular analysis and expert guidance we can help you find that time again.'

Anton Michael Rocke A fully-qualified yoga teacher, Anton has been trained by the International Sivananda Yoga Vedanta centre under Swami Swaroopananda and Swami Durgananda. He has taught yoga and meditation for five years combining hatha yoga (the physical form of practice) with raja yoga (meditation and mental mastery). He has developed a holistic personal training business incorporating exercise and yoga. He believes all of us could benefit from using some yoga principles in our lives, 'Yoga has so many benefits it can touch every part of our physical and mental selves.'

Lynne Robinson Lynne is the world's top-selling Pilates expert having written three books on the Pilates Method. The first ('Body Control: The Pilates Way') has been the UK's number one selling fitness book over the last two years. She is also presenter of three Pilates videos. Lynne has developed a Pilates programme for elite sport and medicine - in particular football, cricket and golf. 'Most people think Pilates is something for dancers but it can influence and improve everybody's lives.' Lynne is also co-founder of the Body Control Pilates Teacher Training organisation and a director of the Body Control Pilates Association.

Professor Stuart Biddle The premise that engaging your mind is half the battle in getting your body to work is a philosophy that Stuart Biddle lives and works by. He's currently Professor of Exercise and Sport Psychology in the Department of Physical Education, Sports Science and Recreation Management at Loughborough University and is a past president of the European Federation of Sport psychology. His main interest is motivation in sport and getting those people who feel exercise is not for them to realise the benefits and enjoyment it can bring. 'The key to behaviour change is to look at the way we think - if we can change behaviour we can make a real difference to people's lives and health.'

Elesa Argent Working as a personal trainer at leading health club Holmes Place's exceptionally busy Barbican branch brings Elesa into contact with people who are devout exercisers as well as those who are less inclined to get physical. 'My job is to make exercise enjoyable and effective for all of them.' She specialises in the motivation of exercisers, however reluctant, and also has a masters degree in the Science of Exercise.

Jane Clarke One of the country's leading nutritionists, and the writer of the Observer's weekly nutrition column. Jane runs a nutritional consultancy, where her clients include stressed businessmen and women, hyperactive and lethargic children, babies with feeding difficulties and marathon runners. She is the author of the best-seller, 'Body Foods for Life'.

Eileen Mulligan Eileen Mulligan is one of UK's most successful and sought after Life Coaches - a new kind of personal trainer for your life and mind rather than body. She coaches media personalities, members of parliament, business executives, and a wide range of individuals, on everything from problems in their personal lives, to business, career, family and financial issues. She is also the best-selling author of 'Life Coaching: Change your Life in Seven Days'.

His main interest is motivation in sport and getting those people who feel exercise is not for them to realise the benefits and enjoyment it can bring. 'The key to behaviour change is to look at the way we think - if we can change behaviour we can make a real difference to people's lives and health.' Elesa Argent Working as a personal trainer at leading health club Holmes Place's exceptionally busy Barbican branch brings Elesa into contact with people who are devout exercisers as well as those who are less inclined to get physical. 'My job is to make exercise enjoyable and effective for all of them.' She specialises in the motivation of exercisers, however reluctant, and also has a masters degree in the Science of Exercise. Jane Clarke One of the country's leading nutritionists, and the writer of the Observer's weekly nutrition column. Jane runs a nutritional consultancy, where her clients include stressed businessmen and women, hyperactive and lethargic children, babies with feeding difficulties and marathon runners. She is the author of the best-seller, 'Body Foods for Life'. Eileen Mulligan Eileen Mulligan is one of UK's most successful and sought after Life Coaches - a new kind of personal trainer for your life and mind rather than body. She coaches media personalities, members of parliament, business executives, and a wide range of individuals, on everything from problems in their personal lives, to business, career, family and financial issues. She is also the best-selling author of 'Life Coaching: Change your Life in Seven Days'.

fields.headline: Good old days
fields.standfirst: Young wine is no bad thing, but a glass of something truly old can be an experience worth investing in
fields.trailText: Young wine is no bad thing, but a glass of something truly old can be an experience worth investing in
fields.body:
Hands up who celebrated the arrival of the new millennium with a bottle of Esprit du Siècle, Moët & Chandon's £13,000 tribute to the passing of the 20th century? No, I thought not. As the north-south divide deepens, the idea of drinking bubbly that's worth more than a terrace in Gateshead is obscene.

As I sipped Esprit at a pre-millennium press launch, two things struck me. First, that it was the most expensive (though by no means the best) glass of wine I'd ever rolled across my palate. And second, that I was tasting history. The oldest component in the blend, a smidgen of 1900, was older than Barbara Cartland. Esprit also contains wines from 1914, 1921, 1934, 1943, 1952, 1962, 1976, 1985 and 1995.

It's not often I get the chance to taste old wines. You might imagine that my life is one long succession of vertical tastings, but it's not. (A lot of them end up horizontal, but that's another story.) No, most of the stuff I assess for a living is designed for the short-term. If anything, the time lag between harvest and dinner table is shrinking. Not so long ago, Beaujolais was the only wine sold in its year of production. Last year, supermarkets were full of 1999s from the southern hemisphere by the summer.

I once read a statistic that 95 per cent of wine is consumed within 24 hours of purchase, and I can well believe it. Very few people own cellars these days, and those who do are more likely to fill them with old bicycles and tennis rackets than cases of claret. There are a few merchants who sell older vintages (Berry Brothers and Justerini & Brooks in St James's, Farr Vintners, Tanners, Lay & Wheeler and The Wine Society), but that's about it. Champagne and port aside, most wine retailers regard the early Nineties, let alone the Seventies, as ancient history.

There's nothing wrong with this. As a founding member of the DIY (Drink It Young) Club, I love the flavour of young wine. I've also had far too many supposedly great wines that have been cellared for 20 years or longer and proved a massive (and expensive) disappointment when I've finally pulled the cork. It's also worth remembering that red wine styles have changed dramatically since the Seventies. Bordeaux, for instance, makes softer and much more approachable wines than it used to. It's perfectly possible to drink classed growth claret at five, four or even three years old these days.

The New World has forever changed the way we think about wine. Ripe fruit and immediacy are what most people want and expect from a glass. I don't blame them, but I sometimes worry that they're missing out on one of the greatest things about wine: its ability to mutate in bottle from alcoholic fruit juice to something of unequalled complexity. It doesn't always happen, but the sheer unpredictability of wine is part of the pleasure. No two bottles are alike.

There's something truly inspiring about a beautiful old wine. I once tasted a 1936 Rioja with an elderly Spanish friend who stared at the label and cried at the memory of his country's civil war. I've had similar emotions drinking wines from the great 1945 vintage in Bordeaux. Despite its laughable price tag, Esprit du Siècle moved me, too. I can't say I feel the same way about an eight-month-old Chardonnay.
