fields.headline: Mash hits
fields.standfirst: With cream, cheese or with pastry in a piping hot pie, potatoes are the ultimate comfort food
fields.trailText: With cream, cheese or with pastry in a piping hot pie, potatoes are the ultimate comfort food
fields.body:
Starch is only truly acceptable with a seasoning of fat. Think toast without butter, pizza without cheese, pasta without olive oil and a baked potato without its compulsory dollop of butter and cheese. Even the most abstemious steamed potato is only worth eating when you dip it in the accompanying sauce or gravy. This isn't gluttony. It is simply easier and more pleasing to get your carbohydrates down with a suitable lubricant. Low-fat alternatives not only fail to hit the bliss point, but their complex manufacture is somewhat dark and mysterious and a world away from the simple pressing of an olive or the churning of cream into butter. I will go along with the idea that a healthy diet contains a hefty amount of carbohydrate, just as long as it includes a judicious helping of dairy produce to help it down.

Though pasta and noodles are now well established in our national diet, the potato remains the British carbohydrate of choice. Which is just as well. You can't grow rice for love nor money in this climate. The new potato, so neat and nutty, is all very well sharing a plate with grilled sole or a few slices of the new season's lamb, but when the weather is cold and wet, only a bulging King Edward, Maris Peer or red-skinned Desiree will do. Trudging home, chilled to the bone, it is only the thought of a hot potato that keeps me going. Better still, a potato with a generous slick of melted butter, cheese or cream.

With a little effort, we can be even more comforting than that. The dishes that brought that Readybrek glow to me as a kid may be out of step with what we eat now, but they can easily be re-thought to include better-quality ingredients. The old cheese and potato pie I used to tuck into at school, a deeply warming double whammy of pastry and potato, is immeasurably more interesting when made with cream and a melting cheese such as Fontina or Taleggio. Those who scoff at the idea of pommes dauphinoise in a puff pastry crust (for that is what it is) are obviously not wet or cold enough.

Those who have an allergy to potato peeling may like to try slicing them thinly and layering them with Taleggio and sage leaves before cooking them gently over a low heat till the potato slices turn the colour of autumn leaves and the cheese forms long strings. Of course, there is always the baked potato. A huge spud, baked till the skin cracks and the flesh is like snow, will satisfy not just the hungry but those coming home so cold and numb as to be incapable of thinking of anything more interesting.

I will not hear a word against a baked potato supper. The pedestrian butter and grated cheese topping can be jazzed up a bit, though. I often let onions cook down over a low heat with a good-sized knob of butter until they are golden and soft enough to squish between the fingers, then pour in a spoonful of grainy mustard and a glug or two of cream. The resulting sauce has both the hit of mustard and the soothing stroke of dairy produce. You need to remember to start the onions a good half an hour before you think you will need them.

The ultimate cheese and potato supper must surely be aligot, a deep, pale and creamy mash of potatoes, butter, cream and cheese, seasoned with garlic, salt and black pepper. It is as soothing a plate of food as you will ever find. Consoling and blissfully gratifying, aligot is traditionally made with la Tomme frache de Cantal, and is subject to many rules and superstitions, including the idea that the mixture should always be stirred in the same direction. It is an Auvergne dish, and one that I have never tasted in its rightful place, though I do know that it takes a bit of stirring to get it as light as the locals insist it should be. I am not sure they would forgive my home-grown version that includes simply mashing any cheese that will melt into hot, creamy mashed potato. But right now, I am too cold and hungry to care.

Potato and Fontina pie

An update of the old cheese and potato pie. It is essential that you leave no holes in the pastry as you line the dish, otherwise the filling will escape and burn (as did my first attempt). Will serve at least six hungry eaters, maybe more.

750g large potatoes

500ml double cream

250ml creamy milk

4 bay leaves, scrunched up a bit

3 cloves of garlic, peeled and thinly sliced

375g puff pastry

250g Fontina or Gruyère, coarsely grated

a few bushy sprigs of dill or tarragon leaves, roughly chopped

Slice the potatoes thinly, no thicker than a £1 coin. Peel them first, if you wish, but I am not sure it is absolutely necessary here. Pour the cream and milk into a large saucepan and drop in the bay leaves, slices of garlic and a few grinds of salt and pepper, then bring it briefly to the boil. Turn down the heat and leave the potatoes to cook gently for about 10 minutes. They are ready when you can push the point of a knife through them with little or no pressure. Turn off the heat.

Set the oven at 220 C/gas mark 7. Roll out the pastry to line a 23cm loose-bottomed non-stick cake tin, pressing the pastry neatly into the corners and pulling it gently up the sides. It is essential that there are no holes, otherwise the cream will leak out and burn.

Fill the pastry with layers of the potatoes and their cream, adding a scattering of grated cheese, chopped herbs, and a little more salt and pepper as you go. Flip the edges of the pastry over the top layer to form a loose lid, pinching the edges together wherever you need to. Cut or poke a hole through the pastry to let out the steam as it cooks.

Bake for 50 to 60 minutes, turning the oven down to 190 C/gas mark 5 after the first 10 minutes. The pie is ready when the pastry is crisp and golden brown, not just on the top, but the sides and base as well.

Let the pie cool for 5 minutes or so before running a palette knife around the edge to loosen it from the tin. Lift off the tin, leaving the pie still on the cake-tin base, then serve it in generous wedges.

Cheese mash

A good side dish for Monday's cold cuts.

leftover mashed potatoes

butter

cheese - anything that you have around that needs using

Tip the mashed potatoes into a shallow ovenproof dish. Level them a little without packing them down too tightly. Dot small knobs of butter over the surface, cover with grated or crumbled cheese, and bake in a hot oven till the cheese has melted and the potatoes are heated through.

Potatoes and Taleggio

It would be technically incorrect to call this a gratin, and even worse to call it a 'bake'. But it is well worth making, whatever name it goes by. Serves 4 as a side dish

5 or 6 medium potatoes

225g Taleggio, Fontina or mozzarella

olive oil

5 thin slices of bacon, coppa or pancetta

70g (a small handful) of grated Parmesan

Bring the potatoes to the boil in deep water, add a little salt and let them simmer till they are tender enough to easily take the point of a knife. Drain them, let them cool enough to make them easy to handle, then slip off their skins and cut each potato into thinnish slices.

Slice the mozzarella into rounds about as thick as a £1 coin, then tear the bacon or pancetta into short lengths. Drizzle a little olive oil over a baking dish or roasting tin, then lay the sliced potatoes in a single layer, tucking in the mozzarella and pancetta, seasoning with salt, black pepper and grated Parmesan as you go. Shake just a little more olive oil over the top, and bake in a hot oven at 180 C/ gas mark 5 for 25 to 30 minutes, by which time the potatoes will be golden and lightly crisp, and the mozzarella melted.

fields.headline: Little big tree
fields.standfirst: Small but perfectly formed. Why bonsai is going to be huge
fields.trailText: Small but perfectly formed. Why bonsai is going to be huge
fields.body:
Just as surely as green is the new black, bonsai is the new garden fix. As age, or even more importantly, the impression of age is the most venerable aspect of bonsai, this is at odds with much of the current trends in gardening, where newness and change and impermanence rule. But, in many ways, bonsai is the epitome of gardening. It takes a naturally occurring plant and manicures, trains and tames it to a miniature representation of itself, which a garden does of the landscape.

Bonsai is small. It is the reduction, almost ad absurdum, of things bigger and stronger than us. The whole aim is to create an impression of nature, and the more weathered and untamable the image is, the greater the skill.

The first bonsai trees only came west at the end of the last century amid the general fascination with all things Japanese (it had originated in China, spreading to Japan in the 11th century). The Royal Horticultural Society has been exhibiting bonsai for more than 90 years - it is one of the stars of the Chelsea Flower Show, given extra charm by the fact that most exhibits are amateur or by small nurseries that have 'made' all their plants. (In bonsai circles, plants are made rather than grown. And there is a logic to this when one considers how minutely they are shaped and trained, pruned and primped and that their makers consider them living sculpture rather than just plants.)

I spoke to Colin Ellis, chairman of Bonsai Kai, the oldest Bonsai society in Europe and a member of the committee of the RHS. He reckoned that there was not necessarily an increase in bonsai enthusiasts despite the increase in sales - a sizeable number of trees die and their owners give up as a result. Also he pointed out that many of the cheap bonsai you can buy in department stores and garden centres for around £20 to £50 are from China, Thailand or Malaysia and are not temperate plants. They must therefore be kept indoors with all the attendant problems. People put them on the television or near a radiator and the things dry up and die in days. People seem to think that the combination of miniaturisation and appearance of age implies a kind of pickling, so the plants do not need watering or caring for. This is miles from the truth.

It is far easier to grow bonsai that are either indigenous or from a temperate zone similar to our own. This means that the plants can spend the majority of their lives outside. I certainly tend to think of them as indoor plants, and Ellis admitted that they do not fit easily into most gardens. 'But,' he said, 'you can go to Japan and see what looks like a potato field of plants growing on ridges and they turn out to be white pines ( Pinus parviflora ) growing for bonsai. The reason for that is that they grow faster outside because the roots have a better run. People think that bonsai is about restricting growth. It is actually about getting things to grow fast, but to control it - not to slow it down unnaturally. Consequently, many growers only pot up their plants in order to exhibit them.' The main limitation on growth is not through pruning, which tends to provoke stronger growth, but by keeping the roots severely constrained (rather like footbinding in their tiny containers), which are the artificial equivalent of the trees you see growing out of rocks in mountains. The rule of thumb is that the depth of the container should correspond to the thickness of the trunk of the tree, and the diameter of the pot should be the same as the diameter of the crown.

As you might expect, everything in bonsai is codified, from the container shape and size to the shape and form of the plant. It is ballet rather than a rave. Bonsai appeals to the combination of gardener and obsessive controller, channelling that control into something rather than into the normal horticultural obsession of collecting. Nevertheless, serious bonsai enthusiasts get the collection bug, too. 'It becomes addictive,' said Ellis. 'I had 180 at one time and most enthusiasts' collections don't really relate to their garden.' Perhaps this is true of all collections: they only ever relate to themselves. But how do people afford to buy all these enormously expensive trees? 'They don't,' he said. 'Most people make their own by grafting and taking cuttings.' So do these collections become enormously valuable? 'No. people have an inflated idea of what bonsai is worth. There was a sale of bonsai at Sotheby's a few years ago where some 400-year-old pieces went for £20,000, but the real skill is in making a 40-year-old tree look 400 years.'

Nevertheless, companies buy bonsai as investments, treating them as works of art and selling them on at a profit. To service this business, there are professional stylists that travel the world shaping and training the trees every few months, like hairdressers or private trainers.

One of the problems I have always had with bonsai is how to use them in the context of a garden. Ellis agreed that this was often a problem. 'Unless you have a large garden and can use them as judiciously placed focal points, you can't put them easily into a garden.' Perhaps a balcony or verandah is best.

Harmony in the bonsaied bush is everything, and to that end, branches are cut off and grafted into new positions, wires are attached to redirect the angle of growth, and the entire tree is regularly lifted out of its container and the roots pruned. No operation is too complicated to enhance beauty and assist the ageing process.

The trunk of a bonsai is short and stubby, tapering as it grows. One that has grown too long can be shortened from the bottom by provoking new root growth above the existing soil layer. Otherwise, pruning as it grows and the passing of time will achieve the desired effect.

Branches can be added by drilling through the trunk and sticking a seedling through the hole, keeping its roots in a small pot stuck on to the side of the main tree. As the seedling grows it will swell to graft with the tree. When you think it has properly bonded, remove the pot and soil from the roots of the seedling and let them dry out. If the leaves of the new 'branch' do not wither it means that nourishment is getting to it via the main trunk and the old seedling roots can be trimmed off. The seedling can also be grafted on to a wound made on the side of the trunk.

Wiring is done in two ways. Either it is wound corkscrew fashion around the branch and trunk, flexible enough to allow the branch to be adjusted to an exact position and rigid enough to hold it there, or guys are anchored to the container, making the Lilliputian tree look paradoxically like Gulliver, tied to the ground.

The main limitation on growth is not through pruning, which tends to provoke stronger growth, but by keeping the roots severely constrained (rather like footbinding in their tiny containers), which are the artificial equivalent of the trees you see growing out of rocks in mountains. The rule of thumb is that the depth of the container should correspond to the thickness of the trunk of the tree, and the diameter of the pot should be the same as the diameter of the crown. As you might expect, everything in bonsai is codified, from the container shape and size to the shape and form of the plant. It is ballet rather than a rave. Bonsai appeals to the combination of gardener and obsessive controller, channelling that control into something rather than into the normal horticultural obsession of collecting. Nevertheless, serious bonsai enthusiasts get the collection bug, too. 'It becomes addictive,' said Ellis. 'I had 180 at one time and most enthusiasts' collections don't really relate to their garden.' Perhaps this is true of all collections: they only ever relate to themselves. But how do people afford to buy all these enormously expensive trees? 'They don't,' he said. 'Most people make their own by grafting and taking cuttings.' So do these collections become enormously valuable? 'No. people have an inflated idea of what bonsai is worth. There was a sale of bonsai at Sotheby's a few years ago where some 400-year-old pieces went for £20,000, but the real skill is in making a 40-year-old tree look 400 years.' Nevertheless, companies buy bonsai as investments, treating them as works of art and selling them on at a profit. To service this business, there are professional stylists that travel the world shaping and training the trees every few months, like hairdressers or private trainers. One of the problems I have always had with bonsai is how to use them in the context of a garden. Ellis agreed that this was often a problem. 'Unless you have a large garden and can use them as judiciously placed focal points, you can't put them easily into a garden.' Perhaps a balcony or verandah is best. Harmony in the bonsaied bush is everything, and to that end, branches are cut off and grafted into new positions, wires are attached to redirect the angle of growth, and the entire tree is regularly lifted out of its container and the roots pruned. No operation is too complicated to enhance beauty and assist the ageing process. The trunk of a bonsai is short and stubby, tapering as it grows. One that has grown too long can be shortened from the bottom by provoking new root growth above the existing soil layer. Otherwise, pruning as it grows and the passing of time will achieve the desired effect. Branches can be added by drilling through the trunk and sticking a seedling through the hole, keeping its roots in a small pot stuck on to the side of the main tree. As the seedling grows it will swell to graft with the tree. When you think it has properly bonded, remove the pot and soil from the roots of the seedling and let them dry out. If the leaves of the new 'branch' do not wither it means that nourishment is getting to it via the main trunk and the old seedling roots can be trimmed off. The seedling can also be grafted on to a wound made on the side of the trunk. Wiring is done in two ways. Either it is wound corkscrew fashion around the branch and trunk, flexible enough to allow the branch to be adjusted to an exact position and rigid enough to hold it there, or guys are anchored to the container, making the Lilliputian tree look paradoxically like Gulliver, tied to the ground.

fields.headline: Your roots
fields.standfirst: A bit of bonding, and other bonsai tips
fields.trailText: A bit of bonding, and other bonsai tips
fields.body:
The shallow pots mean the soil has a large surface area and water will evaporate very fast. The container must have drainage holes, which are first covered with mesh and then a thin drainage layer such as gravel. The pot is then filled with a potting compost. You can buy a special bonsai soil imported from Japan called Akadama, or use a mixture made up from equal parts of loam, sand and peat. Whatever you use must be low in nutrients and neither too retentive of moisture nor too quick to dry out.

Root pruning is done in spring, before new leaves appear. This is because the reserves for new growth have already accumulated and the roots will grow anew after the leaves have developed. Prune in autumn and you are going to diminish this garnering of next season's resources. If roots get broken, new ones are grafted on to replace them. A root is taken from a tree of the same species and the top cut into a wedge and then fitted into a corresponding notch cut into the recipient trunk. The two are bonded together with raffia and sealed. If more action is required, new root growth and direction can be provoked by removing a strip of bark 1cm wide from the area on the trunk where you want new roots to grow. Hormone rooting powder is put on as a paste and the wound surrounded by seed compost (low in nutrients). After about a year the new roots will support the tree and the old root system can be cut off and discarded.

Because the soil has so little by the way of nutrients, feeding is part of the art. A high nitrate feed is given in spring when the leaves start to show. This is repeated weekly, with the nitrogen level slowly tapered off so that by autumn there is no nitrogen in the fertiliser at all.

Bonsai can be started from seedlings (or seed) or purchased as maturing specimens. These two suppliers have a wide range of trees: Herons Bonsai, Wire Mill Lane, Newchapel, Lingfield, Surrey RH7 6HJ, (01342 832657), www.herons.co.uk; Norman Bonsai (01273 506476) operates from Leonardslee Gardens, near Horsham, West Sussex, from 1 April to 31 October. Bonsai Kai is the oldest bonsai membership club in Europe. Call 01707 375242 and c/o 5 Kneller Workshops, Kneller Road, Welwyn Garden City, Herts AL7 3NS. Reference books: Bonsai: The Complete Guide to Art and Technique by Paul Lesniewicz (Cassell, £14.99); Low Maintenance Bonsai by Herb Gustafson (David & Charles, £8.99).

webTitle: Full referral looms in Carlton-United row could see CC referral

fields.headline: Full referral looms in Carlton-United row could see CC referral
fields.trailText: The bitter wrangle over who should control ITV is likely to lead to a full referral to the Competition Commission following Granada's attempts last Friday to scupper a merger between Carlton Communications and United News and Media.
fields.body:
The bitter wrangle over who should control ITV is likely to lead to a full referral to the Competition Commission following Granada's attempts last Friday to scupper a merger between Carlton Communications and United News and Media.

Granada says it has approached the Office of Fair Trading with three proposals: one for it to buy the merged Carlton and United entity; a second for it to bid only for Carlton; and the third for Granada to take over United.

Although the OFT has not yet received any of these proposals, Granada says it is approaching the competition authority with the intention of finding out what would be permissible if the rule limiting advertising sales to 25 per cent of net ad revenue were to be relaxed.

'It now looks as though the entire issue of ITV ownership will earn a full referral to the Competition Commission,' said one industry analyst. 'It's difficult to see how it can be avoided.'

But both Carlton and United were this weekend sceptical about Granada's intentions, accusing them of 'bluff and bravado'. However, Granada chief executive Charles Allen underlined the company's intention to bid for one or both of the rivals if this were allowed.

'These two companies are our number one targets,' said Allen. 'There is absolutely no doubt about that: we want to bulk up our media side ahead of a demerger from our hospitality interests.'

However, unless the Competition Commission and the Department of Culture, Media and Sport increase the upper limit on advertising sales, none of the proposed mergers would go ahead. Granada's intervention will further muddy the waters in what is already likely to be a fairly lengthy review.

The OFT is due to report on the Carlton-United plan in mid February - if the authority rolls in the Granada proposals, it could take longer. A full referral to the Competition Commission would add a further six months.

fields.headline: Shooting from the lip
fields.standfirst: Alan Parker once said our film industry makes great TV, but is not ambitious enough. With a new film - Angela's Ashes - out this week and a new job as chairman of the Film Council, how does the director of hits such as Midnight Express and Mississippi Burning see the future for British movies?
fields.trailText: Alan Parker once said our film industry makes great TV, but is not ambitious enough. With a new film - Angela's Ashes - out this week and a new job as chairman of the Film Council, how does the director of hits such as Midnight Express and Mississippi Burning see the future for British movies?
fields.body:
'Oh I'm much calmer, less controlling, more relaxed these days,' says Alan Parker, smiling, telling me how he has not only written and directed the film version of Frank McCourt's bestseller Angela's Ashes, but also produced the film's poster on his Xerox at home and done the graphic design for the press pack.

In the past, he admits, he has been fond of suggesting that 'directing a film is a crash course in megalomania' and that he 'enjoys the Stalinist approach to moviemaking - as long as I am Stalin' (in homage to this he has a bust of Uncle Joe in his office presented to him by his colleagues). But all that has changed.

Parker has matured, he suggests, mellowed even. Having waged guerrilla warfare against the film establishment in Britain for nearly three decades, he now is that establishment, chairman of new Labour's new Film Council. The perceived chippiness of the Islington advertising man in Hollywood has, he implies, been replaced by a new kind of phlegmatic wisdom.

He reflects on this personal evolution for a moment. 'Of course my film crew would fall about laughing if they heard me say any of that,' he concedes. Parker, explaining his new-found laissez-faire, has a pent-up quality, which seems like it might dissolve into rage. He wears his jacket buttoned and straining, as if to hold his impatience in; he mostly talks gruffly at the floor.

'When I started directing I disagreed with a lot of people and an entire philosophy about what made a good film,' he says. 'a) They thought because you've got a cockney accent you're stupid, which is the ultimate insult, and b) if you disagreed with that intellectually snobby establishment they said you just had a chip on your shoulder. It was easy shit to put out, but I don't think anyone buys that any more...'

In any case, he is at great pains to stress, he no longer feels the need to continually fight his artistic corner. 'I have always said the same thing,' he says, 'that American cinema is the cinema of the audience. I am just as much an auteur as any so-called European director, except that I have to justify people giving me a lot of money. It would be much easier to make an "art" film for my relatives and three critics. But, as I say, I don't think I need to make that argument any more.'

For someone who no longer feels the need to explain himself, Alan Parker does a good deal of explaining. He has just returned from several weeks of television interviews in America and Europe promoting his film. 'In Germany you get seven minutes; in America you get four, including a clip, so it's really just "good evening" and you're off.' Which is just as well, really, because the more he talks about the process of film-making, the less he feels he has anything to say.

'So much of it is instinctive. I'm sure Trevor Nunn can explain it, but I'm so badly educated I've never been able to articulate it.' Still, as he insists, he's not chippy. Parker first read Angela's Ashes as a manuscript, long before the book was published, and tried to buy the film rights then, only to discover that they had already been acquired by the American producer Scott Rudin. When the project eventually came his way, a screenplay had been written, but he went back to the book and started again. 'It was a matter of plundering and giving it a bit more heart,' he says, and anyway, he's always written his own films.

'It's the only way to get the thing really inside your head.' To orient himself in the Limerick of Frank McCourt's childhood, Parker used a map of the book's key locations he'd found on a Japanese web site for Angela's Ashes obsessives. The site brought home to him the extraordinary and universal appeal of a book which had sold six million copies in around 30 countries. Its author was a big help and inspiration, too: 'Frank had been a schoolteacher in New York for so many years that he has this endlessly encouraging and patient manner,' says Parker.

'Even though, when I finished it, it did feel a bit like putting an essay in to your English teacher. You know, "must try harder".' (McCourt returns the compliment suggesting that Parker understood the book so well because 'he comes from a blue-collar background and I come from a no-collar background'.) The difficulties of putting McCourt's memoir on film were always likely to be in preventing its sentiment from becoming too mawkish: it begins, brightly, with the death of the author's baby sister and infant twin brothers from a mixture of illness and malnutrition, and then the trouble really starts.

Parker succeeds in keeping the grimness in check through perfor mances of great intensity and restraint from Robert Carlyle and Emily Watson, who play McCourt's parents, as well as inspirational, and often comic, debuts by the boys who play the growing Frank (typically Parker auditioned 15,000 children to find the Franks he wanted: 'If you get the casting right, the rest takes care of itself,' he says). Even so, as in the book, the real stars of Angela's Ashes are Poverty and Damp, which stalk the hopes of the ever-optimistic McCourt children like personifications from medieval mystery plays.

This is perhaps the wettest film ever made. The rain sweeps in from the Shannon ('the damp heart and silent villain of our story,' as Parker has it). It sluices through the back alleys of Limerick before collecting in big plashy puddles in the McCourts' front room. Ever the craftsman, Parker spent a couple of months at Technicolor, working with a new grading process that holds more of the silver in the print. Thus, as the McCourt family push their soggy belongings in dripping hand carts from one waterlogged basement to another they are bathed in a kind of sepulchral sepia glitter which lends some scenes a monumental pathos (though there are occasional moments, too, when you feel as if you are watching the most lavish Hovis ad ever made).

Two decades ago, the New Yorker 's distinguished film critic Pauline Kael suggested that Alan Parker had 'technique to burn'. Some of the credit for this goes to his crew, many of whom graduated with him from Cinzano commercials and 'Nice One Cyril' to Bugsy Malone and Midnight Express in the late Seventies and have stayed with him ever since. 'One of the great things about working with your friends,' he suggests, 'is that I am able to say to them, "I don't know what the fuck I'm doing here."

As director you're Jack the Lad, but I'm never sure that I'm right, I'm just as insecure as anyone else.' It adds to the sense of loyalty that seems a characteristic of Alan Parker projects: 'Not so much Alan Parker against the world as Alan Parker and his crew against the world,' is how he puts it.

Parker's film's often seem likely military campaigns, with him cast in the role of a pugnacious general under fire. When, for example, he made Mississippi Burning, Time magazine branded Parker's portrayal of the passivity of blacks during the Civil Rights movement 'a cinematic lynching' of history. Parker also exercised America's moral majority and the censors with Angel Heart when he poured chicken blood onto Mickey Rourke's buttocks as he had 'voodoo sex' with Lisa Bonet. He survived, too, making Evita in Buenos Aires, where he was greeted with death threats after casting Madonna - 'Satan in drag' according to the city's bishop - as the lead. He eventually persuaded Carlos Menem to allow him to film from the balcony of the presidential palace and even coaxed Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice to collaborate on a new song.

Angela's Ashes was a doddle in comparison, though he did run into difficulties with Limerick's Catholic establishment, which refused to let him film in the city's churches (he went to Dublin instead). It was the most harmonious set he had been on, he says, and, after almost a decade working out of Los Angeles, it was good to be back filming close to home. A return to London enabled him to be near his four children, though the overriding reason he came back was to take up the challenge of building a new British film industry, initially as head of the BFI, now as chairman of the Film Council with a £27 million annual budget.

In the past, and notably in his 1984 TV polemic A Turniphead's Guide to the Cinema, Parker has been an outspoken critic of little England 'red bus' movies and the 'fiefdoms who went out of their way to help Derek Jarman but don't help anyone else'. He once ran a one-man campaign suggesting he would be forced to leave the country if Peter Greenaway made another movie, distributing posters declaring: 'Instant narcolepsy - see a Greenaway film.'

In a 1997 Bafta lecture Parker suggested that the British film industry made great TV, but not ambitious films in the tradition of David Lean and Carol Reed. He included himself, a little tentatively, in this latter tradition, and also his old friend and sparring partner David Puttnam. Some people have suggested that the Blair confidante Puttnam was behind Parker's appointment to the Film Council, but he barks a laugh at the suggestion. 'He would have been more instrumental in trying to prevent me from getting it,' he says. 'He hates me treading on his toes.' Though they are on good terms now, the pair fell out for a couple of years after Puttnam felt Parker had not given him enough support when he was head of Columbia Pictures. But now that he is poacher-turned-gamekeeper, I wonder, what plans does Parker have for the new organisation?

How does the old firebrand plan to shake up the industry, kick out the old establishment, bring on a new generation of Leans and Reeds and Parkers and Puttnams? 'Well, it's a bit premature for me to say,' he offers, suddenly coy. 'I'm going to be very diplomatic.' 'It's very difficult,' he suggests, before confiding that 'there are things the council agrees on and things that we don't'. When pressed, he concludes that 'it's all at a very delicate stage'. It may not be the turniphead rhetoric of old. But in his new role as cheerleader for a Blairite film revolution, Alan Parker, it seems, is already talking the right language.

 Angela's Ashes opens nationwide on 14 January

webTitle: Cybersquatters with an eye for domain chance

fields.headline: Cybersquatters with an eye for domain chance
fields.standfirst: The Networker
fields.trailText: The Networker
fields.body:
What's in a domain name? Loadsamoney, apparently. Last week, the owners of Year2000.com - hitherto a clearing house for information about the millennium bug - put the name on the market through eBay, the online auction house, and claim to have sold it for $10 million. However, since a previous 'winning' bid proved fraudulent, the vendors will not be celebrating yet. But even if all the eBay bids turn out to be fakes, the vendors have, so they told Wired News received a substantial offer from a known individual.

When everyone is seeking to pitch a stall in cyberspace, domain names become hot properties. Last month Business.com was sold for $7.5m. It's also been reported that a Venezuelan casino paid $1.03m for the rights to wallstreet.com (though why a casino would want such a name is a mystery). These prices are what drive the arcane practice of 'cybersquatting' - registering promising-looking domain names in the hope that they can be sold later to desperate corporations. Given that it costs only $70 to register a dot-com domain name, cybersquatting looked like a good bet.

We can also predict that domain-name ownership disputes will attract m'learned friends. Some of them are already active. A case attracting attention is a dispute between the New York Yankees baseball team and one Brian McKiernan, proud owner of newyorkyankees.com since 1997.

In a suit filed on Christmas Eve (talk about Scrooge) the Yankees accuse McKiernan of 'domain-squatting', citing the Trademark Cyberpiracy Prevention Act, which Congress - ever attendant to the needs of big business - enacted last November.

'This action,' says the law suit, 'seeks to prevent... Brian McKiernan from engaging in cyberpiracy... by registering, trafficking in, and using the domain name'. According to the complaint, McKiernan's actions 'dilute the Yankees' name, thereby causing the baseball franchise severe and irreparable injury'. (Cue violins.) McKiernan's lawyer claims his client registered the domain with the intention of running a non-commercial fan site. He said the Yankees offered a paltry $450 for the name before taking legal action, even though McKiernan had not agreed to sell. Nor, it seems, had he ever got round to putting up the fan site. Even so, this will run and run.

As employers become increasingly shirty about workers' recreational use of the Web, here's the ultimate excuse for visiting the Playboy site: an interesting article about Linux, the open-source (free) operating system many see as a challenge to the server version of Microsoft Windows 2000.

It is written by Gillian Bonner, president of a multi-media company, Black Dragon Inc, and possibly the only senior executive in the US who has also been a Playboy centrefold (she was Miss April 1996).

Her article is a deadpan account of how, in her search for an operating system more stable than Windows, she installed Linux. 'I could just feel the power under the hood of this slick and efficient interface,' she reports. 'I admit I didn't try to test any of my peripherals, but instead stuck to the basics. There was certainly a bit of a learning curve, and if you've never dealt with a text editor, you might run screaming. But with my Dos experience from the old days, I had no trouble getting around. Red Hat Linux makes you feel powerful! I give it five stars!' Eat your heart out, Bill Gates.

webTitle: Clicks and mortar leave property crumbling away

fields.headline: Clicks and mortar leave property crumbling away
fields.trailText: Throg Street
fields.body:
The property market looks in pretty good health. Rents are rising again after a brief dip last year and so are capital values - surveyor Richard Ellis estimates the increase at around 8 per cent a year.

So why are some of the leading property companies trading at such low prices? Land Securities currently stands at more than a third below estimates of what its property will be worth at its March year-end; British Land is at a 40 per cent discount; and even Hammerson and Slough Estates, among the more popular with investors, are trading at a fifth below expected net asset values.

The low ratings are partly because value investing, or buying shares when they are cheap, has been replaced by growth investing - which, in the past few months, has seemed to mean buying shares because they are outrageously expensive.

Companies involved in bricks and mortar - or brewing, engineering, housebuilding, restaurants or virtually anything without a dot.com or a technological gizmo to sell - have been ignored by investors desperately searching out the clicks and mortar companies that seem to double in price every week. Land Securities and British Land, the only two FTSE-100 property stocks, have suffered the biggest falls because their shares are the easiest to trade.

But there is more to the falls than Internet mania. Investors are starting to get nervous about two specific parts of the property market: retailers and the City. Land Securities has about half its assets in shops and retail warehouses, while British Land has a similar proportion in City offices, so it is hardly surprising that they have bigger discounts than Slough, whose strength is in trendy industrial warehouses, and Hammerson, which has respected management and a good geographical spread.

The question is: has the de-rating gone too far? In the City, the worry is about over-supply - cranes are again much in evidence, and Land Securities is one of those contemplating adding more of its own. High-street retailers are struggling, as the rash of Christmas trading statements expected over the next few weeks is likely to confirm. That is bad news for their shareholders, but it will concern their landlords only if they stop paying their rent - which could well happen.

Property analysts at Merrill Lynch say that there are 'real concerns' about the financial viability of some retailers, and signs that some are trying to offload their leases.

That includes some of the large ones. Storehouse, the Mothercare and BhS group, and Arcadia, owner of brands including Dorothy Perkins and Burtons, may not be insolvent, but there are real concerns about their futures. Both are seen as takeover targets, and there is no guarantee that a buyer, assuming one can be found, will want all the properties. Finding replacement tenants would be easy in a busy shopping centre, but well-nigh impossible in many high streets.

However, the risk of tenant defaults should not be overdone. Even the most pessimistic of forecasters would not suggest that a collapse on the scale seen in the late 1980s is likely: supply has been much more tightly controlled, and the economy is looking robust, notwithstanding rising interest rates.

The discounts at British Land and Land Securities are more than twice their historic average: that is too high.

But buyers should not expect them to narrow quickly. Technology stocks may have been hit last week, but that does not mean that investors are preparing to rush into old-fashioned cyclicals. Buyers of these must be patient.

Signet rings tills

Patience has paid off for investors in the Signet jewellery group. An 8.9 per cent rise in sales in the 48 weeks to Christmas and the promise that profits for the full year will be 'well ahead' of expectations is the kind of news the market has been waiting for since James McAdam was shipped in as chairman to tidy up the mess made by his predecessor Gerald Ratner.

About the only thing Ratner would now recognise at the chain is the feel-good factor, evident on a scale not seen since his heyday in the 1980s.

We are treating ourselves to designer labels, to bigger and better watches, to more diamonds. Signet is cashing in handsomely: in Britain, pre-Christmas sales were up 11.2 per cent, and over the 48 weeks as a whole they rose by 4.5 per cent.

In the US, Signet continues to confound those who warn that its sales growth must slow, with another 11.3 per cent like-for-like sales rise. Analysts, already expecting profits to rise from £89.2 million to £104m, are now expecting at least £120m - more than a third up on last year.

Can the momentum continue? McAdam points to the potential for continuing Signet's US opening programme through its conventional Kay stores in shopping malls and its new Jared format of 'category killer' superstores, both of which he believes could be expanded by at least 100 stores. In Britain, the story remains one of maximising the available space rather than expanding it. The company still has a quarter of its H Samuel stores to refurbish, and should be able to reap further benefits from improvements in design and stock replenishments.

The shares have risen strongly in the past six months, jumping again last week. But, based on the upgraded forecasts, they still stand on just 14 times expected earnings. They could have further to go.

Bitten by the bug

Those who warned that the Internet frenzy of the last six weeks of 1999 could only end in disaster have been partially vindicated by last week's events. Technology stocks were the biggest fallers - ARM Holdings even had to suffer the indignity of being downgraded to 'market performer' (the equivalent of a hold) by Goldman Sachs -and there was some sign of interest in old-fashioned businesses such as engineers and even some retailers.

But a week's trading is not enough to mark the start of a new trend. Indeed, the signs are that the falls were virtually the only noticeable side-effect of the millennium bug. Fears about its impact had kept big investors out of the market in the run-up to 1 January, leaving frenzied private investors to set the pace. The return of the serious money has had a calming effect, but it does not mean the technology bubble has burst - yet.

fields.headline: Labour isn't working hard enough
fields.trailText: Few people I know would dissent from the proposition that we have a right-of-centre Government pursuing highly orthodox economic policies. This helps to explain the problems of the Opposition (although it does not entirely account for them). And it makes an even bigger nonsense of the weird Blair 'project', which is supposed to be founded on the idea that the twentieth century was a Conservative one and the first century of the new millennium must therefore be a Labour one.
fields.body:
Few people I know would dissent from the proposition that we have a right-of-centre Government pursuing highly orthodox economic policies. This helps to explain the problems of the Opposition (although it does not entirely account for them). And it makes an even bigger nonsense of the weird Blair 'project', which is supposed to be founded on the idea that the twentieth century was a Conservative one and the first century of the new millennium must therefore be a Labour one.

There are of course exceptions to this general proposition. As the inner Blair circle insists: 'We are doing many good things.' Yes, but there are many other good things they are not doing, indeed may be incapable of doing, given the constraints (or policies) they have imposed themselves.

Do you remember the closing decades of the last millennium? It is surely not too difficult to recall how Labour repeatedly attacked Conservative tax cuts; privatisation; the get-rich-quick, fat-cat society; and the seeming indifference towards the public sector and the less fortunate members of society. What scorn the Labour Opposition poured on an increasingly easy victim! Why, it was as if, especially in its latter phases under John Major, the Conservative Party was confined to the stocks - a victim that could not escape the rotten fruit being pelted on it.

Of course, in opposition the Tories are an even bigger object of ridicule. But the interesting thing is that New Labour has accepted so much of the Thatcherite Settlement when it comes to actual policies, moving in some cases - although matters such as the threat to trial by jury are not the province of the economics commentator - even further to the right.

Perhaps the biggest irony is that Margaret Thatcher was thrown out by a party fed up with her anti-Europeanism and the way she tried to push her luck too far (via the poll tax); yet the present Conservative Party seems as anti-European as Thatcher would have hoped, and is once again basing its economic strategy on reducing taxation.

Taxation - 'getting and spending' - is central to the function of government. There is little doubt that in the past the Labour Party was rather inclined to tax and spend for the sake of it, and less interested than it professes to be now in what is known as 'value for money'. On the other hand, even during the Callaghan 1976-79 government, Labour was beginning to adopt a more reasonable approach. It was Anthony Crosland who decreed 'the party is over' for local government spending; and it was Denis Healey and the Labour-inclined Treasury civil servant Sir Leo Pliatzky (who died last year) who got a grip on public spending at that time.

But it has taken another two decades for Labour to shed its reputation for profligacy with other people's money. In the process, New Labour has treated us to such absurd soundbites as 'we do not believe in policies of tax and spend' - in which case, why stand for office at all?

Sometimes this giant of a Government, with its parliamentary majority of 180, gives the impression of being almost muscle-bound. It sits there, haunted by the loss of the general election of 1992, when tax was indubitably an issue. Ministers recall the way London-based journalists suddenly woke up to the implications of John Smith's Shadow Budget for their own tax rates, and gave maximum publicity to 'Labour's tax plans'.

In Opposition, Labour used to deride Thatcher for refusing to use public funds to build the Channel Tunnel. Shadow Ministers were brilliant at mocking the kind of contortions that lie behind the private finance initiative (PFI). Beachcomber himself could not have dreamed up such a labyrinthine way of avoiding the simple fact that some things are best financed by the public sector, and some are not.

The long-term economics of the PFI are notoriously suspect, and likely to give the taxpayer less 'value for money' than before.

Even under Ken Livingstone (part one) the 'natural monopoly' of London Underground could have been made profitable by closing half the 'uneconomic' lines. But that is not the point. London needs a decent transport system: it is what economists call 'a public good' and there are all sorts of what are known in the trade as 'externalities' (bad consequences) for a city that does not have a decent public transport system.

The Blair government has made itself a laughing stock over the London mayor; and one reason for this is the vulnerability of its confused plans for dealing with public - repeat public - transport.

Gordon Brown recently allowed himself to be tied publicly in knots by the Parliamentary Treasury Committee because he does not like to practise what he preaches about 'transparency' when it comes to the thorny issue of taxation. The 'stealth tax' approach is already running into trouble. I have wondered for some time how this Government will, in the long run, come out of a policy which encourages people to take up private pensions but simultaneously levies stealth taxes on pen sion funds. But in the short run, as the Pre-Budget Report in effect conceded, there is already a limit to the public's tolerance of escalating energy taxes.

On the other hand revenues are being boosted by better-than-expected economic growth. The Chancellor last year came very well out of sticking to his 1-1.5 per cent growth forecast for 1999 when most around him, especially in the press and the City, were losing their nerve. In his Pre-Budget Report he acknowledged that he had been wrong - growth may be 1.75 per cent. And the latest Treasury estimates put it at around 2 per cent for 1999.

But the magnitude of the public spending and social problems facing the Government suggests that something major is going to be required on the tax-and-spend front if concerns about public services are to be alleviated.

Our continental neighbours are much less pusillanimous about the so-called restraints on freedom of action imposed by 'globalisation'. The Scandinavian social model, for instance seems to be performing well despite - or perhaps because of - higher taxes. They are in the new millennium; it is time for the real Labour Party to stand up and be counted.

webTitle: Dunces excel in the knowledge economy

fields.headline: Dunces excel in the knowledge economy
fields.trailText: While all the fashionable blather is of a knowledge economy, the evidence points to an emergence of the 'ignorance economy'.
fields.body:
While all the fashionable blather is of a knowledge economy, the evidence points to an emergence of the 'ignorance economy'.

What constitutes the booming ignorance economy is largely what has fuelled the knowledge economy - soaring share prices, low unemployment, contained inflation. The critical difference is that in the former, knowledge is the bar rather than the spur to growth. Let's take three separate instances of the ignorance economy that have clearly manifested themselves in the past week.

 One: the millennium bug and the cost of keeping it at bay.

 Two: the continual yo-yoing of the value of technology stocks.

 Three: the criticism of the Government for its poor record in buying and implementing computer systems.

The unifying factor in all of the above is that while our economy is being dictated by technological change, at least 95 per cent of business people, commentators and Government officials have little or no technological knowledge of even the most basic kind.

If we are told that the Y2K bug will cost our company £500 million to put right, how many people on the board would be able to authoritatively contradict that advice, or dare to ignore it? We find that it cost Russia $200m to treat its bug, while the US splashed out an estimated $100 billion. Who was right? Were we had? Nobody knows for sure. And clearly the fewer people in the know, the more they can charge for their services.

Nowhere is there a clearer demonstration of the ignorance economy than in the high-tech stock buying in the US and the UK. Our own personal favourite is Freeserve, which continues to hold a valuation of £5bn despite the fact that it has yet to turn a profit or even prove that it can. But at least Freeserve has a brand and customers.

The latest star of the stock market - JellyWorks, a turbo-charged portfolio of Internet interests run by 24-year-old Jonathan Rowland - has soared to unrealistic levels. Nobody can explain why Internet companies are worth maybe 300 times earnings, because no one knows. We can only guess which of them could grow up to be the next General Electric.

And then we are told by a cross-party Select Committee what most of us have known for some time - that the public investment in IT by Whitehall and government has often been disastrous. In this column I have asked previously why ICL has so many concurrent Government contracts, and why so many have apparently gone wrong. Here again we have the problem that on major IT projects at agencies such as the Post Office and the Passport Office, the number of companies of a size and assumed competence to do the work is limited. ICL is no worse than Siemens or EDS, and at least it is based in Britain. But at the end of the day the Government's lack of knowledge about IT systems has undoubtedly cost it dear.

Don't get me wrong, the ignorance economy is liberating in some ways. It has already created and redistributed vast amounts of wealth. Its inherent optimism keeps stock markets from crashing or shareholders from requesting old-fashioned things such as profits. Money and optimism recycled into the economy in such unquestioned amounts are fine so long as a reality never intervenes.

IT consultants are the twenty-first century equivalent of economists: theorists who entertain us with their views and voodoo numbers, but who, in time, will prove to have been right and wrong in equal measure.

The inexplicable phenomenon of the ever-growing US economy has even led to the totemising of the head of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan. Reappointed for another four years by President Clinton, Greenspan is a man of enormous knowledge but even greater luck. And with so much of the commercial world in a state of uncertainty - and ignorance - what better attribute could one have than luck?

emily.bell@observer.co.uk
fields.bodyText: While all the fashionable blather is of a knowledge economy, the evidence points to an emergence of the 'ignorance economy'. What constitutes the booming ignorance economy is largely what has fuelled the knowledge economy - soaring share prices, low unemployment, contained inflation. The critical difference is that in the former, knowledge is the bar rather than the spur to growth. Let's take three separate instances of the ignorance economy that have clearly manifested themselves in the past week.  One: the millennium bug and the cost of keeping it at bay.  Two: the continual yo-yoing of the value of technology stocks.  Three: the criticism of the Government for its poor record in buying and implementing computer systems. The unifying factor in all of the above is that while our economy is being dictated by technological change, at least 95 per cent of business people, commentators and Government officials have little or no technological knowledge of even the most basic kind. If we are told that the Y2K bug will cost our company £500 million to put right, how many people on the board would be able to authoritatively contradict that advice, or dare to ignore it? We find that it cost Russia $200m to treat its bug, while the US splashed out an estimated $100 billion. Who was right? Were we had? Nobody knows for sure. And clearly the fewer people in the know, the more they can charge for their services. Nowhere is there a clearer demonstration of the ignorance economy than in the high-tech stock buying in the US and the UK. Our own personal favourite is Freeserve, which continues to hold a valuation of £5bn despite the fact that it has yet to turn a profit or even prove that it can. But at least Freeserve has a brand and customers. The latest star of the stock market - JellyWorks, a turbo-charged portfolio of Internet interests run by 24-year-old Jonathan Rowland - has soared to unrealistic levels. Nobody can explain why Internet companies are worth maybe 300 times earnings, because no one knows. We can only guess which of them could grow up to be the next General Electric. And then we are told by a cross-party Select Committee what most of us have known for some time - that the public investment in IT by Whitehall and government has often been disastrous. In this column I have asked previously why ICL has so many concurrent Government contracts, and why so many have apparently gone wrong. Here again we have the problem that on major IT projects at agencies such as the Post Office and the Passport Office, the number of companies of a size and assumed competence to do the work is limited. ICL is no worse than Siemens or EDS, and at least it is based in Britain. But at the end of the day the Government's lack of knowledge about IT systems has undoubtedly cost it dear. Don't get me wrong, the ignorance economy is liberating in some ways. It has already created and redistributed vast amounts of wealth. Its inherent optimism keeps stock markets from crashing or shareholders from requesting old-fashioned things such as profits. Money and optimism recycled into the economy in such unquestioned amounts are fine so long as a reality never intervenes. IT consultants are the twenty-first century equivalent of economists: theorists who entertain us with their views and voodoo numbers, but who, in time, will prove to have been right and wrong in equal measure. The inexplicable phenomenon of the ever-growing US economy has even led to the totemising of the head of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan. Reappointed for another four years by President Clinton, Greenspan is a man of enormous knowledge but even greater luck. And with so much of the commercial world in a state of uncertainty - and ignorance - what better attribute could one have than luck? emily.bell@observer.co.uk

webTitle: On the press: Grim Reaper threatens first-class Mail

fields.headline: On the press: Grim Reaper threatens first-class Mail
fields.trailText: What goes up (as Mr Marks might have said to Mr Spencer) can come down with an almighty wallop. It's a prudent post-millennial exercise to look at the highest flyers of the twentieth century and see where the cracks could open. That, for a press watcher, means looking hard at the Daily Mail.
fields.body:
What goes up (as Mr Marks might have said to Mr Spencer) can come down with an almighty wallop. It's a prudent post-millennial exercise to look at the highest flyers of the twentieth century and see where the cracks could open. That, for a press watcher, means looking hard at the Daily Mail. The biggest success around always has furthest to fall.

Modern Daily Mail history, indeed, makes exactly that point. Thirty years ago the Mail was slithering into the pits, selling less than 2 million, and the Express, its arch rival, had a 1.6 million lead. Game over? Look at the last ABC figures, for November 1999. The Mail is on 2,371,000 and rising; the Express is on 1,044,000 - and falling.

What's the secret? Two brilliantly professional editors in succession: David English and Paul Dacre. One exceptional proprietor: the late Lord Rothermere, who put his money into journalism and marketing (exactly where lip-pursed accountants seem to think it shouldn't go). It was a long, gritty haul to re-build a brand, but it stands today as an exemplar for the rest of Fleet Street.

Examine some of the more glowing statistics. Only four national papers emerged from the Nineties with their circulations increased. One (the FT ) found its gains abroad. One (the Times ) used price-cutting for a competitive edge. The other two were the Mail - up from 1,727,000 in November 1989 - and the Mail on Sunday, up from 1,880,000 to 2,310,000. Both were real winners.

Such strength, moreover, comes with depth attached. The Daily Mail and General Trust finished 1999 with pre-tax profits up 9 per cent to £201.9 million. Circulation revenue on the Mail and the Mail on Sunda y was up by 11 per cent - and ad revenue by 15 per cent. No instant collywobbles about Internet doom either. Display ad revenue from Net companies hunting print exposure was up from 1 per cent to 5 per cent. The immediate future looks pretty roseate.

Nor, on the detailed facts of readership, will it be easily blighted. The Mail has as many social grade A readers as the Times, and more ABC1s than the Times and Telegraph put together. Its percentage of women readers to men - 50-50 - is the best balanced of any daily paper. Its total adult readership is only 70,000 or so shy of the Guardian, Independent, Times and Telegraph combined. Its Saturday Weekend magazine - with 6,290,000 readers and a 96 per cent spillover from the main paper - is by far the star performer in that class.

But, of course, the great game of survival for newspapers is never over, either, and age is always going about its withering business. The Mail, at 23 per cent, has a slightly smaller proportion of readers over 65 than the Telegraph (27 per cent) or the Express (28 per cent), but that still means there are 1,315,000 of them out there, more than the famous four broadsheets combined. Add in everyone over 45, and that totals 60 per cent - as opposed to some 49 per cent on the Times. Only 10 per cent of Mail readers are under 24, some 5 per cent off the best broadsheet pace. Our old chum the Grim Reaper has a role to play here. The Mail, partly because of its past triumphs, will have to keep running hard merely to stand still.

Is it fit for a sprint? Success exacts its own penalties in the loss, Tesco-style, of the best executives to flagging rivals. Thus it is, too, in Fleet Street, where demand for graduates from the Mail Academy is ferocious - quite apart from the strain that Associated's own Net forays and the proliferation of Metro freesheets exerts. You can't lose English and Rothermere, dead within a few months in 1998, and not feel the strain.The need to find and grow new backroom talent is absolute.

And this is perhaps also the case in the front room at Derry Street. The Mail's great writing stars - Ann Leslie, Lynda Lee Potter, Ian Wooldridge - are all in their sixties. They won't go on forever, though it would be good if they could. Nigel Dempster, erstwhile gadfly about town, turns 60 this year, and his happening column is full of non-happenings. (Who else, collating scoops of the year, would boast of bringing first news of Kerry Packer's eighth heart attack?)

Politically, too, horizons have shrunk. Paul Johnson, Simon Heffer and Bruce Anderson as your political strike force - with Stephen Glover playing young left wing? The formula can be fetid, going on choking for sheer lack of variety. So - even for Europhobes, I guess - is the endless rooting of all evils in Brussels. So, without a whiff of politics, are the endless features in which five variegated women (from stick-shaped to pear-shaped) react to some anodyne dilemma.

There are times, in short, when the formula alone seems king and greater minds are concentrated elsewhere (maybe Metroland). The news sense is still sharp, but tabloids such as the Mirror are snapping upmarket with mags such as M and drawing only a half-hearted riposte. The production innovation stream has run a little dry since Weekend.

Does that matter? Not for a year or two, surely. Momentum takes a long time to wane, and a fresh burst of creativity will surely carry it on. Dacre has a lot left in his locker. DMGT remains a long-term buy. But still, perhaps, take nothing for granted (as Mr Spencer should have told Mr Marks).

fields.headline: Retailers lose on first e-Christmas
fields.trailText: Orders placed with Internet shopping sites were lower than expected over the Christmas period, and the widely predicted boom failed to happen. The 'e-tail' flop caught out many new entrepreneurs, and even some established retail names, according to the first analysis of seasonal Net trading.
fields.body:
Orders placed with Internet shopping sites were lower than expected over the Christmas period, and the widely predicted boom failed to happen. The 'e-tail' flop caught out many new entrepreneurs, and even some established retail names, according to the first analysis of seasonal Net trading.

Retailers' losses from the first 'e-Christmas' add up to about £75 million, says specialist consultancy firm E-Insight. The firm, which used mystery shoppers to test a range of web retailers, found services wanting. More than a third of orders were not delivered as promised. Some didn't arrive in time or the wrong goods were delivered.

Spending failed to meet pre-Christmas predictions of up to £500m. Sales totalled a disappointing £200m, the survey estimates.

'Bricks and mortar retailers are dabbling in e-tail thinking that they can achieve their goals by using existing systems of distribution and marketing but this means their costs are swallowing up any profit they are making and costing them money,' said E-Insight's chief executive Alan Taylor.

Firms such as Marks & Spencer and Woolworths launched Internet shopping sites only weeks before Christmas, and for a fraction of their ranges. A spokesman for M&S said: 'The intention was to test customer demand so that we could expand. We will put 3,000 items online by the spring.'

But smaller companies who have secured millions of pounds of venture capital, turning their young bosses into paper millionaires, will struggle, Taylor said.

'Many of these start-up dotcoms have been profligate in their approach to marketing expenditure. We are seeing the investor community becoming increasingly careful because they are not seeing the yield they expected.'

Supermarket giant Sainsbury's receives heavy criticism in a report by leading investment bank Goldman Sachs. Its home delivery service is 'difficult to navigate and a far from satisfying experience' analysts say.

webTitle: Which exercise is right for you?

fields.headline: Which exercise is right for you?
fields.standfirst: No two bodies are the same - and there's no one exercise programme that's right for everyone. Here's how to find one that suits you.
fields.trailText: No two bodies are the same - and there's no one exercise programme that's right for everyone. Here's how to find one that suits you.
fields.body:
Excercise is a vital part of the new you programme. By moving, toning and stretching our bodies we can develop not only a better-looking physique but a healthier, stronger body that feels and acts as it was naturally made to do.

But most of us find exercise a chore. As part of a programme to motivate non-exercisers to work out, US-based fitness trainer Michael Gerrish researched the most common reasons why people don't exercise. He found number one is time, two is lack of confidence in physical ability and the rest were a mix of embarrassment about body size, lack of support, perceived cost, lack of results and boredom. Yet none are a natural by-product of exercise. Instead they are the result of people working on programmes that don't suit their lifestyle, their body type, their personality or even their fitness goals. 'And if you do this, you might as well give up and go home,' says Stuart Biddle, professor of exercise and sports psychology at Loughborough University. 'So many of us exercise in the way we think we should, not the way we want.'

Choosing a programme that's right for you is the most important element in choosing a fitness plan you'll stick to. This means analysing a number of factors. You need to look at your natural body type and what it needs to shape it up. According to leading body-type expert Carolyn L Mein who is based in San Diego, bodies come in four types, each governed by a different gland in the body. 'These glands determine our body shape, the foods we crave and our energy levels. If you choose an exercise plan which goes against them you'll be working against the natural strengths of your body,' she explains.

You should assess practical factors, such as what your aims are for the plan you choose; how much time you have; where you can work out and, if necessary, who you need to work out with. Then, find exercise attributes that fit your personality. 'Our personal preferences and traits influence everything we enjoy in life, yet so many of us don't take them into account when we plan an exercise programme,' says Stuart Biddle. 'People take up jogging because they think that's what exercise is - and wonder why they hate it.'

How do you assess all this in one go? Start with the questionnaire on this page, which will guide you to the exercise choice most suitable for you. The volunteers pictured here have completed the quiz; next week, we'll see how they've got on with their chosen activity.

WHY SHOULD YOU EXERCISE?
Apart from toning up your body, exercise has a huge number of health benefits that you tap into when you start to work out - whichever plan is right for you. 'I don't think there's an area of your body that isn't improved by exercise,' says personal trainer Luke Wilkins. 'It's like a pill that just wipes your body's slate clean, preventing everyday illnesses, reducing the risk of killers like cancer and heart disease and even tackling day-to-day irritations like insomnia and low energy. There's nothing it can't touch - from your heart to your libido - and all these benefits come from an average of 30-40 minutes gentle effort a day.'

 Walking for three hours a week cuts your risk of heart disease by 40 per cent.

 You reduce cancer risk. For example, women who exercise reduce their risk of breast cancer by 60 per cent. l Colon cancer risk drops by 10 per cent for every half-hour a day you walk

 Two-thirds of exercisers say they are less stressed than before they worked out.

 Exercisers visit the doctor 50 per cent less than non exercisers.

 Walking for 40 minutes four times a week decreases the time it takes you to fall asleep by half - and increases sleep by an hour a night.

 Female exercisers are 25 per cent more likely to orgasm than non-exercisers, an effect which is heightened by a regime that builds strong abdominal muscles. Men who exercise also have heightened sexual satisfaction.

 Burning off the equivalent of 2,000 calories a week through exercise helps you live longer. It's said that every mile you run adds four seconds to your life.

fields.headline: Dome to be sold for £100m
fields.standfirst: The Millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome is to be sold for up to £100 million, in a privatisation deal that Ministers believe could rescue it from potential financial disaster.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome is to be sold for up to £100 million, in a privatisation deal that Ministers believe could rescue it from potential financial disaster.

Shaken by the negative publicity from some newspapers last week, Ministers are for the first time privately admitting that sales of tickets may only reach 10 million, two million fewer than projected in the original budget, and representing a financial shortfall of £50m.

With 12 different consortiums bidding to take over the Dome, and a short list due to be announced in the next few days, Ministers claim the New Millennium Experience Company is sitting on a substantial asset. A final choice will be made by the Government in the summer.

One Minister said: 'We think the building is now one of the most famous and admired in the world. We are going to get a very substantial bid for the building.'

Any bidder will have to pay for the building itself, as well as for the land. The building is 13 times bigger than the Royal Albert Hall.

The Dome has no unspent contingency fund left in its £758m budget, making it vulnerable to a cash shortfall if sales do plummet.

Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's Press Secretary, last week held a special briefing to attack the media for failing to report the alleged popularity of the exhibition with the visiting public.

If sales do not rise, Ministers believe they will be saved from financial catastrophe by the competition between commercial consortiums to take over the Dome from 2001.

The New Millenium Experience had set aside only £15m in its budget for the disposal of the assets as scrap. All sides accept this figure is ludicrously low. Bids for the Dome include consortiums wanting a venue for a snow dome, Charlton Athletic, a conference centre, a sports stadium, a trade fair exhibition hall, a film theme park and a film studio.

Queues and confusion continued to dog the Dome yesterday as opposition politicians lined up to attack the Government on its handling of the affair. Visitors at times faced waits of up to an hour to enter the Body Zone. At one point, staff struggled to manage the queue which crossed the main thoroughfare.

fields.headline: Millennial divorce rush
fields.standfirst: The Millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Brtions are marking the new millennium by divorcing in unprecedented numbers, putting huge pressure on overstretched counselling services.
fields.body:
Brtions are marking the new millennium by divorcing in unprecedented numbers, putting huge pressure on overstretched counselling services.

Dubbed the 'clean slate syndrome' by psychotherapists, a new determination to question relationships or start afresh has already prompted emergency recruitment drives by the Samaritans and Relate.

'It's chaos,' said the manager of the Relate office in Birmingham. 'The phone hasn't stopped ringing, and we have nothing like enough counsellors to meet demand.'

Counsellors are blaming millennial media hype and a huge gap between expectations and reality - especially over sex during the festive period - for the huge upturn in numbers seeking better relationships.

'There has been so much hype, so much expectation piled onto people that the backlash was inevitable,' said Sandra Bourton, manager of Portsmouth and district Relate. The office took 57 calls in the first day of the year, more than twice the level last year.

London Marriage Guidance is braced for a surge of calls this week when family routine returns to normal, says manager Judy Cunnington.

Britain's largest helpline, the Samaritans, was deluged with calls between Christmas and New Year, and figures are expected to show a substantial increase on the record of 124,000 calls for the same period last year.

'We have spoken to callers ringing from boxes in the middle of the city, clutching a suitcase and saying that they needed to leave right now and that they've done it,' said Joan, a volunteer at the Glasgow centre.

'People pack their bags and go because they don't want another year like the last one. I think this will go on throughout January. This year is worse because the callers I have spoken to thought that this would be a wonderful time, but it wasn't as magical as they hoped.'

In London, the Soho-based centre is so stretched that it will launch a new recruiting campaign this week. 'A lot of people have been holding out for the millennium for a whole year and the pressure on families to be a happy unit has been enormous,' said volunteer Lois.

'Callers have told us that they have got through the Christmas and millennium period and stayed for someone else - the kids, their partner or their extended family - rather than for themselves. If there were already stresses in a relationship then this is when it breaks up. People are emotionally as well as financially in the red.'

Julia Cole, a spokesperson for Relate, said that the beginning of a new century had prompted a new scrutiny of relationships. Sexual problems, always uppermost in people's minds after a holiday period, seemed especially widespread. 'There is an expectation that along with the perfect lunch, the perfect presents, the perfect New Year's Eve, there will be lovely, perfect sex. The contrast between the expectations and reality is often enormous.'

'It's chaos,' said the manager of the Relate office in Birmingham. 'The phone hasn't stopped ringing, and we have nothing like enough counsellors to meet demand.' 'There has been so much hype, so much expectation piled onto people that the backlash was inevitable,' said Sandra Bourton, manager of Portsmouth and district Relate.
