webTitle: 'Fat cat' stars force BBC to seek new talent

fields.headline: 'Fat cat' stars force BBC to seek new talent
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Producers of Stars in Their Eyes, New Faces and Opportunity Knocks can eat their hearts out. Faced with the desertion of top stars to ITV and Sky, the BBC is hosting a year-long series of talent contests to find the next generation of megastars.
fields.body:
Producers of Stars in Their Eyes, New Faces and Opportunity Knocks can eat their hearts out. Faced with the desertion of top stars to ITV and Sky, the BBC is hosting a year-long series of talent contests to find the next generation of megastars.

BBC chiefs complain that 'greedy' stars who learnt their trade at the corporation are now demanding spiralling fees, and they are now asking the Government for millions of pounds to fund the biggest search for new talent in the corporation's history.

'The commitment is huge. It's vital to our future,' one BBC insider said last week. 'We need to find the next Richard Curtis, Zoe Ball, Jeremy Paxman, Chris Moyles and Sara Cox. We need the next Fast Show. This is a long-term commitment. It's about staying in touch with audiences and making sure the next generation of talent is with the BBC.'

Chris Smith, the Culture Secretary, believes that the BBC should have its share of big names but questions whether their stars should be allowed to draw 'fat cat' salaries.

Smith is expected to announce a sharp rise in BBC funding when he responds next week to the Davies committee's recommendations on the future of the corporation and a key House of Commons select committee report on it. Licence-payers are expected to have to pay up to £20 a year more.

This new money will help to fund the search for stars. The corporation is desperate for new comedy writers, actors, DJs and producers as well as presenters.

BBC bosses hope to convince the Government that the corporation will not waste licence-payers' money on big salaries for money-grabbing stars.

The competitions are the brainchild of Robert Warr, a former director of EMI and manager of the Eighties pop bands Human League and Heaven 17, and Angie Stephenson, head of the BBC's Talent Forum. Warr was appointed BBC Controller of Talent at the end of last year following a haemorrhage of big names over the past three years.

Des Lynam, Barry Norman and Frank Skinner have all defected to the independent sector for multi-million- pound contracts after being spotted and nurtured by the BBC. Lynam is said to have signed a deal worth around £5 million over four years. Skinner left after the corporation refused to pay the £20m he was allegedly demanding for a further series. BSkyB has signed David Baddiel for a reported £5.5m to pen a 22-part sitcom.

Internal BBC figures submitted to Ministers show that talent inflation is running at an average 17 per cent a year, largely due to the increase in commercial TV outlets which can offer massive fees. In key areas like comedy quiz shows, popular factual programmes and chat shows the figure rises to 40 per cent. In his report on the future funding of the BBC, Gavyn Davies, the Goldman Sachs economist, estimated that 'superinflation' in talent and rights may add around £250m to the corporation's costs by 2006.

The trend began in America where the stars of Friends doubled their wages by threatening to strike. Channel 4 last month paid almost £125m in a three-year deal for Friends, ER and several other American dramas. If the trend continues, observers say, it will not be long before the first £1 billion show emerges.

Warr told The Observer that the BBC would not rule out paying big wages in the future. In particular, the corporation is keen to hang on to celebrities such as Steve Coogan, Sue Lawley, Angus Deayton, Clive Anderson and Carol Smillie.

But he pointed out that commercial channels can more readily justify the salaries for star names since they boost ratings, and therefore advertising revenue.

The talent competitions, building on the success of one-off contests, such as the young musician of the year, will be launched on 9 March and will reach a crescendo at the end of the year. They will cover most BBC output including sitcoms, game shows, DJs and TV presenters. Winners will be offered six-month contracts.

Warr said: 'We do some of this already, but we get very little recognition for it. We now need to do this on a bigger scale in the face of the competition from commercial TV.'

He hopes the contests will persuade young talent to stay with the BBC by promising to offer a broader career path than ITV. 'We just operate in more genres and can offer people a more varied career. This is not the kind of competition where winners are told, "Here's your cheque, now off you go". We will spot new talent and give it the chance to grow.'

Star Earners: Salaries paid by the BBC

Vanessa Feltz £1 million

Zoe Ball £1 million

Carol Vorderman £1 million

Kirsty Wark £1 million

Charlie Dimmock £600,000

Gary Lineker £500,000

Jeremy Paxman £300,000

John Humphrys £120,000

James Naughtie £120,000

Sue MacGregor £100,000

Carol Smillie £500,000

Michael Parkinson £180,000 (for Parkinson alone)

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Branson takes on six rivals to run National Lottery
fields.body:
Branson takes on six rivals to run National Lottery

Seven bidders intend to throw their hats into the ring to run the National Lottery from 2001. Among the challengers to Camelot is Virgin's Richard Branson and his People's Lottery. Trigger 7 Lotto - a consortium of seven UK corporate bodies - is among the other bidders.

Peru coma man may be Irish

Irish and Peruvian authorities are trying to identify a man who has been in a coma in the Peruvian capital Lima since being injured in a hang-gliding accident before Christmas. During a brief recovery he indicated to doctors that he was Irish and at one point appeared to mouth the word 'Patrick'.

Twin maternities

Maria Harrison, 30, of Filey, North Yorkshire, has given birth in Leeds to what are believed to be the first test-tube quadruplets in Britain born more than a year apart. After having twin girls following IVF treatment 19 months ago, another two fertilised eggs from the same batch were implanted. The second set of twins are a boy and a girl.

Hindley to face brain operation

Moors murderer Myra Hindley, 57, who faces emergency surgery to ease a potentially fatal brain swelling, remained in prison but could be moved at any time to Addenbrooke's Hospital in Cambridge.

Police question four people over the death of baby

Four people were questioned about the the death of a six-month-old boy in Edgbaston, Birmingham.

Diving for dentures

Frogmen diving under the Palace Pier in Brighton have found false teeth, sunglasses and bullets. Some divers cover their expenses by finding coins. Other discoveries include chairs and knives.

Farewell to drugs girl

The funeral took place yesterday of Kerry-Ann Betts, 15, of Coatbridge, Lanarkshire, believed to one of the Scotland's youngest victims of illegal drugs.

Finance Minister's niece killed in road accident

A niece of Northern Ireland Finance Minister Mark Durkan was killed in a road accident in Co Derry yesterday. Deirdre Durkan, 18, died when a Volvo car in which she was a rear-seat passenger crashed off the Desertmartin Road outside Moneymore and hit a post.

Three other members of the family were in the car but escaped with severe shock. The RUC said no other vehicle was involved in the accident. Miss Durkan lived at Edenmount Park, Derry.

webTitle: FA on the attack as paedophiles target football's talent factories

fields.headline: FA on the attack as paedophiles target football's talent factories
fields.standfirst: Former Scottish international Alan Brazil is one who suffered physical abuse as a young player. Now at last a campaign has begun to cleanse soccer of a long-standing scandal
fields.trailText: Former Scottish international Alan Brazil is one who suffered physical abuse as a young player. Now at last a campaign has begun to cleanse soccer of a long-standing scandal
fields.body:
It is the dream of parents everywhere. Their son stands out from his classmates at football, gets spotted by a Premiership club and is soon being touted as the next David Beckham or Michael Owen. While other teenagers study mathematics and geography at school, he attends a footballing academy and learns how to dribble, tackle and shoot.

But there is a dark side to the glamour of soccer's talent factories. An Observer investigation has found that gifted youngsters being groomed at football academies as the stars of tomorrow are being targeted by paedophiles.

Football is taking the threat so seriously that all 92 professional clubs in England's four leagues are taking action to stop boys being exploited. Fears escalated about possible abuse after it emerged last week that a coach with a leading Premiership team has been suspended from his post pending an investigation into allegations that he physically assaulted youths in his charge.

The news comes as the football authorities in England launch an initiative to protect their young stars. Clubs from the Premiership and Nationwide Leagues are attending a series of workshops this month to develop a co-ordinated strategy to combat the abusers.

All 92 clubs have been warned by the FA to attend the seminars or risk losing their licence to run centres of excellence. Experts from football, the National Coaching Foundation and the NSPCC will advise clubs on preventing infiltration by paedophiles.

The conviction of youth coaches at Crystal Palace, Crewe Alexandra and Celtic for physical or sexual abuse has underlined the need for action. Ex-Scottish international Alan Brazil, who also played for Manchester United and Ipswich Town, was among the players abused at the Glasgow club as a junior.

In football's rush to respond, different bodies produced different regulations. But arrangements for the welfare of young players have now been laid out in the Charter for Quality, the FA's blueprint designed to restore English football to its former pre-eminence.

Peter Cates, the Premier League's chief education officer, said coaches in charge of academies had already been advised on child protection. 'We are not being complacent. We know how vulnerable some young people can be and we are committed to developing best practices to ensure high standards of care as much as actually detecting any cases of abuse.'

Cates disclosed that paedophiles who have been denied access to youngsters in other fields because of heightened vigilance about child abuse were now turning their attention to sport.

'Football is trying to be pro-active. We recognise that as more traditional areas have been closed to those trying to gain close contact with children for unhealthy reasons, they have looked elsewhere and football has been one of their targets,' he said.

'We are trying to ensure that opportunities for them are reduced as much as is humanly possible, although we accept there may well be cases in both the professional game and the junior game we do not know about.'

The training workshops will discuss the case of Graham Rix, the Chelsea coach who was jailed for having underage sex with a 15-year-old girl. This incident was unrelated to Rix's position with the club, but anyone wanting to become a coach at a football academy is now vetted and must disclose any convictions relating to children. New members of the FA's own coaches' association undergo a criminal record check by police.

Despite his crime, Rix was welcomed back to work alongside manager Gianluca Vialli at Stamford Bridge.

Aston Villa youth academy assistant director Steve Burns, who will chair one of the seminars, believes Rix would not have been received so favourably had he tried to gain employment in the ranks of junior coaches. 'With a conviction like that, it would be very difficult for him to work in the academy system as opposed to the professional game, even though each case is taken on its merits.'

Youth coaches are now bound by strict rules designed to minimise the potential for abuse. They are not allowed to give lifts home to young players and can work with only two youngsters at a time. When children are treated by physiotherapists, parents must always be present.

As foreign players flood into the British game, soccer clubs are becoming increasingly dependent on youth academies to provide home-grown talent.

If clubs want a steady supply of budding stars, they cannot afford to have a child abuse scandal damage their reputation. As Aston Villa's Steve Burns said: 'If there is a case of abuse at your particular club, you run the risk of youngsters' parents simply not trusting you ever again.'

webTitle: Defence chiefs told it's okay to be gay - but not in public

fields.headline: Defence chiefs told it's okay to be gay - but not in public
fields.trailText: The ban on homosexuality in the British armed forces will be effectively lifted this week, but public displays of affection between colleagues will remain outlawed.
fields.body:
The ban on homosexuality in the British armed forces will be effectively lifted this week, but public displays of affection between colleagues will remain outlawed.

Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon will issue a new code of social conduct, setting out a basic approach to personal relations for both homosexuals and heterosexuals.The code, to be detailed in a Commons statement, stresses that servicemen and women must always 'sustain team cohesion, trust and loyalty', and put the operational effectiveness of the service first.

The code has been forced on the British military fol lowing a landmark ruling by the European Court of Human Rights in September in favour of one woman and three men who had been dismissed from the services for being homosexual. The seven judges ruled they had suffered a gross intrusion in their private lives.

A senior government source said the code would be presented as a common-sense approach requiring all armed personnel not to make public displays of affection to colleagues. Sex between colleagues in private will not be banned. Disciplinary action will arise only if there is evidence of sexual behaviour on duty or in public places.

Traditionally the forces have argued that homosexu ality endangers forces' morale but, since the court ruling, negotiations between Ministers and defence chiefs have led to a compromise. The code, modelled on that of the Australian army, will apply to all service personnel, not just frontline staff.

Ministers had intended to delay implentation until after the next general election but feared that the Government would face a series of expensive and politically embarrassing compensation claims.

From October, discharged gay servicemen would have had an unanswerable claim for damages under European legislation in British courts.

Iain Duncan-Smith, the Shadow Defence Secretary and a former serving officer, attacked the European ruling as mistaken. 'It has always been accepted the military lose many of their rights' and the forces were a special case, he said.

He added: 'What will happen when heterosexuals say they do not want to share a shower or a barrack room with a homosexual. What happens when they say, "I'm off unless he leaves"?' He predicted resentment among heterosexuals, and called for frequent reviews of the code.

Other EU countries, including France and Germany, might not have any formal ban on gays, he said, but in practice exemptions existed for frontline officers or servicemen and women on operational duty.

webTitle: Luminous bugs to help industry pinpoint pollution

fields.headline: Luminous bugs to help industry pinpoint pollution
fields.trailText: Bacteria genetically engineered to shine like microscopic torches are helping scientists to pinpoint metal, oil and chemical pollutants.
fields.body:
Bacteria genetically engineered to shine like microscopic torches are helping scientists to pinpoint metal, oil and chemical pollutants.

Glow-in-the-dark bugs have been used to survey old petrochemical sites for contamination hot-spots and are now being launched by Remedios, a university spin-off company set up last month by the technique's academic inventors.

'With our bacteria, we can - for the first time - pinpoint badly polluted land very quickly, without knowing a site's history,' said biologist Dr Ken Killham, of Aberdeen University.

'We don't need to know if it had been home to an old gas plant or an oil refinery or metal works. Our bugs will tell us in days what is causing the pollution and where the worst hot spots are.'

The technique - developed by scientists in Killham's department, and by researchers at the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology in Monks Wood, Cambridgeshire - may become widely used over the next few months when the second part of the Environmental Protection Act is implemented by the Government.

This legislation will force local authorities to list all areas of contaminated land within their boundaries. A rapid identification technique to pinpoint these zones is therefore expected to have a wide uptake.

'Many different types of marine bacteria glow in the dark,' said Dr Liz Shaw, of the ITE.

'We have taken a gene responsible for light emission in one such strain and transferred it to a strain of bacteria that is found in the ground. As a result, we have soil bacteria that glow of their own accord.'

However, they only do so when they are healthy, say the researchers.

'In the presence of pollutants, bacteria become unhealthy, and they lose their glow,' added her colleague, Dr Elaine Boyd.

Firstly, a sample of soil is taken from a site. Then it is mixed with the glowing bacteria. Shiny, happy bacteria, which continue to emit light, indicate that the land is clean. Dim ones show that the soil is polluted.

'We can also tell what type of pollution is causing the problem,' added Killham. 'For instance, if we blast samples of contaminated soil with air, and this clears off the pollutant, we know that a volatile chemical must be involved. Typically such pollutants are made in paint production plants.'

Bugs are not the only unlikely sensor to which scientists have turned in their battle to fight pollution, however. Institute scientists have also recruited another biological ally: worms. To exploit them, researchers led by Dr Claus Svendsen remove a few cells - using a syringe - from worms dug up at a site to be tested for contamination.

'Tiny bodies called lysosomes act as rubbish bags inside a cell,' said Svendsen. 'You then inject the cells with red dye, and this should be taken up by the lysosomes.

'The cells will remain clear. But if the worm has to pass through a lot of polluted soil, its lysosomes fill up, and there is no room for dye - which then spills out into the rest of the cell. Cells that quickly turn red therefore show that a worm has been burrowing throught polluted land.

'Worms live in soil all their lives, they eat it and tunnel it. You couldn't have a better indicator of the health of a piece of land.'

fields.headline: Nats wanted Irish guns
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Official state papers released in Dublin today report how three nationalist politicians from Northern Ireland asked for arms from the Irish government at the start of the Ulster conflict.
fields.body:
Official state papers released in Dublin today report how three nationalist politicians from Northern Ireland asked for arms from the Irish government at the start of the Ulster conflict.

The request was made in August 1969, when Catholics in Belfast were said to be coming under attack from the largely Protestant and later disbanded B Specials section of the RUC.

The politicians involved were all members of the old Northern Ireland Parliament at Stormont, Belfast. The government documents named them as the late Paddy Devlin, of the Northern Ireland Labour Party, the late Paddy Kennedy, of Republican Labour, both from Belfast, and Paddy O'Hanlon, an independent from Co Armagh.

Devlin had become 'angry and emotional' when told they could not meet the then Prime Minister, the late Jack Lynch.

webTitle: How we are poisoning our wildlife

fields.headline: How we are poisoning our wildlife
fields.standfirst: Britain under threat of another 'silent spring' as owls, foxes, weasels and polecats fall victim to rat poison
fields.trailText: Scientists have discovered alarming levels of rat poisons in British wildlife. Barn owls, polecats, foxes, weasels, stoats, red kites and even some domestic cats and dogs have all been affected.
fields.body:
Scientists have discovered alarming levels of rat poisons in British wildlife. Barn owls, polecats, foxes, weasels, stoats, red kites and even some domestic cats and dogs have all been affected.

Many populations of wild animals face depletion or even eradication in an ecological disaster like the one triggered by DDT over-use in the Sixties, a calamity first highlighted in Rachel Carson's classic book, Silent Spring.

'We have not yet reached the level of another silent spring, but alarm bells should be sounding by now,' said biologist and pesticide expert Professor Robert Smith of Leicester University.

New rodenticides used by farmers since the early Eighties include chemicals such as difenacoum and bromadialone which cause rodents to bleed to death. They were introduced to replace previous poisons, such as warfarin, after rodents developed tolerance to them in many parts of the country, beginning in 1957.

These new poisons have helped to control pest numbers but suffer from a major defect: they linger longer inside rats and mice and are more toxic to birds and mammals that eat rodents. Now, two decades after their introduction, researchers are finding evidence that these chemicals are accumulating in higher-food-chain animals in worrying amounts.

A survey by scientists at the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology in Monks Wood, Cambridgeshire, involved the study of 'road-kill' barn owls. 'In 1983 about five per cent of barn owls that had been found on road verges contained second-generation rodenticides,' said Dr Richard Shore. 'Now the level is 30 per cent. More worryingly, in two per cent of samples, the poisons had been directly responsible for the birds' deaths.'

In a similar study of polecats, about 45 per cent were found to contain rat poisons, while a sample of 100 foxes revealed that 46 had been exposed to rodenticides, and ten had died directly as a consequence of eating poisoned rats or mice. About a quarter of weasels and stoats were also found to be affected.

The situation threatens to escalate. Just as warfarin resistance spread through rats and mice 20 years ago, tolerance to their replacements has begun to appear.

'A hot spot appeared in north Berkshire and south Oxfordshire several years ago,' said Dr Alan MacNicoll of the Ministry of Agriculture's Central Science Laboratory. 'Standard second-generation poisons simply won't kill rats there any more. And now resistance has appeared in rats in East Anglia, Yorkshire, Kent and other areas.'

This has caused alarm for several reasons. First, it means more rats and mice will be consuming increased amounts of rat poisons without harm. When they are eaten they will deliver heavier and more frequently lethal doses of toxin to the predators, a trend that threatens to accelerate the decline of these already threatened animals.

'Resistance also puts pressure on farmers to use even more powerful rodenticides including toxins like brodifacoum and flocoumafen,' Smith said.

'These are only supposed to be used indoors, when laid down by licensed operators. But already cases in which farmers have used them out of doors, illegally, are being uncovered.'

On top of this problem is the danger to the public. Current rat poisons are unlikely to get into the human food chain but the spread of resistance still has health implications.

Rats spread illnesses, such as Weil's disease and salmonella; they spoil crops and stores of foods; and they trigger general contamination. Super-rats would increase such problems and also threaten other wildlife species, particularly rodent varieties - voles and wood mice - with whom they share habitats.

'It is not impossible to eradicate resistant rats,' said MacNicoll. 'We tackled one farm in Berkshire where current poisons were no longer effective and managed to get rid of the rats, firstly by using a different type of rodenticide - calciferol - and then by trapping the survivors. I can't say it was an easy business, however.'

Scientists have stressed that no serious declines in predators such as the barn owl or polecat have yet been observed. 'However, when you look at the increase of rodenticide levels in these creatures, and the appearance of resistance in rats, you realise it is time to start sounding alarm bells,' said Shore.

webTitle: Radicals' debating chamber set to be a shopping mall

fields.headline: Radicals' debating chamber set to be a shopping mall
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Belfast building from which radical students in the late Sixties plotted to overthrow the Unionist-dominated Northern Ireland state seems set to be transformed into a cathedral of capitalism.
fields.body:
The Belfast building from which radical students in the late Sixties plotted to overthrow the Unionist-dominated Northern Ireland state seems set to be transformed into a cathedral of capitalism.

The Queen's University Students' Union provided a debating chamber (formerly McMordie Hall, now renamed Mandela Hall) for students who later became leading politicians in the new Northern Ireland Assembly.

Now a fresh generation of student leaders are concerned because a £50 million development plan to turn the union into a shopping mall contains no provision for a debating hall. A nightclub is to be offered to the students instead.

John McAuley, the union president, fears the stress on wooing private-sector firms into the building will mean that the undergraduates will lose out.

'The union runs one of the most successful nightclubs, Shine, in the city. But our profits are ploughed back into the union to provide for services, such as our bus service for female students who can leave the campus in safety,' he said.

'My worry is that these plans have a very heavy emphasis on outside commercial interests who naturally will want a return on their investment, and that means they will put little back into student services.

'The nightmare scenario is that these plans might lead to the union becoming a grand shopping mall for south Belfast. If the plan is accepted as it is, it will determine the nature of this place for the next 50 years. But if the commercial sector is too dominant and prices students out of the new union, the project will be a white elephant.'

He said the union was in favour of the development in principle. But he added: 'The logic of the plans as they stand now will lead to a change in the ethos at the students' union to a situation where students will be simply consumers.'

A spokesman for Queen's University said the plan offfered the opportunity to transform student services on the campus. 'It will allow us to bring our careers, accommodation, counselling and health service together on one site, alongside the students' union, bars, restaurants and entertainment facilities.

'It will be part of a complex which includes state-of-the-art theatre and film space which will enhance teaching and the cultural life of Queen's and the community it serves,' he said.

But one of Queen's famous graduates, writer and broadcaster Eamon McCann, lamented the proposals. In the late Sixties, McCann belonged to a left-wing student group, People's Democracy, which became the radical cutting edge of the Northern Ireland civil rights movement.

McCann, a veteran of protests, debates and demonstrations at the union building, said: 'These plans suggest that the university authorities are turning Queen's into a training ground for indus try rather than as a crucible for the citizens of the future.

'Many of the political leaders today are graduates who cut their teeth in political debates at Queen's. Can you imagine Northern Ireland in 2000 without the role Queen's students union played?

'I have great memories of Queen's when sparks flew in the debating chambers. These were more educative experiences than any of the lectures I attended. What these changes to the union tell me is that the authorities today have given no priority to the exchange of ideas among their students,' he said.

The union has nurtured the political careers of luminaries both outside and inside the new Northern Ireland Assembly. Among its famous political graduates are John Taylor MP, the former Stormont Home Affairs Minister and now deputy leader of the Ulster Unionist Party; the ex-Mid Ulster nationalist MP Bernadette McAliskey; and Ian Paisley Jnr, the son of the Democratic Unionist Party leader.

The Social Democratic and Labour Party's Mark Durkan, the present Northern Ireland Finance Minister, is a former president of the students' union.

webTitle: Two set to admit arming the IRA

fields.headline: Two set to admit arming the IRA
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Two of the defendants in the Florida IRA gun-running plot are expected to plead guilty before their trial begins on 31 January. And all those charged with illegally posting guns and bullets from the United States to the Republic will have to give DNA samples to the FBI, which will be matched to samples taken from the stamps and parcels used to send the weapons through the US Mail.
fields.body:
Two of the defendants in the Florida IRA gun-running plot are expected to plead guilty before their trial begins on 31 January. And all those charged with illegally posting guns and bullets from the United States to the Republic will have to give DNA samples to the FBI, which will be matched to samples taken from the stamps and parcels used to send the weapons through the US Mail.

Siobhan Browne (34) and Belfast man Anthony Smyth (42) are expected to plead guilty to lesser charges of giving false information to gun dealers. If convicted, they could face from two to five years in a US prison.

Another defendant from Belfast, 26-year-old Conor Claxton, will contest all charges against him and will be defended by a top US attorney, Fred Haddad, who defended IRA suspects in the Stinger missile case in the 1990s. If convicted Claxton could face 20 to 30 years in prison. It is understood Had dad has been paid up to $100,000 to defend Claxton.

Claxton, Brown, Smyth and a Co Antrim man, Martin Mullan, were arrested in July and charged with breaking US arms export laws. It is alleged Smyth and Browne bought 44 handguns from a dealer and the group posted 15 weapons to addresses in the Republic and Britain. Federal prosecutors allege Browne used her name and driving licence to buy guns.

A federal source in Florida told The Observer the group had been under surveillance for two years. 'The FBI estimate up to 140 guns were posted to Ireland as a result of this operation,' he said, adding that an American citizen who was arrested, but released without charge in Ireland as part of a joint FBI/Gardai operation, had earlier been in the former Yugoslavia.

William Flint, with drug-related convictions in the US, was arrested after making mobile phone calls from a hotel in Co Galway to Jacqueline McIntyre, Claxton's girlfriend. McIntyre was charged by gardai with importing six pistols and 120 rounds of ammunition into Ireland from the US. She was released on IR£20,000 bail.

Federal sources say Flint's passport showed he had been in the former Yugoslavia before visiting Ireland in July, when the US was still at war with Belgrade. After the Florida arrests, the IRA Army Council said it had not sanctioned the arms plot.

The Florida trial comes as Ulster unionists wait to see if the IRA will decommission some arms for the Northern Ireland Executive to survive.

webTitle: New Oasis single set to be a flop

fields.headline: New Oasis single set to be a flop
fields.standfirst: Official Oasis website
fields.trailText: They were once the biggest band in Britain, but Oasis's new single, 'Go Let It Out', looks set to flop spectacularly on its release next month as retailers place small orders for the single and critics pan the song.
fields.body:
They were once the biggest band in Britain, but Oasis's new single, 'Go Let It Out', looks set to flop spectacularly on its release next month as retailers place small orders for the single and critics pan the song.

Our Price and HMV have ordered fewer copies than they did of the band's previous single, 'All Around the World', while Virgin Megastores have ordered a 'conservative amount'.

And Oasis's record company, Big Brother Records, a British subsidiary of media giant Sony, does not expect the single to be in great demand. It has shipped 250,000 copies to UK shops, half the amount industry insiders would consider usual. Britney Spears's last single, 'Crazy', merited a shipment of 500,000 copies.

The single will probably enter the charts in the top five when it is released on 7 February and then sink dramatically the next week.

Matthew Kreuzer of Our Price said there was a 'general view the band had never moved on musically' while music industry veteran Jonathan King said: 'The problem with Oasis is what happens to all bands. When they're young, they sound hungry, poor and enthusiastic. These qualities all go with success. The current single sounds like an old, lazy, fat band trying to be hungry, poor and enthusiastic. Oasis have passed their sell-by date, I'm afraid.'

Oasis biographer and confidant Paolo Hewitt said: 'They've established themselves as this fast-living rock group and can't maintain that any more - Noel wants to take his songwriting into different areas. It would surprise me if it wasn't a hit as their Wembley concerts later this year sold out in two hours. But I don't think they'll be buying any mansions on the back of this single.'

Second-hand record shops admitted last week that their shelves contain more unwanted copies of the band's third lacklustre LP, Be Here Now , than any other record. Noel Gallagher last week told GQ magazine that Oasis had earned a place in the 'UEFA cup' of rock groups 'eternally', while the Beatles, Who, Stones and Sex Pistols were 'in the Champions League'.

Others are even more critical of the band's achievements. Newspaper columnist Julie Burchill complains: 'Oasis's songs are like a Xerox copy of old music, one that just gets fainter each time it is passed through the photocopier.'

webTitle: Nelson bomb suspect arrested in the US

fields.headline: Nelson bomb suspect arrested in the US
fields.standfirst:
Lawyer's family attacks DPP's ruling over police 'collusion'
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The chief suspect in the murder of the Northern Ireland lawyer Rosemary Nelson has been arrested in the United States after firearms and drug offences.
fields.body:
The chief suspect in the murder of the Northern Ireland lawyer Rosemary Nelson has been arrested in the United States after firearms and drug offences.

The former Loyalist Volunteer Force member was allowed to flee the province with his family at the end of 1999 after a dispute inside the terrorist group.

He was arrested in San Diego, California, after neighbours complained about guns being fired in the garden of his house, loyalist sources in his home town, Portadown, told The Observer.

Police who searched the house found gun, ammunition and drugs.

The former LVF terrorist was arrested with his wife and another Portadown loyalist following the searches. His two children have been taken into care. He has been in the US since the LVF faction-fighting.

The suspect, who is the brother of a former LVF leader, feared for his life following a coup late last year in the organisation that saw several prisoners recently released from the Maze take control of the group.

The new leaders were incensed that the fugitive had allowed his members to carry out a pipe-bomb attack on the home of Elisabeth O'Neill, a Catholic woman married to a Protestant on a loyalist estate. The LVF's founder, the late Billy 'King Rat' Wright had ordered that no one was to harm the O'Neill family.

The runaway was seen as a danger to the organisation's ceasefire, which had led to its prisoners receiving early releases under the Good Friday Agreement.

A police inquiry team headed by Colin Port, Deputy Chief Constable of Norfolk, wants to question him about the murder of Nelson near her home in Lurgan last March. They believe he placed a bomb under her car moments after she drove away from her house.

The bombing of the solicitor, who defended many Catholic suspects, prompted immediate allegations of security force collusion in the killing.

The revelation that the chief suspect is in custody in the US comes after the murdered woman's family criticised the decision of the Director of Public Prosecutions not to have RUC officers charged over allegations that they threatened her life.

The DPP's decision - confirmed yesterday - was made after a long-running investigation by the Independent Commission for Police Complaints into claims about the threats.

After her murder it was revealed that the RUC had been pulled off the investigation into these allegations nine months before she was killed and replaced by a team of officers draw entirely from English forces.

Nelson's husband, Paul, called yesterday for an independent judicial inquiry into her murder. 'The decision by the DPP is another body blow for our family,' he said.

'Nearly 10 months after her death, there is no sign of any commitment to truth or justice for Rosemary. Tony Blair must recognise his responsibility and order the inquiry.'

Robbie McVeigh, from the Rosemary Nelson Campaign, said: 'The sooner we move to an independent international judicial inquiry into the circumstances of the murder the better.'

The small, anti-ceasefire Red Hand Defenders terror group admitted responsibility for the murder, but informed loyalist sources said the only organisation capable of building the booby-trap bomb used was the Ulster Defence Association.

It is thought UDA members from Belfast built it, and it was then passed to the LVF.

The device was similar to bombs used by the UDA in attacks on republican targets and fellow loyalists.

webTitle: Revealed: Britain on brink of war with Soviet Union in 1968

fields.headline: Revealed: Britain on brink of war with Soviet Union in 1968
fields.standfirst:
Wilson was warned by Healey that Britain could not 'stand idly by' if the Russians continued their expansion

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Britain was on the brink of war with the Soviet Union in the winter of 1968 after Ministers became convinced that the Russian President, Leonid Brezhnev, was about to invade Romania
fields.body:
Britain was on the brink of war with the Soviet Union in the winter of 1968 after Ministers became convinced that the Russian President, Leonid Brezhnev, was about to invade Romania.

Secret documents released by the Public Record Office yesterday show that, in September 1968, Prime Minister Harold Wilson made detailed contingency plans for military intervention in eastern Europe.

Ministers were afraid that the crushing of the 'Prague Spring' - the popular uprising in Czechoslovakia - would lead to the extension of direct Soviet control into neighbouring Romania and even Yugoslavia, seen as the strategic heart of Europe.

Romanian President, Nicolae Ceausescu had condemned the Soviet action in Czechoslovakia and it was thought that Moscow was preparing to teach him a lesson.

Minutes from meetings at the time record Defence Secretary Denis Healey telling Wilson that Britain could not 'stand idly by' if the Soviet Union continued its expansion. A telex from Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart, made public for the first time, shows that towards the end of 1968, Britain believed that Soviet tanks were about to enter Romania. Intelligence sources even put a date - 22 November - on the invasion.

Tony Benn, who as Minister of Technology visited President Ceausescu in June 1968 and remained in contact with Romanian ministers, said last night: 'I had no idea these discussions were going on. But there was a lot of Cold War panic at the time.'

Harold Wilson's biographer, Ben Pimlott, said: 'There were fears and anxieties at the time about a possible invasion of Romania. But no one had any idea that the Government had intelligence about the exact date it was due to happen.'

Plans to send crack British troops to the Balkans were hatched at a secret meeting between Wilson, Healey and Stewart on 6 September 1968. If a 'direct threat' were made to Yugoslavia, Healey planned to arm Yugoslav guerrillas and send crack British Army units of the sort used during the Second World War to aid partisans.

According to the minutes of the meeting, Healey 'agreed with the Prime Minister that a Russian invasion of Romania could well be the first stage towards the establishment of such a threat.'

Wilson suggested a build-up of force in the Mediterranean under the cover of military exercises. 'There could be an exercise by the ACE Mobile Force, some form of "alert" measures or an increase in the number of British ships in the area, especially in Malta and Cyprus.'

1968 was a year of high tension for governments on both sides of the Iron Curtain. In Paris, an alliance of students and workers had come close to bringing down the French government and in the United States opposition to the Vietnam War reached its height after the massacre of women and children at My Lai by American soldiers. In October, Vietnam demonstrators clashed with police outside the US embassy in London's Grosvenor Square.

The European crisis began when Russian tanks entered Prague in August 1968. The Yugoslav leader, Marshal Josip Tito, instructed the Yugoslav ambassador in London to ask what British plans were if Romania was invaded, as Yugoslavia was committed to coming to the aid of its neighbour. Tito was particularly concerned that Nato had come to an agreement with Moscow to set up 'spheres of influence' in Europe.

Foreign Office officials were asked to come up with plans if Britain were called upon to defend Yugoslavia. On 5 September a report was sent to Stewart concluding that 'the consequences of the invasion of Yugoslavia for the balance of power in Europe and the security of Nato are obvious'. Greece and Turkey would be left vulnerable, and the entire Eastern Mediterranean would be threatened. Soviet troops in Yugoslavia and Nato troops in Italy would face each other across the Adriatic.

The next day Healey used even more apocalyptic language, saying that if Nato did not oppose further Soviet expansion it would encourage Russia 'to move against such countries as Finland, Sweden, Iran and possibly even members of the alliance such as Greece and Turkey'.

Throughout September, Wilson and Stewart entered a series of desperate talks with Ceausescu. Soviet troop movements on the Romanian border were beginning to cause serious concern in London and Washington.

The newly opened files also show Britain was terrified about possible attacks on Berlin and Austria. By the beginning of October, the Foreign Office told Washington in a memo that it thought the Russians were 'conducting a war of nerves' with Romania and Yugoslavia and outlined what it believed would be the Soviet plan: troops would move from Hungary and through Romania swiftly to seize Belgrade and key bridges at Novi Sad and Panchevko.

On 19 November, the Foreign and Commonwealth Office received a chilling telex from the British delegation to Nato. It contained precise details of the Romanian invasion plan, which had been received from Dutch military intelligence. 'Soviet, Hungarian and Polish troops will enter Romania on 22 November at 0400 hours, total strength about 150,000. The composition of the Polish contingent: one tank battalion, two airborne battalions, six signal companies, three military police companies, two airborne regiments.'

Three days later, Stewart sent an urgent telex to Bucharest: 'We have assessed the most recent information available to us and have concluded that the Russians are making preparations for very early military action against Romania.'

Here the Public Record Office file ends, without revealing how close Europe came to war in 1968 or why the Soviets called off the invasion at the last minute.

Pimlott believes it was a defining moment of the twentieth century. 'Russia's decision not to invade Romania was the slippery slope towards the end of the Cold War. It is possibly even more significant than the decision not to crush Solidarity in Poland.'

fields.headline: Welcome back to the craic
fields.standfirst: Belfast was described as 'the new millennium's perfect tourist destination' in last week's Observer A-Z of the year 2000. Here the Belfast novelist   Glenn Patterson offers a sardonic guide to Northern Ireland and its capital
fields.trailText: A is for Assembly
fields.body:
A is for Assembly

After decades of resistance to rule from Stormont on the one side and power-sharing on the other, we now have a Stormont Assembly with a power-sharing executive. The high ratio of Assembly Members to population (108 of them for 1.5 million of us) was intended to ensure that none of the 'parties who have previously predicted the mood' of this or that paramilitary group was excluded. Still the UFF-predicting Ulster Democratic Party couldn't get in.

Adams, Gerry . President of Sinn Fein, architect of the Northern republican strategy since the Seventies. Not to be confused with the other Gerry Adams, named by many authors as a senior figure in the Provisional IRA and who disappeared around 1981.

B Bloody Sunday

Long overdue inquiry soon to be under way, despite the efforts of the Daily Telegraph and some of the British military. Some would like this to be the cornerstone of a Truth Commission, though it is to be seen whether, say, a Provisional IRA leader who disappeared around 1981 would be readier to talk about Bloody Friday than the Paras are to talk about Bloody Sunday.

Bellaghy

The birthplace of Seamus Heaney. Think bog, think blackberries, think Bethlehem, to American academics. Think Big Tourist Bucks. Good man yourself, Seamus.

Bann

The River, to the east and west of which Northern Ireland is said to divide. (See Portadown).

Communities

A polite term for sides. There are apparently only two, though where this leaves the Chinese community, the Indian community, the gay community etc is not clear. (See also Traditions)

Crown, The

A bar. The island's finest. Survived numerous bombings only to have its famous stained-glass windows smashed last year by two drunks wielding chairs.

Citybus

Formerly 'the red bus'. Much-improved Belfast service, now that half the fleet isn't burnt out every second week. Also operates a controversial 'Troubles tour'.

D Drugs

Don't bring them on your Citybus Troubles tour, unless you want to become part of a living history 'punishment beating' demonstration.

Derry.

The centre of its own universe. Also known as Londonderry, the outpost of somebody else's.

E Eden

Village outside Carrickfergus. Famous for its 'Eden Says No' graffiti. Like a good many other places, Eden will need to have something new to say for itself, and fast.

Everyone knows

Northern Irish for 'our party thinks'.

Early Release or ER

A programme about which opinion is sharply divided. Finale scheduled for June when the last prisoner will walk from the Maze. A proposed second series, 'ER - The Exiles Return' (expulsions by paramilitaries have carried on unabated), has had a lukewarm reception, not least from biggest fans of ER1.

F FT

Universal graffiti which roughly translate 'you are now entering...' The third letter, P or Q, for Pope or Queen, will tell you whether you are in a Protestant or Catholic area.

Fence

The place where all those who did not subscribe to the orthodoxies of nationalism and unionism were said to have been sitting all these years. Very commodious, in my experience, and heavily populated.

G Giant's Causeway

Impressive volcanic rock formation, but rumours that it predates the rhetoric of the Democratic Unionist Party are surely far-fetched.

H Homer

DJ David Holmes. Famous enough to be the subject of the Jesus Christ joke. (What's the difference between X and Christ? Christ doesn't walk around town thinking he's X.)

I IRA

Once there were only two, Provos and Stickies, now available in three exciting new varieties: Continuity (linked to Republican Sinn Fein); Real (linked to the 32 Counties' Movement); and - for the image-conscious - I-Can't-Believe-It's-Not-IRA, aka Sinn Fein.

IPLO

A splinter of a splinter of a splinter group. Another split or two and we should see them get rid of the last three letters in their entirety.

J Jesus Christ

Evangelical Protestants say he would have voted No in the 1998 referendum. Famous enough for a David Holmes joke.

K Kylie

Popular forename for 13-year-olds. More power to them, and to the Jasons and Lees. Who will say any of these are 'Protestant' or 'Catholic' names?

L Lambeg drums

Often need two people to carry them. Bass drums are what most bands feature. Their sound is duller, less rhythmic, more unnerving.

Loyalist fringe groups

Scarier than 1,000 bass drums. Fundamentalist enemies of 'left-leaning' Progressive Unionist Party and all things Catholic.

M Murals

Wall paintings with all the grace and charm of giant tea-towels. 'Folk art', according to some. 'The cat's piss on the corner,' says political commentator Malachi O'Doherty.

N Northern Ireland

That (not Ulster, the North, the Province or the Six Counties) is the name, don't wear it out.

Never, never, never.

DUP-speak for 'not until we get the departments we want and competitive ministerial salaries'.

O Orangemen

Very few wear bowler hats, still fewer actual sashes. Collarettes over double-breasted suits seem to be the norm. Temperance lodges tend to be on the small side.

Opening hours

Originally relaxed to combat the attraction of the paramilitary-run drinking clubs, now longer than anywhere else in the United Kingdom.

P Paisley, Rev Ian

A political institution.

Purdysburn

A mental institution. (Try to keep these two institutions separate in your mind. Try harder than that.)

Q Queen

God Save Our. (Sung fortississimo.)

R Royal Ulster Constabulary

Variously the finest body of men and women in the known world and the paramilitary arm of the Unionist Party. Name change to be resisted by five-year-olds who will lose their joke: 'Why are the police called the police? Because they RUC.'

Residents groups.

Spontaneous manifestations of local resentment to Orange parades. No, honestly.

S Socialism

Our natural state, it seems. We're so good at it, nobody needs to practise it, least of all those parties claiming to espouse it.

Sainsbury's

The place to hie to in the event that it all goes wrong. As last in, the large supermarkets are a fair bet to be first out. Expect helicopter airlifts from their roofs.

T Total abstinence lodge

Two auld fellas with a banner.

Traditions

As for communities, though may also refer to dancing with your arms by your side and/or marching around in a collarette.

U Union of Catholic, Protestant and Dissenter

The legacy of the United Irishmen and what most of us claim we are trying to achieve. Lead in this is taken annually when the Gaelic Athletic Association votes to continue its ban on members of the security forces.

V Victory

Nobody had one. Which explains all that racing around in cars, a couple of years back, with flags and scarves flapping out of the windows.

W West Belfast

Area that extends further south than much of south Belfast and excludes some westernmost, inconveniently Protestant, districts. Its festival, in a spirit of inclusiveness, coincides with Internment commemorations.

War, The

The preferred term for a grubby murder campaign, indulged in with varying degrees of sophistication and accountability by republicans, loyalists, police and troops.

X

In the old scheme of British Film classification, marked the spot under which Free Presbyterians would be singing hymns and waving placards. More recently they were to be found outside an all-male production of Romeo and Juliet , and the Gilbert and George retrospective at the Ormeau Baths Gallery - to the delight of Gilbert and George.

Y 'Yes I said yes I will Yes'.

James Joyce, Ulysses , from the David Trimble Book of Helpful Quotations, the manuscript of which has been ready for some time, though publication ihas been repeatedly put back. Now expected in February. Probably.

Z Zeds

After 30 years of tumbling out of bed for the first news bulletin of the morning, and sitting up for the last bulletin of the night, this is what most people here will be looking forward to catching once the Assembly is in full session.

Famous enough to be the subject of the Jesus Christ joke. (What's the difference between X and Christ? Christ doesn't walk around town thinking he's X.) I IRA Once there were only two, Provos and Stickies, now available in three exciting new varieties: Continuity (linked to Republican Sinn Fein); Real (linked to the 32 Counties' Movement); and - for the image-conscious - I-Can't-Believe-It's-Not-IRA, aka Sinn Fein. IPLO A splinter of a splinter of a splinter group. Another split or two and we should see them get rid of the last three letters in their entirety. J Jesus Christ Evangelical Protestants say he would have voted No in the 1998 referendum. Famous enough for a David Holmes joke. K Kylie Popular forename for 13-year-olds. More power to them, and to the Jasons and Lees. Who will say any of these are 'Protestant' or 'Catholic' names? L Lambeg drums Often need two people to carry them. Bass drums are what most bands feature. Their sound is duller, less rhythmic, more unnerving. Loyalist fringe groups Scarier than 1,000 bass drums. Fundamentalist enemies of 'left-leaning' Progressive Unionist Party and all things Catholic. M Murals Wall paintings with all the grace and charm of giant tea-towels. 'Folk art', according to some. 'The cat's piss on the corner,' says political commentator Malachi O'Doherty. N Northern Ireland That (not Ulster, the North, the Province or the Six Counties) is the name, don't wear it out. Never, never, never. DUP-speak for 'not until we get the departments we want and competitive ministerial salaries'. O Orangemen Very few wear bowler hats, still fewer actual sashes. Collarettes over double-breasted suits seem to be the norm. Temperance lodges tend to be on the small side. Opening hours Originally relaxed to combat the attraction of the paramilitary-run drinking clubs, now longer than anywhere else in the United Kingdom. P Paisley, Rev Ian A political institution. Purdysburn A mental institution. (Try to keep these two institutions separate in your mind. Try harder than that.) Q Queen God Save Our. (Sung fortississimo.) R Royal Ulster Constabulary Variously the finest body of men and women in the known world and the paramilitary arm of the Unionist Party. Name change to be resisted by five-year-olds who will lose their joke: 'Why are the police called the police? Because they RUC.' Residents groups. Spontaneous manifestations of local resentment to Orange parades. No, honestly. S Socialism Our natural state, it seems. We're so good at it, nobody needs to practise it, least of all those parties claiming to espouse it. Sainsbury's The place to hie to in the event that it all goes wrong. As last in, the large supermarkets are a fair bet to be first out. Expect helicopter airlifts from their roofs. T Total abstinence lodge Two auld fellas with a banner. Traditions As for communities, though may also refer to dancing with your arms by your side and/or marching around in a collarette. U Union of Catholic, Protestant and Dissenter The legacy of the United Irishmen and what most of us claim we are trying to achieve. Lead in this is taken annually when the Gaelic Athletic Association votes to continue its ban on members of the security forces. V Victory Nobody had one. Which explains all that racing around in cars, a couple of years back, with flags and scarves flapping out of the windows. W West Belfast Area that extends further south than much of south Belfast and excludes some westernmost, inconveniently Protestant, districts. Its festival, in a spirit of inclusiveness, coincides with Internment commemorations. War, The The preferred term for a grubby murder campaign, indulged in with varying degrees of sophistication and accountability by republicans, loyalists, police and troops. X In the old scheme of British Film classification, marked the spot under which Free Presbyterians would be singing hymns and waving placards. More recently they were to be found outside an all-male production of Romeo and Juliet , and the Gilbert and George retrospective at the Ormeau Baths Gallery - to the delight of Gilbert and George. Y 'Yes I said yes I will Yes'. James Joyce, Ulysses , from the David Trimble Book of Helpful Quotations, the manuscript of which has been ready for some time, though publication ihas been repeatedly put back. Now expected in February. Probably. Z Zeds After 30 years of tumbling out of bed for the first news bulletin of the morning, and sitting up for the last bulletin of the night, this is what most people here will be looking forward to catching once the Assembly is in full session.

webTitle: The day I almost signed a homosexual star

fields.headline: The day I almost signed a homosexual star
fields.trailText: The players' union has around 4,000 members and its chairman, Gordon Taylor, tells me they have never received one complaint, report or even know of an incident relating to homosexuality in professional football. Alan Smith begs to differ.
fields.body:
The players' union has around 4,000 members and its chairman, Gordon Taylor, tells me they have never received one complaint, report or even know of an incident relating to homosexuality in professional football.

With 4,000 players out there it would seem statistically inevitable that there are gay professional footballers, but I would be surprised if there are many... because the culture of our game neither attracts homosexual men nor encourages them to 'come out' should they have chosen to become a player.

Footballers are a macho bunch who live by a brutal code of banter. There is little time in football for the camp humour this country is so famous for and the videos on pre-match journeys tend to be the 'blue' stand-up material of Chubby Brown rather than Julian Clary.

There is simply no room for sensitivity and it would be very difficult for someone to let it be known he was gay in that environment. We can take it for granted that the abuse from the terraces would be unrelenting, but the stick in the dressing room would probably be merciless.

You have to very thick-skinned to take it. I was recently a target on the Sunday tabloid pages on a different subject and it was a very unpleasant experience for my family and myself. But that didn't stop people having a pop when I next went into training.

If anything, it encouraged them to have more of a go. The only way to survive that is to take it on the chin, but not everyone can handle it.

Stan Collymore, for example, struggles to cope with the stick he gets in games and in the dressing room, but no-one is questioning his sexuality. It would be worse for him, I imagine, if they were. Just look at the abuse Graeme Le Saux gets for reading The Guardian.

I have been in football a long time now and I know how people connected with the game in any form love to gossip. It is a close community in which we all seem to know what the others are up to. The subject of who may be gay or not simply doesn't come up.

Possibly the only gay player I ever knowingly met was one I was very close to signing for Crystal Palace. He was a South African international, who had been training with us and staying with me and my wife. Unfortunately, when it came to his medical we discovered he had AIDS - that was when he told us he was gay and had been planning to bring his boyfriend over from South Africa when he signed.

Obviously, his illness ended the possibility of a transfer, but would I have signed him had he been healthy and I knew he was gay? I think I would have done, but I would have had to seriously consider the reaction from the rest of my squad, both for his happiness and team spirit. I think it would have been very hard for him to come through it all.

In general, football people don't like anyone who is 'different'. That's why Collymore gets it in the neck. We like the players to settle down and marry young, to drive flash cars and talk tough. We like our managers to wear double-breasted suits and raincoats and talk football-speak. Pretty much any other behaviour gets you treated as an outsider.

In team games, we talk about camaraderie, the group work ethic and team spirit which is why, sadly, it encourages everyone to form the same character.

The rest of the country may be becoming increasingly liberal but not so in football and that could be why we see such mediocrity in the game. I find that strange in the respect that football has never been so closely linked to theatre and entertainment and should attract creative people.

It is difficult to avoid generalising on this topic, but some of the most creative entertainers, writers and singers have been gay, so why not footballers? I would think they take one look at the football environment and are immediately put off pursuing the sport as a career. That person would face having to hide his sexuality to survive and that is no way to live.

Maybe one high profile gay player is all it would take to break the barriers down. We have made a start with racism, but that is still something we are trying to eradicate three decades since the first black player played for England. Despite what I've said, I would think and hope that sexual tolerance would be easier and quicker to find its way on to the terraces and into the dressing rooms.

webTitle: Time to come out and play

fields.headline: Time to come out and play
fields.trailText: Kate Hoey, the Sports Minister, is backing plans by the Football Association and Premiership to tackle homophobia.
fields.body:
Kate Hoey, the Sports Minister, is backing plans by the Football Association and Premiership to tackle homophobia. A meeting later this month to discuss the issue could lead to the FA adopting a code of practice and introducing the subject as part of a development programme for young players.

Unlike other high-profile areas, such as the pop and movie industry, top-level footballers who admit to their homosexuality are rare. The most famous example in this country was Justin Fashanu, the former Norwich and Nottingham Forest footballer, who committed suicide in 1998.

But Stonewall, a gay pressure group, has been in discussions with the FA and Premiership about the topic in an attempt to make it easier for footballers to come out.

'I know of a number of closeted gay footballers but because of the way the issue is treated in this country they do not wish that to be known,' said John Miskelly, the chairman of Stonewall and an Arsenal season ticket holder.

The discussions started last year after the row that followed the clash between Graeme Le Saux and Robbie Fowler when the Liverpool player made lewd gestures. 'The government is extremely supportive and determined to stamp out homophobia,' said Miskelly. 'Homophobia in football has never been tackled before. There is no learning or development of kids which even brings it on to their agenda.'

Stonewall has suggested making homophobia a module on the FA's youth development scheme and introducing a code of conduct on the issue.

Hoey said: 'The government has acted firmly in the past and recent legislation has gone a long way to eliminating racist chanting. Homophobia is equally distasteful and the efforts of Stonewall and the FA are to be welcomed.'

webTitle: Portrait of the art thief as a good man

fields.headline: Portrait of the art thief as a good man
fields.standfirst: People who steal paintings are cultural vandals. So why, asks  Sean French, does Hollywood insist on portraying them as heroes?
fields.trailText: People who steal paintings are cultural vandals. So why, asks  Sean French, does Hollywood insist on portraying them as heroes?
fields.body:
There's something particularly chilling about the theft of paintings or sculptures. Of course there are valuable books, but it wouldn't really matter if every surviving copy of Shakespeare's First Folio was put in a pile and set alight. The text of Macbeth survives intact in the cheap paperback on your bookshelf. Once a book has been printed it is very difficult to obliterate. In the early sixteenth century, the English ecclesiastical authorities attempted to buy up and burn every copy of William Tyndale's translation of the New Testament. The money just went to printing more copies. (Hedy Lamarr's husband ran into the same problem in the 1920s when he attempted to buy and destroy every print of the film Ecstasy, in which she appeared nude - the company ran off hundreds of new prints to meet the demand.)

But Cézanne's Auvers sur Oise , stolen over New Year from the Ashmolean, is really gone and it is exposed as the fragile object it actually is. Are the thieves maintaining it in a regulated environment or is it in a bin bag in a lock-up somewhere? Will they return it after a brief interval or sell it to one of those legendary Far Eastern or South American millionaires with a vault full of stolen canvases? Very few of us can create a timeless masterpiece but all of us can destroy one. Perhaps that's why schizophrenics, tormented by voices, so frequently make for a great masterpiece carrying a hammer (Michelangelo's Pietà ), a butcher's knife (Poussin's Adoration of the Golden Calf ) or a shotgun (Leonardo's cartoon of the holy family in the National Gallery).

The art thief is a cultural vandal, and yet in the movies he is an amusing, elegant figure, almost a modern Scarlet Pimpernel. It seems scarcely coincidental that the last two movie art thieves were played by the original and the most recent James Bonds. In the recent remake of The Thomas Crown Affair, audiences virtually cheer the aplomb with which Pierce Brosnan snaffles a Monet from the wall of the gallery. In Entrapment, there are two sophisticated, sexy thieves, Sean Connery and Catherine Zeta-Jones, slicing a Rembrandt out of its frame and rolling it up. One hopes Connery recalled the best joke in Dr No, when, as an enforced guest in Dr No's lair he notices on the wall Goya's portrait of the Duke of Wellington, at that time stolen from the National Gallery.

In real life, art robberies are tawdry affairs - a broken window, a painting shoved under a coat - but in the cinema there is almost a mini-genre of dazzling art thefts - slicing through glass, disabling alarm systems, dangling from wires, dodging laser beams. Their schemes involve an artistry that competes with the creators of the works they purloin. And the thieves themselves are decidedly top-drawer: Peter Finch as the master thief Flambeau in Father Brown, Peter Ustinov in Topkapi, David Niven in The Pink Panther .

What is it that makes this form of crime so acceptable? I'd like to think it is a form of social and cultural protest. In his classic essay on Anthony Blunt (himself a gentleman traitor), George Steiner speculated that one cause of Blunt's Marxism might have been his rage at the private ownership of the great works on which he was such an expert: 'The literal disappearance of a Turner or a Van Gogh into some Middle Eastern or Latin-American bank vault to be kept as investment and collateral, the sardonic decision of a Greek shipping tycoon to put an incomparable El Greco on his yacht, where it hangs at persistent risk - these are phenomena that verge on vandalism.'

Does this sound exaggerated? In 1990 a Japanese businessman called Ryoei Saito bought Van Gogh's Portrait of Dr Gachet for $82.5 million, the most ever paid for a picture at auction. When he died in 1996 the picture was not among his possessions. It may have been sold or even destroyed (Saito had said he wanted the picture to be cremated with him). We wouldn't do that here, would we? But think of Clementine Churchill burning Graham Sutherland's great portrait of her late husband.

Hollywood has a certain wary respect for the passionate struggling artist, but it has nothing but contempt for connoisseurs, owners, galleries. This is curious, since artworks, along with jet planes and drugs, are what Hollywood stars use to soak up their excessive amounts of money. Edward G. Robinson, Billy Wilder and, more recently, Steve Martin, have all been serious collectors of modern art. But men in Hollywood movies who own and admire art are about as dodgy as men who can cook: effete, snobbish, a bit sinister.

I tried hard to think of a story in which the theft of a picture is seen as a painful act and could only think of books - like the betrayal and confusion in Michael Frayn's recent Headlong and the destruction of an imaginary Blake drawing in Thomas Harris's Red Dragon. But when Jack Nicholson's Joker or Mr Bean spray-paint over great paintings on screen, it's just funny.

Film has always had an uneasy relationship with the other visual arts. Television appears in the movies as the banal little screen in the corner bringing pap into the home - or worse, as in Steven Spielberg's Poltergeist in which malevolent ghosts live inside the box. If TV was the new gadget that threatened to replace cinema (as Samuel Goldwyn said: 'Why should people go out and pay money to see rubbish when they can see rubbish for nothing at home?'), then paintings represent the world that movies lost for us, a world of stillness and privacy. When paintings appear in movies they have to be made the butt of slapstick, or the victims of crime, because otherwise they would ask something of us we cannot give: the time needed to contemplate them.
