fields.headline: For Christ's sake
fields.standfirst: As far as  Lynn Barber is concerned, the debate over the empty plinth in Trafalgar Square is redundant - Mark Wallinger's Ecce Homo has taken over the vacant possession and long should he remain
fields.trailText: As far as  Lynn Barber is concerned, the debate over the empty plinth in Trafalgar Square is redundant - Mark Wallinger's Ecce Homo has taken over the vacant possession and long should he remain
fields.body:
Poor Mark Wallinger. Poor Jesus Christ up on his lonely plinth with only the pigeons, traffic and tourists for company. Wallinger's Christ, Ecce Homo, has been occupying the fourth plinth in Trafalgar Square since last July and has certainly endeared himself to me as well as to many more serious people, but his future looks uncertain. He will definitely come down in February, to be replaced by Bill Woodrow's bronze Regardless of History, showing a head crushed by a book, which will be replaced in turn next autumn by Rachel Whiteread's upside-down cast of the plinth.

The fourth plinth has been empty since l84l when Charles Barry designed Trafalgar Square. He meant it to be for William IV but there was no money to fund the project, so the square has had to get along with just George lV and two generals - Napier and Havelock - until five years ago, when Prue Leith, as deputy chair of the Royal Society of Arts, launched a campaign to fill the empty plinth.

But now a committee chaired by Sir John Mortimer, and including such well-known art experts as Ruth Rendell, is beavering away to determine what - or probably whose - statue the public wants to see installed permanently. The current favourite seems to be Nelson Mandela, but there are strong lobbies for everyone from Princess Diana to Captain Cook to 'all the animals killed in war'.

What will happen, of course, is that these deliberations will continue until the Queen Mother dies, whereupon the nation will rise with one voice and shout: 'We want the Queen Mother!' And then some truly terrible sculptor - because, let's face it, the art of portrait statuary is not exactly booming in this country - will be commissioned to produce her likeness, hat and wafty bits and all. (Apparently, there is some arcane rule that you can't have statues of royals while they are alive, though surely that rule never applied to Queen Victoria?)

Either way, it's a poor lookout and the point of this article is to say: 'Look, Wallinger's Christ might not be the most exciting statue ever seen but it's certainly one of the best we've got in London, so why not keep it?'

But even Mark Wallinger doesn't believe there's much hope of that happening. In fact, he feels thoroughly cheated. He thought when he was one of 20 contemporary artists invited to submit ideas for the plinth that it was a straightforward competition and the winner would be installed permanently.

But suddenly it became a hot political potato and the Great British Public had to be consulted. Since when has the GBP ever given a toss about art? They probably hadn't even noticed that there was a plinth going begging till the papers told them. But now, of course, the fourth plinth has become a political soapbox for every posturing philistine in town.

Admittedly, neither Wallinger nor Christ are obvious choices to fill the plinth, but all the better for that. He is a quirky, intelligent, 40-year-old artist who, though Goldsmith's-trained and Saatchi-owned, doesn't quite fit in the Britart mould. He first impinged on public notice in l995 when he was nominated for the Turner Prize, but lost to Damien Hirst.

His work until then was mainly about class, power and nationality (it featured, among other things, a real racehorse called A Real Work of Art) but since then he has moved on to religious themes, most memorably a video called Angel shot in Angel Tube station. This featured him as a blind man 'speaking in tongues' - reciting St John's Gospel backwards - while walking down an up escalator. This is a terribly crass description of a complex and haunting work but it would takes pages to explain it.

Anyway, he says that as soon as he got the phone call asking him to submit ideas for the fourth plinth, he thought immediately of Christ. 'For the last couple of years, I've been making work that uses Christian imagery and is to do with faith and illusion, so a Jesus figure was such an obvious idea; I felt it was a sort of conduit for something. It struck me, too, that it's the millennium and yet everyone's rather squeamish about mentioning Christianity, which seems odd. I mean, they have beacons all around the country saying British Gas. I don't quite see where the ethical line is being drawn!'

He chose the Ecce Homo moment because it seemed to fit Trafalgar Square's associations with crowds and political demonstrations. ('Ecce Homo - behold the man' - were the words with which Pontius Pilate handed Christ over to the mob.) 'Essentially, I wanted to make a piece that had Christ as a human being, at a point of the story where he isn't a deity, he's just a guy being handed over to the lynch mob. I wanted something that reflected back on issues to do with power. And I wanted him to be lifesize because, well, He was made in our image.'

Wallinger's first maquette was of a more traditional Christ, with long hair, beard and dhoti-like loincloth, but he decided in the end to go for a modern Christ, beardless, shaven-headed and with more of a towel. I must say the towel seems to me the statue's one failure - it belongs to the Hollywood Pharaonic era or even the modern YMCA gym era rather than first century Judaea - and Wallinger concedes the loincloth was almost the most difficult decision he had to make. 'I wanted a contemporary Christ, shorn of hair, but at the same time I couldn't have him wearing boxer shorts! It's quite a tricky one, really.'

Some people have complained that the towel makes Christ look gay, but Wallinger is dismissive: 'Yeah, well... if you want someone looking fairly trim and only wearing a loincloth, he will tend to look a bit gay. But it's nowhere near as blatant as, say, Michelangelo's Christ in Rome - a very lovingly carved bottom. I was quite aware that that might happen but there's not a lot I could do about it. And I don't know that we can presume anything about His sexuality anyway.'

He wanted to make the figure look like marble, in contrast to the black bronzes around it, and found a casting studio near High Wycombe that could produce the requisite material, a sanded polyester resin that is more durable than marble because it is completely non-porous. He thought he would have to audition actors to find his Christ, but the studio came up with one of its own employees, an apprentice called Christopher Welch, who was used to modelling for casts, a hideous job involving straws in the nostrils.

Wallinger was rather embarrassed when Welch, on their first meeting, instantly stripped down to his boxer shorts, but then delighted to notice that he was wearing a crucifix. At first, Wallinger posed him with his hands bound in front, but from some angles he looked like a footballer clutching his goolies while facing a direct free kick. So then he posed him with his hands tied behind, which proved much more effective, giving him the slightly bowed shoulders, which are one of the most moving aspects of the statue.

Wallinger's is a modest, unassuming Christ, looking tiny and vulnerable on the edge of his eight-metre plinth, in fact a Christ as we are unused to seeing him, neither a baby in his mother's arms nor a torture victim on the cross, but an ordinary, apprehensive young man. The very modesty of the statue's pose and scale gives it an extraordinary power over its surroundings. As Richard Dorment wrote in the Telegraph: 'What Wallinger has really done is to turn Trafalgar Square into something akin to a meditation on the transience of earthly things.'

The statue has been warmly received by Christians and has twice been the subject of sermons on Radio 4's 'Thought for the Day'. Richard Chartres, the Bishop of London, said he found it 'profoundly moving' and Vincent Nichols, the Catholic Bishop of Westminster, found it 'humbling and affecting'. The Queen's Chaplain wrote to Wallinger saying that he had always had trouble imagining Christ as an ordinary man, and this was an important step for his faith.

But Wallinger is wary of being hailed as a 'Christian artist' and very reluctant to talk about his own beliefs. He describes himself as a former atheist, now an agnostic. At all events, he certainly takes his Christ seriously - there is no element of irony in the work.

For Wallinger, his first venture into public sculpture has been a disheartening experience. At what should have been his proudest moment when the statue was unveiled, he was being interviewed by the BBC and told that 'some people are saying it should be a statue of Posh Spice and David Beckham'. For weeks, he was 'a bit of a basket case. I realised I'd been running on adrenaline for I don't know how long and I was really quite depressed'.

He didn't revisit the statue for two months and when he did, he bumped into some people he knew 'and that made me feel like a sort of sad type hanging around'. Moreover, he was annoyed to find that the sign under the statue explaining that there was a visitors' book for comments at Canada House had got ripped off (though it has now been replaced). He is also disappointed that, although the statue has received plenty of media attention as a news item, it has not been seriously reviewed in the art press.

So what will happen to the statue now? There have been inquiries from Milan Cathedral and one or two other places, but he designed it for Trafalgar Square and very much wants it to stay there. Of course, it has to come down while the Woodrow and Whiteread works are shown, but he hopes it won't then be forgotten. He is indignant at the idea of a committee with no practising artists on it deciding his fate - 'I can't imagine a major literary prize being chaired by two sculptors' - and recalls going to one committee meeting where Bernie Grant and a black lady peer attacked him for showing a white Christ; they said they wanted 'a contrite piece about the slave trade'. 'How on earth you realise that I don't know,' he snorts. 'It wasn't helped by the fact that they kept saying it was in front of the Tate Gallery.'

His money is on the Queen Mother as the final choice, but he won't bother to disguise his anger. 'When they first approached me, there was a considerable enticement that at the end of the day there might be a possibility that the statue would be installed there permanently. So I made it in all sincerity in those terms, but now people make it sound like a sort of shifting circus.'

fields.headline: The real Mary Poppins
fields.standfirst: There's only one Nanny of the Year - and she looks after   Kate Kellaway's children. Not everyone is so lucky...
fields.trailText: There's only one Nanny of the Year - and she looks after   Kate Kellaway's children. Not everyone is so lucky...
fields.body:
Occasionally - when you are not expecting it - life seems to be listening. Last summer, during a maternity leave, I entered our nanny for the Lady magazine's Nanny of the Year competition. Sarah, I wrote, was half my age with twice my energy. I added that she needed this to deal with an extended family of six boys (not that she is always responsible for all of them). It was an idle application. I did not catalogue all Sarah's virtues. I apologised to her. 'I know you deserve to win - but it won't happen.'

I went back to work. It was hard for me and for Sarah, too. I wondered what could be done to make things easier. One evening, as I was thinking about the problem aloud, the telephone rang. 'It is Beverly Davies from the Lady. You entered our Nanny of the Year competition and we think your nanny sounds great and deserves to win.' I was incredulous with delight.

A week or two later, Beverly - 'the lady from the Lady' - came to call. She brought a photographer, accustomed to taking pictures for the tabloids, with her. She also brought Sarah a cheque for £1,000, a framed certificate, the promise of a weekend at Center Parcs with the family, a Halcyon Days enamel travelling clock and a small hill of children's books.

The photographer requested that the boys line up in a military row in the back garden to have their picture taken. Beverly was politely appreciative (impressed by the quantity of boys, evidently a factor in Sarah's win). But I felt like the smilingly distraught Wendy Craig in that farcical domestic sitcom from the Seventies Butterflies. At least half the boys seemed to be in a toxic mood and the obligation to say 'cheese', let alone give a genuine smile, seemed to elude them entirely.

One of the little ones wept bitterly for the duration of the visit, refusing my (hoarsely whispered) bribes of ice-cream for improved conduct. Two of the older boys got into a fight downstairs, just out of earshot (I hoped). I alternated between yelling at them and (with a slammed door for punctuation) attempting light talk with our visitors. I cheered myself with the thought that anyone could see Sarah had earned her title.

What does it take to look after other people's children well? I am exceptionally lucky in Sarah, but can't pretend the relationship with women who have looked after my children has always been plain sailing. I will never forget the childminder who said, her voice a shrill mixture of self-righteousness and contempt: 'You care more about your work than your child.' It was more than a personal slight. I suspected the hostility towards professional women had been there all along. Now it was out, the unspoken thing, produced with a vindictive flourish. I told her that what she had said was unacceptable. But I needed her and the next day I ate large, unpalatable slices of humble pie. For a while, the relationship tottered on.

The relationship between nanny (or childminder) and employer can be a minefield. Rebecca Holmes, who has employed several nannies for her four children, identifies the problem as one of slippery definitions: 'It is difficult to be an employer and a friend. You are asking a nanny to be a stand-in, to be a mother and yet not a mother. You want the children to love the nanny but it can be problematic for you if they love her too much, not least because the attachment is impermanent. Most nannies don't last a year.'

The childminder who upset me so much is not unusual in her attitude. During my maternity leave, I went with Sarah to local playgroups. I sat about, a bovine eavesdropper on the drifting conversations of mothers, childminders and nannies. The nannies dismayed me. There seemed to be a rivalrous double standard at work. The nannies disparaged parents. They were being paid by working mothers but had little regard for them. The subtext was plain - they would never leave their children. Was it the norm, I asked Rebecca Holmes, for nannies to feel superior in this way? 'Most probably do. They see terrible examples of bad mothers. They see the knicker drawers, the bad moods. You don't know them but - my God! - they know you.'

No one trains to be a mother. So why do nannies need to go to college? Any one who watched the BBC's hair-raising two-part series Au Pairs should be able to answer that question. With no experience and no affection, it is possible for an untrained girl to make a catastrophically bad job of looking after children. It is frightening to think of the tide of au pair girls flowing in and out of this country. But there is also a murky standing pool of unqualified British nannies who should fill us with equal alarm. Many are nannies because they can't think of anything else to do. These are the casuals who make up what Rebecca Holmes describes as 'a hidden workforce'.

I was an au pair girl once, in Paris. I was 18. I remember how hard it was to have responsibility without authority. I was quietly mutinous. I often used to throw away the starchy noodles Madame wanted me to force down her daughters' throats. I believed I understood her daughters better than she did. She said her eldest daughter, Delphine, was spiteful. It was unjust. Delphine was jealous of her baby sister. The experience almost put me off having children myself. 'They change your life completely,' I revealed in a letter to my parents.

During this stint as an au pair, I was told what was intended to be a cautionary tale by my employers. Friends of theirs had noticed that whenever they came home after a night when their au pair had been babysitting, their children - usually fitful sleepers - would be out for the count. One night, a concert was cancelled, and the couple returned to find their apartment empty.

They were on the verge of phoning the police when the front door opened and children and au pair girl entered. The children's faces were dirty and they were wearing garish, tattered clothes. They looked liked beggars and begging was what they had been doing: the au pair had been down in the Metro... the moral? Au pairs are the Devil. Decent, hardworking au pairs and professional nannies like Sarah fear extreme stories of this kind. And you have only to say 'Louise Woodward' to get a rise out of them. Sarah speaks out against these traitors. They have undermined trust.

But employers can be far from saintly. I don't accept the moral of the au pair story nowadays. I wonder what could have driven the au pair to such an extreme.

Being an au pair helped me understand the stresses of looking after other people's children. Becoming mothers helped nannies Jocelyn Smith and Debbie Stamp understand their employers. They were astonished to discover how much harder it is looking after their own children. Jocelyn explains: 'The emotional investment is greater. You feel devastated if your two-year-old is anti-social.' Debbie found it 'a shock the way I was with my own son. I'd say, "OK then, have the sweets".' She understands now how parents feel. She recalls the way her charges used to go to pieces when their parents came home: 'Working parents feel guilty and what the children say goes.' The guilt, she thinks, makes parents 'harder on the nanny, softer on the children'.

Rebecca Holmes believes few working mothers are free from guilt. It can produce strange side-effects. It can make control-freak parents fanatically fussy. Remote-control freaks. One nanny told me of an employer who stipulated that she should not drink tea during the day in case an accident should occur and the child be scalded.

Perfection isn't possible. But Beverly Davis told me that Sarah won because she did not try to take over, as many nannies do, but seemed willing to work as part of the family. Jocelyn and Debbie believe this is crucial too. But Debbie points out that criticism is only natural. 'It is normal at work,' she observes mildly, 'to blame the bosses.'

webTitle: She's so caring. Why does my husband hate her?

fields.headline: She's so caring. Why does my husband hate her?
fields.trailText: I work full time and my two-year-old daughter is looked after by a nanny who is reliable and caring. My husband, who works from home, dislikes her.
fields.body:
I work full time and my two-year-old daughter is looked after by a nanny who is reliable and caring. My husband, who works from home, dislikes her. He is almost obsessive and we argue about her a lot. He says I have no idea what it's like having her in the house all day. He wants to sack her but I can't bear losing her.

SM of Lincolnshire

Taking a complete stranger into your home to perform such an important and intimate function as caring for your child is bound to cause stresses. I remember it well. Quite apart from the nanny's competence and rapport with your daughter, there is the considerable feeling of intrusion of an outsider into your domestic life, your inner sanctum. I would guess that the task of advertising, interviewing and selecting fell to your lot, so that the first encounter between nanny and husband was when she took the job on day one.

He may never have got over the culture shock of seeing his daughter's care handed over to this incomer. The noise and activity of the child and her attendant probably pervade the whole house, and make him feel rather like the intruder himself. Men hate to feel gauche and awkward especially in their own homes, and can react in a variety of negative ways.

These points are worth exploring because the problem could be with nannies generally rather than this one specifically. You do not mention any particular reason why he feels such antipathy, and he presumably has considered the consequences of sacking her; that he will have to cope himself, or you will have to stop work.

I suspect this nanny's days are numbered whether you like it or not, as it's unlikely that she's unaware of your husband's strong reaction, and may not find the situation tolerable for much longer. So patiently probe for the full story. If the nanny is an older woman, he could feel intimidated at her domestic competence, and resent being treated like a nuisance who must be swept away into his own room. He may find his dignity undermined by overfamiliarity, or irritated by unremitting chatter. If she is a young woman, and especially if she is personable, there could be a sexual frisson.

Under these circumstances, it is not surprising he resents being a hostage in his own home. I recall a young employee of mine, a girl of many problems, who would scream in terror if any man entered the room where she was working. You can imagine how galling that was; and obviously a touch histrionic, since it stopped as soon as I mentioned it.

Physical separation of nanny/child from husband may not be feasible if your house is of average size. But it might be possible to delineate the use of certain rooms at certain times, and to outline an approximate timetable so that the kitchen will be empty when they are out walking, and so on. If the present situation is unsalvageable these things could be thought out for the next time.

Perhaps more importantly, he could then be charged with the process of nanny selection. Do you trust him enough to do this? It would be revealing to put this proposal to him now and gauge the reaction. You then face the possibility that you might disagree profoundly about the next employee.

Total domestic harmony is the ideal. But if the reasons for his dislike are nebulous, and if she stays the course, you should hang in there a bit longer. Your instincts over child care are better honed than his, and your daughter's well-being comes before his amour-propre. He may just have to adjust.

Reader's responses

I can appreciate how your husband feels. It must be very irritating to have the presence of another person in the house. Would it be possible to work out a weekly rota so when he is in the house, she can be out with your daughter at playgroup or doing a daily trip to the park or shopping? At least then your husband would know when she will be in the house and when she won't and not feel so intimidated. It might ease the strain of listening trying to guess if she is in or out.

L.A. of Notting Hill, London

I certainly do not wish to put a spanner in the works or arouse suspicions and I could be completely wrong, but do you think your husband might have had an affair with this nanny and now wants her out of the house? This would account for his 'obsessiveness' about the issue and he might be desperate to get rid of her in case she lets slip their guilty secret.

Y.R. of Catford, London

Next week's dilemma is from Anon of Dorset

My husband has suffered from chronic clinical depression for many years. I have always sympathised with him and learned to live with his bleak moods. However, recently he has got worse. Although he knows he has got a problem, he will not seek medical advice and thinks his depression would instantly lift if certain problems were sorted out. I know this is not the case. He needs medical help but will not recognise this or seek help. What can I do?

fields.headline: A return to Victorian values
fields.standfirst: New Labour's love affair with grand public buildings is not just old-fashioned civic pride
fields.trailText: New Labour's love affair with grand public buildings is not just old-fashioned civic pride
fields.body:
Next week, in the spectacular setting of the National Portrait Gallery's new rooftop restaurant, Culture Secretary Chris Smith will announce details of a whole raft of new buildings opening this spring.

The setting could not be more apt. As he describes plans to launch the new Tate Gallery at Bankside, the Millennium Bridge across the Thames, the Lowry Centre in Salford, the New Art Gallery in Walsall and a range of major refurbishments to existing museums and galleries, assembled journalists will have all around them evidence of the last time Britain built civic monuments on this scale - the Victorian period.

Not since the nineteenth century has architecture been used so consciously to promote civic, indeed national, pride. Of course, the twentieth century had its building booms - the Sixties housing explosion, the Eighties expansion of office space - but not for more than a century have civic buildings been so much the flavour of the day.

Most of these symbols of our new era would have been as intelligible to a top-hatted or crinolined Victorian as they are to today's trainers-wearing masses. The Dome, the London Eye Ferris wheel, the new Thames Bridge and Tate Modern would all have been instantly understandable to the people who brought us the 1851 Great Exhibition, the Thames-side pleasure gardens at Vauxhall, numerous great engineering projects and most of our major museums (including the National Portrait Gallery).

But what would a Victorian have made of today's new civic monuments? Concrete, flat roofs, manmade materials, like the Dome's Teflon skin, and other twentieth-century inventions have revolutionised the way buildings are constructed and our ideas about how they should look.

A time-travelling Victorian would be astounded at how tall our buildings are, how plain they look. Even so, he might not be altogether lost, particularly if he ended up in Wales. Norman Foster's 100 metre-long, elliptical, glass-and-steel greenhouse at the new Botanic Garden of Wales (which opens this Easter) is the direct descendant of Sir Joseph Paxton's glasshouse at Chatsworth and his extraordinary 1851 Crystal Palace, home to the Great Exhibition. More generally, the engineering aesthetic of high-tech buildings like the Dome owes a debt to Victorian structures such as railway stations and suspension bridges.

What is missing today is the debate in Victorian times over what constitutes an appropriate British architecture. Back and forth Victorians went between classical and Gothic. Classical was held up as the architecture of 'civilised' nations, Gothic as a uniquely British style.

Architecture at the start of the twenty-first century appears infinitely more open, more willing to accept a far wider range of influences. The designers of Tate Modern are a Swiss pair, Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron; Michael Wilford, architect of the Lowry Centre, though British, made his name abroad.

Buildings like the New Art Gallery in Walsall, which opens next month, suggest that other things may be afoot. Its architects, the young London-based practice, Caruso St John, have sought deliberately to create an appropriate architecture for the city, using local mate rials such as terracotta, albeit in very contemporary ways. As globalisation becomes ever more real, it is far from inconceivable that concern over the 'Britishness' of British architecture will grow.

The museums, the galleries, the parks and public squares of Victorian Britain were predominantly the work of private patrons - city fathers and wealthy industrialists, men who had made money and wanted monuments. Their reasons were to educate and 'wow' the masses into a sense of civic and national pride - but the project was never centrally orchestrated.

More interventionist government and lottery funding have changed all that. The result is that there seems something imposed rather than organic about today's civic pride. Once, civic buildings, born out of real wealth and local pride, reflected success. Today, although its building types are similar and its urban bias the same, civic architecture is seen as the catalyst for, rather than a reflection of, regeneration.

Which is not to say that it won't work. There have been wobbles. The National Centre for Popular Music in Sheffield and the Earth Centre in Doncaster have had fewer visitors than expected. There has been grumbling that the Dome is boring. Some critics doubt the viability of the Lowry. It is too early to judge the project as a whole. What is certain is that Victorian values aren't dead.

fields.headline: A double triumph for Tavener
fields.standfirst: Critically acclaimed at the Millennium Dome, John Tavener was further saluted at St Paul's
fields.trailText: Fall and Resurrection | Steven Osborne | A Midsummer Night's Dream | Fantasia
fields.body:
Fall and Resurrection St Paul's Cathedral/ BBC Radio 3
Steven Osborne Wigmore Hall
A Midsummer Night's Dream Opera North, Leeds
Fantasia Philharmonia, Royal Albert Hall

Blissfully dismissive of fashion but acutely aware that he finds himself its epitome, John Tavener launched the millennium for the second time this week. As if one dome wasn't enough, he filled Wren's loftier version with sounds more fitting for a Byzantine temple than an Anglican cathedral.

Beginning in violet near-darkness and ending in candlelight, Fall and Resurrection compresses a Paradise both lost and regained into 70 minutes via a biblical patchwork text by his mentor, Mother Thekla. The work swings from extremes of scale, volume and range. Two choirs, a large orchestra, several exotic instruments including kavals (a form of breathy flute), the great organ of St Paul's and even its bells, their joyful peals used as a finale, roll beguilingly round the building, teasing even the most reluctant ear.

Tavener's volubly declared hatred of art music (music written for the concert hall rather than for God) has set him apart from fellow composers who at once scorn and envy him. One of their plaints is that all his music sounds the same. He would take this as high praise, since his aim is to work within an unchanging tradition, specifically that of his own Orthodox church. Yet however he might protest, Fall and Resurrection is richer and more dramatic than usual, the scoring denser, the grand climaxes almost Mahlerian, though he would recoil at the very idea.

The performers excelled. Patricia Rozario and Stephen Richardson as Adam and Eve were required to sing at the extremes of their vocal range, with the countertenor Michael Chance ethereal and Martyn Hill an oriental-sounding Psaltis. Under Richard Hickox, the City of London Sinfonia, the BBC Singers and the choir of St Paul's gave their all. So did Tavener, who appeared like a frail, angelic giant at the end, rapturous amid the rapture.

From the many to the one. Steven Osborne chose a monumental work from the last century to herald the new. Messiaen's 1945 pianistic epic, Vingt regards sur l'Enfant Jésus , springs from the same fount of faith which inspires Tavener. Their music is an act of prayer, any darkness in it not modern psychological anxiety but ancient terror of damnation. Accept that or the methods irritate, the rep etition baffles. Music of the past two centuries has not prized ritual and symmetry; Tavener and Messiaen look further back and are often misunderstood.

Written shortly after the composer's release from a German prison camp, the Vingt regards uses opposing forces of frenzy and calm. Simple, unearthly parallel motifs, four octaves apart, contrast with close, splashy chords perfumed with jazzy sixths. Each movement has a title ('Regard of the Son Towards the Son', 'Regard of the Spirit of Joy' etc). Their elusive sameness may defeat the listener.

At nearly two-and-a-quarter hours long without interval, this work in praise of God makes pretty stringent demands on Man (and Woman too; it was written for Yvonne Loriod, who was to become Messiaen's wife). The stamina, technique and muscle power required defy belief. Not many can do it. Pierre-Laurent Aimard gave a dazzling account at the BBC's Messiaen weekend a year ago; Osborne was every bit as exciting. In his magicianly hands, the piano transformed itself into harp, vibraphone, organ, bells. His grasp of structure was impressive, his virtuosity unshowy.

Opera North chose midwinter for a no-nonsense production of A Midsummer Night's Dream. Not regarded as one of Britten's finest operas, it nevertheless has a sensuous orchestral score, evoking the pale mysteries of fairyland with delicious adroitness - lovingly performed here by the orchestra of Opera North under the company's new music director, Steven Sloane.

In Moshe Leiser and Patrice Caurier's hands, the production dared to play down, if not remove entirely, woodland magic and fairy wings. Bottom (Jonathan Best) keeps his ass's head but all around him are transfigured into some vague prehistoric age. Christian Fenouillat's designs were minimal and geometric, offset by Agostino Cavalca's ingeniously detailed costumes.

The awkward distribution of characters, uncertain enough in Shakespeare but further weakened in the Britten/Pears libretto, mars the work's dramatic pace, with wearying emphasis on the Pyramus and Thisbe scene. The Athenian lovers, though well sung, never quite establish their identity, Theseus and Hippolyta are reduced to a nonsensically brief appearance, while the rude mechanicals outstay their welcome.

But Opera North's cast was first class, led by Claron McFadden as Tytania and Christopher Josey as Oberon, and Jan Knightley in the speaking role of Puck. The score is always worth hearing. The next performance is in Leeds on Saturday, then Nottingham, Manchester and Newcastle until the end of February.

My colleague Philip French found little to recommend in the remake of Fantasia, now touring Imax cinemas. Having rougher sensibilities, and seeing it with a live performance of the music by the Philharmonia, conducted by James Levine at the Royal Albert Hall, I enjoyed it rather more than the original. Using shorter pieces did less damage to the music and eliminated the longueurs of the 1940 version. Stokowski's conducting of The Rite of Spring to apocalyptic imagery may have switched a few children on to the music but surely turned thousands more off.

Lowering its aspirations, Fantasia 2000 was merely entertaining. The cartoons for Rhapsody in Blue and Carnival of the Animals were a delight, though Donald Duck in a sugary Noah's Ark, inexplicably linked to Elgar's Pomp and Circumstance , was a strain. But the flying whales got me to the end of Respighi's interminable Pines of Rome for the first time ever.

If anyone was going to broaden my musical horizons, I didn't expect it to be Disney.

fields.headline: Degsy's celebrity firmament
fields.trailText: Degsy in the Morning |  Nicky Campbell | The Vortex
fields.body:
Degsy in the Morning (Talk Radio)
Nicky Campbell (Radio 5 Live)
The Vortex (R3)

At the end of the day, you can't have your cake and eat it, it's going to get worse before it gets better and no one is without blemish, unless it is Derek 'Degsy' Hatton on Talk Radio, who has more clichés up his sleeve ready to squirt over callers than Posh Spice has knickers, especially now that she's sharing them with David Beckham.

I am not being gratuitously smutty. Her borrowed underwear was the main topic of discussion after the 11am news on Talk Radio last Thursday. But before you write Degsy's programme off as tabloid radio aimed at the mindless masses, let me tell you that before he aired Mrs B's thong, he covered the same subject as Nicky Campbell on Radio 5 Live - the new civil christening ceremonies. Campbell had worthy ladies from the Universal Church talking earnestly about the need for children to bond with the Universe. Degsy had Andy from Docklands who, well, like, didn't hold with religion but saw no harm in christening the kid in a hotel if that's what turned you on. Same with funerals. Why should they be in church?

All that talk about heaven and hell was downright divisive, if you asked Andy. And since Degsy had asked him, he and we were duty-bound to listen to every last glorious word. Good on you, Andy - up with atheism.

The knickers were purely a peg from which to hang the far more serious subject of celebrity. Posh Spice, Liz Hurley and Anthea Turner had only themselves to blame for trying to manipulate the press to their advantage, declared one of Degsy's studio experts, who raised the whole tone of the debate by referring to the world of showbiz thus: 'Of all the stars in the celebrity firmament, Chris Evans has the greatest integrity.' If that's what drivers are listening to no wonder there are so many motorway pile-ups.

Try as I might, and brilliant as they are said to be, I just cannot hack one more Noël Coward centenary play. Last week, it was The Vortex , the week before Easy Virtue , both scoring 10 for performances and minus 10 for content. Maybe it's because his characters are parodied so often that the originals sound clichéd and trite. It must be fun to act him, with all that clipped 'Dulling, I adore you', but listening to it soon palls. I never tire of the upper-class hoorays in Waugh or Mitford. It may be that Coward the performer does the job so well himself in cabaret that the plays, with their ludicrous plots, are redundant.

If that's what drivers are listening to no wonder there are so many motorway pile-ups. Try as I might, and brilliant as they are said to be, I just cannot hack one more Noël Coward centenary play. Last week, it was The Vortex , the week before Easy Virtue , both scoring 10 for performances and minus 10 for content. Maybe it's because his characters are parodied so often that the originals sound clichéd and trite. It must be fun to act him, with all that clipped 'Dulling, I adore you', but listening to it soon palls. I never tire of the upper-class hoorays in Waugh or Mitford. It may be that Coward the performer does the job so well himself in cabaret that the plays, with their ludicrous plots, are redundant.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: The writer of Bhaji on the beach and the maker of Beyond Skin are separately redefining the image of British Asians. But Meera Syal and Nitin Sawhney might have starred together in Goodness Gracious Me...
fields.trailText: Nitin Sawhney | Meera Syal
fields.body:
Nitin Sawhney The first time I saw Meera was on Tonight With Jonathan Ross in about 1992. It was astounding to see someone in a sari running rings around Ross on mainstream TV. She was very sharp and articulate. I was in my twenties and I'd only seen Asian people as stereotypes on television before - in It Ain't Half Hot Mum, Mind Your Language, The Party. They were never funny unless they were the butt of the joke. What surprised me was how in control she was as an Asian woman. I grew up in a very white, middle-class area, in Rochester in Kent, and remember always feeling inferior in some way. It was the way the educational system and the media work; and the National Front were very strong in my area. The stereotypes in the media seemed to condone children to openly mock Asian kids. When I saw Meera, it just made my eyes boggle.

About seven or eight years ago, I met her at the Leicester Haymarket. At the time, I was doing a double-act with Sanjeev Baskar called the Secret Asians. Then we encountered Meera, doing her stand-up routine. At the time, she had just had a personal tragedy, and it was incredible how professional she was. She just went back on stage and was funny, in control of herself and the audience.

Two years later, we worked together on a musical called Night Train to Poona. She had a beautiful voice and was a great lyricist and we found we could write things on a serious level as well. We still cling to this idea of writing a musical together, perhaps with Philip Headley, artistic director of the Theatre Royal at Stratford East.

She asked me to act and write music for a series she was doing for Radio 4 called Masala FM - a spoof radio show. There was quite a lot of the team from Goodness Gracious Me there. That was before John Ploughman, the head of BBC Light Entertainment, asked if we wanted to try for a TV series. I hadn't worked with anyone else as an actor or a writer, until Masala FM. But she believed in me.

She's very flexible, very giving as a writer, and works without ego or arrogance. Meera has a very powerful sense of humour that combines satire with a sense of compassion and political awareness. It also stunned me how multi-talented she was. She can dance, write scripts, novels and music, and was in an a cappella band many years ago. With Goodness Gracious Me, she put a lot of work into making everything feel organic, and all of us had a real sense of fun about it.

I don't write comedy any more. I've had a very successful year with my new album, but I still miss the idea of getting up on stage and having a laugh with a bunch of friends - which is what GGM was. Meera still comes to all my gigs, then phones me up and tells me what she thinks. In our work, the humour came from us being friends and getting on. More than anything, she's an inspiration as a person.

There is almost an Asian renaissance that has gone on in this country. People talk of an Asian underground, but it's very much overground now. Meera was one of the early pioneers, making Asian people realise that stereotypes were no longer relevant to a multicultural Britain. She set a precedent for looking away from the stereotypes and preconceptions that people like Norman Tebbit were trying to impose upon us. She was a good friend as well.

Meera Syal I first saw Nitin when I went to see him at a Secret Asians gig. I'd heard they were the best up-and-coming comedy duo. I was so impressed with both of them. It was a standard of comedy and music that I hadn't really seen coming out of us lot. Nitin was very much the strong silent one. He looked too young and had such grace, switching quite effortlessly from fooling around to producing this amazing music. It was so seamless.

I assumed he wouldn't be interested in working with me but when I got to know him he was very self-effacing. He doesn't doubt his own ability but he's not very good at blowing his own trumpet. We all big each other up. There's such a small band of us, that we have to really.

It's very much a British Asian thing for both of us. Nitin is still very interested in his culture, as am I. He's been to India loads of times. We don't make a point of discussing our backgrounds. With people on a similar wavelength, you've got a shorthand, which is what you want if you aren't going to go crazy together. The worst thing is having to explain yourself the whole time with other people. You can have in-jokes with each other.

It was great working with him because we could just shortcut loads of things. It was a case of kindred spirits - people whom you click with. On one occasion, he turned up to write a song for a show the next day. We had the lyrics but no tune. I was really panicking - I had to sing it in about 10 hours. We came up with a tune in about 10 minutes. It was perfect. We both pick things up very quickly. We did write a really beautiful love song together - We Meet Again - about two people who have the feeling that they've met before.

When it comes down to what he wants - he's an absolute control freak. Getting a compliment from Nitin was a very big thing. He doesn't give them out lightly. We're quite similar. I don't know if he suffers from this, but sometimes I worry that I'm a jack of all trades and not really brilliant at anything. He made absolutely the right decision to leave GGM and concentrate on his music, it was just upsetting because we were all working together, and we missed him. Writing the series, we'd have a laugh and then have to structure and graft it into a sketch that worked. It's difficult editing your own work all the time. It helps to have someone else there to say when it doesn't work. You need the reassurance of the group. If everybody laughs at a joke, you can be fairly sure that it's not because it's offensive. It was all very organic: we never sat down and discussed what the show was going to be about. You can't manufacture that shorthand.

Nitin's suddenly got this lifestyle that's almost out of a movie. He'll say: 'Oh, Paul McCartney came round last week.' You always find out who he's met a month afterwards. I went to an evening with Tom Jones recently: I think I told everyone - people I didn't know, actually - I was ringing random people out of the phonebook. I can't really pop round any more just to see Nitin. I have to find out what part of the world he's in first. What binds you in the end is whether you have a friendship and get on. We're not just bound together because we're second generation British Asians. It's about the answer to the question: 'Do you want to hang out with this person?'

fields.headline: Grooming report: Look sharp
fields.standfirst: The dashing blade's guide to getting a good shave
fields.trailText: The dashing blade's guide to getting a good shave
fields.body:
A poor shaving routine is probably as common, and as much a rite of passage for men as its female equivalent - the ill-fitting bra (even if it doesn't attract quite the same amount of attention). Men usually learn to shave either by trial and error, or from their fathers, picking up bad habits and sticking with them.

The episode of The Simpsons where Homer takes Bart through his first shave would seem to be not too far from the common experience: randomly slap dollops of foam on to face, attack with a blunt blade and finish off by splashing after-shave on to open wounds. But male grooming is, albeit slowly, coming out of the closet. The British male is buying moisturiser and Boots has opened its first male-only stores, although the finer points of the most basic of male grooming routines remain a mystery.

Some men use their facial hair to make a statement, but this should be approached with caution. George Clooney's stubble looks good because he is one of the most handsome men in the world. Dali's moustache had acceptable flair because he was a world-class entertainer. Liam Gallagher gets away with a beard because he's a rock star. But these are the exceptions; anthropologists theorise that a smooth face is a sign of youth and vitality. Shaving is also a multi-million pound industry, and manufacturers make aspirational ads encouraging us to keep a smooth face by selling a lifestyle that most men can only dream of, with slogans such as 'the best a man can get.' The best most men could get is a lifetime guarantee of keeping a full head of hair. But a great shave would be a start.

The rules
According to David Waters, author of Grooming Essentials for Men (Carlton Books, £12.99), there are 10 steps to a successful shave:

1 Get wet. Electric razors may be convenient and time-saving but will never achieve the closeness of a wet shave.

2 Buy a swivel-headed razor with a two- or three-blade head. It should be replaced every three to four uses, depending on the thickness of your beard. According to barber Daniel Rouah, using the same blade for a dozen shaves is the equivalent to shaving with a shard of glass.

3 Before you begin, smooth your fingertips over your face to feel the direction of growth of your facial hair. The general rule is that this is the direction in which you should shave. This rule may be broken for the areas in which your beard growth is multi-directional or to achieve an ultra smooth result, but go carefully.

4 Never shave the moment you get up. Wait 20 minutes to enable your facial muscles to tighten, and lift whiskers away from the face to make them easier to shave.

5 Prepare your face for a shave by wringing a towel in hot water and pressing it over the contours of your face for 20 seconds.

6 Shave during, or directly after, your shower or bath. According to dermatologist Neal Schultz MD, if you keep the hairs moist, the force you need to cut them decreases by two-thirds.

7 Go traditional. A shaving brush is a great way of whipping up lather. It helps remove dead skin cells and lifts the beard away from the face.

8 If your beard is especially heavy, apply a moisturiser over your already damp skin before applying shaving gel. This provides another moisturising layer and helps avoid nicks.

9 Start your shave by the side of the ears using slow but short downward sweeps and a steady pressure. The growth is less dense there, giving the shaving foam more time to soften the tougher growth around your neck and chin. Work on the area above the top lip before finally moving on to the chin and neck. Throughout your shave, use your free hand to gently pull and stretch the skin and create a flat surface for your blade.

10 When you have finished, rinse off the lather and splash your face with cold water to rinse and refresh your skin. Always use a clean, soft towel to pat your face dry gently; rubbing may irritate and stretch the skin.

Shaving myths
1 Shaving does not remove a tan; tanning occurs at lower levels of the skin than shaving. It can improve the look of a tan by removing the flaky skin cells that make the skin look dull.

2 The speed at which your hair grows is hereditary and not determined by the age you start shaving.

3 Shaving does not encourage hair to grow darker, faster or thicker. New growth is blunt-edged and synchronised so it may appear to be coming through thicker and faster.

Shaving facts
1 A man's beard grows approximately four tenths of a millimetre a day or six inches a year.

2 A beard contains 7,000 to 20,000 hairs.

3 Beard hair is extremely tough - about as strong as copper wire and the same thickness.

4 The first safety razor was patented by Mr King Camp Gillette in 1903.

5 During an average lifetime, men spend around 3,350 hours removing over 27 feet of whiskers.

fields.headline: Best cellars
fields.standfirst: Some older wines worth knowing
fields.trailText: Some older wines worth knowing
fields.body:
1989 Campillo Gran Reserva Rioja (£13.99, Unwins) Produced at one of Rioja's very few single estates (most wineries buy their grapes on the open market), this Tempranillo-dominated red is a wonderful example of the benefits of bottle ageing. Smooth and gamey on the palate, this is a supple, savoury, complex red with notes of vanilla, leather and wild strawberry.

1990 Wehlener Sonnenuhr Riesling Auslese, Dr Loosen (£16.99, from Waitrose Direct on 0800 188881) Very few, if any, white grapes develop in the bottle as well as Riesling does. This elegant Mosel from one of the best producers in Germany (and one of the finest vineyards) is starting to settle into honeyed maturity, but still tastes remarkably fresh. The sweetness is kept in check by a leash of minerally acidity.

1992 Corton Bressandes, Domaine Jacques Prieur (£29.99, selected branches of Sainsbury's. Call 0800 636262 for details of your nearest store) 1992 was a better year for whites than reds in Burgundy, but there are still some very drinkable wines around for early drinking. This Grand Cru Cte de Beaune red is a fine example. The oak is well integrated, the fruit is sensuous and sweetly hedonistic and the tannins are as smooth as an ice rink. Great value for a wine of this quality.

fields.headline: Naughty Roy
fields.trailText: Thirty years on, the truth can be told. In 1969, the household of Roy Hattersley may have been a little more assiduous than that of the Prime Minister, Harold Wilson, in boycotting South African goods. Or not.
fields.body:
Thirty years on, the truth can be told. In 1969, the household of Roy Hattersley may have been a little more assiduous than that of the Prime Minister, Harold Wilson, in boycotting South African goods. Or not.

Cabinet papers released under the 30-year rule include a reprimand from the Prime Minister to then junior Minister Hattersley for giving the impression in a television interview 'of a [Wilson] household somewhat half-hearted in its dislike of apartheid'. Hattersley had said that 'while the Wilson household - or Mrs Wilson - did not buy very many South African goods, the Hattersley household buys no South African goods'.

Hattersley, then hoping for promotion from whatever his duties were as Minister of Defence for Administration, apologised profusely, but it is the civil servant's note to the Prime Minister that gives us the inside track: 'We have not been able to trace any utterances by you in the House about the extent to which the Wilson household purchases South African goods. I have done the skeleton of the draft but I have left it to you to develop further, as I am not quite sure what points you wish to make.' Since then, we've watched Yes, Prime Minister and know that muted exasperation.

Good fun, but a secret worth keeping 30 years? The Blair household will be delighted to know that nothing in the Freedom of Information Bill reduces our wait for similar revelations of their ethical purchasing policy.

webTitle: A New Year's night to celebrate

fields.headline: A New Year's night to celebrate
fields.trailText: As someone who was on the streets of London, in a group of six, from 7.30pm until 3am over the New Year, I can testify that at no stage did the police seem to play other than a passive role; individual officers on the streets, however, could not be faulted for their helpfulness and good humour.
fields.body:
As someone who was on the streets of London, in a group of six, from 7.30pm until 3am over the New Year, I can testify that at no stage did the police seem to play other than a passive role; individual officers on the streets, however, could not be faulted for their helpfulness and good humour.

The whole night struck me as one of leaving people to their own devices, and I was amazed not to read of casualties the next day. That there were none seems more due to the good nature and stoicism of the British when in a difficult situation, than because of any overt action by the police during the evening.
David Pollard
Addlestone
Surrey

So Euan Ferguson (News, last week) thinks 'we live in a rather graceless country which offers little scope for deviation from the Tesco norm'. What? I was at the London celebrations, and far from a 'passion-free crush' experienced a wonderful time with my fellow countrymen and women in a great capital city.
Edward Scarff
Birchington on Sea
Kent

Having experienced the terror of the Hillsborough-like crushes along the Thames, we feel that the entertainment should have been organised with more vision to cater for the safety of the thousands of revellers.
Lucy, Penny and Naomi Tyler, Donald Daby, Jim Gladstone and Geoff Prout
London W11

fields.headline: Barbara Doll
fields.body:
I fear that your columnist Barbara Ellen is either fishing for compliments, or the photographer responsible for her portrait is a skilled practitioner in the blacker of his or her arts. A joint father-and-teenage-son glance at her photograph brought reactions of rare harmony in this household. We both agreed that she is, to use adjectives apparently current, 'well fit'. In a further act of unprecedented solidarity, we are also both agreed that age is no boundary to sexual attraction.
John and Michael Griffiths
Northolt, Middx

fields.headline: Life and death in South Central LA
fields.standfirst: South Central Los Angeles is notorious both for its violent gang warfare and for the gangsta rap that celebrates it, yet the media rarely ventures there. Orlando Anderson was the main suspect, and when he himself was killed in LA some 18 months later, many considered it a job well done.
