fields.headline: World In Brief
fields.trailText: Benetton unites with Italian anti-death penalty campaigners
fields.body:
Benetton unites with Italian anti-death penalty campaigners

Fashion giant Benetton is joining a growing campaign in Italy against the death penalty. Its latest advertising campaign, to be released world-wide at the end of the month, features American death-row inmates in prison uniforms staring into the camera over the words, 'Sentenced to Death'.

Last-ditch fight for Cuban boy, 6

Attempts continued in Miami to block the decision by the US immigration authorities to return to Cuba Elian Gonzalez, 6, found in November clinging to an inner tube after his mother and others drowned attempting to reach America. A lawyer has issued a subpoena requiring him to testify to Congress in an attempt to extend his stay beyond next Friday's date for his repatriation.

Norwegian train toll reaches 19

Norwegian search teams found a nineteenth body in the wreckage of two trains that collided five days ago. They hope it will be the last, but planned to continue the search into today.

Police also published the names of 10 of those killed in last Tuesday's head-on crash at Asta, north of Oslo. The dead ranged in age from 21 to 69 and all were Norwegian, except one Danish woman.

Armenian charged

Aruntun Arutunian, deputy director of Armenian television, has been charged with helping organise an attack in parliament last October that killed Armenia's premier, Vazgen Sarkisian, and seven other top officials.

Hot shock

A husband in Trento, northern Italy, who called an erotic chatline that promised to put him through to a 'hot housewife' got a shock when his wife answered. She had been driven into the job by boredom.

Wife divorces wife

An 80-year-old Kenyan tribeswoman has divorced her young wife because of 'cruelty and violence'. Some tribes allow women to 'marry' when an elderly widow has not had a son, and one is needed to perpetuate the family line.

webTitle: Timbuktu logs on to the world

fields.headline: Timbuktu logs on to the world
fields.standfirst: Can the Internet create a short cut between the end of the Earth and the global village
fields.trailText: Timbuktu is a town of myths and this is the latest: the Internet will catapult into modernity a place known since the late nineteenth century as 'the ends of the Earth'.
fields.body:
Timbuktu is a town of myths and this is the latest: the Internet will catapult into modernity a place known since the late nineteenth century as 'the ends of the Earth'.

Malle Diahara draws her white scarf round her head and taps into her computer at the Internet access centre. 'When I was little, we didn't have TV or the telephone, but I didn't know I was isolated,' she said. 'It's only now, with the Internet, that I feel it. The need to communicate never occurred to me before.'

Diahara has the zeal of a convert. She is one of four young people who run the centre. 'With the new technology of the Internet, we can exchange experiences with others, and the way they do things can inspire us,' she said.

Timbuktu has had the Internet for nearly a year now, and in a few months the connection will be made even faster.

There are thrice-weekly flights to the capital of Mali, Bamako, but the road to Timbuktu is still cut every year when the River Niger floods, and transport is expensive. A handful of people have started to use the Internet centre regularly, because at 500CFA (the equivalent of 50p) it is much cheaper to send an e-mail to Bamako or Paris than to phone.

Abdoul Malick, an unemployed youth, has found that he can even make a little money by logging on to news sites and printing out reports The bestseller of last year was the story which broke the week the centre started - Bill Clinton and Monica.

'The Internet is not a luxury,' said Dr Ahmed Ba, a dentist. 'It allows us to be part of the world of science, because honestly at the moment we're not. We just have our basic training. It helps us get up to date with new methods of treatment, which are maybe simpler or more effective.'

Timbuktu is one of the poorest places in Africa - many of the dental problems Ba sees are caused by malnutrition and vitamin deficiency.

Africa has always inspired outsiders to dream up technical solutions to poverty, most of which have failed. An abandoned Norwegian frozen fish factory on the shores of Kenya's Lake Turkana is one of the most infamous monuments to the folly of foreigners. But while the Kenyans never expressed a desire for frozen fish, the educated people of Timbuktu do want to end their isolation. The question is how.

Half a millennium ago, Timbuktu was a seat of Islamic learning. A cross-roads between Africa, Europe and the Middle East, it boasted a university and hundreds of scholars. Now, after decades of decline and the Tuareg rebellion in the early Nineties, tourism has corrupted the culture. Children play truant from school, running through the dusty streets begging money from visitors.

The evidence of Timbuktu's cultured past lies in about 20 private libraries, where thousands of handwritten documents in Arabic script are piled up in old cupboards, boxes and leather camel saddle bags. Some documents date back to the twelfth century, but most are from the sixteenth when Timbuktu was part of the Songhai Empire. They detail every aspect of life - astrology, religion, poetry, mathematics, music, commerce - a trove of information waiting to be studied.

Abdel Kader Haidara's family have been collecting documents for generations. An American foundation gave him the money to build a library, which is due to open this week, so he can move his manuscripts from the outhouse where he has been keeping them. Soon he hopes to get computers so he can copy the documents on to CD-Rom and make them available on the Internet.

Computers have brought Timbuktu into the information age, and may well have the potential to help the town preserve its heritage and overcome a legacy of neglect. but the key lies not in the technology, but in the skills and resources put into education and training to make it work.

Lindsey Hilsum and Tim Lambon's film on the Internet in Timbuktu will be shown on Channel 4 News tonight at 7.30pm.

webTitle: Butcher of Cambodia set  to expose Thatcher's role

fields.headline: Butcher of Cambodia set  to expose Thatcher's role
fields.standfirst: Ta Mok, one of Pol Pot's genocidal henchman, who faces trial, tells  Jason Burke in Phnom Penh he will expose the West's part in training the Khmer Rouge
fields.trailText: In a small, dark, heavily guarded cell in Phnom Penh's main military prison sits a man of 74, wizened, white-haired, one-legged. He is in good health and surprisingly high spirits, given his grim future and grimmer past.
fields.body:
In a small, dark, heavily guarded cell in Phnom Penh's main military prison sits a man of 74, wizened, white-haired, one-legged. He is in good health and surprisingly high spirits, given his grim future and grimmer past.

He is Ta Mok, also known as the Butcher or Chhit Chouen - possibly the cruellest and most violent of the Khmer Rouge commanders who turned Cambodia's green countryside into the killing fields.

The Prime Minister of Cambodia, Hun Sen, has hopes to try Ta Mok for his crimes next month. Many in his shattered country are happy at the prospect. Others, including many of the political leadership and bureaucracy, fear his testimony will unveil their own roles during the time of Pol Pot's genocide.

The unease is not restricted to the small, desperately poor, swampy country of 10 million that is modern Cambodia. For when Ta Mok takes the stand, his lawyers promise, no one will be spared - least of all the Western leaders who, they say, supported the Khmer Rouge despite the Maoist extremists' atrocities being widely known.

The most damaging element, for Britain at least, of Ta Mok's court appearance will be new evidence about how British troops and diplomats helped the Khmer Rouge in their fight for power.

Contacted in his prison cell through an intermediary last week, he confirmed to The Observer that the extent to which London and Washington helped the Khmer Rouge in their fight to control Cambodia would be revealed during his trial. The evidence will contradict statements made by Margaret Thatcher's Government - which authorised the operation at the time.

Ta Mok's lawyer, Benson Samay, said the court would hear details of how, between 1985 and 1989, the Special Air Service (SAS) ran a series of training camps for Khmer Rouge allies in Thailand close to the Cambodian border and created a 'sabotage battalion' of 250 experts in explosives and ambushes. Intelligence experts in Singapore also ran training courses, Samay said.

To allow Ministers to deny helping the Khmer Rouge, the SAS was ordered to train only soldiers loyal to the ousted Prince Norodom Sihanouk, and the liberal democrat former Prime Minister, Son Sann, who were fighting alongside Pol Pot's Communists. However, Samay said the court would be told the Khmer Rouge benefited substantially from the British operation.

'All these groups were fighting together - but the Khmer Rouge were in charge. They profited from any help to the others. If they had won the war outright, then Pol Pot would have been back in charge,' Samay said.

The Khmer Rouge and their allies were fighting against the Vietnamese-backed puppet regime Hanoi had installed after ousting Pol Pot's extremist Communists and exposing the horrors of the killing fields.

In a classic piece of Cold War realpolitik, Britain - prompted by the Americans - appears to have given military assistance to the Khmer Rouge-led coalition, despite knowing of Pol Pot's atrocities, in an attempt to limit the power of the Soviet-backed Vietnamese.

'Thatcher, Reagan, Kissinger - they should all be on trial along with Ta Mok,' Samay said last week. He said the court would also hear that humanitarian supplies for Cambodian refugees in Thailand were diverted to the Khmer Rouge with, he claims, the knowledge of the Americans and the British. The court would also hear, he said, how the diplomatic support offered by London and Washington to the coalition led by the Khmer Rouge was 'a great help and morale booster' for Pol Pot's troops. The coalition retained the Cambodian United Nations seat throughout the Eighties.

Ta Mok's journey from jungle hideout to power to hideout and eventually to prison last May is a powerful symbol of the political tides that have washed over Cambodia in the past decades. In April it will be 25 years since Pol Pot's Chinese-backed Maoist revolutionaries defeated a weak pro-US government and entered Phnom Penh. They themselves were ousted by the Soviet-backed Vietnamese four years later and for 15 years a vicious civil war - fuelled by Cold War politics - racked the country.

The trial of Ta Mok and his Khmer Rouge colleague Kaing KhekIev (nicknamed 'Deuch') - who ran the regime's most notorious torture centre - is a litmus test for this deeply scarred nation. Arguments over the format of proceedings have yet to be resolved - the United Nations and human rights groups fear the trial will be used by the government for political ends or be a sham, or both. But it seems likely it will go ahead nevertheless. Few feel, however, that anyone will be pleased by the outcome.

Not far from the prison where its former commander is being held, the Tuol Sleng torture centre still stands. Its iron beds, manacles and electric cables are intact, though tourists and groups of school children now walk wide-eyed through its cells.

Overlooking the rusting barbed wire are the garish villas of the nouveaux riches who have successfully exploited Cambodia's recent shift towards a new, hugely corrupt, free-market economy. Outside its gates loiter half a dozen beggars - dirty children and disabled victims of the mines that still litter Cambodia's countryside - hoping to beg a few riels (Cambodia's virtually worthless currency) from wealthy farang (tourists).

They know what should happen to Pol Pot's henchmen. 'They should all be punished,' said Pheach Yui, 35, who lost his leg to a mine while fighting against the Khmer Rouge 12 years ago. 'They should all be rounded up and judged and punished for their sins. They should be in jail until they die.'

Yui is likely to be disappointed. There are thought to be 50,000 former Khmer Rouge fighters in government positions. At least five are Cabinet Ministers. Others have been effectively pardoned and live well. They include Ieng Sary, the Khmer Rouge number three and Pol Pot's brother-in-law, Nuon Chea, who was known as 'Brother Number Two' and Khieu Samphan, the movement's one-time Prime Minister.

Even Ta Mok says that they should face punishment. 'I know about only a fraction of what happened,' he told The Observer through an intermediary. 'You should ask Ieng Sary and the others too.' Several key Khmer Rouge commanders are gen erals in the Cambodian army and look untouchable. Even the Prime Minister himself was a Khmer Rouge cadre until being recruited by the Vietnamese.

Ta Mok and 'Deuch' may end up being the only senior Khmer Rouge brought to justice for their crimes. Pol Pot, the architect of the the massacres, died in 1998 and no one else has been arrested or is likely to be.

Though some argue that 'national reconciliation' means forgetting the past, to many the failure to bring the Khmer Rouge killers to justice merely emphasises the cheapness of human life in Cambodia today.

The psychological scars of genocide and war are obvious everywhere. The smallest incident can provoke extreme violence. The crime columns in the press are almost grotesque: three men blow themselves, and a café, to bits playing Russian roulette with an anti-tank mine; a man is murdered in a row over whether the millennium bug is a hoax; a syphilitic farmer kills five children and drinks their blood in the hope of being cured; a chess game ends with one dead, two badly injured. Arguments over land regularly lead to murder.

Attacks with acid have become more common. Last month a government official's wife hideously burnt her husband's mistress by pouring five litres of nitric acid over her while bodyguards held the screaming woman down. Such 'crimes of jealousy' are increasing. Last summer Cambodia's most famous actress was shot dead in the street. The press reported that her murderers had been hired by the wife of the Prime Minister - her alleged lover.

'There is an ingrained culture of might is right,' said one Western diplomat. 'It needs very little to spark off appalling violence.' Armed robbery is common and, as the police are corrupt and ineffectual, people take the law into their own hands. Vigilante killings are rou tine, with even novice monks and art students beating suspected robbers to death. The customs and the military, often with the co-operation of senior members of the government, collude in massive smuggling - of beer, drugs, people, tropical hardwood and the country's archaeological heritage.

Cambodia has lost half its forests in the past 30 years, and the trees are still falling fast. Last year soldiers used heavy equipment to break up 30 tonnes of stone carvings from 1,000-year-old archaeological sites before loading them into army trucks and driving them to Thailand to sell to dealers with rich Western clients. The military have even been reported to have been extorting 'protection money' from those trying to conserve Angkor Wat - Cambodia's world-famous jungle temple complex.

The level of development is appallingly low. Average life expectancy is 52, one in five children dies before reaching the age of five, more than a third of the population live below the poverty line and half the children show the effects of malnutrition. Aids killed 6,000 people last year. The elite's exclusive golf course, on the outskirts of Phomh Penh, charges $20,000 (£12,000) for membership, 80 times the average income.

Even the international community's well-meaning interventions often come unstuck. The UN peacekeeping operation hugely boosted Aids in the country and created a parallel dollar economy. A senior French aid worker was reported to be pimping the orphans in his care.

Recently the partly British-funded Cambodian Mine Action Centre was found to have been clearing land for former Khmer Rouge warlords. They included Chhouk Rin - the commander who, in 1994, kidnapped and killed three Western tourists including a Briton.

Khieu Phen is, like Ta Mok, an old man. He was 30 when the Khmer Rouge came to power and lost his brothers, sisters and brother-in-law in the massacres. He survived the killing fields - where he was forced to work 'day and night' and watched 'sons forced to murder their fathers' - by working harder than everyone else. Now he rides a scooter around Phnom Penh hoping to pick up a passenger and earn enough for a bowl of noodles.

'Sometimes I think we are cursed,' he said. 'Everybody takes from this country. So few people give anything. Everybody betrays us in the end.'

Contacted in his prison cell through an intermediary last week, he confirmed to The Observer that the extent to which London and Washington helped the Khmer Rouge in their fight to control Cambodia would be revealed during his trial. The evidence will contradict statements made by Margaret Thatcher's Government - which authorised the operation at the time. Ta Mok's lawyer, Benson Samay, said the court would hear details of how, between 1985 and 1989, the Special Air Service (SAS) ran a series of training camps for Khmer Rouge allies in Thailand close to the Cambodian border and created a 'sabotage battalion' of 250 experts in explosives and ambushes. Intelligence experts in Singapore also ran training courses, Samay said. To allow Ministers to deny helping the Khmer Rouge, the SAS was ordered to train only soldiers loyal to the ousted Prince Norodom Sihanouk, and the liberal democrat former Prime Minister, Son Sann, who were fighting alongside Pol Pot's Communists. However, Samay said the court would be told the Khmer Rouge benefited substantially from the British operation. 'All these groups were fighting together - but the Khmer Rouge were in charge. They profited from any help to the others. If they had won the war outright, then Pol Pot would have been back in charge,' Samay said. The Khmer Rouge and their allies were fighting against the Vietnamese-backed puppet regime Hanoi had installed after ousting Pol Pot's extremist Communists and exposing the horrors of the killing fields. In a classic piece of Cold War realpolitik, Britain - prompted by the Americans - appears to have given military assistance to the Khmer Rouge-led coalition, despite knowing of Pol Pot's atrocities, in an attempt to limit the power of the Soviet-backed Vietnamese. 'Thatcher, Reagan, Kissinger - they should all be on trial along with Ta Mok,' Samay said last week. He said the court would also hear that humanitarian supplies for Cambodian refugees in Thailand were diverted to the Khmer Rouge with, he claims, the knowledge of the Americans and the British. The court would also hear, he said, how the diplomatic support offered by London and Washington to the coalition led by the Khmer Rouge was 'a great help and morale booster' for Pol Pot's troops. The coalition retained the Cambodian United Nations seat throughout the Eighties. Ta Mok's journey from jungle hideout to power to hideout and eventually to prison last May is a powerful symbol of the political tides that have washed over Cambodia in the past decades. In April it will be 25 years since Pol Pot's Chinese-backed Maoist revolutionaries defeated a weak pro-US government and entered Phnom Penh. They themselves were ousted by the Soviet-backed Vietnamese four years later and for 15 years a vicious civil war - fuelled by Cold War politics - racked the country. The trial of Ta Mok and his Khmer Rouge colleague Kaing KhekIev (nicknamed 'Deuch') - who ran the regime's most notorious torture centre - is a litmus test for this deeply scarred nation. Arguments over the format of proceedings have yet to be resolved - the United Nations and human rights groups fear the trial will be used by the government for political ends or be a sham, or both. But it seems likely it will go ahead nevertheless. Few feel, however, that anyone will be pleased by the outcome. Not far from the prison where its former commander is being held, the Tuol Sleng torture centre still stands. Its iron beds, manacles and electric cables are intact, though tourists and groups of school children now walk wide-eyed through its cells. Overlooking the rusting barbed wire are the garish villas of the nouveaux riches who have successfully exploited Cambodia's recent shift towards a new, hugely corrupt, free-market economy. Outside its gates loiter half a dozen beggars - dirty children and disabled victims of the mines that still litter Cambodia's countryside - hoping to beg a few riels (Cambodia's virtually worthless currency) from wealthy farang (tourists). They know what should happen to Pol Pot's henchmen. 'They should all be punished,' said Pheach Yui, 35, who lost his leg to a mine while fighting against the Khmer Rouge 12 years ago. 'They should all be rounded up and judged and punished for their sins. They should be in jail until they die.' Yui is likely to be disappointed. There are thought to be 50,000 former Khmer Rouge fighters in government positions. At least five are Cabinet Ministers. Others have been effectively pardoned and live well. They include Ieng Sary, the Khmer Rouge number three and Pol Pot's brother-in-law, Nuon Chea, who was known as 'Brother Number Two' and Khieu Samphan, the movement's one-time Prime Minister. Even Ta Mok says that they should face punishment. 'I know about only a fraction of what happened,' he told The Observer through an intermediary. 'You should ask Ieng Sary and the others too.' Several key Khmer Rouge commanders are gen erals in the Cambodian army and look untouchable. Even the Prime Minister himself was a Khmer Rouge cadre until being recruited by the Vietnamese. Ta Mok and 'Deuch' may end up being the only senior Khmer Rouge brought to justice for their crimes. Pol Pot, the architect of the the massacres, died in 1998 and no one else has been arrested or is likely to be. Though some argue that 'national reconciliation' means forgetting the past, to many the failure to bring the Khmer Rouge killers to justice merely emphasises the cheapness of human life in Cambodia today. The psychological scars of genocide and war are obvious everywhere. The smallest incident can provoke extreme violence. The crime columns in the press are almost grotesque: three men blow themselves, and a café, to bits playing Russian roulette with an anti-tank mine; a man is murdered in a row over whether the millennium bug is a hoax; a syphilitic farmer kills five children and drinks their blood in the hope of being cured; a chess game ends with one dead, two badly injured. Arguments over land regularly lead to murder. Attacks with acid have become more common. Last month a government official's wife hideously burnt her husband's mistress by pouring five litres of nitric acid over her while bodyguards held the screaming woman down. Such 'crimes of jealousy' are increasing. Last summer Cambodia's most famous actress was shot dead in the street. The press reported that her murderers had been hired by the wife of the Prime Minister - her alleged lover. 'There is an ingrained culture of might is right,' said one Western diplomat. 'It needs very little to spark off appalling violence.' Armed robbery is common and, as the police are corrupt and ineffectual, people take the law into their own hands. Vigilante killings are rou tine, with even novice monks and art students beating suspected robbers to death. The customs and the military, often with the co-operation of senior members of the government, collude in massive smuggling - of beer, drugs, people, tropical hardwood and the country's archaeological heritage. Cambodia has lost half its forests in the past 30 years, and the trees are still falling fast. Last year soldiers used heavy equipment to break up 30 tonnes of stone carvings from 1,000-year-old archaeological sites before loading them into army trucks and driving them to Thailand to sell to dealers with rich Western clients. The military have even been reported to have been extorting 'protection money' from those trying to conserve Angkor Wat - Cambodia's world-famous jungle temple complex. The level of development is appallingly low. Average life expectancy is 52, one in five children dies before reaching the age of five, more than a third of the population live below the poverty line and half the children show the effects of malnutrition. Aids killed 6,000 people last year. The elite's exclusive golf course, on the outskirts of Phomh Penh, charges $20,000 (£12,000) for membership, 80 times the average income. Even the international community's well-meaning interventions often come unstuck. The UN peacekeeping operation hugely boosted Aids in the country and created a parallel dollar economy. A senior French aid worker was reported to be pimping the orphans in his care. Recently the partly British-funded Cambodian Mine Action Centre was found to have been clearing land for former Khmer Rouge warlords. They included Chhouk Rin - the commander who, in 1994, kidnapped and killed three Western tourists including a Briton. Khieu Phen is, like Ta Mok, an old man. He was 30 when the Khmer Rouge came to power and lost his brothers, sisters and brother-in-law in the massacres. He survived the killing fields - where he was forced to work 'day and night' and watched 'sons forced to murder their fathers' - by working harder than everyone else. Now he rides a scooter around Phnom Penh hoping to pick up a passenger and earn enough for a bowl of noodles. 'Sometimes I think we are cursed,' he said. 'Everybody takes from this country. So few people give anything. Everybody betrays us in the end.'

webTitle: Hero of the Arab ghetto in run-in with French police

fields.headline: Hero of the Arab ghetto in run-in with French police
fields.trailText: His one-man show has sold out every night for the past six months. Over the holiday he fronted three prime-time television shows in a row. The Arab with attitude, he is the hero of the graffiti-daubed housing estates. Now he's in big trouble.
fields.body:
His one-man show has sold out every night for the past six months. Over the holiday he fronted three prime-time television shows in a row. The Arab with attitude, he is the hero of the graffiti-daubed housing estates. Now he's in big trouble.

Jamel Debbouze, 23, filed a formal complaint against Paris police on Friday for 'violence leading to a certified incapacity to work for six days', warranting the appointment of an investigating magistrate.

The comedian of Moroccan origin with his trademark withered right arm - the legacy of a boyhood dare on a railway line; it cost a close friend his life - is one of the hottest names in the French entertainment world. He presents one television series, stars in another, has just finished a successful show at a top Paris venue, Le Bataclan, and has two films in post-production. He is the idol of Paris's disaffected immigrant youth.

Like footballer Nicolas Anelka, the star of last season's Arsenal side, Debbouzze grew up in the high-rise, low-income sprawl of Trappes on the outskirts of Paris. Like Anelka, he now makes enough to employ his brothers, buy houses for his parents, and drive Jaguars, Mercs and Porsches.

On New Year's Day things went awry. Debbouze was returning after midnight from a millennium concert of Rai music for Paris's North African community, at which he had been guest of honour. Police tension around the gig was high - 2,000 young people had tried to get in without tickets.

Versions of what happened next tend to differ. For the Debbouze camp - notably his brother Karim, press agent Nadia Mourine and her sister - a traffic policeman ordered the comedian to drive on through a red light, and then dragged him out of the car when Debbouze replied: 'You should ask a little more politely.'

Mourine said: 'The cop opened the door and dragged Jamel out. He slammed him against the car three times. Then there was a crowd of traffic cops around him. One hit him on the neck with a walkie-talkie and another in the stomach with a truncheon. Jamel fainted.' Photographs taken of the incident by Debbouze's entourage made the front pages on Monday. The anti-racism group SOS-Racisme instantly declared the alleged attack a 'revolting act that reveals the shameful practices of public servants who believe themselves above the law'. The group said the police 'had it in for an Arab who has managed to succeed'.

But this account does not tally with that of the police, who allege that Debbouze ignored instructions not to interfere with a police convoy escorting millennium-night Ferris wheels and stands out of the city.

He was reportedly driving dangerously. Halted at a red light, he was asked for his papers and refused to hand them over. 'Don't push it too far, I'm on the 1 o'clock news tomorrow with the Interior Minister and I can get you fired,' he is alleged to have told one officer.

Another swears Debbouze never lost consciousness, but was instructed to stay on the ground by his press agent while she took the apparently incriminating photos. Another denies blows were struck and insists no one did more than push Debbouze, who was 'over-excited, shouting and gesticulating and threatening in all directions'.

Police have suggested that the German-registered Mercedes Debbouze was driving was not legal in France, that his driving licence was void, as he had failed to undergo the regular health tests needed because of his handicap, and that a student had complained of being assaulted by Debbouze the previous night in an apparent case of road rage.

The inquiry will have to choose between two familiar phenomena: a notoriously heavy-handed police force frequently accused of racism and convicted last year of torture by the European Court of Human Rights, and a tendency among some black and Arab celebrities to insult the police at every opportunity.

Whichever way the verdict goes this time, with regard to Debbouze, a comedian of elegant wit and fine inteligence, it will have a big impact on race relations in France.

fields.headline: Dalai Lama succession in doubt
fields.trailText: The unexpected arrival over the Himalayas of one of Tibet's most revered spiritual leaders may be the first signs of a power struggle over who succeeds the Dalai Lama.
fields.body:
The unexpected arrival over the Himalayas of one of Tibet's most revered spiritual leaders may be the first signs of a power struggle over who succeeds the Dalai Lama. The seventeenth Karmapa, aged 14, arrived last week in Dharamasala, seat of the Tibetan government in exile, after a gruelling seven-day journey in mid-winter. The boy then had a 30-minute meeting with the exiled Tibetan leader.

The Karmapa, head of the Kagyu or 'black hat' sect of Tibetan Buddhism, is revered as a living Buddha by many Tibetans and considered second only to the Dalai Lama.

For centuries it has been the Dalai Lama's sect, the Gelugpa or 'yellow hats', who have ruled Tibet. And traditionally when a Dalai Lama dies, it is then his appointed successor, the Panchen Lama - chosen from the yellow hats - who takes over.

But the Panchen Lama is at the centre of a bitter dispute with the Chinese. Since 1995, Gedhun Choekyi, the 10-year-old boy nominated as Panchen by the Dalai Lama, has been kept under arrest by the Chinese, who then installed another 10-year-old boy, Gyaltsen Norbu, as their puppet Panchen. Tibetans see the second boy as a fake.

The Karmapa's dramatic defection is, therefore, the most important of its kind since the Dalai Lama himself left in 1959 following the Chinese invasion and is extremely significant for the future of Tibet. In terms of age and experience the Karmapa will be more senior than the Panchen Lama, giving him a strong position to claim leadership of Tibet.

This places the Dalai Lama in an awkward position, although it would mean that there was an agreed figurehead for the next generation of Tibetans. The Kagyu sect is now the most flourishing school in the West, with hundreds of Buddhist centres worldwide, thousands of followers and heavily endowed by Taiwanese supporters. His predecessor, the sixteenth Karmapa, helped establish monasteries from Woodstock to the Scottish highlands.

The seventeenth Karmapa is also unique because he is the only lama recognized by both China and the Dalai Lama. Losing such an important spiritual leader is a severe embarrassment for the Chinese government, which was grooming him to become a patriotic leader who could legitimise their hard-line control of Tibet. His escape makes a lie of Chinese claims that Tibetans enjoy full rights and religious freedom.

Last year the Karmapa met the Chinese Prime Minister, Jiang Zemin, spoke fluent Mandarin and was described by the Beijing government as the key to the 'development and stability of Tibet'. Now Beijing can only rely on their young Panchen Lama, seen by most Tibetans as a puppet.

Significantly, however, the Chinese official news agency, Xinhua, has not condemned the Karmapa's sudden departure - implying the door is still open should he wish to return. Xinhua cited a letter written by the boy, saying he did not mean to betray 'the state, the nation, the monastery or the leadership' by leaving. His reason, according to the letter, was to retrieve various sacred objects, including the venerated black hats, from Rumtek monastery in the north Indian state of Sikkim.

In Sikkim yesterday, monks from Rumtek monastery, the exile seat of the sixteenth Karmapa, were celebrating their leader's return. For the Karmapa to step fully into his power as an eminent spiritual leader it is absolutely vital he retrieves these religious artefacts used by previous 'incarnations'. When his predecessor, the sixteenth Karmapa, fled Tibet in the Fifties, he took the 'Vajra Crown' or 'black hat'.

The origins of the crown are ancient and according to a prediction in the eighth century by the Indian teacher, Padmasambhava, who brought Buddhism to Tibet, the person who wears this crown is said to guide 'limitless beings to enlightenment'.

The Karmapa is said to know where, when and into whom he will be reborn and has done so since his first incarnation in the twelfth century. Another of the Karmapa's roles is to make small black pills called ril nak, said to have miraculous properties, multiplying overnight and giving remission during cases of terminal illness. The ingredients for these pills are also in Rumtek monastery in Sikkim.

The Karmapa began his clandestine escape from Tibet with four monks on 28 December. Details of their dramatic journey are still hazy, but the Karmapa is thought to have escaped while on a religious retreat, avoiding Chinese guards and covering the 900-mile journey on foot and on mule.

His decision to flee reflects hardening of religious policies in Tibet since Patriotic Re-education campaigns began four years ago. He had been kept under increasingly tight guard, nominally for his own security after an alleged assassination attempt on his life last year, in his ancient monastery, Tsurphu, 50 miles from the Tibetan capital, Lhasa. It is unlikely the Karmapa left because of direct persecution, as the Dalai Lama did 40 years ago.

The Karmapa's unannounced arrival places the Dalai Lama in an awkward position as he usually encourages all Tibetans who flee to exile to return to Tibet.

'If bridges are not burnt between the Dalai Lama and Beijing, the Karmapa may decide to go back,' says Richard Oppenheimer from Tibet Information Network in London.

'China will use all pressure possible on the Indian government to force him to return.' The Indians have traditionally been lenient on Tibetan refugees but granting exile to such an important figure could place them at loggerheads with China.

Born Urgyen Trinley Dorje, into a nomad family in Eastern Tibet in 1985, amid many auspicious signs, the Karmapa was nicknamed 'Apo Gaga' meaning 'happy, happy brother.' He was described as a gifted and clairvoyant child who was taken into a local monastery for special education. Traditionally a new incarnation of the Karmapa is found through signs in a written form, usually a letter left by his predecessor. In 1981 the sixteenth Karmapa concealed a letter in an amulet that he gave to his teacher, Tai Situpa Rinpoche, giving coded details of his reincarnation's birthplace.

In 1991 a party of high lamas set to find the boy and a year later he was recognised by the Dalai Lama and Beijing. The Chinese traditionally revere the Karmapas who were gurus to the Emperors of China. A year later, he was enthroned in a grand ceremony attended by 20,000 pilgrims and apparent miracles, including three suns in the sky surrounded by rainbows.

webTitle: Torture - but it won't cost an arm and a leg

fields.headline: Torture - but it won't cost an arm and a leg
fields.trailText: Money can't buy you love - and it can't buy you fitness, either.
fields.body:
Money can't buy you love - and it can't buy you fitness, either. So why is it that at this time of year so many people manage to convince themselves that spending £500 or more to join a fitness club will get them in shape?

Carole Seheult, a sports psychologist at Durham University, puts it down to a sort of puritan work-ethic approach: 'People think that getting fit is a chore requiring some kind of sacrifice - paying for it adds to the feeling that they are taking their punishment.'

'There's also a sense that if you've paid £600 or whatever, you must be healthier,' says Di Swanston of the Health Education Authority. But does this sort of skewed logic help you to stick to a new fitness regime?

Not according to Kathryn Leigh, fitness editor of Health and Fitness magazine. She says: 'Even the clubs know that most people won't stick it out much beyond February.' This may account for the large joining fees that most clubs charge (see below).

'But getting fit doesn't need to cost you anything at all,' says Swanston. 'The biggest mistake people make is assuming that physical activity has to be vigorous to be beneficial.'

Research shows that moderate exercise - an activity, such as brisk walking, that leaves you 'feeling warm and breathing more heavily than usual' - is just as good, provided you do it three to four times every week.

Of course, fitness clubs have their place, but if you've never set foot in one before, Leigh recommends trying out your local council-run leisure centre before committing yourself to a year-long membership of a private club. 'Local authorities are a bit more on the ball these days,' she says. Many offer the same kind of facilities as private clubs, including such extras as saunas, spa baths and steam rooms.

Going to a local authority-run club isn't free, but because you pay as you go it can work out a lot cheaper.

This is a particularly important consideration when you are just embarking on a fitness regime and haven't yet built up to the recommended level of exercising three to four times a week. For example, if you swim once a week for a year, going to a public pool might cost a total of £100. This is about £400 less than the yearly cost of the cheapest private club.

Even if you manage three swims a week, the public pool option will still save you about £150. But once you're going that often, you can save even more by buying a season ticket for the public pool.

Aerobics classes are a different matter, and whether you will get a better deal by paying as you go depends largely on where you live. Londoners doing three classes a week at a central leisure centre could spend nearly £600 a year, which is slightly more than the cost of joining a private club. Residents of Leeds doing the same number of classes would spend about £400 to work out at a local authority-run exercise studio. Compared with the cheapest private club (which means no pool) the pay-as-you-go option is still a better deal.

Wherever you live, if you go to the gym only once a week, you'll be better off by paying as you go. Once you become a model three-times-a-week gym-goer, the cost per session at a private club is again cheaper for Londoners, but not for people who live in Leeds.

On top of the cost of the facilities for your chosen exercise there is the kit to consider. If you want to look the part when swim ming, expect to pay about £40 in total for a Speedo Endurance Piped Splashback swimsuit (which Speedo claims lasts 20 times longer than ordinary swimwear, and is quick drying and chlorine-resistant), an Adidas swimming cap (with zip-up storage case) and Adidas Missionary Z goggles (with anti-fog lenses and Neoprene eye cups).

Don't expect to get much change out of £100 if you plan to go to the gym or do aerobics, because proper trainers are essential. What you wear with them is entirely up to you (thong leotards are not mandatory), but if you are not content to turn up in your old track suit bottoms and a scruffy T-shirt, another £100 or so will see you kitted out in style.

So why is it that at this time of year so many people manage to convince themselves that spending £500 or more to join a fitness club will get them in shape? Carole Seheult, a sports psychologist at Durham University, puts it down to a sort of puritan work-ethic approach: 'People think that getting fit is a chore requiring some kind of sacrifice - paying for it adds to the feeling that they are taking their punishment.' 'There's also a sense that if you've paid £600 or whatever, you must be healthier,' says Di Swanston of the Health Education Authority. But does this sort of skewed logic help you to stick to a new fitness regime? Not according to Kathryn Leigh, fitness editor of Health and Fitness magazine. webTitle: Don't pile on the pounds as you work off that weight

fields.headline: Don't pile on the pounds as you work off that weight
fields.standfirst: What to look for and how to keep at it
fields.trailText: One of the main reasons why paying to exercise privately can be more costly than using your local leisure centre is the joining fees most charge.
fields.body:
One of the main reasons why paying to exercise privately can be more costly than using your local leisure centre is the joining fees most charge. If you drop out, you won't get this fee back - although you could try negotiating a refund if injury rather than indolence has stopped you from going. The exception is Virgin Active, which doesn't charge an upfront fee.

Then there's the membership fee. Very swanky clubs may expect you to pay a year's membership in advance, but a monthly membership fee is more common. Paying monthly may help to spread the cost, but if the club imposes a minimum membership of a year - as LA Fitness does - giving up part-way through will be costly, because you have to carry on paying until your membership expires. All the other clubs we looked at said they had a minimum membership of one month.

What you get
This also varies. The fee usually covers use of the gym, the pool (if there is one) and 'relaxation' facilities, but you may have to pay extra for classes.

At Cannons, for example, yoga, aerobics and step classes are included in the fee, but specialist classes such as t'ai chi cost more.

Other extras at most clubs include the services of a personal trainer (though not necessarily the cost of an initial fitness assessment and specially designed exercise programme), sunbeds and other 'beauty' treatments.

What to look for
 Try before you buy. Many clubs offer a free day's trial.

 Take out a joint or off-peak membership. This can often halve both the joining and the membership fee.

 Wait for a new club to open in your area. For example, Fitness First (which, in January, is opening around nine new clubs up and down the country) waives its £100 joining fee if you sign up in the first month. LA Fitness and Virgin Active offer special rates to people who sign up before a new club opens.

 Agree to pay annually rather than monthly. Living Well clubs offer 12 months' membership for the price of 11 if you pay as a lump sum.

 Avoid clubs with swimming pools if you don't like swimming. Access to a pool pushes up the cost.

 Look out for special promotions. You're most likely to see discounts at times when clubs are quiet - usually in the summer and before Christmas. But some clubs may offer discounts on joining fees to take advantage of the interest caused by New Year resolutions.

 Go more than three times a week. With even the most expensive clubs, this will bring the price per session down to about what you would pay at a leisure centre. To work this out for yourself multiply the number of times a week you realistically expect to go by 45 (which allows seven weeks for sickness and holidays) then divide that by the total fees.

How to keep at it: top tips
You're not going to get your money's worth - or get fit - if you give up after a month or two. So how do you make sure that you stay the course? This is what the experts say:

 Find an activity you enjoy.

 If you stop enjoying it, find something else.

 Set yourself achievable, specific and measurable goals - 'getting fit' is too nebulous.

 Don't expect overnight results - it takes between four and six weeks before you start to feel a difference.

 Keep a written record of your progress and make it as visual as possible.

 Be sure to do it for health, not cosmetic, reasons. It's better motivation.

 Arrange to go with someone else - you'll feel guilty if you let them down.

 Ask for an individually designed fitness programme if you go to a gym - and have it changed if it becomes too easy.

 Choose a class rather than the gym. Having a fixed 'appointment' can make it less easy to skip.

 Hire a personal trainer. This costs from £15 to £20 an hour, or at least £50 an hour for one who comes to your home.

 Become a fitness instructor yourself. A 90-hour course spread over three weekends costs around £600 for the basic 'exercise to music' qualification.

webTitle: These are matters of life and debt...

fields.headline: These are matters of life and debt...
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott  on US guru Alvin Hall's television spending tips
fields.trailText: Maria Scott on US guru Alvin Hall's television spending tips
fields.body:
The party's over. It's time to reckon up. If the new year has brought resolve to tackle unruly finances, you may draw inspiration from the new series of Your Money or Your Life, BBC2's money makeover programme, starting on Wednesday.

This is a second run for the series, presented by American financial guru Alvin Hall, built around real-life case studies. The new series coincides with the publication of a book by Hall, Money For Life .

He made his name training stockbrokers on Wall Street, but you will not hear much about stocks and bonds. Many of the people who submit themselves to Hall's makeovers are foraging rather lower on the financial food chain. A common theme is overspending and overborrowing.

There are the Fung sisters, bankrolled by an indulgent father, whose love of shopping and partying has led to £30,000 of debt between them. A Devon couple, Jo and Jason Dutfield, have it all: detached house, two cars their own business - and £50,000 of debt. Sherry Morris-Davies from Hereford has a car boot sale habit that has helped her clock up debt of more than £30,000.

The case studies are extreme, but they make watchable telly. And many viewers will see a little of themselves in Hall's victims. In an age where cash is accessible 24 hours a day, credit is on tap and shops are the new cathedrals, Hall argues that deep self-scrutiny may be necessary if you want to get your finances under control.

A common theme among his case study subjects was a belief that they deserved to spend money. 'A lot of people have a sense of entitlement. Because they are middle class, living in this or that community, or are young, they deserve to spend. I don't know where this sense of deserving comes from. Perhaps we have bought into the media dream.'

Hall believes that we are all bored and need to look for new ways to get pleasure. There is nothing wrong with treating yourself, he says, but keep it in perspective.

If all this sounds stern, the tone of Hall's shows is anything but. He has a touchy-feely style, a ready giggle and a one- or two-line answer for everything. He admits that watching other people deal with money has persuaded him to re-evaluate his own life: 'I can see my own demons.'

One of his demons is art, and in the spring he will be selling off a chunk of his collection, because he has decided he does not need all the pieces. 'It's time to simplify,' he says.

The same is true of any financial plan, he says. And though Hall is not a conventional financial guru it is hard to argue with the suggestions he makes for getting chaotic finances under control:

 Start by drawing up a budget. If the kitty is empty when friends ask you out, say you're busy, Hall advises.

 Limit the number of times you go to the cash machine, and do not use an overdraft.

 Get rid of superfluous credit cards. Pare them down to two or three, and use them less frequently.

 If you are in debt, pay off the high-interest borrowing first.

 Work on that sense of entitlement. 'Just because you have achieved something in life doesn't mean you have deserved it.'

 Shop less. 'Almost everyone out there spends an incredible amount of time shopping. It's sometimes better to sit back and decide what you want and make getting it an achievement.'

Accumulating money that you then give to charity would be an achievement. Hall cites the example of a washerwoman in the US who recently endowed a university with the fruits of her life saving: $150,000.

Does his regime work? Out of the six case studies in the series, four changed their habits, says Hall, one modified them and the Fung sisters ignored most of what they were told.

 'Your Money or Your Life', Wednesday, 8pm, BBC2. Hall's 'Money For Life' (Hodder & Stoughton, £9.99).

fields.headline: Physically active, fiscally attractive
fields.standfirst: It isn't necessary to get yourself down to the local leisure centre to get fit. There are ways to shape up for free.
fields.trailText: It isn't necessary to get yourself down to the local leisure centre to get fit. There are ways to shape up for free.
fields.body:
Change your job
If your current employer is not enlightened enough to offer an in-house fitness facility - or at least free or subsidised membership of a local gym - why not change to one that does? Pros: Provided the facility is open to all employees, it should cost you nothing. Even if you have to pay tax on this workplace perk, it's still cheaper than a gym membership.
Cons: Do you really want your new boss to know how unfit you are?

Buy a dog
If you have a problem with self-motivation, a canine personal trainer could be just the thing you're looking for. Pros: You'll have to go walkies whatever the weather.
Cons: You'll have to go walkies whatever the weather.

Go running
If you don't count the cost of a pair of proper running shoes (which you must have to reduce the risk of injury), running is free, environment-friendly and you don't need any other special kit.
Pros: If you don't feel like going, you can blame the weather.
Cons: Small children pointing and giggling.

Sack the cleaner:
Just think of all that bending, stretching and lifting - not to mention the running up and down stairs because you forgot the Mr Muscle.
Pros: Your home will be spotless. And even if you get bored of housework-as-workout after a few months, you'll probably have saved up enough to pay a gym's joining fee.
Cons: Having to have a shower after you've cleaned the bathroom.

Take control of your finances
Like regular aerobic exercise, good financial habits reduce stress and can delay the ageing process, says Dr Michael Roizen, author of Real Age: Are you as young as you can be?
Pros: There's no need to work up a sweat.
Cons: It won't do much for your muscle tone.

Walk more
You've heard it all before, but here's a quick reminder: leave the car at home; get off the bus/train/tube one stop early; use the stairs rather than the lift; and walk up escalators instead of standing on them.
Pros: No special skills required.
Cons: If you walk briskly enough for it to do you any good, you'll be sweaty when you get to your destination.

Take a dip
After all, it doesn't cost anything to go for a swim in the sea or a lake. And if those brave souls who go swimming on Christmas Day can do it, why not you?
Pros: Very invigorating and it doesn't matter if it's raining.
Cons: Do we need to tell you?

webTitle: On the superhighway to a deal

fields.headline: On the superhighway to a deal
fields.standfirst: Sarah Cunningham on wheeling and dealing for cars on the Internet
fields.trailText: Sarah Cunningham on wheeling and dealing for cars on the Internet
fields.body:
When the time comes to buy your next car - new or secondhand - you will do yourself a big favour if, rather than rushing out to a showroom, you stay indoors and spend a little time on the Internet.

Whether you want a discount on a brand-new vehicle - sourced in the UK or abroad - or free access to thousands of small ads for used vehicles, there are websites galore.

Although, like everything to do with e-commerce, these are early days, the growing importance of the Internet in bringing price competition into car buying can already be seen in the decision by Mitsubishi, announced at the end of last year, to lower its list prices. The pressure on other manufacturers is set to increase. The Competition Commission is shortly due to report to the Department of Trade and Industry on its inquiry into new car pricing.

The Consumers' Association, which has spearheaded the campaign to bring new car prices down in the UK, believes the Internet is of central importance. 'People are fed up, and looking at other ways to buy. The Internet will play a significant role in how to buy a car in the future,' the association's Jenny Driscoll says.

Fletcher Research predicts that one in five new cars will be bought with the aid of the Internet by 2003. 'Aid' is a key word here: people generally use the Internet as a way of finding the lowest price, rather than to carry out a full transaction, and most sites are designed to direct customers to dealers' showrooms.

Autobytel UK, an arm of the US operation, has had 10,000 purchase requests in the UK since setting up here last April. But that is from 65 million hits on its site. Although a lot more people are looking rather than buying, the business is confident that in time it will convert more of those hits into deals. It offers a free service for customers, allowing them to place a request online for new, used and business cars. This request is passed on to the nearest Autobytel-accredited dealer, who then contacts the prospective buyer.

There are some similar home-grown services, such as New Cars Direct or CarDeal. Both look throughout the UK for the best price for the make and model you require, the latter charging a £10 fee. CarDeal says that it will refund your fee if it is unable to find your car or if it is unable to beat a quote you obtain yourself.

New Cars Direct says it achieves its discounts by ordering in bulk - including orders for fleet buyers, traditional recipients of the best car deals in this country.

The website of the magazine Auto Trader has details of more than 180,000 used vehicles, and offers a new car service and advice on financing and other issues.

Should you want to do the whole shebang - from choosing the colour to arranging delivery - online, OneSwoop, due to be launched later this month, will find cheaper cars overseas, do all the importing paper work, and deliver your chosen vehicle to your door. Backed by Atlas Venture, a venture capital firm, and offering finance through Marks & Spencer Financial Services, OneSwoop aims to offer the most seamless value-for-money car-buying service on the Internet.

In the meantime, it is worth looking at the highly informative website of Broadspeed. It pioneered the idea of buying cars from a country - such as Ireland or the Netherlands - where manufacturers charge lower prices to compensate for high local taxes. These taxes do not need to be paid if you are exporting the vehicle, so you get a bargain. All you have to pay is British VAT at 17.5 per cent when the car arrives in this country.

There are difficulties to overcome, however: for example, specifications and names vary from market to market, and you may have to wait weeks, or even months, for delivery if you are ordering a right-hand drive model in a left-hand drive country.

The deals are nonetheless tempting. A Jaguar S-Type 4.0 can cost as little as £26,270 plus VAT on the Continent, compared with £32,000 plus VAT in the UK. An Audi A3 1.6 is available for £8,321 plus VAT elsewhere in Europe and £12,962 plus VAT here. A new Nissan Micra 1.0 can be had for as little as £3,682 plus VAT on the Continent compared with £7,144 plus VAT over here. However, with overseas prices you may need to add between 5 and 10 per cent to cover the cost of ordering a right-hand drive vehicle.

Traditionally, dealers in the cheaper countries have not been encouraged by manufacturers to sell to foreigners, but European Union law is in the consumer's favour and Broadspeed will help point you in the direction of the friendlier dealers. It sells guides on how to buy a car from overseas through its website. The Consumers' Association produces a free guide, available from its website.

Broadspeed also runs 'car cruise' ferry trips to Continental dealerships for those determined to cut out the middle men. Details are available on its website. Whether OneSwoop, which will remove this legwork, can manage prices as low as those at Broadspeed remains to be seen.

If you are not so worried about having a brand new car but want a fancy marque, you can try Premium Cars. This Channel Islands-based business specialises in offering low-mileage secondhand Mercedes, Jaguars, Porsches and Ferraris for import into the UK.

Another useful stop for those buying secondhand is NetCar, a free advertising billboard for anyone wishing to buy or sell a used vehicle.

Buying a car will never become a totally sedentary experience. Research shows that most people are put off buying on the Internet because they want a test-drive. Getting round that problem may not, eventually, prove insuperable to the computer and marketing bods.

In the meantime the Internet has already proved itself as a way of avoiding overpaying for cars. Better still, it makes it possible to avoid those often dreaded face-to-face encounters with car salesmen.

It offers a free service for customers, allowing them to place a request online for new, used and business cars. This request is passed on to the nearest Autobytel-accredited dealer, who then contacts the prospective buyer. There are some similar home-grown services, such as New Cars Direct or CarDeal. Both look throughout the UK for the best price for the make and model you require, the latter charging a £10 fee. CarDeal says that it will refund your fee if it is unable to find your car or if it is unable to beat a quote you obtain yourself. New Cars Direct says it achieves its discounts by ordering in bulk - including orders for fleet buyers, traditional recipients of the best car deals in this country. The website of the magazine Auto Trader has details of more than 180,000 used vehicles, and offers a new car service and advice on financing and other issues. Should you want to do the whole shebang - from choosing the colour to arranging delivery - online, OneSwoop, due to be launched later this month, will find cheaper cars overseas, do all the importing paper work, and deliver your chosen vehicle to your door. Backed by Atlas Venture, a venture capital firm, and offering finance through Marks & Spencer Financial Services, OneSwoop aims to offer the most seamless value-for-money car-buying service on the Internet. In the meantime, it is worth looking at the highly informative website of Broadspeed. It pioneered the idea of buying cars from a country - such as Ireland or the Netherlands - where manufacturers charge lower prices to compensate for high local taxes. These taxes do not need to be paid if you are exporting the vehicle, so you get a bargain. All you have to pay is British VAT at 17.5 per cent when the car arrives in this country. There are difficulties to overcome, however: for example, specifications and names vary from market to market, and you may have to wait weeks, or even months, for delivery if you are ordering a right-hand drive model in a left-hand drive country. The deals are nonetheless tempting. A Jaguar S-Type 4.0 can cost as little as £26,270 plus VAT on the Continent, compared with £32,000 plus VAT in the UK. An Audi A3 1.6 is available for £8,321 plus VAT elsewhere in Europe and £12,962 plus VAT here. A new Nissan Micra 1.0 can be had for as little as £3,682 plus VAT on the Continent compared with £7,144 plus VAT over here. However, with overseas prices you may need to add between 5 and 10 per cent to cover the cost of ordering a right-hand drive vehicle. Traditionally, dealers in the cheaper countries have not been encouraged by manufacturers to sell to foreigners, but European Union law is in the consumer's favour and Broadspeed will help point you in the direction of the friendlier dealers. It sells guides on how to buy a car from overseas through its website. The Consumers' Association produces a free guide, available from its website. Broadspeed also runs 'car cruise' ferry trips to Continental dealerships for those determined to cut out the middle men. Details are available on its website. Whether OneSwoop, which will remove this legwork, can manage prices as low as those at Broadspeed remains to be seen. If you are not so worried about having a brand new car but want a fancy marque, you can try Premium Cars. This Channel Islands-based business specialises in offering low-mileage secondhand Mercedes, Jaguars, Porsches and Ferraris for import into the UK. Another useful stop for those buying secondhand is NetCar, a free advertising billboard for anyone wishing to buy or sell a used vehicle. Buying a car will never become a totally sedentary experience. Research shows that most people are put off buying on the Internet because they want a test-drive. Getting round that problem may not, eventually, prove insuperable to the computer and marketing bods. In the meantime the Internet has already proved itself as a way of avoiding overpaying for cars. Better still, it makes it possible to avoid those often dreaded face-to-face encounters with car salesmen.

webTitle: A first-class degree in juggling loans

fields.headline: A first-class degree in juggling loans
fields.standfirst: Years after she left college, this graduate is still paying the price of being a student.  Margaret Dibben reports
fields.trailText: Years after she left college, this graduate is still paying the price of being a student. Margaret Dibben reports
fields.body:
Paula Blezard is worried about her debts. Though she does not live an extravagant lifestyle, she graduated in summer 1997 owing thousands of pounds in student loans, and has had to continue borrowing to make ends meet. She was earning money while she was studying but still the debts mounted.

She explains: 'As a working-class student, I had part-time jobs during term-time and full-time work during the vacations but I still managed to clock up debts of £4,500. By the time I started university, grants had been frozen for 10 years and then they were reduced by a further 10 per cent for three consecutive years.'

When she finished university she took out her first graduate loan - for £1,000. This, she says, was to cover travel expenses and clothing for work. She now has a job in an academic library, where she earns £14,345 a year. She pays rent of £250 a month and other bills amount to around £80. But, although she has a full-time job, she has had to take out more loans.

She says: 'Unfortunately, due to my paltry salary, this borrowing situation has continued for two-and-a-half years.'

At the moment, she has student loans outstanding of £4,400, although her income is low enough to delay repayments. She has a £3,600 bank loan from HSBC, which she is repaying at a fixed interest rate of 14.9 per cent until January 2004. She has her current account with HSBC and also owes the bank £1,000 through an overdraft.

Paula has asked us for advice on managing these debts and how she can stop them continuing to build up, as her income is likely to remain low.

webTitle: A valuable roof over your head

fields.headline: A valuable roof over your head
fields.standfirst: Experts say house prices will carry on rising this year, says  Jill Insley, but bricks and mortar will still be a good bet
fields.trailText: Experts say house prices will carry on rising this year, says Jill Insley, but bricks and mortar will still be a good bet
fields.body:
Your home could well be your best investment this year: house prices are expected to rise by almost as much as last year.

Property values increased by an average of 13.6 per cent in 1999, according to the Halifax, and by as much as 25 per cent in parts of London and the South East. Rising interest rates and the final abolition of Miras (mortgage interest relief at source) are expected to slow increases this year, preventing a runaway housing boom.

But despite these negative influences, economists and estate agencies are predicting strong rises. Barry Naisbitt, chief economist at Abbey National, says: 'High employment and good prospects for income growth will continue to underpin households' financial positions and affordability in the housing market. So a fur ther increase in transactions of 6 per cent is expected, with house price increases averaging 10 per cent.'

David Parry of Nationwide is even more bullish, expecting prices to rise by an average of 11 per cent. The good news for prospective buyers is that property will remain good value, despite increases. Parry says: 'An average house is currently worth around three times annual average earnings, which is considerably below the peak of five times in 1989. And although standard variable mortgage rates are likely to rise next year, they will remain far below the 14.5 per cent reached in 1989.

'This means that even with the demise of Miras, the proportion of post-tax income necessary to cover a first time buyer's mortgage repayments will remain around 15 per cent, compared with more than 22 per cent in the late Eighties.'

Demand in the first six months of this year could be fuelled by a 'new millennium, new home' mindset, according to David Woodcock of Bradford & Bingley Estate Agents. However, he expects the market to 'pause for breath' in the second half of the year, resulting in a national average increase of about 7 per cent for the whole year.

In London, house price growth is expected to slow markedly. Gary Styles of the Halifax says there will be a more even pattern across the country with prices rising more rapidly in regions dependent on manufacturing as that sector recovers from its recent recession.

But he adds: 'Prices are still expected to increase most quickly in the South as the economy there remains buoyant. So the North-South divide is set to widen further during 2000.'

Ian Davies of Bradford & Bingley's southern regional office says there has also been a resurgence of people buying second homes - for investment purposes or as holiday properties. 'This trend is particularly noticeable in the West Country, and we believe the best is yet to come.'

The shortage of properties has led to knock-on demand in towns within 100 miles of London. Prices in Norfolk and the Midlands rose by about 10 per cent, while the average rise in Oxford, Cambridge, Hertfordshire, Buckinghamshire and Essex was 20 per cent. Alan Gottschalk, also of Bradford & Bingley, predicts that if a shortage of quality properties and the positive economic environment continue, prices will go up by another 10-15 per cent.

Prices for homes in the country also escalated dramatically last year - by up to 20 per cent in the South East during the first half of 1999, according to estate agent Knight Frank, where Edward Rook says: 'There is a strong correlation between country house prices and the stock market. As we have seen less volatility with the stock markets, confidence has grown in the housing market.'

He does not think rises in the South East during the Year 2000 will exceed 10 per cent, but adds: 'Buyers are looking for space, setting and views, and, to get these, they are prepared to travel further. Their priority is to find a gem of a house that has it all in terms of privacy and quiet, and those properties that fulfill the criteria will continue to achieve enormous premiums.'

This year should also be a good one for landlords. Rental yields - the amount of rent a landlord earns as a proportion of the property's value - actually fell in 1999 by between 1 and 2 per cent. But demand is expected to exceed supply this year, and a slowdown in the housing market after July is expected to benefit the lettings market, nudging up rents.

webTitle: No hysteria, no disasters. Great news

fields.headline: No hysteria, no disasters. Great news
fields.trailText: So the bug didn't bite. After months of anxiety and a bill estimated at $400 billion worldwide, the millennium bug failed to play havoc with our lives or finances. Was all that money mis-spent, as was suggested last week?
fields.body:
So the bug didn't bite. After months of anxiety and a bill estimated at $400 billion worldwide, the millennium bug failed to play havoc with our lives or finances. Was all that money mis-spent, as was suggested last week?

When it comes to our finances, the answer must be almost certainly not. For once, regulators seem to act pre-emptively. As defenders of Y2K spending said, just because there wasn't a problem doesn't mean there wouldn't have been. Things could have been very different. In banking and investment, panic is as much the enemy of stability as instability itself. Mass withdrawals of money would have caused as much havoc as a real bug. But we were persuaded that everything would be all right on the night.

The story is not over. Over coming months, computers may make bug-related mistakes. The possibility of them being major ones must be diminished by the absence of panic and disaster so far.

The Financial Services Authority chose the week before Christmas to make its low-key response to concerns over mis-selling of endowments, confident the news would be buried - as it was. But the issue comes into focus afresh this week with the announcement of endowment bonuses. There will be more cuts, so more home owners could face shortfalls on their mortgages. The FSA is not recommending a review of all sales but homeowners should take matters into their own hands. If they believe they were not warned sufficiently of the risks they should approach the Personal Investment Authority Ombudsman.

webTitle: Which car? Let your mouse do the mileage

fields.headline: Which car? Let your mouse do the mileage
fields.trailText: The Consumers' Association is planning to launch an Internet car buying service on its existing website later this year.
fields.body:
The Consumers' Association is planning to launch an Internet car buying service on its existing website later this year.

It has already tested the scheme with some of its members, and has imported and sold close to 100 cars into this country - all at well below UK list prices.

Chris Peers, head of corporate strategy at the CA, said that he expects to sell 4,000 to 5,000 cars a year through the scheme once it is up and running. So far, the tests have shown savings of up to £5,000 on some BMW models, or about £1,500 on cheaper makes. Working with a network of UK and foreign dealers, the scheme will deliver to the buyer's door the exact make of car ordered through www. which.net, with full UK specifications, taxed and registered in this country.

'We won't be selling Vauxhall cars,' Peers said, 'because on the Continent they are called Opel. What we will be selling is exactly what consumers can buy in this country, but at lower prices.'

The scheme is part of the CA's campaign to make manufacturers' reduce their prices in this country to bring them in line with the Continent. The cars are to be sourced from Germany, Holland, Belgium, Scandinavia and Ireland.

Peers will be keeping a close eye on prices offered by OneSwoop and similar operations to ensure the CA service is competitive.

fields.headline: Briefcase
fields.trailText:
BUY...

Domino's Pizza company, which last week made a great leap forward in promoting employee rights. Domino's dropped a long-standing ban on bearded employees after a 12-year Maryland lawsuit in which the company was accused of discriminating against a Sikh employee, whose religion forbids shaving.
fields.body:
BUY...

Domino's Pizza company, which last week made a great leap forward in promoting employee rights. Domino's dropped a long-standing ban on bearded employees after a 12-year Maryland lawsuit in which the company was accused of discriminating against a Sikh employee, whose religion forbids shaving.

A change of heart? No such thing. The second-largest pizza chain in the US said it dropped the ban because of a change in fashion. 'Look around you,' a spokesman said. 'There are TV stars and athletes sporting goatees. That seems to be the most popular statement of individuality out there in the last five years.' The Michigan-based company admitted that outlawing facial hair had made it harder to attract new employees so it had to give in.

The move vindicates Prabhjot S Kohli, who waged a 12-year legal battle against Domino's after it refused to hire him as a trainee manager unless he shaved. Domino's argued that sales would suffer if it relaxed its no-beards policy and that beards on food handlers could spread illness. However, Pizza Hut, America's number one pizza chain, has long permitted its employees to wear beards.

SELL...

It's been an ugly Christmas for the company that should make more out of Santa Claus than any other business. US retail giant Toys 'R' Us last week announced disappointing trading figures for the nine weeks up to 2 January.

The chain, which has been buffeted by online toy retailers such as eToys over the past 12 months, revealed that like-for-like sales in its US stores over the period were down 2 per cent on the same time the previous year. Chief executive Michael Goldstein blamed the slump on falling prices in the video market and a shortage of electronic products to sell.

Toys 'R' Us said its total sales for the holiday period were unchanged at $4.4 billion (£2.7bn).

For Goldstein's sake, here's hoping Christmas comes really early this year.

Like March.

Watch out for:

Pace Micro Technology, which makes the little black boxes that enable us to watch digital television, reports half-year results tomorrow. House broker ABN Amro is predicting interim pre-tax profits of £10 million, against £8.3m for the same period the previous year.

Pace is expected to unveil new products, including a new type of decoder that also acts as a smart video recorder, taping programmes it thinks you will like, and a home shopping device.

Pace will also start talking up something called the home gateway system - its decoder will link with a whole raft of intelligent devices so that you can control them no matter where you are. The company wants its new generation of gadgets to allow you not only to watch TV but also to do everything from putting the washing on to watering your plants.

All very sci fi, but the City seems to like it. Pace's share price soared from around 100p last January to around 500p at the close of year. Phenomenal growth in anyone's book.

The challenge for Pace now will be to turn the theory into practice.

Outlook 2000

Sir Clive Thompson, CBI President

'One of the best things that will happen is that there will not be much for economic commentators to talk about. We have the

best economic outlook for 30 years, with the prospect of steady growth, low inflation and high employment.

Given the boom and bust cycles of the past, this is an unusually stable environment for British business, and this will help firms to plan their futures.

Unfortunately there is little sign of respite for our manufacturers, because sterling is likely to remain at a high value. Many exporters now accept that an overvalued sterling is a fact of life and perhaps not overvalued at all. They are learning to live with it.

The other major occurrence will be the continuing march of the dot.com revolution, which will have a huge impact on the way we do business. Internet companies are starting up at a rapid pace. Research suggests that Internet use is growing faster than any previous technological advance.

This means consumers will be able to compare prices more easily and buy goods directly from suppliers, making traditional methods of distribution unnecessary. This will create a more competitive environment, forcing companies to be more dynamic and innovative in order to achieve growth and retain margins.'
