fields.headline: Figures lift M&S gloom
fields.trailText: First signs that Marks & Spencer may have arrested its precipitate sales collapse are expected this week, when the company delivers a trading update covering the crucial Christmas period.
fields.body:
First signs that Marks & Spencer may have arrested its precipitate sales collapse are expected this week, when the company delivers a trading update covering the crucial Christmas period.

M&S's figures, due on Wednesday, are expected to show that clothing sales in the three months since October are below levels seen a year ago. But the fall is reckoned to be of substantially less than 10 per cent - not nearly as bad as some commentators had suggested. Sales of M&S foods are thought to have been 2 or 3 per cent ahead of a year earlier.

A week before Christmas, some reports suggested that M&S's pre-Christmas clothing sales had dropped by 15 per cent. They were wrong. The company struggled in November, with double-figure percentage sales declines in some weeks. But there was a modest recovery in December, according to insiders, with clothing sales less than 5 per cent down on 1998.

It is still likely that M&S will make no more than £500 million in pre-tax profits this year. Only two years ago, it made more than £1 billion.

The company is also close to naming a new chairman - the favourite for the job is Luc Vandevelde of French grocery group Promodès.

This week will see a raft of Christmas trading announcements. They are expected to reinforce what a Confederation of British Industry sur vey showed last week: the strongest growth in high street sales for three years.

Selfridges is thought to have seen exceptionally strong sales. And Dixons, parent of Currys, PC World and The Link, is likely to have cashed in on the boom in mobile phones and computers. Analysts are predicting that Dixons' interim results will show half-year profits approaching £85m, compared with £80.9m a year ago.

Whitbread is also due to deliver a trading statement this week. It is thought that the pubs and eating-out market picked up after a poor autumn. Its figures are 'fine, but not dramatic', said one source.

Selfridges is thought to have seen exceptionally strong sales. And Dixons, parent of Currys, PC World and The Link, is likely to have cashed in on the boom in mobile phones and computers. It is thought that the pubs and eating-out market picked up after a poor autumn. Its figures are 'fine, but not dramatic', said one source.

webTitle: TransTec duo kept silent on £11m claim

fields.headline: TransTec duo kept silent on £11m claim
fields.trailText: Two former executive directors of TransTec, the collapsed engineering firm founded by former Treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson, knew of a £11.2 million claim agreed with Ford but failed to disclose it to their board for more than two years
fields.body:
Two former executive directors of TransTec, the collapsed engineering firm founded by former Treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson, knew of a £11.2 million claim agreed with Ford but failed to disclose it to their board for more than two years, The Observer can reveal.

According to City and industry sources, the claim - a contractual penalty for late delivery of engine parts - was finalised with Ford Europe's headquarters in Cologne in the autumn of 1997.

The duo, high-flying chief executive Richard Carr and finance director Bill Jeffrey, resigned abruptly before Christmas after admitting knowledge of the penalty to the board and its advisers.

The revelation was the last straw for TransTec's bankers, led by HSBC, who called in receivers to the heavily indebted group 10 days ago.

'During all that time Carr and Jeffrey kept the Ford issue quiet. There were no discussions with the auditors, the audit committee, the board or the bankers,' one source close to TransTec said.

The firm's debts are now put at well over £70m, with other creditors due another £100m. The collapse has left Robinson's shares, which were once valued at £36m, all but worthless.

Robinson formed TransTec in 1991 after a deal with Robert Maxwell but resigned as chairman in May 1997 on being appointed Paymaster General. Despite intense speculation there is, say City and TransTec sources, no evidence that Robinson was informed of the Ford penalty. Last Friday, Ford also said Robinson was not involved in negotiations over the claim.

The Stock Exchange is now investigating the affair, but the Serious Fraud Office says it is not currently involved in investigating alleged accounting irregularities.

Embarrassingly, the Department of Trade and Industry is expected to launch an investigation once receiver Arthur Andersen completes a statutory review of directors' conduct.

The Ford claim arose from the late delivery of engine cylinders from TransTec's new Northern Ireland factory in 1996. According to industry and City sources, after lengthy negotiations Carr agreed in late 1997 to give Ford £11.2m of rebates, of which £7.5m was made in 1998 and another £3.7m is still due for 1999.

Under the deal, rebates were also booked to other TransTec subsidiaries. The subsequent accounting treatment also obscured the underlying source of the claim from the auditors, sources said.

Ford said on Friday it had no knowledge of how the issue of the claim was communicated internally within TransTec.

Carr and Jeffrey acknowledged the claim after TransTec's advisers identified the issue 10 days before Christmas following talks with Ford, The Observer has established. 'They admitted they hadn't discussed it fully with the auditors or the board,' one source said.

When confronted, they also said the accounting treatment reflected the commercial arrangement reached with Ford, another source said.

Last week The Observer was unable to contact Carr or Jeffrey for comment. Robinson also declined to respond. The receivers are seeking buyers for TransTec's motor, rubber and plastic, and precision control operations, which employ 4,500 people.

Ford is also in talks to save the Ulster factory. 'We are optimistic about selling the businesses as going concerns,' an Andersen spokesman said.

webTitle: US capital firm hires QXL founder heads Net start-up firm

fields.headline: US capital firm hires QXL founder heads Net start-up firm
fields.trailText: Tim Jackson, the 34-year-old journalist and millionaire who set up online auction business QXL, is to head a US venture capital firm's European operation.
fields.body:
Tim Jackson, the 34-year-old journalist and millionaire who set up online auction business QXL, is to head a US venture capital firm's European operation. His brief will be to seek out investment opportunities.

Jackson, who retains a 17.5 per cent stake in QXL worth some £240 million, has been appointed managing director of Carlyle Internet Partners Europe (CIPE). The fund, part of the Carlyle Group, a private equity investment firm formed 12 years ago, was launched last October and is believed to have an initial 500m euros (£314m) to spend on stakes in promising Internet firms.

Jackson, who is understood already to have invested $10m of Carlyle's money in an as yet unidentified target, was approached by the venture capital firm last summer.

Having set up QXL, Jackson argues that he is well-placed to help any Internet companies CIPE might invest in. 'I spent two years running an Internet business,' he says. 'I think I have a pretty good idea of what entrepreneurs are looking for.'

fields.headline: Vodafone 'must bid billions in cash'
fields.trailText: The gloves came off in the biggest hostile takeover in corporate history last night as Mannesmann's supporters claimed Vodafone AirTouch would have to pay billions of pounds in cash to acquire the German company.
fields.body:
The gloves came off in the biggest hostile takeover in corporate history last night as Mannesmann's supporters claimed Vodafone AirTouch would have to pay billions of pounds in cash to acquire the German company.

Sources close to Vodafone, which has ruled out offering a cash component, immediately attacked the claims, made as Mannesmann prepares to unveil its defence document and as the UK operator gears up to launch its mobile Internet strategy - thought to include a deal with Microsoft. Mannesmann's defence document, which will be released towards the end of this week, is expected to highlight a series of bureaucratic constraints which, the company will say, threaten to stall a combined Vodafone-Mannesmann group, depriving it of the ability to move fast, something telecoms firms need.

Chief among the problems is a squabble over what will happen to the Mannesmann-owned Orange network, the UK's third-largest. Vodafone wants to refloat Orange if its bid for Mannesmann succeeds. This would prompt a rebellion from those Mannesmann shareholders who had rejected the bid and wanted to keep control of Orange.

Mannesmann's 20-strong management board includes investor and employee representatives, so it is responsible to all the shareholders. This means it would have to respond to the minority of investors in the new company who rejected the bid.

Sources close to the German company argue that to be able to bypass these shareholders, Vodafone would need a 'domination agreement', a legal instrument which would allow it, as Mannesmann's majority owner, to refloat Orange, despite the opposition.

Under German law, such an agreement would be possible only if Vodafone were to offer cash - instead of shares - to the minority of Mannesmann shareholders who had resisted the bid.

An independent accountant would have to place a value on the minority stake, normally corresponding to market rates. In this case it would run to billions of pounds.

However, sources at Vodafone said the UK company had subsidiaries around the world which respected minority shareholders. It did not foresee any need to invoke a domination agreement.

webTitle: Experts predict ¼-point interest rate rise

fields.headline: Experts predict ¼-point interest rate rise
fields.trailText: The city is expecting interest rates to rise by a quarter percentage point to 5.75 per cent when the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee meets this week.
fields.body:
The city is expecting interest rates to rise by a quarter percentage point to 5.75 per cent when the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee meets this week.

Most economists contacted by The Observer last week said housing and labour market data plus consumer spending figures pointed to a rise.

MPC members Mervyn King, Willhelm Buiter and John Vickers voted for a 25 basis point rise in December, when rates were held at 5.5 per cent. Other members are expected to join these 'hawks'.

Last week a Confederation of British Industry survey reported the strongest annual retail sales growth for three years.

Figures from the Halifax showed house prices rising by 13.6 per cent last year. Consumer credit in November leapt to £1.3 billion, and the Chartered Institute for Purchasing and Supply found strong activity in manufacturing and services.

Merrill Lynch's Ian Stewart said: 'Since December the data has been showing consumer confidence and house price increases. I think a 25 basis point rise is most likely.'

Both David Hillier of Barclays Capital and a team at Credit Suisse First Boston point to average earnings in December rising well above the 4.5 per cent viewed as the upper limit by the MPC as a key factor in a 25bp rise.

The CBI's Kate Barker said the MPC would leave rates as they are because of slower service sector growth and the effects of stock building.

fields.headline: Getting smart on subsidies
fields.standfirst: We all know the handout is finished, says  Oliver  Morgan. But has it been rebranded as a productivity incentive?
fields.trailText: We all know the handout is finished, says Oliver Morgan. But has it been rebranded as a productivity incentive?
fields.body:
New Labour seems to hate 's' words. Socialism, supertax and subsidies are not mentioned in the latest edition of the 'Lexicon of Economic Correctspeak' (first published by Handbag Press of Smith Square in 1979). Its 's' definitions go straight from share ownership (wider) to sunset clauses (red tape).

Indeed, those who openly recognise the role of government money and intervention in industry - the Germans with their banks, the Spanish with their coal, the French with their electricity industry - are vilified in Whitehall as enemies of the single market.

The Government publicly sees no role for intervention or subsidies. Recent requests for cash to bail out Ellington Colliery in Northumberland and to save other mining jobs have received stern rebuffs.

This, after all, is Anglo-Saxon, post-Margaret Britain, not the corporatist Seventies, with their job-protecting handouts to steelmakers and shipbuilders. Subsidies and intervention are discredited and outdated, aren't they?

Well, no. For starters, economists point to successful US corporations that have grown with the help of close relationships with government. From Microsoft and Boeing to Texas Instruments and IBM, the list is extensive.

The fact is that subsidies have come a long way since the Seventies, and now appear, rebranded, as incentives for making companies more productive and 'bridging the equity gap'. Whether or not they are technically direct payments is of less importance than their aim: to support business.

Although the Millbank tendency opposes handouts, the ultra-modern Stephen Byers, Trade and Industry Secre tary, has loosened regulations covering shipbuilding subsidies and, to a sceptical European Commission, is defending the Government's £150 million payout to encourage BMW's investment in the Rover car plant at Longbridge, Birmingham.

Paul Geroski, Professor of Economics at the London Business School, says subsidies must now act within a marketplace, rather than try to replace it: 'What matters most is that a market exists,' he says.

'Subsidies can then be devised effectively - for example, the procurement policy of the US Defence Department has contributed to the development of computers and metallurgy in the commercial world.'

Professor Paul Stoneman of Warwick Business School adds: 'Subsidies can be used perfectly legitimately to compensate for excessive market risk, which prevents companies doing certain things.' But he adds: 'There are policies which have given subsidies a bad name, like supporting Seventies lame ducks.'

Remnants of unreconstructed subsidy still exist, such as the discredited Common Agricultural Policy, driven by the EU. But Britain is increasingly trying to emulate the smart-subsidy culture of the US.

The difficulty is that while some interventions may be entirely legitimate, genuinely looking to promote the growth industries of tomorrow in high-risk areas, there are also bad ones trying to dig governments out of big job-loss headlines but dressed up as incentives for performance enhancement. Politics determines that there is confusion between the two.

Under this and previous governments since 1985, for example, the Launch Aid programme has poured £1.6 billion into the European Airbus consortium's aero-engine projects and the EH101 Westland Helicopter. Launch Aid is paid to projects upfront. If they fail, there is no pay-back, and when they succeed, repayment is linked to profits.

Perhaps it is a testament to the value of such subsidies that there have always been repayments - it certainly suggests that the scheme is better at choosing beneficiaries than most. It shows that the Government accepts that subsidies should be used in such high-risk markets.

Warwick University's Stoneman says: 'Launch Aid is a classic example of the Government intervening in a highly risky area - aerospace. It seems justified: it has created a successful industry. The question is: are there other sectors which should benefit?'

There is also a raft of subsidies made to stimulate Britain's regions - such as the £100m a year Regional Selective Assistance, often used to lure inward investment.

The EU operates, over the head of Westminster, very complicated rules which, in general, prohibit subsidies that distort competition across borders. These vary across activities and sectors: for example, there are European subsidies for training and environmental protection, and there are regional funds for the most deprived parts of the EU. But the Commission is wary of subsidies in the sectors that have traditionally received them, such as steel, car making, textiles, shipbuilding and coal.

There have been complaints about handouts to the coal industries of Germany and Spain.

And UK aid to BMW could land the Government in difficulty unless it is accepted that there was a real risk of BMW moving the operation to Hungary. This deal has also attracted criticism at home, despite the Government's claims that the package includes incentives to raise productivity at the plant. New Labour has moved beyond these programmes with a series of micro-economic measures - generally tax reliefs for business, not standard subsidies. But they deal with the same problem - market failure and risk.

Chancellor Gordon Brown has introduced enhanced capital allowances to encourage small businesses to invest, and has eased capital gains tax. He has introduced a tax credit on research and development, and tax incentives for employee share ownership schemes.

Steve Bond of the Institute for Fiscal Studies says these initiatives prove that the Government is becoming far more interventionist than the Conservatives were. 'This policy agenda rests on two premises: that the market misallocates resources between small firms and large firms; and that spending small amounts of taxpayers' money can make a significant improvement,' he says. 'Hard evidence for either premise is thin on the ground.'

Warwick's Stoneman suggests these British Government initiatives are actually not enough like subsidies. He points to Holland and Finland, where government gives to small, risky businesses on the same basis as UK Launch Aid - no-win, no-fee.

Here, perhaps is the big problem for the Government. Too much coherence could look too much like subsidy, and could attract the attention of the commission. But lack of coherence can actually distort aid programmes.

Coal provides perhaps the best example of such contortions. The crisis of 1997 was resolved not through a handout but by rigging the - admittedly imperfect - market, preventing the construction of gas power-plants, which threaten coal mines. The result: the Government produces the outcome - overriding the market - which is the text-book reason for not allowing subsidies in the first place.

This time around, coalfield MPs realise there's no chance of cash, so they have taken a subtler approach: they're arguing that the Government should help investment in environmental equipment to power stations so they can burn more coal.

The problem is that these interventions are stretching the golden rule: intervention and subsidies work with, not against, the market.

As ever, then, the conundrum is how to decide what to assist, and how to justify it. Last month in its Competitiveness Index, the Department of Trade and Industry made clear that it admired the success of the partnership between US government and business, and saw it as an important part of the knowledge-based economy.

Alan Hughes, the Margaret Thatcher Professor of Enterprise Studies at Oxford University, believes there is a simple way to do this - better subsidies for universities.

He points to the successful collaboration of academics and business in the US, Germany and France. The difference with the UK? Funding, both of facilities and staff.

Hughes says: 'If you want a knowledge-based economy, you have to fund the production of the knowledge.'

That approach has advantages: the European Commission could not object, and it will sit comfortably in New Labour's economic lexicon - under the heading 'e' for education spending.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Index beaters
fields.body:
Index beaters

It was a mammoth task, calculator in hand, reviewing some 150 Stockwatch recommendations last year. But we hope it was worth it.

Overall, we are pleased to report, our portfolio - made up from selected brokers' tips, market gossip, rumours and steers or simply gut feeling - beat the FTSE-100 index last year, rising by an average of 19.8 per cent against 17.8 per cent for the blue chip index.

To be even-handed, however, we must also report that - with the FT All Share index rising 21.2 per cent - we were just shaded by the market as a whole. Still, a result midway between the two benchmarks is quite respectable, and far better than any rate you will get from your high street bank or building society.

Given that the market was dominated by high-tech stocks last year, which Stockwatch is prone to avoid, we are pretty relieved. And even more so because, in the 'old economy', most shares fell, notwithstanding the equity market's overall rise.

Transens-ible

We were saved, frankly, by a handful of spectacular performers, without which any portfolio last year would have been lacklustre.

ARM Holdings, the advanced microchip designer, jumped a spectacular 370 per cent to £41.77 from the 890p at which we recommended them in September. ARM leapt all the way, indeed, into the FTSE-100 index. Colt, the telecoms firm wiring up major European cities, also did us proud, rising 156 per cent to £31.69 since we tipped them in May. Orange rose 136 per cent as it was snapped up by Mannesmann late in the year, while Pace - supplier of set boxes to Sky - repaid our faith with a 177 per cent rise from May.

In the more traditional industry of supplying victuals (even computer programmers have to eat), Booker handsomely doubled its share price from April, as it put old woes behind it.

Our third best performing share was sportswear group Hay & Robertson, which went into orbit thanks to a deal with the England football team and Internet shopping prospects late in the year. H&R's 289 per cent rise was a respectable cricket score.

First prize, however, beating even ARM, goes to tiny automotive technology firm Transense, which celebrated a whopping 547 per cent rise since May by moving from the Ofex market to the AIM last month. At the end of the year, Transense shares had risen to 323p from the 50p at which we recommended them.

Wrong calls

Inevitably we misjudged some things: we pointed out the attractions of medical imaging group Nycomed Amersham as its shares hit their high of more than £5 in April, only to see them drop by nearly 30 per cent before the year's end.

Like most other people, top brokers included, we did just as badly with utility, transport and a raft of engineering shares as the market shrugged off defensive or pure metal-bashing stocks.

Others we missed through pure cynicism, such as PNCTele.com, whose shares more than trebled.

webTitle: Shy dealmaker who kept quiet about costly details

fields.headline: Shy dealmaker who kept quiet about costly details
fields.standfirst: As receivers pick over the carcass of ill-fated TransTec, and the investigation into its accounting anomalies widens, its boss has gone to ground, writes  Paul Farrelly
fields.trailText: As receivers pick over the carcass of ill-fated TransTec, and the investigation into its accounting anomalies widens, its boss has gone to ground, writes Paul Farrelly
fields.body:
He was the ultimate City high flyer. Plucked from obscurity at merchant bank Warburgs in the Eighties, Richard Carr followed a trail blazed by Lord White at Hanson the decade before.

In 1987, he was not even a Warburg director. But over the next six years, Carr built the US arm of Greg Hutchings' Tomkins conglomerate into a multi-billion pound empire, along the way snapping up gunmaker Smith & Wesson among a quickfire series of deals. Carr's reward, on his return to Britain, was an eyecatching £10 million bonus, a staggering sum six years ago.

In late 1994, after leaving Tomkins, the shy, slightly built dealmaker sought to repeat his success at TransTec, a small Midlands engineering group assembled by Geoffrey Robinson.

Today, that ambition is dead, as receiver Arthur Andersen picks over TransTec's remains. Carr, 47 next Monday, has gone to ground after quitting abruptly ahead of Christmas Eve, when TransTec's shares were suspended after the board's discovery of accounting irregularities involving an undisclosed £11.2m claim from Ford, the group's biggest customer.

Last week, during an Observer investigation, repeated attempts to contact Carr at his Stratford-upon-Avon home and via the firm and former colleagues came to nought. Nor could former finance director Bill Jeffrey, who also quit, be contacted to answer questions in a widening probe into TransTec's 'Fordgate' affair.

Ford has yet to furnish the receivers with key documents which will shed further light on the affair. There is no evidence to suggest Ford was aware of any lack of disclosure within TransTec.

According to TransTec and City sources there is also no evidence to suggest Robinson knew of the alleged irregularities, nor, according to Ford, was Robinson involved in the negotiations over the claim.

In retrospect, Carr might feel his fall was fated. TransTec was hardly the most auspicious vehicle for a second glittering career. It started out as Central & Sheerwood , a property outfit that was part of Robert Maxwell's private empire and nearly went bust in the Eighties. In 1991, Robinson controversially reversed his private Transfer Technology firm into C&S, emerging with a hefty stake that still stands at just over 16 per cent.

But by 1994, after a string of disappointments, the City was clamouring for the future Paymaster General to split the role of chairman and chief executive. 'Carr was the bees' knees at Tomkins. He came highly recommended,' one former TransTec adviser said.

Carr set about realising his vision, splashing out on deals in the UK, US, Spain and Australia. By 1997, sales had doubled to £350m, losses of £12m were turned to a £17m profit and TransTec's shares had trebled to a record 120p. By late 1997, however, with the strong pound hitting the motor industry, TransTec was under severe pressure. Debt ballooned past £65m in mid-1999, breaching banking covenants.

In September worried bankers and US bondholders formed a steering group comprising HSBC, Bank One of the US and Boston law firm Bingham Dana. This group, The Observer can reveal, asked accountant Arthur Andersen to investigate TransTec's financial position. 'By then there was significant anti-management tension at the banks, just waiting to snap,' one City source said.

With trading bad and cash tight, the board brought in debt negotiators and corporate financiers from Close Brothers, the City merchant bank that handled the Brent Walker collapse. In November, while working on refinancing and disposal, Close, in turn, brought in the business regeneration unit of TransTec's auditor, PriceWaterhouseCoopers, to get a grip at ground level.

Last week, neither would comment on their role. But The Observer has established that both advisers became increasingly concerned at the situation they found. 'They were helping to negotiate with creditors. Clearly it was in no one's interest for TransTec to go down. In doing that, the roads led the accountants to Ford,' one source said.

A cornerstone of Carr's dream of a world-leading auto-components group was a new factory in Northern Ireland, at Campsie near Londonderry, commissioned in 1996 to make over £20m a year of single overhead camshafts for the six-cylinder engine version of Ford's four-wheel-drive Explorer model.

From its factory at Louisville, Kentucky, Ford turns out 500,000 Explorers a year and Campsie was crucial for a quarter of that. But from the start, the plant - which received government grants - suffered commissioning problems, cost-overruns and delivery delays. 'When you go to an area to set up a highly automated factory, you need skills and they simply weren't there,' said TransTec chairman Colin Cooke. 'You should never just follow the grants.'

What Cooke and his predecessor Richard Rimington - who took over from Robinson in May 1997 - deny is any knowledge that from late 1996 Ford had lodged claims for compensation under its contract. Through two audits, in 1997 and 1998, according to City sources, PwC's audit team were not told of the Ford claim. Andersen, put in by the banks before a new £70m facility was agreed last October, also missed the problem.

During December, sources say, PwC's new team found something unexplained among all the paperwork: 'debit notes' from Ford, which claimed discounts on invoices issued by TransTec subsidiaries, including TransTec Automotive (Campsie) Ltd, which ran the Ulster plant.

Inquiries at Ford Europe's purchasing department in Cologne established that Carr had negotiated with Ford over the £11.2m Campsie penalty for almost a year until a deal was reached in autumn 1997. Ford says it has a written agreement following correspondence with Carr to that effect. The debit notes, the PwC team found were set off against the $100m a year of Ford business the group was doing, not just Campsie. Sources say that made the origin of the claim hard to track.

In all, £7.5m of the claim passed through the group's 1998 accounts, with £5.5m charged against profits and £2m capitalised as tooling expenditure. In late 1999, Ford issued more debit notes on the penalty's £3.7m balance.

'If you look through the 1998 accounts, and the exceptionals items in subsidiaries, nothing leads you to realise it all related to Ford at Campsie,' one source said. 'Only more digging did that.'

On 15 and 16 December the advisers, Cooke and the board confronted Carr and Jeffrey, who was group finance director before moving to TransTec's Australian operations in March last year.

'They confirmed a series of discussions had taken place with Ford over this liability. Other directors confirmed they were unaware,' one source said. 'In their defence, they said the accounting treatment truly reflected the commercial arrangement with Ford,' said another.

At a further board meeting late on 23 December, Carr and Jeffrey resigned, leaving just one executive - current finance director Richard Parkin - on the board. At 6.5p on Christmas Eve, shares were suspended. For the banks, it was the final straw. Close Brothers' advice to trade on was rejected, financial support was withdrawn and the receivers went in.

This weekend, as Andersen prepares for a sell-off, shareholders, bondholders and creditors are considering their hand. Had the full Ford claim been recognised when it arose, TransTec's profits, reputation and share price would have been dented and the firm would have looked less attractive to investors.

webTitle: Golden boy lost his Midas touch

fields.headline: Golden boy lost his Midas touch
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Robinson, the colourful and controversial MP for Coventry North West, may well feel cursed. Certainly, the golden boy has lost his Midas touch. A year after the home loan scandal that cost him and Peter Mandelson their government jobs, TransTec's demise has now robbed Robinson of a chunk of his personal fortune.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Robinson, the colourful and controversial MP for Coventry North West, may well feel cursed. Certainly, the golden boy has lost his Midas touch. A year after the home loan scandal that cost him and Peter Mandelson their government jobs, TransTec's demise has now robbed Robinson of a chunk of his personal fortune.

Not that the indefatigable Labour bankroller, who still owns two Lutyens mansions, the New Statesman magazine and a large chunk of Coventry football club, will cry over spilt milk for too long. Robinson made his luck by being in the right, if sometime controversial, place at the right time.

His early rise was rapid. After a spell with Harold Wilson's Industrial Reorganisation Corporation in the 1970s, Robinson joined British Leyland, becoming chief executive of Jaguar in 1973 at just 34. He was elected to his safe Coventry seat three years later, and in the 1980s forged a relationship with publisher Robert Maxwell.

In the week of the TransTec revelations, Robinson was cleared by the DTI of false accounting at Hollis Industries, a collapsed Maxwell firm that he chaired. This was not the only link with Maxwell. In 1991, the publisher chaired TransTec, then called Transfer Technology, after a deft piece of financial engineering saw another of the publisher's firms absorb Robinson's private interests at a fancy price.

In 1994, Robinson's fortunes were further bolstered by a lottery-style £12.75m bequest on the death of Joska Bourgeois, a Belgian multi-millionairess who ran Jaguar franchises on the Continent.

The way Robinson held his TransTec and Belgian fortunes - in offshore trusts - caused further, predictable, controversy after his long-coveted government appointment in May 1997. Tax havens and a Treasury minister were a godsend to press and Tories alike.

Then, last March, he was also roundly rebuked for the third time by the Commons Standards and Privileges Committee for failing to declare all his business interests. Five months previously, Robinson provoked uproar after delivering a Commons apology in the most perfunctory of ways.

With the media scenting blood again, TransTec, City sources and Ford say there is no evidence Robinson knew of the alleged accounting irregularities. Indeed, he was no longer on the board when the firm's chief executive settled with Ford in late 1997. Robinson was, however, still chairman in 1996 when the Campsie problem first arose.

webTitle: A wider Net for eBusiness shares

fields.headline: A wider Net for eBusiness shares
fields.standfirst: Jamie Doward predicts a more mature but no less enthusiastic attitude to Internet stocks
fields.trailText: Jamie Doward predicts a more mature but no less enthusiastic attitude to Internet stocks
fields.body:
The arrival of Y2K may have failed to wreak havoc for Internet companies, but their share prices nosedived regardless. The threat of interest rate hikes alarmed City and Wall Street traders, who know their debt-laden investments will suffer if the cost of borrowing goes up.

But the slide is likely to be temporary. Analysts predict a bumper year for Internet flotations on both sides of the Atlantic.

Alexander Drobik, vice-president of eBusiness at IT analyst the Gartner Group, said: 'I don't think we're going to see a major crash. That will come. But for now the jury seems to be saying that Internet stocks are the future, so we'll invest in them.'

Even last week there were signs that enthusiasm for Internet stocks was not abating. Dixons' offshoot Freeserve, for example, announced interim pre-tax losses of around £8.6 million but still saw its shares shoot up by 5 per cent immediately after the announcement.

And there was a continuing buzz around JellyWorks, which specialises in buying stakes in Internet companies. The company, run by 24-year-old Jonathan Rowland (son of Seventies' financier David) saw its share price soar from 5p when it floated on 21 December to 141p at the end of the month.

The Americans, about 18 months ahead of the UK in riding the online wave, are looking to take an ever bigger slice of the UK Internet sector as excitement on their side of the pond starts to dry up. Specialist US investment vehicles such as Cross Atlantic and the Carlisle Group - which today appointed Tim Jackson, founder of QXL, as managing director - are giving financial backing to fledgling UK Internet firms with a view to floating them.

The Internet itself has played a part in fuelling the excitement. The number of online investors in the UK rose from around 250,000 to 400,000 last year, with the majority buying Internet and IT-related stocks. This was not the easiest thing to do. Last year only around a dozen Internet companies floated on the UK markets.

Lack of equity was cited as one of the reasons why the share prices of Internet firms went through the roof. UK investors are likely to find it a little easier this year to jump on the Internet bandwagon, according to investment group Durlacher. It predicts that around 50 Internet companies will float in the UK in the next 12 months.

Robert Conway, global technology industry leader at PricewaterhouseCoopers, said: 'The Internet boom is going to continue. Clearly there will be a lot of IPOs (initial public offerings) but they will not be the only vehicle for Internet companies coming to market. I forecast consolidation and a lot more merger and acquisition activity. Shareholders are going to see their companies bought out by higher-valued stocks.'

Many IPOs will come from well known businesses spinning off their Internet inter ests to capitalise on the boom, as Dixons did, floating a part of Freeserve. Egg, the Prudential's online banking arm, looks a good bet. Some analysts speculate that the Financial Times's online operation, FT.com, could soon be spun off from Pearson.

Others will come out of Internet incubators - holding companies which buy into online companies and fatten them up by injecting new management, cash and services.

But will the sector's bubble burst as more equity becomes available? Analysts think this is unlikely. Alex Birch of OC&C Strategy Consulting, which advises firms on their Internet tactics, said: 'All of the quality offers so far have been massively oversubscribed. There is clearly huge appetite for risk in this area.'

However, investors' nerves will be tested over the next 12 months as the Internet sector suffers jitters. Individuals trading online make for a volatile market; the prospect of interest rate rises looks set to be a permanent spectre; and there is always the danger that companies such as Amazon will not meet expectations.

But if 2000 is likely to be the year of the Internet IPO (around 600 are predicted for the US) it is also set to be the year when the market becomes more discerning. The City is likely to become much less interested in the e-retailer and far more appreciative of less glamorous Internet companies.

Miles Saltiel, director of technology research at WestLB Panmure, believes that talking of Internet companies in generic terms is practically meaningless. His team now divides Internet companies into five categories: backroom firms - companies that specialise in software for online payments are an obvious example; businesses which use the Internet to build new markets - such as eBay the US auction house; content providers; Internet access providers; and companies which change strategy in order to buy and sell to other firms directly online - the 'business-to-business' model.

Saltiel is especially bullish about firms which fall into the first and last categories. These companies differ greatly from those which came to market last year: 'Some seem to have a business model which has been: go to market, get capital, spend it on advertising, then go back to the market for more money.'

Finding Internet companies built on more than hot air is no mean feat. Scores of the near-300 US firms which IPO'd last year sank without trace. Alex Graham, managing director of European equity capital markets at investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said: 'US investors have learnt by painful experience that not every IPO makes money.'

Victor Basta, managing director of Broadview, the technology investment bank, said: 'The real issue is not the number of Internet companies which float this year, but how many do so with a market capitalisation of more than £200m. Institutions don't tend to invest below that, which means it's difficult to raise money. And being ignored is very dangerous.' Bets on how long before we hear of the first ebankruptcy?

His team now divides Internet companies into five categories: backroom firms - companies that specialise in software for online payments are an obvious example; businesses which use the Internet to build new markets - such as eBay the US auction house; content providers; Internet access providers; and companies which change strategy in order to buy and sell to other firms directly online - the 'business-to-business' model. Saltiel is especially bullish about firms which fall into the first and last categories. These companies differ greatly from those which came to market last year: 'Some seem to have a business model which has been: go to market, get capital, spend it on advertising, then go back to the market for more money.' Finding Internet companies built on more than hot air is no mean feat. Scores of the near-300 US firms which IPO'd last year sank without trace. Alex Graham, managing director of European equity capital markets at investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said: 'US investors have learnt by painful experience that not every IPO makes money.' Victor Basta, managing director of Broadview, the technology investment bank, said: 'The real issue is not the number of Internet companies which float this year, but how many do so with a market capitalisation of more than £200m. Institutions don't tend to invest below that, which means it's difficult to raise money. And being ignored is very dangerous.' Bets on how long before we hear of the first ebankruptcy?

fields.headline: @large
fields.trailText: It is as we had suspected all along: Netheads are strange individuals. Nearly one in two Internet users believe in aliens compared with one in three of the general population according to a survey in @Demon, the magazine for Demon Internet.
fields.body:
It is as we had suspected all along: Netheads are strange individuals. Nearly one in two Internet users believe in aliens compared with one in three of the general population according to a survey in @Demon, the magazine for Demon Internet.

Other fascinating revelations include the fact that 21 per cent of the population never feel stressed, compared with only 9 per cent of Netheads. It's obviously a tough life sitting in front of a screen for hours on end downloading pictures of Pamela Anderson.

The prize for eRetailer of the week goes to mighty Wal-Mart which, in a bid to stretch its tentacles into cyberspace, last week relaunched its website. The new site was the product of months of brainstorming and won praise for its design.

Unfortunately, the company's wholesome image was tarnished by the fact that the website offered browsers a range of sex books and hardcore porn videos. The glitch was the result of downloading a database of titles from a third-party supplier. A lesson for all eRetailers perhaps.

It's coming up to the biggest sporting event in the US, Super Bowl XXXIV. But the pitched battle on 30 January will be as nothing compared with the dot.com advertising that will surround it.

Two of the biggest US beer brands, Miller Lite and Budweiser, are using the Internet to reach parts other media can't. Miller is sponsoring superbowl.com, the National Football League website. Arch rival Budweiser is running a promotion on ESPN.com which will feature interactive games and a download section with free screen savers.

Back in the UK, companies that offer goods and services over the Internet are no different from normal firms and must adhere to consumer protection measures. Law firm Reynolds Porter Chamberlain warns that eBusinesses which fail to give consumers the right to withdraw from contracts within seven working days could soon face criminal prosecution.

The measure is part of the Government's proposals to implement the EU 'Distance Selling Directive', which must be in place by 4 June 2000.

fields.headline: Media Diary
fields.trailText:
Domeward Bound
Much of the festivity at the Dome on Millennium Eve was missed in the sketchy follow-up reporting - possibly because press and editors were restricted to pavement-side views. One persistent rumour being that New Millennium Experience chief executive Jennie Paige had to placate an angry group of partygoers, including Cherie Booth, Peter Mandelson, Polly Toynbee, Lord Falconer, some Brazilian dancers and William Hague, who had queued for an hour and a half under the misapprehension that they were going to see teen sensations Boyzone, only to find themselves confronted with a latex tunnel and some fake armpit hair. Media diary is sure this is not true, but did hear that Peter Mandelson's former aide Benjy Wegg-Prosser happily posed for snaps with Hague and Ffion... watch out Amanda Platell.

Media diary is sure this is not true, but did hear that Peter Mandelson's former aide Benjy Wegg-Prosser happily posed for snaps with Hague and Ffion... watch out Amanda Platell.

A final Dome thought from abroad: who would we like to see at the back of the queue? Early nominations include: the entire board of the New Millennium Experience; Bob Geldof, whose Big Time company was in charge of the 'River of Fire'; the editor of GQ or whoever was responsible for the magazine's 'lingerie' supplement; Catherine Zeta-Jones and her disagreeable 'beau' Michael Douglas, preferably standing next to Neil and Christine Hamilton, (sorry no New Year amnesty for Hamilton and his 'lucky suit').

Scam Alert!
Wapping-based company 21st Century Faxes are a naughty set of tinkers making money out of the hard of thinking. Their ongoing fax 'polls', which proffer important-looking ballot papers, with 'Should We Bring Back News At Ten?' printed above a 'yes' and 'no' box, invite you to fax back the reply. For anyone half-witted enough to think that this really is an official census, think again. The company charges between £1 and £3 for every poll form faxed back - making this the biggest money-spinning scam since 'Lonely Housewives Chat Lines' stuck an 0898 number in Sunday Sport.

Michael and Clive - a sitcom
The story so far: Michael and Clive own two media companies but have decided to merge them - with hilarious consequences!

This week Michael and Clive choose office furnishings. With a keen eye on cost-cutting, the pair head off to Courts at Brent Cross to furnish the office they will shortly have to share. Michael likes the green leather chesterfield with the walnut veneer roll-top desk. Clive, however, wants an upturned tea crate and a park bench which has been 'borrowed' from Wandsworth Council. 'I know, let's toss for it,' says Clive. 'Best of three,' says Michael. 'No, five,' says Clive. After some bickering the two hit on the perfect solution to their impasse 'I know,' they say simultaneously, 'Let's call Gerry.'

fields.headline: Health check
fields.trailText: Your personal happiness is greatly affected by the mental health of the business you work for.
fields.body:
Your personal happiness is greatly affected by the mental health of the business you work for. Like families, companies can be dysfunctional, extremely well-balanced or, more likely, somewhere in the middle. In the first in a series of five articles on organisational health and sickness, Malcolm Kerrell, of management consultant Wildfire Corporation, tells you how to rate the culture you work in.

Many people in organisations today, who were brought up on traditional management theories, are stuck in their thinking while fresh approaches challenge them. So how do you know if your organisation is healthy - healthy, that is, in millennium terms, not those of past generations?

Here are two checklists, the first unhealthy, the second healthy.

Your bosses/colleagues:

 Regard any new idea from below with suspicion.

Encourage people to criticise each other's proposals.

 Express their criticisms freely and withhold praise.

 Treat problems as a sign of failure.

 Decide in secret to reorganise or change policies.

 Assign to lower-level managers responsibility for suggesting cuts or moves.

 Believe their experience and knowledge means they know all they need to know.

Or your bosses/colleagues:

 Encourage all employees to learn and ask questions.

 Provide a variety of learning methods and projects beyond the immediate job.

 Provide horizontal career paths to open possibilities.

 Link reward to output not status, performance not age.

 Constantly encourage initiative and achievement.

 Focus on the needs of the individual.

You cannot measure mental health precisely - but, from the above, you will have a feel for your business's state of mind.

fields.headline: Infamous 5's star ratings
fields.standfirst: With millions of videos to retune and a paltry programme budget, few foresaw success for Britain's newest terrestrial. But it's a triumph, reports  Emily Bell
fields.trailText: With millions of videos to retune and a paltry programme budget, few foresaw success for Britain's newest terrestrial. But it's a triumph, reports Emily Bell
fields.body:
Question: Which is the only mainstream broadcaster to increase its audience share over the past year? Was it:

a. BBC1

b. ITV
c. Channel 4
d. Channel 5

Non-anoraks may have to phone a friend or even ask the audience to try to crack this one, because the correct answer is 'd'. Yes, Channel 5, once the derided repository of poor reception and poorer press, is, by this measure, Britain's most successful broadcaster.

BBC1's annual audience share figures showed its worst ever performance, C4 held steady and ITV showed a slight overall audience dip despite increasing its primetime audience to 38.8 per cent (which was close enough to the 39 per cent target for its executives to pick up bonuses).

C5, on the other hand, increased its share to 5.4 per cent. Last week, as news of the channel's slow but steady progress in capturing ratings filtered out, its shareholders were bidding to up their stakes in the company - an exercise that valued it at around £1.2 billion.

When merchant banker Anthony Fry speculated that C5 would be worth £1bn within three years of its launch, on Easter Sunday 1997, few thought his prediction would come true. The immense problems the channel faced in retuning the nation's video recorders and its annual budget of £110m for programming did not bode well for building public confidence and a stable audience. ITV, freely spending £800m a year, and Channel 4, with its new-found enthusiasm for the sex-and-death formats that helped launch C5, both seemed formidable opponents. Surely the channel was doomed to failure.

So what went right? David Elstein, C5's chief executive, puts it down to the science of television.

'It is simply logic. What we have done is refined our schedule, learnt by our mistakes and kept at it. In Britain we have such a conservative audience that we can predict - sometimes to one tenth of a percentage point - what our weekly audience will be. What we have done is counter-punched against the ITV schedule and that is how we have improved our numbers.'

Elstein dismisses the handy claim that C5 is all about 'films, fucking and football' - a phrase used but not, Elstein says, coined by C5's head of programmes, Dawn Airey.

'Football has practically no impact on our overall viewing - it might provide very handy spikes in our weekly audiences but overall it has contributed very little,' he says. 'Similarly the soft porn films in the evening. What undoubtedly does well for us are films in the 9 o'clock slot.'

He adds to the list the staple programmes that may not have caused a stir at the Baftas but are drawing enough eyes to the screen to keep C5 ahead of schedule: Night Fever, the grim karaoke show; Fort Boyard, the copy of Crystal Maze enhanced by Melinda Messenger, Dirty Den and some real tigers; even the revived It's a Knockout.

Reading down the roll call of C5 favourites, it is almost certainly true that industry commentators and other executives probably watch very little of the output - there is nothing there to incite a single wag from the tongue of one member of the chattering classes. Unless of course it is to repeat the out-dated jokes about snowstorm reception or the mildly titillating nature of its late-night programming.

What offends the sensitivities of those who prefer to prate about TV rather than watch it is that C5 is almost shockingly dedicated to achieving audience targets and financial results. It pays lip service but little more to manufacturing television that matters, that has some significance beyond half-an-hour's diverting entertainment. The nearest C5 is likely to get to a costume drama is a woman in, or preferably out of, a swimsuit. It has unashamedly championed the return of Miss World to our screens and will continue to focus its documentary output on controversial and slightly prurient subjects like the Moors Murderers. Even the much-copied Channel 5 News, which made Kirsty Young a £1m star who was poached by ITV, is not sacrosanct.

'Every time we move it in the schedules it gets a bigger audience and I would move it again if I could,' says Elstein. His belief is that it should run at 5.30pm, and the channel has further ambitions for sprucing up its early evening schedule, including an as yet unannounced coup in buying a well-known programme from one of its competitors.

This week Elstein appears in front of the Independent Television Commission chief executive Peter Rogers and his panel to answer questions relating to the annual assessment of the performance of all the commercial terrestrial franchise holders. Elstein says he would be very surprised if there were to be anything more than the mildest criticism of the network's output.

Industry analysts put a large part of the company's success down to Airey and her genius for scheduling, and the strength of the sales department under Nick Milligan.

'Those two are very much the stars of the show and the channel's success will depend on an ability to hold on to them,' says one source.

Elstein confirms that one of the cornerstones of C5's good results has been 'to keep together a very tight, loyal, motivated team'. The management currently enjoys 'shadow' share options and with existing shareholders consolidating their holdings it seems highly unlikely that the channel will now be floated on the stock market this year, or indeed next.

A bigger question may revolve around who will ultimately control the company. The appointment of ITV chief executive Richard Eyre as head of Pearson TV - one of C5's three big shareholders - has galvanised speculation that the company is ready to wrest control of the whole shooting match. This may be made easier by the fact that another shareholder, United News and Media, is attempting to merge with Carlton Communications. This might force United to lower its interest in C5 if the competition authorities see fit. With a single shareholder and big bucks behind it, the prospects for C5 could be very interesting.

But then, as Elstein puts it, the low-cost nature of C5 has made it surprisingly fresh. Kirsty is poached by ITV, so the station decides to promote a new unknown, Andrea Cathewood, as its new face. It picks up formats that cannot find room in the schedules of its richer competitors and it hits the opposition when they are not looking.

'We make programmes for £120,000 an hour - they make programmes for £240,000 an hour. Why would they ever want to buy any of our shows?' says Elstein. 'In a whole year ITV scheduled against us once - they have bigger targets to worry about; and if that's the way it carries on, so much the better.'

fields.headline: How to
fields.standfirst: Recognise a bully
fields.trailText: Recognise a bully
fields.body:
1. Accept that most people (including you) have the potential to be bullies. Most bullies are appalled if they find out how other people regard them. You are more likely to humiliate and undermine others if you are unhappy or resentful; if you have been treated badly; if you work in a climate of fear; if you are in a position to abuse others; and if you let your emotions take over at times.

Physical abuse and bullying have occurred in many children's homes where an imbalance of power left the children unprotected.

2. Look for the conditions in which bullying flourishes: intense competition between colleagues to reach sales targets or avoid redundancy; or hierarchical structures where subordinates have little power to answer back. Many occupations have institutionalised bullying - by giving power to the hectoring army sergeant, for example, or the battleaxe headmistress. 'Some bullies just like to have power over others,' says psychologist Sandi Mann, author of Psychology Goes to Work. 'For some it's just a way of managing: they don't know any other way.'

3. Ask yourself how often you are criticised by juniors and peers. If people are scared to say anything critical to you, the chances are you frighten them, which means you have bullying tendencies.

4. Examine your emotional response to work. If you get depressed by it, sleep badly, hate Sunday evenings, something is clearly wrong and you may be the subject of bullying. Many victims do not recognise the fact - perhaps because they are used to being bullied at home or at school, or they think it would seem wimpish to complain. Men are particularly scared of admitting to being bullied: harassment is a more comfortable word.

5. Check to see that you are not abusing your power. A sure sign of your emotional corruption is if you treat subordinates in a way that you would never treat your superiors. The healthiest people will question their own bosses but treat their staff with respect and encouragement. If you have to shout at someone, it should be your boss, never your staff.

webTitle: Rage against the dying of light

fields.headline: Rage against the dying of light
fields.standfirst: Tired of toiling away in an unhealthy gloom? You're far from alone, writes Nick Gillies
fields.trailText: Tired of toiling away in an unhealthy gloom? You're far from alone, writes Nick Gillies
fields.body:
If you've ever thought that buildings aren't as well lit as they used to be, don't worry. You're not suffering from nostalgia: modern buildings are badly lit - by design.

The result has been a loss of efficiency. And workers in the worst lit class of buildings - call centres - may be suffering long-term damage to their health.

Many of the problems can be traced to a misunderstanding that is proving very difficult to eradicate: office blocks are often equipped with lighting that is designed to a safety standard, not a comfort standard. Moreover, the size of the buildings limits the amount of daylight getting in. This is especially problematic for the increasing number of people working unusual shifts: lighting that would be adequate by day plays havoc with their circadian rhythms, causing long-term damage.

'Some of the ways we are working now are unhealthy by design,' says Roger Spiller of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union (MSF). 'Businesses don't think of the stress they are causing, but they'll get away with it until the epidemiologists catch up with them.'

However, the situation is about to improve in some ways, because new buildings are now being planned to let in more daylight.

But in other ways it may get worse, warns Jonathan David of the Chartered Institution of Building Services Engineers (CIBSE). He worries that the planned European standardisation of lighting standards will turn CIBSE's Lighting Guide Category 2 into a standard - particularly for 'speculative offices', built by a developer on a speculative basis, then furbished before a buyer is sought.

'It was never meant to be a standard for working,' he says. 'It was a fallback for speculative offices. It doesn't cause problems under all conditions, but it doesn't provide good lighting. It's gloomy: there's no light on the walls.'

The guide was meant to advise on necessary levels of lighting for safe working. It was designed to let people see hazards and judge their position. Unfortunately, says David: 'Manufacturers have started making products to that standard. I always tell them to ignore it.'

Too little light thrown on walls means that, except on objects immediately under the lighting, the room is dim. This limits glare, one of the two major problems in lighting (the other is reflection).

But light does more than make things visible.

'Sunlight supplies vitamins, and suppresses melatonin,' says Adrian Hallam, of Adrian Hallam Architects, the RIBA's special adviser on light. 'Melatonin is a soporific. It tells you when it's dark it is time to sleep. When sunlight hits the eye, melatonin production is suppressed and you become alert. Several forms of artificial light [most light bulbs and fluorescent tubes, for example] don't do this.'

Hallam says that if you look at a graph showing the visible spectrum of natural light, it's like a plateau - but 'fluorescent light is like shark's teeth'. He cites early studies done on Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD) in the 1960s.

'In Stockholm you could go to work in the dark and be deep in a building until you went home. People complained of feeling drowsy all the time. Now most GPs will tell you they have a stock of patients they have to help through the winter.'

Hallam points out: 'In Germany, workers have the right to be within six metres of natural daylight.'

But why exactly do we want natural light? 'The light energy from daylight is the least important part of it,' says Professor Peter Tregenza of Sheffield University.

There are two main priorities: to able to see outside (the reason why supermarkets so often have large windows looking on to boring car parks) and, if you are inside, to maintain contact with the outside through light falling on cupboards, desks and other surfaces.

'It is seeing outside that gives the satisfaction,' says Tregenza. 'Light falling on surfaces is the next thing people need. It is contact with outside, with the changes in light telling them what time it is and what the weather is like.' People deprived of light - kept in interrogation rooms or dungeons, for example - can very quickly become disoriented and depressed.

In a properly lit building electrical lighting only provides 'task lighting', Tregenza adds. Artificial light will be there to support the natural light - not to replace it. 'Daylight falls on surfaces. The artificial lighting must not mask the daylight.'

But there have always been people who have worked away from daylight. So why has this deficiency not been pointed out before? Perhaps because it was universal in some industries, and its effects could be attributed to other causes: miners have never been noted for their good industrial relations, for example. Night nurses have desk lamps, and move to brightly lit operating theatres to deal with emergencies.

Shift workers in call centres are a new and growing group, and most are affected by bad lighting. Lighting is kept dim so as not to interfere with VDU screens.

'It should be at least as bright as daylight, so as not to interfere with their circadian rhythms,' says MSF's Spiller. But that would limit their ability to see the screens. 'These are workers working in a deliberately unhealthy environment. The Working Time Directive says work must be designed to fit the worker, but the British Government has not implemented that part of it.'

Making office lighting comfortable may sound rather 'soft'. Workplaces, employers may say, are there for people to earn money, not to provide a pretty window. But such employers are doing themselves a disservice. Uncomfortable employees tire easily, and are short-tempered, easily distracted and rebellious.

It is odd that the lighting lessons used in animal husbandry have never been applied to the human workplace. In farming it is used to make sheep breed twice a year rather than once. This may not seem immediately applicable, but it does show the very real affect that lighting has on the brain.

How to brighten your day

1. Move nearer to a window.

2. Adjust your position so you get the least reflection and glare: move your computer monitor; raise your seat; move your desk if you can.

3. Adjust your monitor to a level that suits you.

4. Get your union rep to speak to the buildings manager: It may be possible to adjust the levels of lighting.

5. If the office is being redecorated: ask for light-coloured paint or paper on surfaces that will catch daylight.

6. Change jobs - and ask for a guided tour before you accept your new one. Sounds drastic, but why go on being lethargic and miserable?

The Manufacturing, Science and Finance union (MSF) used to have a Health & Safety Committee. Now it has a Working Environment Committee. 'We've changed the title because we are taking a holistic approach,' says the committee's national secretary, Roger Spiller. 'You can't consider health or safety in isolation. Parental leave, working time, sick building syndrome: these all affect health and the ability to do the work safely.'

webTitle: Kennedy in bid to build a profile

fields.headline: Kennedy in bid to build a profile
fields.trailText: In a bid to raise his worryingly low profile, Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy will demand big spending boosts for education and health. This follows party polling which reveals that most floating voters are opposed to Labour's planned income tax cuts.
fields.body:
In a bid to raise his worryingly low profile, Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy will demand big spending boosts for education and health. This follows party polling which reveals that most floating voters are opposed to Labour's planned income tax cuts.

The polling also reveals deep disenchantment with Labour's inability to deliver improved public services, especially in the National Health Service, and that Kennedy, elected party leader last summer, is failing to make an impact with voters. As many as 40 per cent were unable to express a view on his competence.

But among those expressing a view, Kennedy scored well on trustworthiness and honesty.

The survey, conducted last month among floating voters in the party's target areas, shows that, by a margin of 18 to 82 per cent, voters would prefer not to see the Chancellor cut income tax by 1p this April. They want the money spent on public services instead. The Lib Dems' figures show Gordon Brown could spend an extra £30 billion up to 2005. Kennedy has been told by his Treasury spokesman that Brown has hidden the surplus through a higher contingency fund and is under-spending on social security.

The polling also shows that Labour is trailing badly on the NHS with 63 per cent saying the Government is doing 'much worse' or 'worse' than expected, a finding the Health Secretary Alan Milburn is likely to use to extract extra cash from Treasury in the summer's spending review.

On transport, 71 per cent of voters think the Government's performance is much worse, or worse than expected. Forty-seven per cent said the Government was doing much worse.

On education, voters seemed less disenchanted, possibly because expectations were not so high. Only 30 per cent thought the Goverment was doing worse than expected and 8 per cent much worse than expected.

Liberal Democrat strategists believe the most significant finding is the huge proportion of floating voters in key seats who want more resources for public services.

'It looks like the old tax and spend paranoia is dead, and we won't frighten floating voters by saying public spending is the priority over tax cuts,' said one.

'We are not going to be reckless in our spending pledges, but we should not be worried about attacking Lab our over holding back public spending.'

In most Liberal Democrat-held marginals and target seats, the Tories, not Labour, are the main opposition.

Past leaders feared a pledge to raise spending would drive floating voters to the Tories. Some Liberal Democrats now believe they can improve on their current 46 seats at the next election. They believe the Tories have wrongly chosen to highlight the tax burden and Europe while William Hague's personal ratings remain dismal.

webTitle: Don't just sit there - mean something

fields.headline: Don't just sit there - mean something
fields.standfirst: Amal Asfour and Paul Williamson's richly informative Gainsborough's Vision sets out to make us look at his work with more informed enjoyment
fields.trailText: Amal Asfour and Paul Williamson's richly informative Gainsborough's Vision sets out to make us look at his work with more informed enjoyment
fields.body:
Gainsborough's Vision
Amal Asfour and Paul Williamson
Liverpool University Press, £47.99, pp567
Buy it at BOL

For lovers of art history, it is high noon. Not only have international exhibitions, together with unprecedented coverage via photography and television, made possible Malraux's dream of a 'universal museum' but publishers have crowded the market with catalogues, monographs and histories of the fine arts and architecture in every style and epoch. These, in turn, are, at their best, illustrated to a standard never before possible. Many a renaissance fresco or medieval sculpture, many a byzantine mosaic or Attic frieze is today more visible in every detail in books than in situ.

The problem is that two somewhat conflicting impulses are in play. Art historians belong to a ferociously specialised guild, equipped with technical skills and a mandarin idiom. On one level, they produce learned papers, catalogues and studies in depth of particular artists or schools which are intended to persuade their jealously watchful peers. On the other, they seek to interest a general public. Only the most humanely gifted - Gombrich being the stellar example - are comfortable with both purposes, bringing the most erudite authority within reach of a wider public. Too often, publications risk ending up either on the coffee table or on the academic shelf.

Amal Asfour and Paul Williamson have set out to make us look more knowledgeably, with more informed enjoyment at the paintings of Gainsborough. This might seem a superfluous enterprise, few masters being more immediately enjoyable. But their treatment is richly informative. It locates Gainsborough in relation to Reynolds and Hogarth on the one hand, to Rubens and Van Dyck on the other. Homing in on certain recurrent motifs and practices in Gainsborough's oeuvre - the concept of nature and emblem, pastoralism and rococo, the presence of music - Asfour and Williamson seek to define the specificities of Gainsborough's eye and sensibility together with that which makes him illustriously representative of his milieu.

What makes the ravishing portrait of Mrs Philip Thickness or that Wooded Landscape with Peasants in a Country Wagon so distinctive of Gainsborough yet so characteristic of mid-eighteenth England? Why, even at a distance, do we know at once that the Mr and Mrs Hallett at their morning walk (National Gallery) can only be a Gainsborough? Is it the enchanting dog so like his master and mistress; is it the lady's plumed chapeau, alive with motion or, perhaps, the mien of shared discretion, of aloofness from the viewer? Painterly reflexes and habits of feeling are both explored in this finely illustrated volume.

Our authors are illuminating on the philosophic background. 'After Locke, the process of observing has a definite and almost universally acknowledged resonance.' But Bishop Berkeley brilliantly challenged Locke's empiricism with its emphasis on the geometric. Berkeley underlines the constructive role of the intellect in our interpretation, in our 'reading' of 'the perpetual mutability and fleetingness of those immediate objects of sight'. Our authors analyse the interactions of these two epistemological points of view in Gainsborough's 'ambiguities of space', in his capacity to imply, to enact motion in his sitters. Static poses turn wonderfully active. A ribbon, a piece of lace can carry both light and shadow, embodying their dynamic interconnectedness.

The reading of Mr & Mrs Robert Andrews is a bravura piece. Asfour and Williamson demonstrate the contradictions between the landscape and the two figures. Hunting props contrast with the imagery of harvest. The privileges of squierarchy and ownership are subtly subverted not only by the scale of the land but by implications of seasonal, almost sacred autonomy far outweighing the boastful transience of human ownership.

These seminal tensions are crystallised, as it were, in the famous off-centredness of the young couple. They seem banished to the edge of the canvas, a marginalisation countered, almost childishly, by the bouffant volume of Mrs Andrews's skirt.

A striking feature relates the landscapes painted in Bath between 1759 and 1774. Almost half of the 40 paintings exhibit a markedly curving, indeed circular principle and effect. This device accentuates the scene as a self-contained space, set apart from the viewer as through a spyhole. This can be understood as a simultaneous suggestion both of 'snug immediacy' and of self-enclosure. It ensures 'a sense of autonomy by which the viewer is displaced'.

What is extraordinary is Gainsborough's achievement of seemingly unforced bucolic naturalness via techniques of considered artifice. Hence the importance of Gainsborough's show-box in which he displayed his transparencies - that is, landscapes painted on glass. In miniature, the lens produced those magnifying and distancing sensations which endow the Extensive Wooded Landscape of 1772-4 with its singular aura. Here, indeed, one experiences what Asfour and Williamson characterise as an ideal of 'neo-epicurean leisure'.

The book closes with a lesser-known facet of Gainsborough's spirit, the 'devotional optimism' which connects him with a master such as Murillo. We owe to this impulse the 1782 Girl with Pigs, Reynolds's favourite, and a much richer performance than at first meets the eye.

Gainsborough's Vision breaks off tersely. It refers only once to, and scorns to illustrate, the most loved of Gainsborough's icons, The Blue Boy. The learned monograph has taken over from the general argument. Yet the unraised question nags. What is it in so masterly an artist, in so systematically intelligent a painter, which, at the last, disappoints? Why should Claude Lorrain's landscapes seem so much deeper in their inward magic? Why should Goya's portraits, only a few years later, be so 'much the greater thing', to borrow a radical nuance from Henry James? In what ways does the demon of charm, even of prettiness, hover at the edge of a Gainsborough? For Asfour and Williamson, such questions are amateurishly extraneous. The more's the pity.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: Comedian Arthur Smith bets intrepid gambler Tony Hawks that he can't play and beat the entire Moldovan football team at tennis. Never one to pass up a subject for a book, he accepts the challenge and the two agree a forfeit for the loser - to stand outside Woolworth's in Balham High Street and sing the Moldovan national anthem - naked.
fields.body:
Playing the Modolvans at Tennis

Tony Hawks
Read by the author
Random House £8.99, 3 hours approx

Comedian Arthur Smith bets intrepid gambler Tony Hawks that he can't play and beat the entire Moldovan football team at tennis. Never one to pass up a subject for a book, he accepts the challenge and the two agree a forfeit for the loser - to stand outside Woolworth's in Balham High Street and sing the Moldovan national anthem - naked.

Without a care in the world, nor a glance at his bank balance, Hawks sets off for Moldova having made no preliminary inquiries as to the availability of the 11 men in question. By the end of side two, he hasn't seen a Moldovan score a goal, let alone hold a racket.

This account of a people struggling with a newly acquired freedom that they don't quite know what to do with is much less frivolous than Hawks's hike around Ireland with a fridge a couple of years ago (another bet).There is an air of pointlessness to this venture, but all credit to the man - if anyone could pull off such a stunt in a country where red tape is as thick as horse meat it's Hawks, although all the bureaucratic hurdles he must clear leave little scope for impromptu dalliances.

His enthusiasm in reading his account is as energetic as the doing, but whereas it was fun hearing Hawks do an Irish brogue, the Moldovan tongue is less pleasing to the ear. Somewhere more exotic next time please.
