fields.headline: Mad about the boys
fields.standfirst: Caravaggio was an obnoxious kind of genius but he didn't deserve this... Philip Hensher on David Thomas' life of Caravaggio, M
fields.trailText: Caravaggio was an obnoxious kind of genius but he didn't deserve this... Philip Hensher on David Thomas' life of Caravaggio, M
fields.body:
M
Peter Robb
Bloomsbury, £25, pp567
Buy it at BOL

Caravaggio disturbed all his contemporaries, and has gone on disturbing people ever since. Most people thought he was barking mad, and deeply dangerous. A word that recurs, in descriptions of him, is stravagantissimo, a term that implies extreme, lavish eccentricity. It's an idea that spilt over, in the way these things do, to affect the way people looked at his paintings.

We know a fair amount about him, since most of those who met him remembered him, and quite a lot of them wrote something down about his terrible behaviour. Still more helpfully, he often found himself in direct conflict with the law, and the meticulous records of the courts record his movements and the worst of his actions.

He was hauled up for writing satirical verses about a rival painter, throwing stones (twice), swearing at a policeman, carrying a sword without a licence, beating an acquaintance with a stick, stabbing someone with a sword and a hunting knife and, once, throwing a plate of artichokes at a waiter. These are just the offences recorded between 1600 and 1605.

The other thing about him that horrified and fascinated his contemporaries was what they saw as an embarrassing keenness on boys. Helen Langdon wrote an interesting book a couple of years ago, in which she said that the textual evidence for Caravaggio's homosexuality wasn't decisive, and it isn't; but to deny his tastes, you have to look away from the paintings, which show a consistent appreciation of a particular sort of lushly available male beauty.

The point of Caravaggio is that he is probably the single most influential painter in European history. His meaning is quite a simple one - the banal theme that youth and its bloom never lasts - and, in that, it is amazing that he is always a black painter, but never a depressing one. The greatness of him, though, is in his unprecedented, unprejudiced susceptibility to flesh and light, his utter mastery of it.

This is an absolutely awful book, just ghastly in every single respect. There is a certain amount of interesting material here, and Robb has done a great deal of homework. But the interesting nuggets are buried among speculation stated as solid fact. Robb blithely identifies, for instance, certain figures in Caravaggio's paintings with some names from the archive, with no sense of how controversial or even incredible this often is.

If you are struck by a quotation, and wonder where it is from, the footnotes frequently refer you to somebody else's biography rather than the original source, so everything is veiled in the most unnecessary mystery. Personally, I find it difficult to believe that a biography as long as this can reasonably be written about anybody who lived before the eighteenth century apart from kings and popes. Robb only manages it by drawing every last drop of meaning out of what may be a meagre source in the archives.

It is recorded, for instance, that when Caravaggio was arrested in 1598 for carrying a sword without a licence, he also had a pair of compasses on him. Robb remarks that they may have looked like an offensive weapon, which is fair enough. But then he completely loses the plot.

'The instrument... would've been unfamiliar to the police, though it was currently fascinating the literary minds of Europe.' He goes on to cite John Donne, who had likened his own and his lover's souls to 'a pair of stiff twin compasses'. Later that year, in Italy, he says, 'the poet Guarini had published a madrigal that turned on the same image of compasses for lovers' constancy'.

Robb surmises that Caravaggio's compasses 'probably came from Cardinal Del Monte's collection of scientific equipment'. What all this has to do with anything, God only knows.

The most infuriating thing about the book is how badly written it is. It has various whimsies, the worst of which is referring constantly to Caravaggio as 'M', giving the narrative the faint air of The Spy Who Loved Me. There's a recurrent breeziness about the tone which is maddeningly patronising. 'You'd've had to have quite a stake in [Caravaggio] to stay.' It is trying to be vivid and immediate, but it's noticeable that Robb is almost never concrete; his writing is both demotic and abstract, hardly ever managing to convey the physical appearance of a painting.

'Caravaggio was able to make art so breathtakingly objective only because he was peculiarly true to his own subjective way of seeing. His visual explorations laid bare his own psyche and his own susceptibilities with a touching frankness and courage.'

Maybe we will never fully understand Caravaggio - his contemporaries admitted they didn't, so I don't see why we should. But it's annoying to finish a biography and feel that you know less about its subject than you did when you started it.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Caroline Boucher on Antonia Logue's combination of fact and fiction, plus The Folded Leaf, After Silence and The Penguin Book of Art Writing
fields.body:
Shadow-box
Antonia Logue
Bloomsbury £6.99, pp309
Buy it at BOL

Winner of the Irish Times Irish Fiction Award, this novel's narrative is an imagined correspondence between two real people - the American boxer Jack Johnson and the English modernist poet Mina Loy. The first letter, dated January 1946, is by Jack in Chicago, making contact with Mina after they had lost touch.

Johnson was an Afro-American who boxed his way out of the Galveston docks to become world champion from 1908-15. His prowess as a boxer at a time of great racial prejudice caused an uproar, and a former champion - the 'great white hope' James Jeffries - was brought out of retirement to fight him in 1910, but Johnson knocked him out. The description of the fight and the hatred in the stadium is electrifying. Equally interesting is Mina's description of her exile in Italy (tucked away there by a jealous but neglectful husband) when she meets Marinetti and the Futurists. The style of weaving facts and fiction is like that used by E.L. Doctorow in Ragtime, but this is a much more lyrical book.

The Folded Leaf
William Maxwell
Panther £6.99, pp310
Buy it at BOL

Boxing runs through this story of boys growing up in Chicago in the 1920s. Spud Latham has been forced to move to the city when his father lost his job and large house in the country. His way of channelling resentment is to pick fistfights. He befriends Lymie whose mother has died and whose father copes through alcohol and blowsy women; each envies the other's lifestyle while wishing to escape his own. Maxwell worked at the New Yorker for 40 years, editing the likes of Updike, Cheever and O'Hara. The Folded Leaf was first published in 1945 and has the slightly stiff, understated style of the period.

After Silence: Rape and my Journey Back
Nancy Venable Raine
Virago £7.99, pp278
Buy it at BOL

One afternoon in October 1985 Nancy Venable Raine was putting the rubbish outside her apartment. While her back was turned, a stranger slipped through the open door and when she went back inside he raped her. In the immediate aftermath, as she painstakingly began to rebuild her life, Raine little realised the enormity of the task. This is how she heard a rape victim describe it on TV in 1991: 'The rape is just the beginning. Then it's one long drop into hell.'

To begin with, she sought refuge with her mother, trailing after her like a tiny child, never letting her out of her sight. Then there were the practical tasks, moving to a new neighbourhood, dealing with the medical tests and police. Then came the therapy and the lull, where some friends were frighteningly over-tough in their attempts to get her back to work, and the unpredictable reaction of people which continues: a therapist who became hostile and unbending when she cancelled a first appointment; a woman who reacted to Raine's marriage by saying she couldn't understand how she could get married after being raped. An extraordinary book.

The Penguin Book of Art Writing
edited by Martin Gayford and Karen Wright
Penguin £12.99, pp618
Buy it at BOL

An interesting and at times puzzling collection spanning a wide time scale and divided into sections: the artist at work, travel, psychology etc. Inclusions range from Veronese defending himself against a interrogatory council, Updike visiting a blockbuster Renoir exhibition, an overlong Robert Hughes piece on Miro, a memorable William Feaver essay on Michael Andrews's Thames River series, undertaken when the artist was terminally ill. Or there's Andy Warhol's 1975 interview by a girl called Damian, which Warhol reports in the first person (presumably in his old magazine Interview) where they kick around the old 'what is art?' chestnut. This is a hefty tome, which almost reaches the Vikram Seth uncomfortable weight, and is probably best used for reference and dipping into.

fields.headline: How Darwin's other half lived
fields.standfirst: Robin McKie follows Alfred Wallace in Snadra Knapp's Footsteps in the Forest and Gavan Daws and Marty Fujita's Archipelago
fields.trailText: Robin McKie follows Alfred Wallace in Snadra Knapp's Footsteps in the Forest and Gavan Daws and Marty Fujita's Archipelago
fields.body:
Footsteps in the Forest: Alfred Russel Wallace in the Amazon
Sandra Knapp
Natural History Museum £16.95, pp90
Buy it at BOL

Archipelago: The Islands of Indonesia
Gavan Daws and Marty Fujita
University of California £27.50, pp275
Buy it at BOL

Few men have led lives that inspire so dramatically as Alfred Russel Wallace's. Born in near poverty, denied higher education, and refused recognition during his early life, the naturalist was afflicted by hardships that would have broken most men. Even after becoming a biologist he suffered appalling misfortune: a ship fire destroyed his priceless Amazon specimens, he contracted malaria, was maimed in a gun accident, and lost a brother to yellow fever.

Yet Wallace endured and became a noted collector of rare animal and plant specimens; invented the science of biogeography, the study of animal distribution; and, in a fitting response to 'the ague', cracked the secret of natural selection in the midst of a malarial fever. He became a supporter of women's rights, socialism, land nationalisation, and - in case you thought he was too good to be true - spiritualism. As E.O. Wilson states in a prologue to Archipelago , Wallace succeeded because he was 'an intense young man, totally focused, awesomely persistent, resilient to tropical disease that killed so many others, and nobly selfless'.

However, his greatest achievement remains the unravelling of natural selection, a theory that still obsesses humanity - though we usually associate its principles with its co-discoverer, Charles Darwin, with whom Wallace announced joint success in their breakthrough at the Linnean Society in London in 1858. Their intellectual bombshell reverberates today, with books on evolution still making bestseller lists, while biographies of Darwin are now a publishing industry in their own right.

By contrast, Wallace has been shunned, although he was by far the most interesting of evolution's early proponents. Dismissed - quite unfairly - as the 'moon to Darwin's sun' who accidentally stumbled on the truth, he has only recently begun to receive proper credit, a good example of this being The Spice Islands Voyage (Little Brown, 1997), Tim Severin's account of how he traced Wallace's second great journey round Indonesia. Now we have two more: an elegant volume on Wallace's early career by Sandy Knapp, a Natural History Museum expert on South American botany; and a lavish, coffee-table tome on his later journeys by conservationists Gavan Daws and Marty Fujita.

Each neatly complements the other. For example, Knapp quickly demolishes the notion that Wallace was somehow lucky. From the outset of his voyaging, he recorded his desire to solve 'the problem of [the] origin of species', not an easy task for an uneducated lad from Usk, in Monmouthshire, the eighth child of a failed businessman. First Wallace had to educate himself (in reading rooms and at evening classes), later becoming a teacher and finally a land surveyor before using a £100 pay-off to finance his 1848 trip to South America.

In the Amazon, he drew superb maps and magnificent depictions of the fauna and flora, collected rare species, and constantly asked himself fundamental biological questions. 'What are the circumstances which render certain rivers and mountain ranges the limits of numerous species, while others not? What physical features determine the boundaries of species?' Wallace wrote in his notebooks. This was a young man with evolution on his mind.

The work was intellectually exhilarating but dangerous. Wallace blew part of his hand off in a gun accident and was plagued by insects and vampire bats. After four years, he had had enough, and set off home, with cases of specimens, monkeys, and a menagerie of parrots, macaws, and a toucan. In mid-Atlantic, the brig Helen caught fire and everyone took to the boats. Of his goods, only two notebooks and a parrot survived. 'I had not one specimen to illustrate the unknown lands I had trod,' he recalled.

Knapp imbues her narrative with authority and tells her tale with admirably brevity, crisscrossing her account with abundant quotes from Wallace's letters and drawings from his two surviving notebooks. However, the lack of an adequate map is confusing and the absence of an index unhelpful.

By contrast, Daws and Fujita's book is a vivid offering - filled with glorious modern photographs of the Indonesian islands and a succinct text - that satisfies both eye and intellect. Wallace arrived in the Malay Archipelago in 1854, unbowed and determined, and 'surrounded by wild nature and uncultured man' continued to ponder the Big Question. In Sarawak, he realised half the answer: 'Every species has come into existence coincident both in space and time with a pre-existing, closely allied species.' But he was still short of understanding how such species emerged from their predecessors.

The final breakthrough came in 1858, on Gilolo. Afflicted once more by malaria, Wallace lay shivering in his tiny tent when he realised that similar forces - that is, sickness - must be even more strongly at work among animals, selecting the strong for survival, the weak for death. This skews the nature of future generations. He had found the key to the origin of species and, still in an 'ague fit', sketched out a paper which he posted to Darwin.

The letter arrived on 18 June, 1858 like a thunderbolt, for Darwin had also been pondering a similar notion. In the end, a joint reading of papers was arranged. 'But what if Wallace, instead of sending his paper to Darwin, had sent it to a journal in London to be published?' ask Daws and Fujita. And what about those discrepancies in dates and postings that lead some academics to suggest Darwin received Wallace's manuscript much earlier and plagiarised it? Whatever else, it is clear the great evolutionary biologist Ernst Mayr is right when he says: 'Whenever one speaks of natural selection, one ought to mention both Darwin and Wallace.'

But we don't - partly because Wallace was cripplingly shy and 'nobly selfless'; partly because we seem able only to accommodate heroes in singletons; and partly because of our ignorance of the man. This latter flaw is the one that can most easily be corrected, as Daws and Fujita argue. While their book is a magnificent scene-setter, the authors acknowledge that we now desperately need a major biography of Wallace 'not just as a scientist but as a figure of his times'. And as the historian Jane Camerini puts it: 'Wallace deserves to be known, not just as a disembodied thinker, but as a man worth knowing for his Victorian goodness.'

fields.headline: A Gothic gem
fields.standfirst: Stephanie Merritt relishes more than the intricately constructed plot of Charles Palliser's murder-mystery The Unburied
fields.trailText: Stephanie Merritt relishes more than the intricately constructed plot of Charles Palliser's murder-mystery The Unburied
fields.body:
The Unburied
Charles Palliser
Phoenix House, £6.99, pp448
Buy it at BOL

The wintry, melancholic landscape and Gothic backdrop of an M.R. James story; an ancient, unsolved murder; academic and ecclesiastical rivalries; lost manuscripts; hidden corpses; hints at restless spirits prowling damp, shadowy cloisters - Charles Palliser's second novel appears at first glance to have all the ingredients of a rollicking Victorian ghost story. Despite its supernatural overtures, however, it turns out to be far more subtle - a suspenseful murder-mystery with a plot as intricate and complex as the machinery of a pocket watch.

As the nineteenth century draws to a close, Dr Ned Courtine arrives one Christmas in the dreary, chill cathedral town of Thurchester to visit his former university friend, Austin Fickling, a schoolmaster. Courtine and Fickling have not spoken for 20 years after an enigmatic rift, but Courtine hopes the visit will renew their previous affection. Fickling appears anxious, gaunt and consumed with existential guilt. To deflect Courtine's questions, he recounts the story of Thurchester's ghost, William Burgoyne, a royalist and treasurer of the cathedral, murdered in the aftermath of the Civil War.

Courtine's imagination is captured by the tale and as he pursues his own quest for an eleventh-century manuscript he believes to be hidden in the dean's library, so he becomes increasingly fascinated by the ancient murder and its links to one of the houses in the cathedral close, now home to Mr Stonex, an elderly miser. Courtine is surprised to receive an invitation to tea with the old man, together with Austin Fickling, and yet more surprised when, shortly after they leave the tea party, Stonex is discovered brutally murdered.

Hidden clues abound to both mysteries, yet Palliser teases out the suspense until the very last. Even at the conclusion of Courtine's account, Stonex's murderer has still not been revealed, although the reader can continue to piece together the allusions and hazard a guess. Like another historical murder mystery, Eco's The Name of the Rose, Courtine's account is presented as having been discovered in a manuscript. This is only opened after his death, and edited with an all-important epilogue by a character who, at the very last, proves to have a pivotal role in the Stonex murder.

Palliser has clearly immersed himself in Wilkie Collins and M.R. James, for his pastiche is as faultless here as it was in his previous novel, The Quincunx. The Unburied is much more, however, than clever literary mimicry; not only a gripping story but a thoughtful meditation on metaphysics, history and human passions.

Like another historical murder mystery, Eco's The Name of the Rose, Courtine's account is presented as having been discovered in a manuscript. This is only opened after his death, and edited with an all-important epilogue by a character who, at the very last, proves to have a pivotal role in the Stonex murder. Palliser has clearly immersed himself in Wilkie Collins and M.R. James, for his pastiche is as faultless here as it was in his previous novel, The Quincunx. The Unburied is much more, however, than clever literary mimicry; not only a gripping story but a thoughtful meditation on metaphysics, history and human passions.

fields.headline: Nirvana? No, Nevada
fields.standfirst: In Nevada David Thomson finds pigs in military uniform, fake volcanoes and nuclear fallout... thank goodness for one-armed bandits
fields.trailText: In Nevada David Thomson finds pigs in military uniform, fake volcanoes and nuclear fallout... thank goodness for one-armed bandits
fields.body:
In Nevada: the Land, The People, God and Chance
David Thomson
Little, Brown, £20, pp380

As a film critic, David Thomson is a noctambule, who long ago exchanged the healthy daylight for the silvery, lunar glimmer of a screening room. One of his early books on the cinema was called America in the Dark. More than a reviewer, he is a metaphysician of the movies, both enchanted and alarmed by an art which replaces reality with fantasy.

Now, impelled by these anxious scruples, he has emerged, blinking, into the light. In Nevada is a travel book in which Thomson overexposes himself to the glare of the blistering desert sun and to the cold frenzy of a neon galaxy in Las Vegas. He even remembers the searing alternative sun which exploded in Nevada in 1945, when the atom bomb was tested: scientists thought they could shield themselves from radiation by wearing goggles and smearing suntan lotion on their faces.

Returning to the open air, Thomson does not quite manage to rejoin reality. This is America after all, where truth always defers to the allurements of fiction. The earliest and most fervently sublime tributes to the landscape of Nevada were written by the explorer Fremont and his daughter Jessie, neither of whom had ever been there: American romanticism, as Thomson says in analysing their rhetoric, 'has always had one hand on its own pulse and one eye on the movie rights'.

Thomson too, though he has travelled intrepidly up and down the state, finds himself inside a film. What he has written is a road movie - a picaresque and paranoid tour of lonely highways where the car behind you could be driven by a maniac with a private cache of anthrax, while if you look off to the salt flats beside the road you might see the vapour trail left by 'something we would have to call a vehicle, or even a car' as it hurtles through the sound barrier.

Nevada is a region of tall tales and outlandish myths. Even geographically, it seems unreal. Despite the desert, it gets its name from its snowy mountains. Its heights are incongruous, and its depths are mind-boggling: Nevadan lore maintains that Lake Tahoe is bottomless, with a cosmic abyss at its deepest point. One of the Las Vegas casinos boasts a scenic volcano, which playfully spits lava and coughs up styrofoam boulders every hour. For bomb tests during the Fifties, spurious landscapes were constructed and populated so that they could be destroyed at the moment of ignition: the scientists planted pine forests in concrete tubs, and outfitted pigs - stand-ins for human victims - in miniature military uniforms.

Las Vegas and the nuclear proving ground are both 'experimental places'. It's somehow not surprising to discover that the test site, still viciously toxic, describes itself as an 'Environmental Research Park', or that the air base has chosen 'Dreamland' as its call sign.

Extraterrestrials - according to local rumour - chose the state during the Fifties as a colonial base. For miners during the gold rush, it was an earthly paradise of precious metals; deluded seekers still go there in quest of enrichment, though rather than digging into the bedrock they shake hands with the one-armed bandits in the casinos, awaiting a pay-out.

As an adoptive American, Thomson (a Londoner now living in San Francisco) sympathises with these great expectations and with the credulity which powers them: 'I believe in very little except those who believe in stories. It is enough, and story is an arc of hope.' He even challenges God to do the same, licensing men to find heaven on earth. If there is gold in the ground, why shouldn't a high-roller be able to beat the house in Las Vegas?

The casino with the sportive volcano is called the Mirage, and Nevada itself often looks to Thomson like a shimmering illusion, a play of deceptive and dangerous light. It demonstrates conclusively that the movies can be bad for you, even fatal: one of Thomson's best yarns is about the filming of The Conqueror, in which John Wayne preposterously impersonated Genghis Khan - an absurd piece of trash yet also a tragic document, since the location was so close to the Plutonium Valley test site that almost half the cast and crew of 220 people subsequently died of cancer.

Thomson admires the fortitude and grace of the Hoover Dam, whose curved membrane of concrete defies the desert and makes a 'great, bold, simple and lovely human assertion'. But he is also obliged to admit that the state's next 'most beautiful man-made thing' is a monument to human destructiveness: the 'bleak wonder' of the crater left behind when a bomb blast in 1962 dislodged 12 million tons of earth - the Grand Canyon of the nuclear age. Thomson finds Nevada both beautiful and terrible, and he does it justice in his surreal and scary book.

webTitle: Love and philosophy with a pinch of salt

fields.headline: Love and philosophy with a pinch of salt
fields.standfirst: Warwick Collins' impressive The Marriage Of Souls explores the eighteenth century through the old story of boy meets girl
fields.trailText: Warwick Collins' impressive The Marriage Of Souls explores the eighteenth century through the old story of boy meets girl
fields.body:
The Marriage Of Souls
Warwick Collins
Weidenfeld & Nicholson, £16.99, pp482
Buy it at BOL

Every now and then, a writer emerges who just gets better and better. These are the really exciting ones to encounter. Their novels carry the promise of so much more to come. Warwick Collins is one such writer. He is the author of several novels and each has been an extraordinary improvement on the last. The Rationalist marked Collins out as a writer who would be able to challenge the supremacy of Hilary Mantel, Rose Tremain and Ferdinand Mount. The Marriage of Souls confirms that he has arrived.

The Marriage of Souls, like The Rationalist, is an exploration of humanist philosophy wrapped between the delicate leaves of an eighteenth-century tale. The story of the two novels - and they should be read as a two-volume work - centres around the old war-horse of boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy finds girl. But what a boy and what a girl.

The Marriage of Souls is set in Lymington, on the Solent. The year is 1798. The French Revolution and its aftermath has filled the town with hundreds of French émigrés who bring with them money and foreign ways. The salt furnaces provide wealth and jobs but they destroy those who work in them. Although the town is picturesque, the forces maintaining it are dangerous and uncontrollable.

The novel begins with the disappointing information that the future happiness and reconciliation promised in The Rationalist failed to materialise. Silas Grange, the Scottish doctor who would prefer to live and die by David Hume, has suffered a mental and physical collapse. Mrs Celia Quill, the enigmatic stranger who seemed poised to unlock the constraints around his rational heart, has departed suddenly and without trace. Dr Hargood, Grange's best friend and mentor, carries inside him the burden of guilt and knowledge.

What makes The Marriage of Souls such a wonderful book is Collins's intricate reconstruction of the late eighteenth-century world. Simplicity and philosophy are the hallmarks of eighteenth-century art and architecture. The classically pure lines look deceptively simple and unburdened by heavy symbolism or imagery. But the unique accessibility of the eighteenth-century mind belies a complex and sophisticated philosophical framework. This is the essence of The Marriage of Souls.

The irony is that there are few eighteenth-century novels which succeed in capturing the eighteenth century as well as some twentieth-century writers can do today. The average eighteenth-century novel is, of course, of its time, but that is not the same thing as being able to capture the time. Fanny Burney's Evelina exemplifies the former, Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice exemplifies the latter. The same goes for the modern novel. Some novels simply emerge with the Zeitgeist, others shine a beacon of light across society. Today, we are fortunate that the historical novel has reached such extraordinary heights of technical mastery. The ability of society to connect with the past holds out the greatest hope for it being able to embrace the future.

The only criticism of The Marriage of Souls is that, like The Rationalist, the female characters receive less of the author's passion than the male. The men are fascinating, deep and sympathetic. The women do not sparkle or breathe with the same humanity. However, apart from this small caveat, The Marriage of Souls is a must read. The pacing is superb and the subplots ingenious. Lymington itself, with its foundry works belching fire and smoke, has never been so lovingly portrayed. Each street and house has its own character; even the sounds of Lymington resonate in the words.

The novel exudes a vibrancy and an embrace for life. The tragedy within the novel is that Silas Grange cannot feel it until it is almost too late.

fields.headline: Short, but not sweet
fields.standfirst: Tim Adams takes up the challenge posed by Tibor Fischer's new collection of stories, Don't Read This Book If You're Stupid
fields.trailText: Tim Adams takes up the challenge posed by Tibor Fischer's new collection of stories, Don't Read This Book If You're Stupid
fields.body:
Don't Read This Book If You're Stupid
Tibor Fischer
Secker & Warburg, £10, pp250

In one of these stories, Tibor Fischer's narrator works part-time as a book reviewer (his full-time occupation is a personal quest to read every book ever written in English: to guarantee maximum efficiency, he devours them two at a time - in his right hand Three Weeks in Mopetown, in his left If I Were God). 'A book to review,' he notes flatly, 'that would be 300 words saying what it was like and 300 words saying what it wasn't like: fine.'

If you were to apply the same critical technique to Fischer's own collection, you would probably note that these stories read a lot like Martin Amis subplots: the terrain of minor Keith Talents and Nicola Sixes, whose currency is apocalyptic metaphor and deadpan hyperbole. 'London wasn't a city,' Jim, former bag-carrier, drink-buyer and taxi-caller for small-time gangsters, flourishes. 'It was a war.'

Or (pondering the big questions): 'Death wouldn't be cocky. Wouldn't be a dandy... Death would be the last to be picked at football. Death would have a peanut-sized dick... Death would take the bus and not make any interesting comments in the queue...'

What they are not like is most of contemporary British short fiction. Fischer invests acutely in the comic surface of his tales, which tend to start in misery and hurtle blackly towards despair. He packs more scabrous one-liners into a paragraph than many thirtysomething novelists manage in a book.

In the most ambitious of the stories - 'We Ate the Chef' (which takes Jim, now a wannabe dot.com mogul, on holiday to the French Riviera with investment bankers) or 'Then they say you're drunk' (the extended soul dredging of Guy, south London's least lucky solicitor's rep) or 'I Like Being Killed' (the murderous fall from grace of a sex-obsessed, stand-up comedienne) - he sustains a level of savage invention that makes Irvine Welsh seem like Joanna Trollope.

The collection bears the authentic voice of the vacuous Nineties, a kind of Canterbury Tales for 'defuckers of computers' and the employees of consultancies that consist of 'a designer, a goatee beard and a school leaver'. It revels in the absurdities of the century's fag-end decade.

In one story, a conceptual artist ('failurist') overcomes the difficulties presented by his nonentity name - John Smith - to persuade a dealer to take him on: 'I began to look for a new medium to conquer and it took me only 45 minutes to create a whole new art form...'

He christens his new art form the Grabby - it consists of fragments of impossible conversations overheard in pubs and interrupted by the artist. Thus to a man about to be posted to Plovdiv, Bulgaria, he explains that he 'lived there for two years' and enthuses about the quality of the cooking and the beauty of the scenery; to a gay beefburger scientist he argues that fat can be beautiful. 'A Grabby isn't a porky,' he confides; 'it's a personalised fabulation, a bespoke tale.'

The idea is a neat metaphor for Fischer's own method - the bespoke tales here are real enough to have been dreamt up by drunks and surreal enough to ring almost entirely true. As the book's title might have had it, you'd be stupid not to read them.

webTitle: Why A team should have more to do

fields.headline: Why A team should have more to do
fields.standfirst: Vic Marks says the shadow Test squad should have a range of fixtures in the English summer as well
fields.trailText: In the wake of a numbing defeat, the trawl for some fresh players begins. Vic Marks says the shadow Test squad should have a range of fixtures in the English summer as well.
fields.body:
In the wake of a numbing defeat, the trawl for some fresh players begins. So where do we start the search? Logically with the A team. After all, 11 from the original party of 17 chosen for the South African tour have arrived via this route. The exceptions are Stewart and Tufnell, who are too old for A tours (the first was in 1989-90); Mullally and Tudor, who somehow skipped them, although Tudor will doubtless have to go back to finishing school after his anonymous senior tour this winter; and Adams and Hamilton, presumably because they were never thought to be good enough.

Read the reports and the A team seems to be the ideal nursery for English cricketers. England are uniquely successful at this level. They have not lost a first-class match since the one that began on 1 January 1994 in Durban. Then Natal, led by Malcolm Marshall and including little gems like Shaun Pollock and Lance Klusener, defeated them by an innings. (This is a slightly bogus statistic since the A side lost a four-day game against New South Wales B in 1996, but it was deemed by the Australian Cricket Board not to be a first-class fixture.)

So, since 1994 the England A team have become the modern invincibles and the provocateurs of some purple prose. For example, the Benson and Hedges Cricket Year book reports that the side that toured Zimbabwe and South Africa last winter had 'an unquenchable will to win; a team spirit whereby the whole is truly more than the sum of the parts... the players showed all the qualities for which the full Test team has striven for so long while finding them so elusive'. David Graveney must have taken note. From that A side, Vaughan, Flintoff, Maddy, Read, Swann and Solanki currently find themselves in South Africa with the senior team.

It was just the same in Australia in 1996-97. 'This team', we read in Wisden , 'did not wilt at the first whiff of cordite. Instead adversity gelled them into a spirited fighting unit.' On that tour the stars, soon to be promoted, were Mark Butcher and Dean Headley. Two years earlier, after an expedition to India, we could boast of 'a clutch of young players bursting with talent, character and naked ambition' ( Wisden ). These included Mark Ramprakash, Dominic Cork and Ian Salisbury. The team that lost in Durban six years ago, nonetheless, had an 'unreservedly successful tour'. All except two went on to play Test cricket (the unfortunates were Mal Loye and Adrian Dale), though ominously Darren Gough is the only one who still does.

Clearly we have to be wary of this success story. The concept of A tours and A teams is a good one, but we obviously take them a little more seriously than some of our international counterparts. One example: in 1996-97, the A team defeated South Australia in Adelaide in a closely fought match by 12 runs. However, that victory was tarnished slightly by the fact that Darren Lehmann, the opposition's best batsman, was absent during South Australia's second innings , 'having been called away to undertake promotional work for the Australian Cricket Board'.

Without wishing to denigrate any of the performances of successive A tourists, it seems clear that these expeditions are relatively cosy affairs compared to the senior tours. By and large, the matches are watched by three men and a dog unless you happen to be in one of the 'lesser' countries like Bangladesh. The A tours attract a small, friendly press corps - unlike the senior tour - who are eager to be supportive and to get to know potential stars of the future. And sometimes the opposition are not too taxing; indeed it would probably be more beneficial if the A team lost more frequently. (The gurus keep telling us that we learn more from defeat than victory.)

The plateau created by the professional status of the game in England means that there are probably more reasonably good cricketers in this country than in any other. If a World Third XI competition were instigated, there's a fair chance that England would win it (OK you Aussies, start writing). Part of the problem is that the A tours do not syphon out the moderate also-rans ruthlessly enough. Selection for an A tour leaves a player with a better than 50 per cent chance of a senior cap, yet far too many of these players finish their international careers with no more than three or four caps to their name. They are soon found wanting at Test level and discarded. We need to be able to discover those limitations when they are in the A side.

So how can we improve our nursery? It would help us if the status of these tours was enhanced, especially in Australia . On two A tours there, England have yet to be granted a fixture against an Australian A side. But to improve the chances of other countries improving the A team schedules, England may be required to make some sacrifices of their own, which brings us back to familiar territory: the county club versus country conflict.

If the A team really are the means to advance the progress of our potential Test cricketers, then they should have a range of fixtures in the English summer as well. In the past they have had a meaningless match at the beginning of April against the County Champions, in which every player is clad in half a dozen sweaters.

It would, however, be possible for an A team fixture against the tourists to become the 'sixth' Test match - or the 'third' in the case of Zimbabwe this summer. The counties are constantly criticised for putting out sub-standard XIs against the tourists, why not field A teams three or four times a season against the tourists and visiting A sides instead? This would only be worthwhile if every county cricketer was available for selection for these games, not just those who have a break in their county schedule.

The counties, I can assure you, would detest this suggestion. Already they are losing their Test players for unprecedentedly large chunks of the season; they would not be happy to sacrifice their A team players as well. However hostility from the counties does not necessarily make this a poor idea.

Clearly we have to be wary of this success story. The concept of A tours and A teams is a good one, but we obviously take them a little more seriously than some of our international counterparts. One example: in 1996-97, the A team defeated South Australia in Adelaide in a closely fought match by 12 runs. However, that victory was tarnished slightly by the fact that Darren Lehmann, the opposition's best batsman, was absent during South Australia's second innings , 'having been called away to undertake promotional work for the Australian Cricket Board'. Without wishing to denigrate any of the performances of successive A tourists, it seems clear that these expeditions are relatively cosy affairs compared to the senior tours. By and large, the matches are watched by three men and a dog unless you happen to be in one of the 'lesser' countries like Bangladesh. The A tours attract a small, friendly press corps - unlike the senior tour - who are eager to be supportive and to get to know potential stars of the future. And sometimes the opposition are not too taxing; indeed it would probably be more beneficial if the A team lost more frequently. (The gurus keep telling us that we learn more from defeat than victory.) The plateau created by the professional status of the game in England means that there are probably more reasonably good cricketers in this country than in any other. If a World Third XI competition were instigated, there's a fair chance that England would win it (OK you Aussies, start writing). Part of the problem is that the A tours do not syphon out the moderate also-rans ruthlessly enough. Selection for an A tour leaves a player with a better than 50 per cent chance of a senior cap, yet far too many of these players finish their international careers with no more than three or four caps to their name. They are soon found wanting at Test level and discarded. We need to be able to discover those limitations when they are in the A side. So how can we improve our nursery? It would help us if the status of these tours was enhanced, especially in Australia . On two A tours there, England have yet to be granted a fixture against an Australian A side. But to improve the chances of other countries improving the A team schedules, England may be required to make some sacrifices of their own, which brings us back to familiar territory: the county club versus country conflict. If the A team really are the means to advance the progress of our potential Test cricketers, then they should have a range of fixtures in the English summer as well. In the past they have had a meaningless match at the beginning of April against the County Champions, in which every player is clad in half a dozen sweaters. It would, however, be possible for an A team fixture against the tourists to become the 'sixth' Test match - or the 'third' in the case of Zimbabwe this summer. The counties are constantly criticised for putting out sub-standard XIs against the tourists, why not field A teams three or four times a season against the tourists and visiting A sides instead? This would only be worthwhile if every county cricketer was available for selection for these games, not just those who have a break in their county schedule. The counties, I can assure you, would detest this suggestion. Already they are losing their Test players for unprecedentedly large chunks of the season; they would not be happy to sacrifice their A team players as well. However hostility from the counties does not necessarily make this a poor idea.

fields.headline: The natives get nasty
fields.trailText: Arise Graeme Hick, England captain. Indeed, 'tis true - the game's original comeback kid will lead the men from Mud Island against an invitation XI at St George's Park today. Telford Vice reports from Port Elizabeth.
fields.body:
Arise Graeme Hick, England captain. Indeed, 'tis true - the game's original comeback kid will lead the men from Mud Island against an invitation XI at St George's Park today.

The three-day match is an assignment that teams who have lost a Test series early could do without. Except that England have rested their dead men walking from the Kingsmead stalemate and the Newlands checkmate. So Hick, himself a new addition to this tour, will captain a side who will carry only physical baggage into the dressing room.

Anything else would have been cruel and inhuman punishment of an England touring party that seems to be running on empty with a Test match, at least six one-day internationals and another tour match - a sure to be dreary affair against minnows North West under perhaps the only lights in the permanently Prozac-stricken Afrikaner town of Potchefstroom - still to be played.

Evidence of England's flagging spirit was there for all to see in the hotel bar hours after what became the final day at Newlands. More than just the disappointment of defeat, their faces hung with despair at another tour, another Test series, gone sour. By the look of some of them, it could have been one series too many. Seldom, if indeed ever, has Phil Tufnell glared out of a pub - a pub for goodness sake, Tuffers - with such an obvious 'wish-I-was-somewhere-bloody-else' look about his steadily greening gills. Michael Atherton roamed the place like a moose with a migraine.

Some of the South Africans among the bar's patrons were quick to sense the mood and, with all the gracelessness they could muster, they lapsed into a muffled refrain of, 'You're so shite it's unbelievable' - a vicious echo of the Barmy Army's 'We're so rich it's unbelievable'.

Kepler Wessels, in his newspaper column, put it more articulately but no less harshly. Having praised the efforts of Michael Vaughan, Wessels wrote, 'There are just too many players in this team who are not up to the job. Chris Adams plays with so much bottom hand that his early dismissal against top quality bowlers is almost inevitable... One would feel more sorry for him if he didn't have so much to say. If you want to shout the odds then you have to be able to do the job as well. So far he has only been good at the former. Andrew Flintoff, now injured, is so ordinary that I cannot believe it... Nasser Hussain tried hard to sound like a cricketing General Patton in the wake of the Cape Town thumping, spitting the odd "you lot" at the gathered press and an occasional "bloody" into their thirsty microphones. Thing is, Patton won a few.'

Wouldn't it be nasty if Hick went out and did just that in Port Elizabeth. Unbelievable, in fact.

fields.headline: Shoaib back in the swing
fields.trailText: The International Cricket Council yesterday allowed Pakistani fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar to play in a triangular one-day cricket series involving Australia, India and Pakistan. Kamran Abbasi reports on how the ICC has once again been found woefully lacking in dealing adequately with a major controversy.
fields.body:
The International Cricket Council yesterday allowed Pakistani fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar to play in a triangular one-day cricket series involving Australia, India and Pakistan.

Last month, the ICC banned Shoaib for using an illegal bowling action. Pakistan appealed against the ICC illegal bowling committee's ruling

The ICC advisory panel reviewed the video footage on Shoaib's bowling action and felt that he had problems with his action while bowling a bouncer, Jagmohan Dalmiya, the ICC president, told reporters in Calcutta.

'Since bouncers are not used in one-day cricket, as these are called no balls, it would be best to permit Shoaib to play for Pakistan in the triangular series, while continuing with the remedial coaching to be conducted by the Pakistan Cricket Board,' Dalmiya said.

The triangular series begins in Australia today.

Dalmiya said he took the decision in consultations with Sir Clyde Walcott, chairman of the ICC cricket committee.

He also said video footage will be taken of Shoaib's bowling action during the series under the supervision of international referee Cammie Smith.

The ICC panel would have a second review of Akhter's bowling action prior to Pakistan-Sri Lanka Test series beginning in Pakistan next month. 'An umpire is always at liberty to apply the law if he feels any bowler is not delivering the ball correctly,' Dalmiya said.

Shoaib will be mightily relieved as both his international career, and his £125,000 Nottinghamshire contract, are dangling precariously. He was banned for throwing by the ICC's advisory panel on illegal deliveries on 30 December.

The whole affair has been a huge embarrassment for the ICC, who have turned cricket's most exciting find of 1999 into a villain. Pakistan's appeal rested on the circumstances surrounding last month's hearing.

Pakistan had asked for the hearing to take place four days earlier before the party left for Australia and because their representative, Imran Khan, would only be available on that day. The ICC refused to change the date and Imran's replacement, Intikhab Alam, was not allowed to attend as the national team coach. The Pakistanis had not been informed that Intikhab would be excluded.

Once again the ICC has been found woefully lacking in dealing adequately with a major controversy.

fields.headline: Hussain lacks men of Steele
fields.standfirst: A gamble on a greying county act has dire legacy
fields.trailText: Vic Marks England's capitulation at Newlands was a painful reversion to Old England, hapless and spineless; the sort of performance that must cheer the Zimbabweans, England's next Test opponents, who are eager to hand over the wooden spoon of international cricket.
fields.body:
You should not be surprised that England trail 2-0 after four Tests against South Africa, but you are allowed to feel disappointed, dejected even, at the manner of their defeat in Cape Town. South Africa are obviously the superior team, expected to win, but the capitulation at Newlands was a painful reversion to Old England, hapless and spineless; the sort of performance that must cheer the Zimbabweans, England's next Test opponents, who are eager to hand over the wooden spoon of international cricket.

The familiar trigger reactions after another English Test walloping soon surfaced: there were the laments about a soft county game, the perils of the benefit system, poor pitches, staffs too big, hearts too small. All valid points. Then comes the demand to toss in the youngsters, any youngsters. That, too, is a perfectly reasonable reaction (indeed, my sports editor has just suggested this). Why not catapult Vikram Solanki, newly arrived in South Africa after a successful A tour, in to the team for the Fifth Test? Send for Chris Schofield; he bowls out of the back of the hand, doesn't he? What have you got to lose?

Solanki and Schofield may be fine cricketers; they may both be future Test cricketers. Let's hope so. But - and I know you sensed a 'but' coming along - an important point about selection needs to be hammered out before handing out Test caps to 23-year-olds who have suddenly become the flavour of the month.

The selection of a debutant is the start of a long process; it dictates selectorial strategy not for five days, but for a season. That initial assessment of the talent and temperament of potential debutants is critical, since its consequences linger for so long. Get it wrong and the whole process is tangled up for months to come. Once selected, those debutantes deserve time and patience. The wait has to be worthwhile.

Over the past year or two too many of these selectorial punts have not worked. Often their failure can be put down to what we may call 'The David Steele Syndrome'. Twenty-five years ago Tony Greig plucked that craggy yet charismatic artisan out of county cricket to take on Dennis Lillee and Jeff Thomson. The gamble worked spectacularly. Steele, who went on to average 42 in his eight Test matches, was embraced by the public as affectionately as the Dad's Army characters he resembled. He was the BBC's Sports Personality of the Year (try to imagine a cricketer winning that trophy now).

Ever since then selectors have sought to repeat that masterstroke - plucking out a county stalwart and tossing him to Test cricket - to no avail. Steele was the exception. In the Eighties they tried Chris Cowdrey and Tim Curtis, and moving into the Nineties there were Rob Bailey and Richard Blakey. In 1998 it was Steve James. Last summer they suddenly plumped for Aftab Habib, even though he had never been chosen for an A tour.

Habib, 27, was undoubtedly talented, but even his own coach queried whether he had the toughness for Test cricket. Unfortunately for Habib the experiment lasted for only two Tests but the about-turn in selection policy when he was dropped caused a major Hick-inspired ruckus and the sudden abandonment of Gatting and Gooch as selectors.

Then at the end of the 1999 English season the mandarins at Lord's demanded a change of personnel from the selectors. So they plucked out Chris Adams to start a Test career at the age of 29. No questions asked about his toughness; he was picked for his 'character'. But the sad fact is that you can possess the most positive and combative of characters and find it of limited value sitting in the pavilion having nicked another drive into the slip cordon. The Adams experiment had to last at least four Tests and may continue for the entire series. In all probability it has been a waste of time. Gavin Hamilton, another never selected for an A tour, was another trigger reaction based on 'character', though he was ditched after one disastrous Test.

So far the selectors are in serious debit. Admittedly the process of selection is trickier than it was two decades ago. Then, if you wanted to assess the quality of a county batsman you could go to Southampton or Bristol or Nottingham and watch him bat against Malcolm Marshall or Courtney Walsh or Richard Hadlee and Clive Rice. If the batsman could handle them, then you knew he had a chance at Test level. The presence of so many quality overseas bowlers enhanced the selection process and the quality of our batsmen.

However, the current selectors can claw back a little credibility in their choices of Michael Vaughan and Andrew Flintoff. By most international standards this pair has performed modestly in South Africa, but there is something there. Vaughan looks composed and has batted for a long time in this series; Flintoff hasn't, but he excites during the brief periods that he remains at the crease. Both should start in the Test team in May. These are our investments for the future, but we cannot afford to have many more novices in our Test side at the same time and realistically expect to win.

The selection for the final Test of this series at Centurion Park becomes something of a mish-mash. Darren Maddy will presumably play so we have a chance to learn a little more about him. Hamilton may yet get a reprieve as a replacement for Flintoff who will be in plaster for the next month. Graeme Swann, who seems to have spent three months in South Africa to satisfy the ECB's September PR requirements ('Look, we have farsightedly included two 21-year olds' - Swann and Chris Read) would be understandably furious if Solanki leap-frogged him now.

Of more interest and significance will be the make-up of the first Test side of next summer and something remarkable will have to happen at Centurion this week if Mark Butcher and Adams are in it. I have a weakness for picking the best players so have not written off Mark Ramprakash, average 40 in his last stint as an England player, though I like the idea of considering him as an opening batsman. Elevation in the batting order worked spectacularly for Gooch and Amiss, who both had nightmarish starts to their Test careers. There can be less pressure at number one than six. David Graveney should encourage him to open the batting for Middlesex in April, if their new captain, Justin Langer, permits.

Nor would I blackball Gra ham Thorpe because he chose not to tour. By opting out this winter, Thorpe trod the same path as some stalwart heavyweights of the past - Botham, Gooch and Boycott, for example. He has to earn his return though in the current climate that should not be too difficult. Far better for Thorpe to have made his decision in August last year than to have moped around South Africa this winter, wishing he was somewhere else.

These two are potential replacements for Butcher and Adams; their experience should allow Vaughan and Flintoff some freedom to continue their development as Test cricketers. Then the nucleus of seamers could be augmented by Tufnell or Swann or Schofield or even, as a batting all-rounder, Solanki - but only after detailed research and debate, not as a desperate, populist reaction to public opinion and the latest cock-up.

webTitle: Taxes, certainly - but on all our houses

fields.headline: Taxes, certainly - but on all our houses
fields.trailText: The recent controversy about the European Union's proposed withholding tax on interest payments is only one in a growing number of problems of international tax harmonisation, not only in Europe, but across the globe.
fields.body:
The recent controversy about the European Union's proposed withholding tax on interest payments is only one in a growing number of problems of international tax harmonisation, not only in Europe, but across the globe.

The withholding tax debate may be somewhat obscure, but most people are aware of at least one instance where the lack of tax harmonisation is anomalous - when they load up their cars with wine as they come back from their holidays in France. In a common market, sales taxes in neighbouring states cannot in the end differ too markedly without perpetuating such distortions. But it is easy to understand the British government's reluctance to reduce its dependence on such a major and long-standing source of revenue as our high rates of tax on alcohol.

What is more difficult to understand is the Government's proposed introduction of swingeing energy taxes on British industries, such as steel, at potentially much higher levels than their overseas or continental competitors. With CO² emissions a global issue, it seems particularly inappropriate to attempt to tackle it in this uncoordinated fashion.

Such unilateral action is liable to divert demand from British companies to other steel producers, which in some cases will be more serious sources of pollution.

The Government has already begun to realise the danger of this approach by reducing its original proposed rates of taxation and increasing the rebates offered: if the negotiated energy targets are met, companies will get a rebate of 80 per cent - an interesting case of taxation by negotiation! But the clear moral is that such taxes make sense only if levied on a uniform regional or global basis.

It seems strange that a Labour government should have given so little prior thought to the dangers of imposing fresh taxation on industries such as steel, already struggling with low prices and a strong pound, but prove so sensitive to the possible effects on London Eurobond dealers of clamping down on tax evasion by investors in these securities. There is obviously some validity in the Government's argument that imposing a withholding tax, or enforcing an exchange of information, might lead the market to relocate outside the EU; but the moral is that this is a case for tax harmonisation on a global basis, not that the UK government should defend the use of the London market as a respectable tax haven.

Regional tax harmonisation may be sufficient for goods and services with appreciable transport costs, but when it comes to financial transactions, which may be carried out virtually anywhere in the world, harmonisation on a global basis will become increasingly necessary.

However narrow or broad the scope of such arrangements, we shall have to face up not only to the initial problems of negotiating the original agreements with a common tax rate and rules of the game, but also the fact that subsequent changes will depend on intergovernmental agreement.

This will require new institutional arrangements and new habits of thought. Some forms of 'national' taxation will take on an increasingly international dimension. So far we have been assuming that all taxes, even if imposed by international agreement, are raised for national purposes; but we are entering an era in which international taxes are needed for international purposes, such as development assistance, combating environmental pollution and peacekeeping.

The most long-standing candidate in this field is the so-called Tobin Tax, Professor James Tobin's 1972 proposal to levy a low rate of tax, say 0.1 per cent, on all foreign exchange transactions. This was originally conceived as a means of damping down speculative activity in currency markets, something even more desirable today than it was then. Recently it has come to the fore as a possible revenue raiser for international purposes, and is actively backed by organisations such as Oxfam.

Such a tax would need to cover all the main currency markets - and to give governments the incentive to participate they could keep part of the proceeds for national purposes. This would be particularly attractive to the UK, which covers a third of all such transactions.

Hitherto, sales of goods and services have been regarded as fair game for finance ministers, but sales of financial instruments have been left virtually untouched - in the cause of maximising liquidity. Recent financial crises have provided clear evidence, however, that there can be too much liquidity and thus speculative activity.

Foreign exchange transactions may not be the only field where low taxes may be a useful in avoiding excessive speculation. Just as the finance ministers (including Chancellor Gordon Brown), have become enthusiastic about 'green' taxes as a politically correct source of revenue, so other forms of taxation that would dampen down price fluctuations in financial markets may come into their own in the next decade.

 John Grieve Smith is a fellow of Robinson College, Cambridge.

The Government has already begun to realise the danger of this approach by reducing its original proposed rates of taxation and increasing the rebates offered: if the negotiated energy targets are met, companies will get a rebate of 80 per cent - an interesting case of taxation by negotiation! But the clear moral is that such taxes make sense only if levied on a uniform regional or global basis. It seems strange that a Labour government should have given so little prior thought to the dangers of imposing fresh taxation on industries such as steel, already struggling with low prices and a strong pound, but prove so sensitive to the possible effects on London Eurobond dealers of clamping down on tax evasion by investors in these securities. There is obviously some validity in the Government's argument that imposing a withholding tax, or enforcing an exchange of information, might lead the market to relocate outside the EU; but the moral is that this is a case for tax harmonisation on a global basis, not that the UK government should defend the use of the London market as a respectable tax haven. Regional tax harmonisation may be sufficient for goods and services with appreciable transport costs, but when it comes to financial transactions, which may be carried out virtually anywhere in the world, harmonisation on a global basis will become increasingly necessary. However narrow or broad the scope of such arrangements, we shall have to face up not only to the initial problems of negotiating the original agreements with a common tax rate and rules of the game, but also the fact that subsequent changes will depend on intergovernmental agreement. This will require new institutional arrangements and new habits of thought. Some forms of 'national' taxation will take on an increasingly international dimension. So far we have been assuming that all taxes, even if imposed by international agreement, are raised for national purposes; but we are entering an era in which international taxes are needed for international purposes, such as development assistance, combating environmental pollution and peacekeeping. The most long-standing candidate in this field is the so-called Tobin Tax, Professor James Tobin's 1972 proposal to levy a low rate of tax, say 0.1 per cent, on all foreign exchange transactions. This was originally conceived as a means of damping down speculative activity in currency markets, something even more desirable today than it was then. Recently it has come to the fore as a possible revenue raiser for international purposes, and is actively backed by organisations such as Oxfam. Such a tax would need to cover all the main currency markets - and to give governments the incentive to participate they could keep part of the proceeds for national purposes. This would be particularly attractive to the UK, which covers a third of all such transactions. Hitherto, sales of goods and services have been regarded as fair game for finance ministers, but sales of financial instruments have been left virtually untouched - in the cause of maximising liquidity. Recent financial crises have provided clear evidence, however, that there can be too much liquidity and thus speculative activity. Foreign exchange transactions may not be the only field where low taxes may be a useful in avoiding excessive speculation. Just as the finance ministers (including Chancellor Gordon Brown), have become enthusiastic about 'green' taxes as a politically correct source of revenue, so other forms of taxation that would dampen down price fluctuations in financial markets may come into their own in the next decade.  John Grieve Smith is a fellow of Robinson College, Cambridge.

fields.headline: Crash? What crash?
fields.trailText: In any normal market, it would be seen as a rout. In just four days, shares in Freeserve have fallen 20 per cent, despite better than expected quarterly figures; shares in Misys fell by almost a quarter, in QXL by 18 per cent. Even star-performing ARM Holdings is off 14 per cent.
fields.body:
In any normal market, it would be seen as a rout. In just four days, shares in Freeserve have fallen 20 per cent, despite better than expected quarterly figures; shares in Misys fell by almost a quarter, in QXL by 18 per cent. Even star-performing ARM Holdings is off 14 per cent.

Once, falls on that scale would have sparked a stampede for the exit. Now, investors just shrug their shoulders and see them as one more reason to pile into technology shares. The equanimity is partly because a correction was widely expected following the frenzy of buying in December - a frenzy caused largely by retail investors as most institutions stayed out of the market in the run-up to the milllennium.

Now, they are clearly being tempted to bank at least some of the profits on their holdings. Anyone who bought into the sector as little as a month ago is still sitting on handsome profits - and those who came in six months ago could have seen their holdings at least quadruple. The equanimity also reflects a change in attitudes to stock market investment following five years of double-digit rises in the FTSE 100.

Investors, both retail and institutional, may know the old adage that shares can go down as well as up, but they no longer really believe it. Their only concern is that they are on the latest bandwagon when it starts rolling. But signs of caution crept into the market last week.

Philip Wolstencroft, UK strategist with broker Merrill Lynch, is among the most bearish, but predicts the FTSE 100 index will end the year at 6,300 - more or less where it closed on Friday. Poor compared with recent years, but hardly a rout. He warns, however, that the risk is on the downside and he would not rule out a larger correction - although he says that, at anything below 5,900, 'shares would start to look cheap'. He believes share valuations are stretched, in absolute terms and compared with bonds, and that good news - like our fast economic growth and the buoyant US labour market - is bad for shares since interest rates may rise faster than expected. 'Individuals are very bullish.

In the US, retail investors are more bullish than they have ever been. If everyone else is bullish, it is often right to be bearish,' Wolstencroft says.

Interest rate worries were one of the key reasons for last week's correction - a growing number of economists think rates will have to rise by 0.25 or even 0.5 points this week.

Normally, that would make investors sell interest-rate sensitive stocks - brewers, retailers and leisure firms - and buy companies, such as telecoms and technology firms, that are expected to shrug off an economic slowdown. Last week, however, the reverse happened. While telecoms and technology shares languished, companies closest to the consumer rose.

Richard Jeffrey, head of strategy at Charterhouse Securities, thinks that is partly because these stocks are ridiculously cheap. But it is also because a rise in interest rates changes the arithmetic of technology stocks, making profits seem even more remote. That, he says, sparked realisation that 'on any serious model of profit growth for many of the telecoms and IT stocks, within a foreseeable time - and that can be as long as five or 10 years - they cannot earn profits large enough to sustain their current valuations. If interest rates are going to rise, that will exacerbate the problem.'

Technology stocks have been looking overvalued for months, yet hardly anyone will say so. Most investors echo Michael O'Sullivan, equity strategist with Warburg Dillon Read, who believes they are the future. That is undoubtedly true. The question is whether they are worth paying more than 100 times forecast sales (not profits), and whether the outlook for old-fashioned companies is so bleak that they are not worth any more than 10 times their earnings. Last week's trading suggests investors are starting to say no to both questions, but it will take more than four days before the answer is clear.

webTitle: Can't men live without a shoulder to cry on?

fields.headline: Can't men live without a shoulder to cry on?
fields.standfirst: Women now have a new burden - the depressed dad
fields.trailText: In case you haven't heard yet, the twenty-first century is female. Women are set to scale the highest peaks of the world of work; their skills are the ones needed in the new, creative economy; they are calling the shots (and calling it quits) in relationships. Exit breadwinning man. Enter superwoman.
fields.body:
In case you haven't heard yet, the twenty-first century is female. Women are set to scale the highest peaks of the world of work; their skills are the ones needed in the new, creative economy; they are calling the shots (and calling it quits) in relationships. Exit breadwinning man. Enter superwoman.

But amid the celebrations over the economic and social emancipation of women - somewhat overstated in any case - are siren voices foretelling the destruction of family and community in the wake of woman's onward march. The counter-revolutionary cry of 'The children will suffer!' was thankfully exploded by decent social research. In place of the latch-key kid, a new victim has emerged: the depressed dad.

New research suggests partners of high-flying women are suffering depression and anxiety, absorbing the woes of their spouse or girlfriend. Friday night conversations with each partner vying for the status of most stressed at work looks to be taking a higher toll on the male than female.

Evelyn Webster, a publishing director at 30, is in the vanguard of the gender revolution in the workplace. 'My partner and I live apart, after living together for a while,' she says. 'People think something has gone wrong but actually it is much better. If you are both working really hard, and really busy, you go to your shared home and just talk about work. But if one of you is going to the other's home, you put a different head on.'

Webster's is a radical survival tactic for the new world, in which men and women are struggling to cope with the competing demands of their own jobs, domestic work, child care, while maintaining their relationship.

Sophie Crossfield of Hertfordshire University is co-author of the work on stress 'transmission' in dual career couples and says the findings may reflect the birth pangs of the new equality at work. 'It could be that men have always looked to women for emotional support that may not be available in the same capacity when they have as demanding jobs as their partners,' she says.

Evidence that the mental health of men in dual-income households is suffering may reflect shifting masculine and feminine identities. Men have traditionally defined themselves in terms of their work; while women's family status has been a key defining characteristic for them. Women thankfully have more choices now - but men's role, their unique contribution to the family and wider society, becomes unclear once the mantle of breadwinner is lost.

They have a female boss at work and often - because women still undertake the bulk of child care and domestic responsibility - a female boss at home. Cue the Loaded generation, desperately trying to cling to a hard-drinking, boorish male identity.

It is easy to overstate the feminisation of the world of work. There are few breaks in the grey monochrome suits of most boardrooms. Women's pay is still 20 per cent lower than men's, and there is little sign of the gap narrowing. But there are more women than men reading law and medicine; childless female graduates outperform their male counterparts; women make up 48 per cent of first-level management in the Civil Service, compared with 29 per cent in 1984; they account for 18 per cent of managers, double the proportion just eight years ago. Et cetera.

A spokeswoman for the Government's Women's Unit said the aim was to reduce the pay gap to zero. But public policy is confused. On the one hand, the Government seems to want women to be equal competitors in the workplace. On the other, it wants them to carry the bulk of the home burden (or else we might have seen the introduction of paid paternity leave).

On Monday, a minister will call for an end to the gender gap in the world of paid work; on Tuesday, a minister will say that women have the cen tral role in families and communities. A woman is actively encouraged, to be at the top of a profession - so long as she remembers to buy the nappies, pick up the kids, run the PTA, organise breakfast. Forget men's troubles for a moment: what are we asking of women here?

'The rhetoric of the Government reinforces the view that child care is a women's issue,' says Helen Wilkinson, a writer on gender and employment issues. 'It is a difficult balance, because at the moment it is true that women do the bulk of child care, but the perceptions of gender roles do need to change.'

In the United States, where the female assault on the workplace is a few years older, it is still difficult for women to be a mother and a top executive: while 95 per cent of senior male managers are married, just 5 per cent of women are.

We are at a crossroads. It is an inescapable fact - if one few will utter - that women will not be able to compete on an equal footing in the workplace as long as they are expected to bear an unequal share of the load at home.

Some are calling for a halt in the revolution, a restatement of the essential differences. Trevor Berry, chairman of Families Need Fathers, which campaigns on behalf of men with children, says: 'The policy now seems to be to make the roles of men and women interchangeable. In fact, mothers often suffer pangs of guilt on returning to work. If that makes me old fashioned, I'm sorry.

'Men like a competitive situation, and have traditionally been the main breadwinner. Men can feel a certain sense of inferiority if they are playing second fiddle to their partner - it is just the way they are. You can't change that.'

Commentators like Berry, and Melanie Phillips, author of the Sex Change State , reckon the limits of our ability to change roles has been reached, and that we need to accept that men will always do more breadwinning, women more caring.

Others argue that the only thing for it is to reduce the pay gap, finally remove the glass ceiling, and help men come to terms with the new reality. Joanna Foster, chair of the National Work-Life Forum, says that new skills will have to be acquired by men, as well as a richer appreciation of their role as fathers and partners. 'Men haven't had to deal with this before,' she says of the dual-earner study. 'New sets of interpersonal skills, emotional intelligence, will be needed.'

If real equality is to be reached, men's role in the home will have to increase, to balance the loss of the monopoly at work and allow women to compete fairly. This is already beginning to happen: over the past 30 years, men have increased the time they spend on child care fourfold - although women still spend twice as much time on looking after children.

Young women are acutely aware that taking time out to have children can dent their career prospects, and are choosing to delay having a family or decide against children altogether. 'I am deferring homely decisions until later,' says Webster. 'At the moment it is all about work. And my perception is that women do work much harder than men.'

Once men start writing letters to Loaded asking how to combine their career with being a good husband, once men in playgrounds on weekdays don't feel like aliens, we'll know the new world has truly arrived. For the moment, women are able - at some cost - to buy the help they need to lead two lives.

Webster says: 'I have two sisters with children and successful careers, and they manage to live two lives by employing people to help them, not because their partners are any different.'

In the shorter term, Crossfield says there are two areas where change is required. First, there is a pressing need to challenge the long hours culture. 'Doing relaxation exercises while listening to dolphin music may reduce stress in the short term,' she says, 'but wouldn't it be great if we could focus interventions on actually preventing workers getting stressed in the first place?'

Second, women and particularly men will have to think more about how they relate to their partner. Only three out of 80 participants in the survey said their discussions with partners dealt with the 'the good stuff' at work.

'It does tend to paint a rather depressing picture of couples coming home and talking about the down side of work, and perhaps not sharing the more positive aspects of their day,' she says. 'Perhaps we just need to find a healthier balance, rather than using our partner as an emotional dumping ground.'

Webster takes a harder-headed view, arguing that it is up to women to reconfigure their lives, and earn enough to make their own choices. 'It is entirely unfair that they have to manage two lives in a way that men do not,' she says. 'But I can't see it changing, not for a long time anyway.'

The path to equality

Steps forward

 Women now earn 80 per cent of average male salaries, up from 55 per cent in 1970

 The number of women MPs is 121, up from 20 in the early 1980s

 18 per cent of managers are women, a tenfold increase since 1974

 New freedoms: 75 per cent of 16- to 19-year-old women had at least one sexual partner last year, compared with 50 per cent of men the same age

 Half of all parents say childcare is shared equally

Steps backward

 Three-quarters of clerical and secretarial staff are women

 23 per cent of women and 27 per cent of men agree that 'a husband's job is to earn the money; a wife's job is to look after the home and family'

 In four couples out of five, the woman usually or always does the ironing

 A third of women say they haven't got time to learn new skills because of family commitments, compared with 16 per cent of men

 Only 56 per cent of women hold a driving license, compared to 81 per cent of men
