fields.headline: Champion of the innocents
fields.standfirst: Bob Dylan immortalised him with his haunting ballad, 'Hurricane'. Now boxer Rubin Carter, unjustly jailed for murder, is the subject of a highly acclaimed film starring Denzel Washington. Carter talks to Stephen Pearlstein about his fight for justice
fields.trailText: He speaks in highly polished sermons delivered with the rhythmic cadences of a gospel preacher. Although he has sight in only one eye, his gaze is piercing. And while his mantelpiece displays a belt attesting to his honorary title of world middleweight boxing champion, the fighter known as 'Hurricane' because of his punishing left hook now finds the sport barbaric. His new passion: gardening.
fields.body:
He speaks in highly polished sermons delivered with the rhythmic cadences of a gospel preacher. Although he has sight in only one eye, his gaze is piercing. And while his mantelpiece displays a belt attesting to his honorary title of world middleweight boxing champion, the fighter known as 'Hurricane' because of his punishing left hook now finds the sport barbaric. His new passion: gardening.

Despite 19 years in prison for a triple murder he did not commit, Rubin Carter considers himself blessed. 'I would not change one single thing in my life,' he says in the basement of his Toronto house. 'Everything that went before has made me what I am today. And today I am deeply and seriously in love with myself. I don't want to be anyone but who I am. I am perfect.'

The American lets out a loud laugh meant to demonstrate his new-found lust for life. But it becomes clear that the laughter is also a salve for deep emotional wounds that have estranged him from much of his family, his country and even those who worked hardest for his release.

Still, these are heady days for Carter, 63. His story, chronicled early on in a Bob Dylan ballad, is now movingly portrayed by actor Denzel Washington in the film The Hurricane, which opened last week in Washington to acclaim and a buzz of Oscar expectations. Carter has already been to a special screening for President Bill Clinton at the White House, and this month there will be another at the United Nations to celebrate Human Rights Day.

Then, too, there's Hurricane:The Miraculous Journey of Rubin Carter, the new authorised biography out this month by journalist James S. Hirsch, along with a reissue of Lazarus and the Hurricane, an earlier chronicle of Carter's fall and rise by Canadian friends Terry Swinton and Sam Chaiton.

Yet Carter is intent on his new mission: gaining freedom for others who may have been unjustly imprisoned. His Association in Defence of the Wrongly Convicted, run from his house, has already helped to spring a number of high-profile prisoners from Canadian jails with the use of volunteer lawyers, private detectives and new DNA evidence.

'Many innocent people are locked up, and somebody ought to be held accountable,' he says.

In the case of the State of New Jersey versus Rubin Carter, it's fair to say there has been no accountability. Most of the prosecutors have gone on to become judges, and the judges have gone on to become appellate judges. The cop who headed the investigation was promoted. Lee Sarokin, the federal judge who finally overturned Carter's conviction, was virtually hounded into retirement by Republicans who tagged him 'Let 'em go' Lee.

Now, however, Hollywood aims to even the score with an inspiring morality play that demonises the New Jersey cops and prosecutors and glorifies Carter's saintly resolve, and tells of a small band of idealistic Canadians who won Carter's freedom.

The story begins in Paterson, New Jersey, on 16 June, 1966. Two black men entered the Lafayette Grill and shot dead the owner and two patrons. Within hours, police pulled over a white Cadillac driven by John Artis, 19, with Carter, the car's owner, in the front seat.

Carter was well known to the Paterson force. As a child, he had been sent to reform school for throwing a bottle at a man's head; as an adult, he had served several prison terms for beatings and handbag snatches. As a boxer he picked up the black nationalist rhetoric of the time, and talked of the need for blacks to use guns to protect themselves from bigoted white cops and judges.

The initial evidence did not point to Carter and Artis. Various witnesses declined to identify them. Their own stories - that Carter was merely giving Artis a lift home before heading to a meeting with his sparring partner - were supported by lie-detector tests. The guns were never found.

But several months later the police claimed to have turned up two petty thieves who had been staking out a nearby building and saw Carter and Artis flee the bar. Although their testimony had won them immunity from prosecution for burglary, it was enough for an all-white jury to convict Carter and Artis of the killings. Both received life sentences.

Artis became a model prisoner and won parole in 15 years, but Carter proudly and stubbornly refused to wear prison clothes, eat prison food or take a prison job, winning himself long and repeated stays in solitary confinement. He slept during the day, and at night read law books to help with his appeal, and tapped out an eloquent, angry biography, The Sixteenth Round. He insisted that guards and other inmates call him Mr Carter and, out of some mixture of respect and fear, they did.

In the racially charged, protest-driven politics of the early Seventies, Carter became a folk hero for the radical chic. His cause was taken up by the likes of Burt Reynolds, Roberta Flack, Stevie Wonder, Ed Koch, Jesse Jackson, Norman Mailer, Jimmy Breslin, Bill Bradley, Candice Bergen and Dylan. There was a benefit concert at Madison Square Garden, marches and TV interviews.

Finally, after Alfred Bello, one of the two thieves, recanted his story to the New York Times, Carter and Artis were granted a new trial in 1976. Muhammad Ali showed up to post bail. But by the time the second trial came, the police had pressurised Bello into recanting his recantation. Prosecutors, desperate to provide a motive for the killing, played the race card, asserting without much proof that the grill murders were revenge for the killing of a black bar owner six hours earlier. With Carter's history of inflammatory racial rhetoric, the jury was open to this theory. He and Artis were convicted a second time.

That broke Carter's resolve. Back in his cell, he cut off all communication with his wife and children from his first marriage, his supporters and his lawyers. He threw away his law books and began reading philosophy. His diet was a can of soup every three days. Botched prison surgery cost him his sight in one eye.

But one day in 1980 Carter decided to open one of the many letters he usually let pile up unanswered. It was from a 17-year-old black teenager, Lesra Martin, in Toronto. Martin had picked up The Sixteenth Round at a library book sale, and was so inspired by it that he wanted to thank Carter.

Martin had grown up poor and, until then, illiterate. That summer he'd been adopted, in effect, by a group of University of Toronto graduates impressed by his wit and intelligence. He moved into the Canadians' group house in an upmarket Toronto neighbourhood and had daily tutoring.

The Sixteenth Round was the first book he had ever read, and his letter to Carter the first he had ever written. Carter's response led to visits from Martin and four other commune members: Gus Sinclair, a Vietnam protester who gave money to US draft dodgers; Lisa Peters, a tough woman who ran away from home as a teenager and grew up on the streets; Terry Swinton, whose father was president of Encyclopaedia Britannica International; and Sam Chaiton, whose parents survived a Nazi concentration camp.

Carter's plight appealed to their left-wing politics and determination to stamp out racism and injustice. Their interest in Carter rekindled in him not only the will to live, but the determination to get out of prison. By 1983 Peters, Chaiton and Swinton moved to an apartment 20 minutes from the prison to work full time on Carter's appeals. Martin, now enrolled at the University of Toronto, often flew down at the weekends.

Judge Sarokin's final decision, on 7 November 1985, confirmed the value of new evidence the Canadians had dug up. He ruled that the convictions were 'predicated upon an appeal to racism rather than reason, concealment rather than disclosure'. Threats to witnesses and concealment of evidence by the police, and the prosecution's appeals to racism and violations of the Constitution, were 'as heinous as the crimes for which these petitioners were tried and convicted'.

The Hollywood film ends with Carter drinking in sunshine and vindication on the court steps, but the reality was more complicated. Carter had to wrestle with the demons he had taken to prison and those he accumulated during his 19 years behind bars. He joined the Canadians' communal home, confronted his alcoholism, nurtured by prison moonshine. A platonic jail love affair with Peters quickly developed into something else. But in time Carter came to view the house - with its strict ban on alcohol and cigarettes, its uncompromising communalism and its insularity - as a new prison and himself as a 'trophy horse'.

The relationship with the strong-willed Peters, always tempestuous, turned more so after they decided to marry. Carter stormed out of the house for the last time in 1994, showing up at Lesra Martin's Toronto flat. Even that arrangement broke down after Martin decided to resume legal studies in Halifax, Nova Scotia. It is a measure of Carter's estrangement from the Canadians that when the movie opened in Toronto they sat three rows apart and never exchanged a word.

The cocky, boastful Rubin Carter of his middleweight days can still be seen a little, but he spars now with words instead of his fists. Still the dandy, he proudly shows off his updated wardrobe. His white Cadillac has been changed for a Mercedes.

He refuses to set foot in New Jersey again, and is seeking Canadian citizenship.'The US authorities don't need a reason to do what they do to black people. They just need an opportunity - and I don't want to give them another one.'

Carter has an American girlfriend in her twenties, and has re-established relations with Lesra Martin, who ironically is now a prosecutor in British Columbia.

Martin says: 'I am in a unique position to make sure that wrongful convictions don't happen.As Rubin will tell you, it's easier to stop one before it happens than overturn it afterwards.'

The man the authorities came to blame

For somethin' that he never done.

Put in a prison cell, but one time he could-a been

The champion of the world...
